fields.headline: 'It must be the devil or De Foe'
fields.standfirst: John Mullan  takes a look at the many lives of a literary trickster in Daniel Defoe: Master of Fictions by Maximillian E Novak
fields.trailText: John Mullan takes a look at the many lives of a literary trickster in Daniel Defoe: Master of Fictions by Maximillian E Novak
fields.body:
Daniel Defoe: Master of Fictions
Maximillian E Novak
680pp, Oxford University Press, £30
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Thieves and pirates, a castaway and a courtesan - the protagonists of Daniel Defoe's fiction are adventurers who risk their souls as well as their skins. Captain Singleton and Moll Flanders, Robinson Crusoe and Roxana are set loose to make or lose themselves. In what we now call his novels (though the genre scarcely existed when he wrote them) and in Defoe's other lives of criminals and buccaneers, the world is a trackless place. Fortunes are to be made, and all restraints on human selfishness have to be newly-invented by ordinary men and women.

These stories are at once primitive and morally demanding. The excitement for the reader is not so much in the adventures as in the attempt to make moral sense of them - to redeem human character from the laws of mere physical need. Crusoe must discover how to make religion as well as pots; Moll must save herself from hunger, but also from becoming another of the "hell-hounds" of Newgate, the prison that is her birthplace; Captain Singleton must learn the laws of human fellowship in the company of pirates. Defoe's protagonists are great opportunists, but as, in later years, they tell their own tales, they remember the terrors against which they have had to battle. They have skirted annihilation and damnation.

In his biography of Daniel Defoe, Maximillian E Novak sees these characters as direct projections of their author. Defoe was an inspired chancer who made adventurers in his own image. He habitually risked not only his financial security but also his credibility as a writer with any consistent principles. An apparently mercenary hack, employed secretly by governments of every political complexion, he fought to persuade himself of his own integrity. Driven by a "spirit of defiance and contradiction", he took risks when he hardly needed to, relishing the war of words that raged in early 18th-century Grub Street.

He became a writer after he failed as an entrepreneur, and kept being tempted back into speculative schemes. He tried wine importation, brick manufacture, hosiery and the making of perfume from the glands of civet cats. Twice he was bankrupted, and he was never successful. Novak shows that he made large sums of money as a writer, and lost a good deal of it in commercial speculations. He was "in every sense a projector", excited by ingenious schemes rather than hard-earned profits. His first published book was his Essay on Projects (1697), full of ambitious schemes for a new and better nation (from an academy for women to improved schemes for helping bankrupt businessmen).

His first novel was not written until he was almost 60. In his lifetime he was famous, or infamous, as a satirist, a journalist and a political polemicist. He left a clear track of enmities, and Novak unfolds a rich record of the attacks and lampoons that he inspired. He made his name with The True-Born Englishman , an anti-Tory satire that celebrated, topically for us, the qualities of a 'mongrel' nation:

A True-born Englishman's a contradiction;

In speech an irony, in fact a fiction.

He forged his future with The Shortest Way with Dissenters , a mischief-making parody of High-Church rhetoric that had him put in the pillory (where he was cheered by the London mob) and then in Newgate Prison. He was rescued by chief minister Robert Harley, who put him to work as a government spy and propagandist. Harley was a Tory, but a man of moderation who seems to have won, and not merely purchased, Defoe's allegiance. Very few Defoe manuscripts survive; his letters to Harley were secured for posterity because they were lodged in secret-service files. Self-dramatising, often self-pitying, they bring alive a writer equally preoccupied with his place in history and his ever-precarious finances. With his self-importance and his pseudonyms, it is almost a surprise to find that he had considerable political influence. Under Harley at least, he spoke for those who ruled.

After Harley fell from power, Defoe became a more feverish, less influential writer for various masters, and it becomes impossible to follow him through the twists of his political journalism. He was paid by government agents to supply copy for, even edit, anti-government journals, in order to make them less effective. Enemies sensed what he was up to, and he was often denounced in the press: one typical newspaper article talked of his "binomical Performance", deploying "the little Art he is truly Master of, of forging a Story and imposing on the World for the Truth". His very employers sometimes seemed confused by the elaborateness of his journalistic imper sonations. Novak sees Defoe the trickster as the apprentice novelist: "The need to present multiple views helped to shape him into a masterful writer of fiction." Even the didactic works of "family instruction" brought to life, in sharp dialogues, a rich drama of bourgeois anxiety and soul-searching.

Defoe's shape-changing skills as a writer required the anonymity or pseudonymity of most of what he wrote. He was always complaining of all that was attributed to him; if a work was anonymous and controversial, "it must be the Devil or De Foe". His particular skill was for creating scenes "as if he had been on the spot". So, for instance, he made his New Voyage Around the World seem genuinely to have been written by an intrepid circumnavigator, rather than a clever fabricator with a good library. This gift for inventing the empirical, made him a pioneer of novel-writing; his novel that most brilliantly uses the force of the eyewitness account, A Journal of the Plague Year , was for half a century taken to be the genuine memoir of a man who had lived through this terror.

Defoe's talents of impersonation and habits of secrecy have left academics to argue over what he did actually write. He was probably responsible for more pages of print than any other major writer, yet much is irrecoverable. Novak is often oddly confident about his ability to detect Defoe's hand where other scholars have taught caution, yet his biography does have a feel for what made Defoe singular: his audacity, his energy, his gambler's trust in the future. Novak calls him "an incorrigible futurist", ever projecting into tomorrow. What made him a great writer was the way he caught in his novels the fears and dangers shadowing the resourcefulness of the modern individualist. The representatives of his brave new commercial world were thieves and pirates before they made good; the free modern individual living with terror and solitude as well as excitement and opportunity.

fields.headline: White wash
fields.standfirst: How can a history of the British Empire underplay racism? Richard Gott examines Ornamentalism: How the British saw their Empire by David Cannadine
fields.trailText: How can a history of the British Empire underplay racism? Richard Gott examines Ornamentalism: How the British saw their Empire by David Cannadine
fields.body:
Ornamentalism: How the British saw their Empire
David Cannadine
288pp, Allen Lane, £16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

One of the peculiarities of the British vision of their past is that they learn about Britain and the British Empire from different groups of historians, often coming from different historical traditions. In some undefined division of labour, rather like the chasm that exists in a newspaper office between departments of home and foreign news, one group deals with the metropolis, another with the wider world. As a result, the British are positively discouraged from seeing their homeland and their Empire as an indivisible whole. The seamless web that once linked Westminster and Whitehall with the most distant outposts of Empire has been broken down through these fractured spectacles into its component parts, resembling a patchwork quilt rather than finished cloth. "British social historians never significantly ventured overseas," writes David Cannadine in his new book, "while imperial social historians rarely ventured to Britain" - with the result that no authoritative social history of the Empire has ever been written.

Cannadine is an adventurous, original and highly accessible historian, and he has sought to resolve this paradox by examining the last 100 years of Empire and motherland - this "vast interconnected world" - through a single lens. His ambitious and thoroughly praiseworthy aim is "to put the history of Britain back into the history of Empire, and the history of Empire back into the history of Britain".

An unusual and initially compelling portrait comes into focus almost immediately. Empire, he argues, was "the vehicle for the extension of British social structures - to the ends of the world". The constructs that the British made in the Empire were primarily "the mirror images of the traditional, individualistic, unequal society that existed in the metropolis."

The Empire, according to this view, sought to recreate the rural arcadia of Tory England, where local government since the 16th century had been controlled by those with high social prestige. "This meant that it was in the hands of the traditional authorities, the greater grandees and the lesser gentry, that it was relatively inexpensive, and that it was amateur." So was born the "indirect rule" system of government that characterised much of the Empire, with power devolved to an entire hierarchy of greater and lesser chiefs.

If this was the sum total of his argument, Cannadine's book would have been less contentious. But he moves on to shakier ground when he argues that the Empire was not so much about "race or colour" as about "class and status". This old-fashioned emphasis on class might warm the cockles of ageing Marxists, and it comes very naturally from the author of Class in Britain . Cannadine might simply argue that he has extended his earlier analysis of conservative, traditional, hierarchical Britain to the imperial arena.

Yet if you underplay the role of race in the imperial cocktail, you miss the reason for the Empire's sudden collapse. The first world war over-extended the Empire; the second world war, which turned out, at its end, to have been a war against racism, accelerated its downfall. If it was right to oppose Hitler, it was as necessary to dismantle an Empire that was built on the same racist principles as the Nazi Reich. There is the additional difficulty of the complicity of the great British people in the imperial scheme. If the Germans are blamed for Hitler, should not the British be blamed for their Empire? The imperial system may have been set up by the ruling class, as Cannadine suggests, but a lot of lesser mortals rather enjoyed lording it over people they regarded as their racial inferiors.

In this context, there is something curiously perverse about Cannadine's emphasis on the pre-eminence of class over race; he himself shows signs of unease about his fundamental formulation. One chapter of his book, "Limitations", deals with some of the drawbacks of his thesis. He claims, rather shamefacedly, that since race has made all the running in recent analytical accounts of Empire, he is merely trying to regain a sense of balance by returning to some of the arguments laid out by Joseph Schumpeter (in Imperialism and Social Classes ) some 50 years ago. Yet a close reading of his text suggests that he really does believe that class is more significant, and in passages of purple prose he makes the most of it. Forget about race, he proposes, think rather about "antiquity and anachronism, tradition and honour, order and subordination; about glory and chivalry, horses and elephants, knights and peers, processions and ceremony, plumed hats and ermine robes; about chiefs and emirs, sultans and nawabs, viceroys and proconsuls; about thrones and crowns, dominion and hierarchy, ostentation and ornamentalism".

This splendid passage provides Cannadine with his title (a direct attack on Edward Said's Orientalism ), yet once you realise that his jeu d'esprit is essentially confined to the ruling class, you can enjoy the wonderful chapters about the absurdity of the inflated honours system and on the role of the re-invented monarchy - both indissolubly linked to the demands of Empire. Jonathan Freedland suggested in the Guardian recently that royalty is "an ancient feudal idea" that rests on "medieval concepts of bloodline and heredity", but Cannadine counters this by pointing out that the British variant is rather more firmly rooted in the artificial superstructure of the Empire created in the 19th century. The ridiculously inflated monarchy that the British still retain only ever made sense as the apex and apogee of a great global empire. Without an Empire, it is meaningless. "Thanks largely to Disraeli," writes Cannadine, "the British monarchy was refurbished and re-invented as an imperial crown of unprecedented reach, importance and grandeur." And if only the Empire still existed, and not the miserable Commonwealth, there would still be excellent opportunities for any number of royal duchesses and countesses of Wessex to earn an honest crust.

The difficulty about Cannadine's thesis (and his subtitle) is that it is already known "how the British saw their Empire". They saw it as pictured on a biscuit tin, or as the label on a bottle, with the native orderly standing outside the campaign tent with a tray of Camp coffee essence, ever at the ready to serve the expectant British officer. Cannadine gives some continuing credence to this vision by recalling, in an appendix, his own nostalgic memories as "a child of Empire", born in 1950, of what it was like to live in its misty afterglow. What he fails here to understand, yet what has become ever clearer in much recent research and the concurrent re-examination of the imperial experience, is that the British were in a supreme state of false consciousness about their Empire. When the British "saw" their Empire, they did not really know, or they chose not to know (with the exception of a few honourable dissenters over the centuries), what was being done in their name.

When Henrietta Marshall published Our Empire Story in 1908, an excellent book in many ways on which most imperial citizens were brought up for more than half a century, she made virtually no reference to the various indigenous populations that the empire-builders encountered. With rather less excuse, Cannadine makes the same mistake, although he admits that the particular vision of Empire he has uncovered was "an ignorant oversimplification" of something that was extremely complex. Yet it is rather disingenuous on his part to talk euphemistically about "colonies of settlement" when what he means are colonies where the indigenous population has effectively been slaughtered. "When it comes to the systematic settlement of Australia, New Zealand and South Africa," he writes, the British did not hesitate "to banish the indigenous peoples to the margins of the new imperial society". The Jews of central Europe were also banished to the margins of society, but we usually dwell rather more on their extermination.

I, too, born a decade earlier than Cannadine, have some misty memories of Empire, but they are less upbeat than his. I chiefly remember my headmaster in tears when he heard of the death of his star pupil, Major Earl Wavell, killed during the Mau Mau "Emergency" in Kenya in 1954; and I recall the head boy who was shot, during conscription, fighting the anti-imperialist communist guerrillas in Malaya. Nothing very ornamental about those deaths. We now know that the British Empire was essentially a Hitlerian project on a grand scale, involving military conquest and dictatorship, extermination and genocide, martial law and "special courts", slavery and forced labour, and, of course, concentration camps and the transoceanic migration of peoples. Whatever way we now look at Empire, this vision must remain dominant.

This is very far from being Cannadine's view, but his book is not just a restatement of traditional conservative history, it is a romantic and postmodernist version suitable for the New Labour era. With a simple and plausible idea and an attractive narrative sweep, the burden of imperial guilt can be shifted off the backs of the long-suffering British people as a whole and placed firmly back where it belongs - at the door of the old Tory party. If only things were so simple.

Richard Gott is writing a book on imperial repression and resistance.

They saw it as pictured on a biscuit tin, or as the label on a bottle, with the native orderly standing outside the campaign tent with a tray of Camp coffee essence, ever at the ready to serve the expectant British officer. Cannadine gives some continuing credence to this vision by recalling, in an appendix, his own nostalgic memories as "a child of Empire", born in 1950, of what it was like to live in its misty afterglow. What he fails here to understand, yet what has become ever clearer in much recent research and the concurrent re-examination of the imperial experience, is that the British were in a supreme state of false consciousness about their Empire. When the British "saw" their Empire, they did not really know, or they chose not to know (with the exception of a few honourable dissenters over the centuries), what was being done in their name. When Henrietta Marshall published Our Empire Story in 1908, an excellent book in many ways on which most imperial citizens were brought up for more than half a century, she made virtually no reference to the various indigenous populations that the empire-builders encountered. With rather less excuse, Cannadine makes the same mistake, although he admits that the particular vision of Empire he has uncovered was "an ignorant oversimplification" of something that was extremely complex. Yet it is rather disingenuous on his part to talk euphemistically about "colonies of settlement" when what he means are colonies where the indigenous population has effectively been slaughtered. "When it comes to the systematic settlement of Australia, New Zealand and South Africa," he writes, the British did not hesitate "to banish the indigenous peoples to the margins of the new imperial society". The Jews of central Europe were also banished to the margins of society, but we usually dwell rather more on their extermination. I, too, born a decade earlier than Cannadine, have some misty memories of Empire, but they are less upbeat than his. I chiefly remember my headmaster in tears when he heard of the death of his star pupil, Major Earl Wavell, killed during the Mau Mau "Emergency" in Kenya in 1954; and I recall the head boy who was shot, during conscription, fighting the anti-imperialist communist guerrillas in Malaya. Nothing very ornamental about those deaths. We now know that the British Empire was essentially a Hitlerian project on a grand scale, involving military conquest and dictatorship, extermination and genocide, martial law and "special courts", slavery and forced labour, and, of course, concentration camps and the transoceanic migration of peoples. Whatever way we now look at Empire, this vision must remain dominant. This is very far from being Cannadine's view, but his book is not just a restatement of traditional conservative history, it is a romantic and postmodernist version suitable for the New Labour era. With a simple and plausible idea and an attractive narrative sweep, the burden of imperial guilt can be shifted off the backs of the long-suffering British people as a whole and placed firmly back where it belongs - at the door of the old Tory party. If only things were so simple. Richard Gott is writing a book on imperial repression and resistance.

webTitle: Review: The Holocaust on Trial by DD Guttenplan

fields.headline: The burden of truth
fields.standfirst:
Marcel Berlins finds the search for certainty in the Irving libel trial documented in The Holocaust on Trial by DD Guttenplan
Read an extract
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins finds the search for certainty in the Irving libel trial documented in The Holocaust on Trial by DD Guttenplan
fields.body:
The Holocaust on Trial
DD Guttenplan
343pp, Granta, £17.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

David Irving versus Penguin Books and Deborah Lipstadt was, on the face of it, a straightforward libel dispute. The American academic Lipstadt had written, and Penguin had published, accusations against the right-wing historian Irving which, he claimed, had ruined his professional reputation. When the case came to trial last year, the judge himself was anxious to peddle that line. "This trial is not concerned with making findings of historical fact," Mr Justice Gray announced early on. Unavoidably, however, it was.

Before the judge could decide who had won the court case, he had to make up his mind on a series of awesome historical questions. How many Jews died in the Holocaust? How many were gassed at Auschwitz? How much did Hitler personally know about the methods and extent of the killings?

The problem was that English libel trials are not meant to discover the truth about anything. The process is a highly artificial one, aimed at deciding whether or not published words have tended to diminish someone's reputation. It does so clumsily, relying on a verbal shoot-out between two opposing sets of partial witnesses and their silver-tongued lawyers. At the end, the choice is which bunch to believe. This blunderbuss method may sometimes produce justice; it rarely gets to the truth.

But in the Irving case there was no choice. Lipstadt had written that Irving was a denier of the Holocaust, an apologist for Hitler, a distorter of historical evidence in favour of the Nazi version of events. To defend themselves against his libel claim, she and Penguin had to show that what she'd said was true. To do that, in effect, they had to prove the existence of the Holocaust and the gas chambers at Auschwitz all over again, as well as the falsity of Irving's interpretation.

DD Guttenplan, an American journalist, sat through every day of the two-month trial in London's Royal Courts of Justice. He also interviewed most of the main participants, including Lipstadt, Irving, many of the lawyers and the judge (who, because of the complexity of the case and the volume of documentation, dispensed with a jury and heard the case himself).

His book is, at one level, a straightforward, intelligent account of the proceedings. He manages to make dense and complex issues understandable. Guttenplan's dif ficulty is that the trial itself was not particularly lively. Sparkling moments were infrequent: some forensic sparring between Irving and Richard Rampton QC, Penguin's barrister; occasional clashes between Irving and the expert witnesses; and a few examples of Irving - who, unable to afford expensive lawyers, represented himself skillfully - in full declamatory flow, combining high intelligence with arrogance and naivety.

But for the most part it was a dour trial, unleavened by much humour or any sensational revelations. Its explosive highlight should have been the confrontation between alleged victim and accuser; but the defence team decided that Lipstadt should not go into the witness box, thus denying Irving, to his great disappointment, the opportunity to cross-examine her. Only nine witnesses were heard - the tip of the evidential iceberg. Much of the material relevant to the case was contained in detailed reports and other documents, which the judge spent weeks reading.

It is not Guttenplan's fault that there are times when the reader's attention may not be gripped; fascination for the minutiae of Auschwitz's building plans has its limitations. The outcome of the trial was predicable and predicted. The judge's 333-page judgment comprehensively vindicated Lipstadt's position and he had some savage criticisms to make of Irving's integrity both as a historian and as a witness during the trial.

But the book has another dimension, making it far more interesting than a mere chronicle of a high-profile trial. Guttenplan is clearly uneasy at the haphazardness and inadequacies of the legal process in dealing with such sensitive and large-scale questions. Perhaps he expected too much from the trial - that it would provide an important answer, shed some new light on the Holocaust. He muses on the distances between facts, court evidence, history and truth, and finally spots the missing link. The judge had heard from experts and seen lots of documents. But not a single witness in court was a survivor of, or witness to, the atrocities. "Without human voices to put flesh on the facts, we have something which, while it may pass muster as history, can never tell the truth." He's right, of course, but how could he have thought for a moment that an English libel trial could fulfill that onerous task?

fields.headline: Channel chic
fields.standfirst: One of France's most fashionable resorts is only 45 minutes from Calais. Channel-hopping expert  Sharron Livingston joins the jet set in Le Touquet
fields.trailText: One of France's most fashionable resorts is only 45 minutes from Calais. Channel-hopping expert Sharron Livingston joins the jet set in Le Touquet.
fields.body:
As you turn off the A16 motorway after a quick dash from Calais, the road ahead suddenly changes colour as if laid out like a red carpet, a suitably regal welcome to Le Touquet.

The most chic of all northern French resorts offers an abundance of fashionable shops and restaurants in stylish, pristine streets. Within walking distance are a finely-manicured forest and a fabulous beach where you can be tutored in sand yachting by the world champion.

The story of Le Touquet began in 1837 when a notary called Alphonse Daloz bought 1,600 hectares of dunes on the Canche Estuary for 6,005 Napoleons (Ffr120,000). In the mistaken hope that it would be good arable land, he planted potatoes, rye, Jerusalem artichokes and trees. Only the trees survived, but by the 1900s, the area had matured into an attractive forested seaside location. It became so popular with Parisiens that it became known as Le Touquet-Paris Plage.

In 1903, two Englishmen, John Whitely and Allen Stoneham, bought the forest and set up the Le Touquet Syndicate Ltd, building villas and hotels. In the 1920s, PG Wodehouse and Noel Coward bought houses in the forest, and the luxury hotels filled up with weekending English nobility.

What to see

Hôtel de Ville
Rue des Oyats

Built from local stone by Louis Debrouwer and Pierre Drobecque, the town hall is an imposing example of 1920s Anglo-Norman manor-house architecture.

The former diving-board of the swimming pool
Front de Mer

It may seem odd to include a diving-board in a list of a town's heritage attractions, but this is no ordinary board. It was designed in 1948 by Louis Quételard, whose name was synonymous with "le Style Touquettois Moderne", and anyone bold enough to use it was seen as fashionably avant-garde; if the diver was a female in a bathing suit, even a tad risqué. These days, it is a symbol of the modernity of post-war times.

Le Touquet Museum
Intersection of Avenue du Golf and Avenue du Château Tel: 00 33 (0)321 05 62 62.
Open: Wed - Sun, 10am - noon and 2pm (Sun 2.30pm) - 6pm.
Entrance: adults Ffr20, children Ffr5.

Le Touquet's only museum, housed in a typically handsome 1930s villa, has a fine collection of landscapes by Edouard Leveque who inadvertently gave the opal coast its name. His palette consisted mainly of pinks, beiges and slightly iridescent colours resembling the hues of opal stone.

What to do

Sand yachting
Contact: Bertrand Lambert (00 33 (0)3 21 05 33 51). Discovery session Ffr70 (2 hours); perfecting session Ffr220 (2 hours).

The meticulously clean, fine-sand beach is perfect for sunbathing, but its length also makes it ideal for more active pursuits such as sand yachting. These lightweight craft reach exhilarating speeds three times faster than the wind. Beginners are tutored by the best.

Aqualud
Front de Mer Tel: 00 33 (0)321 05 63 59
Open: daily 10am-6pm from April to the end of August.
Admission: three hours Ffr65, four hours Ffr71, full day Ffr82

The exotic water adventure park is ideal for families, featuring a range of pools, Jacuzzis, saunas, some inside a glass pyramid for chilly days, some in the open air. Kids will love the flumes, slides, toboggans and other state-of-the-art rides.

Thalassa Le Touquet
Front de Mer
Tel: 00 33 (0)321 09 86 00

Clients are pampered with concoctions containing oceanic minerals. One-day, weekend and week-long health "cures" are designed to rejuvenate, stimulate, invigorate or just relax.

Parc International de la Canche
Avenue de la Dune aux Loups
Tel: 00 33 (0)321 05 15 25

Set in the shady beauty of the forest, the Parc is regarded as one of the best-equipped equestrian centres in France. As well as providing tuition, it arranges romantic horse rides along the coast at dawn, dusk and sometimes in moonlight.

Shopping

The best shopping street is Rue St Jean, stretching from the seafront to the forest.

Nota Bene Piu
3 Rue St Jean
Tel: 00 33(0)3 21 05 44 46

Specialises in stylish sailing and leisure wear, particularly the famous Aigle tailored wellies.

Chez Martine
40 Rue St Jean
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 14 09

If you want to look good on the golf course or the tennis courts, this is where to buy the winning kit.

Flais Gérard
9 Rue St Jean
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 42 41

An antique shop exuding style, even before you enter, with wood carvings decorating the exterior from top to bottom. The goods inside won't disappoint any serious collector.

Rien Que Pour Elles/Lui
37 Rue St Jean
Tel: 00 33(0)3 21 05 29 78

Whoever your favourite designer is, you should find something of their collection at this chic fashion outlet: Paul Smith, Moschino, Lacroix, Gaultier, Dolce & Gabanna, and the list goes on.

Florence Kooijman
89 Rue St Jean
Tel: 00 33(0)3 21 05 21 73

A quaint shoe shop displaying a large range of the owner's exclusive designs. If you like the design but not the colour or material, you can choose from a range of swatches and the shoes will be made to order within two weeks.

La Mascotte
56-61 Rue St Jean
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 02 98

This huge general store takes up space on both sides of rue St Jean. The jet set place their wedding lists here. British tourists come to get their hands on beautiful Lalique crystal at a third off the UK price. Everyone comes here for their leather goods, Cartier, Hermès, Baccarat and Christofle products.

Le Chais
70 Rue de Londres
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 59 83

For quality wines from all the country's main regions.

Le Petit Marché
71 rue Metz
Tel: 00 33 (0) 21 05 70 10

If you have a cooler bag, bring it here and stock up on top-quality cheeses.

Au Chat Bleu
47 rue St Jean
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 03 86

For divine hand-made chocolates. The owners insist that they invented le Bouchée - literally a mouthful but actually a chocolate bar. Choose from 56 different varieties.

The Market
Place du Marché Couvert
Open: June 1 - Sept 15, Monday, Thursday and Saturday; Sept 16 - May 31, Thursday and Saturday.

The beautiful, half-moon-shaped covered market was designed by Henry-Léon Bloch and completed in 1937. Perishable products such as cheese, meat, fish, fruit and vegetables are sold in the market's covered area which is adorned with attractive tiling. The stalls in the central courtyard sell superb cheap textiles, clothes and shoes. With appealing views of the sea and the Jardin d'Ypres.

Where to eat

Café des Sports
22 rue Saint Jean
Open: daily 9am-4am
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 05 022
Tariff: various

This is a very popular, casual and comfortable brasserie with Parisien music in the background. Specialities include Welsh rarebit, only loosely based on the British dish - a soup plate filled with melted cheese cooked in beer. The bread makes a small appearance at the bottom.

Flavio's
Avenue du Verger
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 10 22
Tariff: from Ffr240

Flavio's is the favourite haunt of the regulars staying at Le Touquet's most highly regarded hotel, The Westminster. The décor and service exude prosperity and civility. As well as the à la carte menu, there are two set menus. The first, Le Privé, offers three courses and a bottle of wine for Ffr240. The speciality menu at Ffr380 is unforgettable if you love lobster and other seafood, but the wine is extra.

Café des Arts
80 rue de Paris
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 21 55
Closed: Wednesday and Thursday
Tariff: from Ffr100-300

High-quality food is prepared in imaginative combinations, blending fruit and unusual vegetables with seafood.

La Dune Aux Loups
Avenue de la Dune aux Loups
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 42 54
Closed: Tuesday afternoon.
Tariff: Ffr99-Ffr286

An excellent traditional wood-beamed restaurant deep in the forest, close to the equestrian centre.

Le Village Suise Restaurant
52 Avenue St Jean
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 69 93
Tariff: from Ffr130

Built in 1905 in medieval style by the architect Bertrand with a pretty folly, a turret and a narrow flight of steps leading to the restaurant. Excellent traditional cuisine.

Where to stay

The Westminster
(four star)
Avenue du Verger
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 05 48 48
Tariff: Ffr500-Ffr1,300

Le West, as it is affectionately known, is Le Touquet's most sumptuous hotel. Over the years, it has entertained a huge range of celebrities, recorded in an impressive hall of fame exhibiting framed and signed photographs of film stars and politicians from Sean Connery to Gandhi.

Park Plaza Grand Hotel
(four star)
4 Boulevard de la Canche
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 06 88 88
Tariff: Ffr500-Ffr1,295

An elegant modern hotel in the heart of the forest with a panoramic view over the Canche bay. Inside, the Thalgo Le Touquet Health and Beauty Centre offers a revitalising course of beauty and relaxation treatments designed to enhance your well being in conducive surroundings.

Novotel
(three star)
Front de Mer
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 09 85 00
Tariff: Ffr570-Ffr920

Ibis
(two star)
Front de Mer
Tel: 00 33 (0)3 21 09 87 00
Tariff: Ffr440-Ffr630

It seems a little incongruous to stay in a basic chain hotel while in Le Touquet. However, these two are on either side of the Thalassa centre on the beach front, which allows for internal access from the hotels into the centre, and anyone using the therapy services is at least guaranteed a room with a sea view.

Way to go

Lydd International Airport
Lydd, Kent TN29 9QL
Tel: 01797 322411
Price: flights from June to October. Ticket prices have not yet been confirmed but are expected to be about £95 return.

P&O
Tel: 087 0600 0600
Price: five-day return for a car and up to nine passengers from £99.

Eurotunnel
Tel: 08705 35 35 35
Price: Mini breaks from £99. Economy returns for five days or more from £179

SeaFrance
Tel: 08705 711711
Price: car and five passengers, day return from £39, five-day return from £149.

Hoverspeed
Tel: 08705 240 241
Price: Car and two passengers, five-day return from £137.

webTitle: Audiobook: Mortal Causes by Ian Rankin, read by James Macpherson

fields.headline: Mortal Causes by Ian Rankin, read by James Macpherson
fields.trailText: You get more corpses in an audiobook thriller - there simply isn't room on two cassettes to cram in the details and leave enough air for the suspense
fields.body: You get more corpses in an audiobook thriller. These unintended victims are plot and character. It's not the abridger's fault. There simply isn't room on two cassettes to cram in the details and leave enough air for the suspense. Having taken three sides to set up the mystery, there has to be a mad scramble home on the fourth. In Rankin's original novel, about Protestant paramilitaries in Scotland, the denouement must have been better plumped out. Ditto the central character, Inspector John Rebus, an intriguing, dour hardnut who was presumably deliberately named - a rebus is a puzzle. But in this condensed version he ends up practically invisible as he unravels the bloody racket with dazzling speed. James Macpherson is an ideal reader for it. If only he had more tape to play with.

fields.headline: Family sue race watchdog over jail murder inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Special report: prisons
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The family of an Asian teenager murdered by his cellmate at Feltham youth jail is to take the commission for racial equality to court to stop it holding an inquiry into prison racism behind closed doors.
fields.body:
The family of an Asian teenager murdered by his cellmate at Feltham youth jail is to take the commission for racial equality to court to stop it holding an inquiry into prison racism behind closed doors.

Zahid Mubarek was beaten to death by Robert Stewart, a known racist psychopath, after a string of blunders by the prison service.

In the wake of outrage over the murder the CRE announced a formal investigation into the prison service errors that led to the death of Mr Mubarek, 19, and into wider racism in Britain's jails.

Mr Mubarek's family have asked the high court for a judicial review so they can be represented and can cross-examine witnesses about the events and decisions leading up to the teenager's murder.

The family also want the part of the inquiry covering the murder to be held in public.

The inquiry has been set up under the 1976 Race Relations Act. The CRE says this does not allow the inquiry to be in public and that the Mubarek family cannot be represented.

But the family wantan investigation similar to the Stephen Lawrence one, which proved a watershed in British race relations.

The family have also applied for a court order halting the first session of the hearing, which will be in public, when the prison service chief, Martin Narey, and home office minister Paul Boateng will be questioned.

Suresh Grover, speaking for the Mubarek family, said: "The family believe only through public scrutiny of the events leading to Zahid's brutal murder will the real truth ever be known on how the prison service allowed his murder to take place.

"The Lawrence inquiry showed the necessity of families being involved integrally in any inquiry.

"If the CRE do not allow the family to cross-examine witnesses, they're acting extremely shabbily and insensitively and this inquiry will have no integrity."

However, a CRE spokesman said: "During the course of the formal investigation we are not allowed to disclose the names of those giving evidence unless they approve. It's not a question of having it behind closed doors but of complying with the law and what is commensurate with our powers."

The spokesman said the final report would be published.

A spokesman for the prison service said: "We will comply with whatever the CRE asks us. If that means doing an inquiry in public, we would go along with that."

Robert Stewart was last year convicted of the murder.

A confidential prison service report following Mr Mubarek's murder concluded that the youth jail was guilty of institutional racism, that there had been failures by senior management and that ethnic minority staff and inmates had endured overt racist abuse from officers.

webTitle: Rugby League: Crawley spread gospel into the deep south

fields.headline: Crawley spread gospel into the deep south
fields.trailText: In those traditional rugby league strongholds of St Albans, Ipswich, Wolverhampton and Crawley the past week has been spent preparing for the start of the Summer Conference, a rare example of successful expansion within the British game.
fields.body:
In those traditional rugby league strongholds of St Albans, Ipswich, Wolverhampton and Crawley the past week has been spent preparing for the start of the Summer Conference, a rare example of successful expansion within the British game.

Since its debut on a trial basis in 1997 this amateur competition for clubs from outside the game's heartlands has grown steadily to encompass 30 teams this season. But just as significant has been the respect it has gradually earned.

David Waite, then the future Great Britain coach, attended last year's grand final between Crawley and Rotherham and Lionel Hurst, the Cheltenham lawyer who was the driving force behind the competition, is now the chief executive of the London Broncos.

In addition two Hemel Hempstead players, Simon Tillyer and Jack Howieson, have been playing with the Sheffield Eagles following the trail blazed by the Oxford Cavaliers forward Darryl Griffin, now on the fringe of London's Super League squad.

There are six new clubs this season - with the Cardiff Demons joining a strong Central-South pool, and a new North-East section including teams from Bridlington, Durham, Newcastle-Gateshead, Sunderland and Teesside.

The competition also has a sponsor for the first time in the league website totalrl.com, and Les Dyl, the former Leeds centre who coaches the Bridlington Bulls, admits he has been pleasantly surprised by the increased profile his club has enjoyed since joining the conference. "The launch at Rugby School was a good occasion and I've already had Sky TV up here this week," he says.

Bridlington have been playing for 17 seasons, either in one of the Hull competitions or against teams from the north-east. "But moving in with the rugby union club and switching to summer has given us access to a new group of players, as well as a more regular fixture list," their player-secretary Peter Brumby explains.

That has been the story across the conference, with most teams based at rugby union clubs. From those roots, though, a number of clubs, of which Crawley are the most obvious example, have developed as primarily rugby league operations.

It has led to suggestions of a National Premier League and possibly even of merger with the amateur, winter National Conference competition or the semi-professionals of the Northern Ford Premiership - or possibly both.

The viability of a Premier League will be explored this season with the cross-conference games pairing teams according to record rather than a random draw. Rotherham will, therefore, travel to Crawley in a fortnight while today Hemel host Oxford and Newcastle go to Crewe.

But the pick of the opening round for anyone who can resist a trip to the seaside to watch Bridlington play Sunderland is the North London Skolars' visit to Crawley. That the south is regarded as the toughest group says it all about the conference's potential to change the general impression of rugby league.

webTitle: Heineken Cup: Euro flop rankles as Swansea go for title

fields.headline: Euro flop rankles as Swansea go for title
fields.trailText: Swansea will clinch a record fourth league title if they defeat Glasgow at St Helen's this afternoon, but the champagne will taste a little flat after their tame exit from the Heineken Cup earlier this year.
fields.body:
Swansea will clinch a record fourth league title if they defeat Glasgow at St Helen's this afternoon, but the champagne will taste a little flat after their tame exit from the Heineken Cup earlier this year.

At the start of the season, their captain Scott Gibbs said Europe was his priority, but heavy defeats away to Wasps, Stade Français and Leicester in January left them with only the Welsh-Scottish League to concentrate on.

"We have only had two bad months this season and Jan uary was the one when we needed to be at our best. Winning the league would be a consolation, but no more than that," said Gibbs.

"With the strength in depth we have in our squad, we should be challenging for the Heineken Cup far harder than we have been. The fact that no Welsh club has ever won the competition rankles with me and it is something I am determined to put right next season."

Swansea lead the Welsh-Scottish League by three points with two games to play. Only the champions Cardiff can catch them, but the Whites have a vastly superior try count which is worth an extra point.

Victory for Swansea over Glasgow would render academic Cardiff's interest in the title, but if Swansea's arch-rivals Llanelli defeat the champions at Stradey Park this evening, the race will be over in every sense.

"We will be looking for Llanelli to do us a favour whatever the result against Glasgow," said Gibbs, who has been put on stand-by for the Lions tour to Australia next month.

"That is the way rugby goes, but Llanelli will have their own agenda after conceding 65 points to Cardiff in the Welsh Cup at Stradey Park a couple of months ago. Their pride was badly hurt and revenge will be on the menu: the fact they could hand us the title will in no way hold them back."

Cardiff have already put up the white flag and are resting their four Australia-bound Lions for the trip to Llanelli. "The league title is Swansea's to lose, not ours to win," said the Cardiff coach Lynn Howells, who is leaving the club at the end of the season.

"We blew it earlier this year when we lost at home to Bridgend and then away to Ebbw Vale."

fields.headline: McRae in the clear as fog lifts
fields.trailText: For once, the cards have fallen in Colin McRae's favour and, to general astonishment, the Scot held a commanding lead after six stages of the Rally of Argentina.
fields.body:
For once, the cards have fallen in Colin McRae's favour and, to general astonishment, the Scot held a commanding lead after six stages of the Rally of Argentina.

While McRae's turn of speed has never been in doubt, even he suggested that victory here was more or less out of the question. World Rally Championship rules dictate that crews begin in championship order and, as he has yet to score a point this year, he started 14th on the list.

On Argentina's dirt roads, he fully expected to spend the week dodging boulders and slithering through the ruts dug out by earlier cars, driving with something in hand and hoping to inch his Ford into the points as others ran into trouble. Instead, road conditions have initially proved quite favourable and, far from playing the percentage game, he has opted to throw caution to the wind.

Better still, fog has helped his cause no end, as it had largely lifted by the time he attempted yesterday morning's special stages. Beyond question, he has ridden his luck to spectacular effect and was almost 40 seconds ahead after just four of the rally's 21 stages. Even Tommi Makinen described McRae's performance as "incredible", yet his advantage is handsome rather than secure.

McRae said: "We're pushing as hard as we can and we worry about the rocks when we see them. The first stage today I was surprised at the time. I thought it would be good, but not as fast as it was.

"But this is the type of rally where you can lose it if you touch a rock or something. It would be nice to pull out a bit of a lead and guard it for the next two days, but it's easier said than done."

Richard Burns survived a fifth-gear spin in his Subaru that cost him 20 seconds on the third stage to burst ahead of Makinen and Carlos Sainz to claim second place, despite trouble with the brakes and the power steering. McRae's younger brother Alister, in a Hyundai, dropped to ninth when he had problems with his engine misfiring.

Argentina has never been Colin McRae's lucky rally and the roughest, most demanding stages are lurking just before the finish tomorrow, but although Burns is the one driver who has looked capable of beating him so far, his belief that he can reel in the Ford driver is not widely shared.

fields.headline: Tobougg's fitness gives him the edge
fields.standfirst: Godolphin colt should prove a worthy favourite in 2,000 Guineas
fields.trailText: Godolphin colt should prove a worthy favourite in 2,000 Guineas.
fields.body:
Guide to TV races

There are three key questions to be answered in today's Sagitta 2,000 Guineas at Newmarket. Will the Godolphin colts have a fitness advantage, will Aidan O'Brien's Minardi stay a mile and can Nayef can live up to the hype?

The answer to the first is probably "yes" but "no" to the other two.

In the worst spring in living memory, preparing horses for an early campaign has been the stuff of nightmares but while English and Irish colts have had to contend with desperate conditions all has been plain sailing down in the Gulf.

Godolphin's Tobougg, Rumpold and Divine Task looked in wonderful shape on their first appearance on Newmarket Heath on Wednesday and their wellbeing could be a crucial factor.

Tobougg (3.40), the chosen mount of Frankie Dettori, was trained last season by Mick Channon but was predictably transferred to Saeed Bin Suroor after winning the Prix Salamandre and Dewhurst Stakes, both Group One contests, in the autumn.

On public form he stands out along with Aidan O'Brien's Minardi who has similar credentials, but while the boyish O'Brien has a mature training brain and a touch of genius, Minardi is up against it on two counts - preparation and breeding.

No doubt O'Brien will have him fit (he is not a gross horse) without a prior outing, but the weather in Ireland has been just as bad as here while on the question of stamina there are grounds for doubts.

Although class can often carry a horse beyond the staying pretensions of his pedigree, Minardi, who did not race beyond six furlongs as a two-year-old, has a predominance of speed in his bloodline. He may get a mile but it is by no means certain.

Rumpold, another Godolphin colt, beat Minardi as a two-year-old. He is hard to assess but, having won the recent Dubai trial at Nad Al Sheba, cannot be left out of calculations.

We now come to Nashwan's half-brother Nayef, unbeaten in two minor races as a juvenile and hailed in some quarters as a future champion.

The bubble seemed to have burst when he could finish only third in the Craven Stakes behind King's Ironbridge and Red Carpet last month - a run which prompted jockey Richard Hills to desert him in favour of Munir.

But was the judgment too hasty? Marcus Tregoning, his trainer, said he knew the colt would need the outing and it may have brought him on leaps and bounds.

Certainly in the Craven Nayef looked short of pace, suggesting a longer trip might suit, so I overlook him and take Tobougg (3.40) to beat Rumpold and Munir.

HAYDOCK 1.30: Crazy Horse was a fluent winner at Aintree and has had four weeks to recover, while Behrajan comes out again just a week after having a hard race to finish third to top stayer Baracouda at Sandown.

HAYDOCK 2.00: Bring Sweets has top weight but should still go close. He was impressive when beating Mr Cool over the course and distance in February.

HAYDOCK 2.30: Free Rider ran third to Welcome Friend in a 22-runner handicap at Newmarket last time and seems to have less to do.

HEREFORD 2.45 : New Bird will be hard to beat. Sixth in the County Hurdle at Cheltenham last season, he looks to be coming into his own over fences.

NEWMARKET 3.00: Moon Solitaire was a creditable third to Gentleman Venture at Kempton and will be sharper now. Tarboush, representing Henry Cecil's stable, has not run since winning a maiden at Sandown in June.

NEWMARKET 4.15: Kier Park looks each-way value. He was just beaten by Pipalong in this last year and an unplaced run at Nottingham last month should have put him right.

HEREFORD 4.30: Miracle Kid drops in class and can be fancied on his fourth to Batswing at Doncaster in February.

NEWMARKET 4.45: Tayif, from David Nicholls's in-form stable, looks a good bet. He finished strongly when third to Regal Song at Musselburgh over a furlong shorter trip.

webTitle: Racing: Sheikh joins Tour in Kentucky

fields.headline: Sheikh joins Tour in Kentucky
fields.trailText: For the third year running Sheikh Mohammed will miss the 2,000 Guineas at Newmarket today to be at Churchill Downs where Express Tour bids to change Godolphin's luck in the Kentucky Derby.
fields.body:
For the third year running Sheikh Mohammed will miss the 2,000 Guineas at Newmarket today to be at Churchill Downs where Express Tour bids to change Godolphin's luck in the Kentucky Derby.

His team's efforts in the past two seasons have fallen woefully short, Worldly Manner finishing seventh in 1999, with China Visit sixth and Curule seventh last year.

But UAE Derby winner Express Tour, the mount of David Flores, is reckoned Godolphin's best hope yet in the first leg of the US Triple Crown, due off at 11.04 tonight our time.

Express Tour is quoted as short as 8-1 by British bookmakers, though he is 15-1 on the Churchill Downs morning line. Favourite in all lists is Gary Stevens's mount Point Given, a 9-5 chance locally to give Bob Baffert a third Derby win in four years.

Go Racing, the consortium which is made up of Arena Leisure, BSkyB and Channel 4, yesterday confirmed it has reached the necessary level of acceptances from Britain's 59 racecourses to trigger its deal to acquire media and related rights to British racing.

On Tuesday the Racecourse Association board voted to recommend the contract to all its members. Go Racing, bidding the equivalent of £400m for a 10-year deal, has now received acceptances from racecourses representing over 71% of betting turnover.

The final signature version of the contract is due to be distributed within 24 hours with the deadline for acceptance by the other tracks on May 11.

Christopher Stoddart, chief executive officer of Go Racing, said: "I am delighted that we have had such a good level of acceptances so quickly from the courses. We hope to be able to welcome most of the remaining racecourses by May 11 to ensure we deliver the best solution for racing."

fields.headline: Hughes to miss York
fields.trailText: Richard Hughes will miss York's Dante meeting after being banned by the Newmarket stewards yesterday. Riding Salford Express in the Sagitta Jockey Club Stakes, he was found guilty of interference of a minor nature when impeding eventual third Holding Court soon after the start of the mile-and-a-half event.
fields.body:
Richard Hughes will miss York's Dante meeting after being banned by the Newmarket stewards yesterday. Riding Salford Express in the Sagitta Jockey Club Stakes, he was found guilty of interference of a minor nature when impeding eventual third Holding Court soon after the start of the mile-and-a-half event.

This offence brought a three-day ban and invoked a further suspension which was deferred by the disciplinary committee last summer. The ban runs from May 14-22.

John Dunlop continued his amazing run with a 56-1 double, highlighted by Millenary in the Jockey Club Stakes.The St Leger winner was always moving powerfully as Salford Express cut out the pace and when Pat Eddery asked him to quicken around two furlongs out the Rainbow Quest colt responded positively.

A trip to Epsom for the Coronation Cup is the next target for Millenary according to the trainer who feels the undulating course will hold no terrors for his four-year-old. "Now that he has strengthened up so well I don't think we will have any problems with the track at Epsom," said Dunlop.

"After that I hope he will be able to have a Group One career over a mile and a half. He has not been entered for the Ascot Gold Cup and I have no plans to run him over longer distances. The fact that he won the St Leger does not mean he will stay another six furlongs."

Favourite Wellbeing failed to go through with his run after being in a challenging position at the three-furlong marker and finished a disappointing fourth.

Dunlop's double, and that of Eddery, was instigated by Rosi's Boy who led home a one-two for the trainer who also supplied runner-up, Fair Question, in the Newmarket Stakes.

Rosi's Boy is a Derby entry and received a 25-1 quote from Hill's. However, Dunlop was keeping his cards close to his chest about the prospects of the Caerleon colt reaching Epsom."We will have a think and let the dust settle," he said.

webTitle: Racing: Muwakleh should be another sunshine wonder

fields.headline: Muwakleh should be another sunshine wonder
fields.trailText: The vibes are good about Muwakleh (3.45) in tomorrow's Sagitta 1,000 Guineas at Newmarket although it is harder to make a case for her than Tobougg in the 2,000.
fields.body:
The vibes are good about Muwakleh (3.45) in tomorrow's Sagitta 1,000 Guineas at Newmarket although it is harder to make a case for her than Tobougg in the 2,000.

This filly has shown her class in Dubai by easily winning the UAE Guineas, her second victory on the dirt at Nad Al Sheba in two runs. She has never run on turf and it is impossible to compare her dirt form with her rivals here but there is no mistaking the confidence behind her in the Godolphin camp.

Sir Michael Stoute's Karasta, a lovely, big filly by Lake Coniston has been strong in the market in the last few weeks.

She beat Ameerat by a length at Doncaster last season and then went to France for the Prix Marcel Boussac where she finished runner-up to Amonita after slipping on the turn into the straight.

Karasta does not give the impression that she does anything too quickly, however, and she may be found out for lack of pace.

Crystal Music, trying to give trainer John Gosden a second sucessive win in the race, was unbeaten in three races as a juvenile and saw out the mile well when winning the Group One Meon Valley Stakes at Ascot.

Dora Carrington has not been out since finishing third to Minardi in the Heinz at Leopardstown in August, beaten six lengths, but that is probably excellent form.

fields.headline: Horse sense
fields.trailText: Curtain Time, so impressive in a midweek work-out at Newmarket, will have his Derby credentials tested to the full in the opening race on today's 2,000 Guineas card. A minor problem with Henry Cecil's colt does not seem to be hindering his progress, but the John Gosden camp are expecting a big run from Terrestrial, who enjoyed a nice pipe-opener behind Olden Times at the Craven meeting.
fields.body:
Curtain Time, so impressive in a midweek work-out at Newmarket, will have his Derby credentials tested to the full in the opening race on today's 2,000 Guineas card. A minor problem with Henry Cecil's colt does not seem to be hindering his progress, but the John Gosden camp are expecting a big run from Terrestrial, who enjoyed a nice pipe-opener behind Olden Times at the Craven meeting.

In the following juvenile contest we have good marks for newcomers Lake Verdi and Ocean Sound, from the respective Ben Hanbury and Barry Hills stables.

The Palace House Stakes promises to see a return to form by Kier Park, who has turned in some sharp work since his comeback run. Note, too, Cassandra Go, who is in foal. Geoff Wragg's mare came to hand quickly last season.

Annette Vallon is a likely market-mover in the Ladbrokes Handicap. Peter Harris's filly has been working well with classy sprinter Primo Valentino, and the stable's 1,000 Guineas hope Dora Carrington.

With the proviso that the ground is good, Crazy Larrys (4.20) should go well at Newmarket tomorrow. Though not an extravagant home worker, he is ready for this. Bali and Reef Diver are interesting newcomers in Division One (5.20) of the mile maiden. Painted Room is worth opposing with Mugharreb in Division 2 (5.50).

At Salisbury, Night Haven (4.05) is reported in good shape for her reappearance and Continuation (4.40) keeps going the right way.

On Monday, we want to be with Broadway Score (4.50) at Kempton. John Hills's colt caught the eye more than most with his finishing effort in the Wood Ditton Stakes.

From Barry Hills's powerful raiding party at Chester, we are strongly advised not to miss The Glen (4.10) on Tuesday. Hyderabad and Mr Combustible give Hills a strong hand in the Chester Vase the same day, while Perfect Sunday is on course for next Saturday's Derby Trial at Lingfield.

webTitle: Racing: Eddery back in Guineas groove

fields.headline: Eddery back in Guineas groove
fields.standfirst: Jamie Reid finds the veteran champion chasing more success at Newmarket today
fields.trailText: Jamie Reid finds the veteran champion chasing more success at Newmarket today.
fields.body:
The sponsor's logo on the breeches spelt out "Red Devil" as the champion jockey 11 times over hurried into the paddock at Bath on Tuesday. It seemed an appropriate label for the resurgent talents of Patrick James Eddery. Not long ago the diminutive Irishman appeared to have settled for the life of a jobbing professional heading for retirement. But this spring he has been as quick out of the stalls as the most precocious two-year-old. And at Newmarket this afternoon, 27 years after his first Classic victory on Polygamy in the Oaks at Epsom, he will take the reins of the highly regarded Frenchman's Bay in the 2,000 Guineas.

Confidence should not be a problem. He had two winners at Newmarket yesterday, including Millenary for John Dunlop in the feature Jockey Club Stakes, and last Sunday produced one of the finest displays of his illustrious career when driving home Golden Snake to take the £48,000 Group One Prix Ganay at Longchamp. The partnership kicked on from the outset and were three lengths clear at the top of the straight. The local runners, waiting complacently for their usual sprint finish, never got back on terms. "Remember Pat was winning Arcs when Olivier Peslier and the rest were still in short trousers," explained Dunlop, Golden Snake's trainer.

Racecourse rumour suggests that the 49-year-old Eddery and Dunlop may combine to take other Group One prizes this season, possibly even the Epsom Derby itself with Olden Times, the handsome three-year-old colt they brought out to win the Fielden Stakes over nine furlongs at Newmarket a fortnight ago.

"Oh, he's got gears," says Eddery. "He could drop back to a mile, no problem. You'd think he ought to have stamina too, as his sire is Darshaan who beat me on Sadlers Wells in the French Derby in '84. But there's a lot of speed on the dam's side and it may be that 10 furlongs will be his limit. But, either way, he's a serious horse."

A serious horse. Eddery's lexicon never changes but then one of the most striking things about the man is how little he seems to have altered since the mid-70s. He has had no serious weight problems of the kind that almost destroyed Walter Swinburn. Every March he reappears looking tanned and fit after a winter holiday and he will have a new set of wheels to go with his handsome cashmere coats, tailor-made suits and handmade shoes.

The manner does not change much either. He still has that old dead-behind-the-eyes look he inherited from Lester Piggott. But then Flat racing is a tough commercial business and the top jockeys - including Frankie Dettori behind the laughter - are all hard men who recognise their worth but also know the importance of keeping their options open. And if Olden Times does not run in the Derby, Eddery may want to team up with Aldwych on whom he scored an eye-catching win in the unofficial Derby trial at Bath on Tuesday.

"He's a nice horse," he says. "He was pulling hard early on and I had to try and settle him, but he's learning. They have to be handy on that left-handed turn out of the back straight at Bath. It wouldn't be the worst preparation for Epsom. When I switched him out and asked him to quicken he did it well. He wasn't fully fit but he'll come on for the run. I like him." On such brief post-mortems the hopes of owners, trainers and punters' investments wax or wane at this point in the season.

Aldwych is a stable companion of Frenchman's Bay and the two colts work out together regularly on Roger Charlton's gallops. Those close to the yard leave you in no doubt that over distances from six furlongs to a mile Frenchman's Bay shows the form of a top-class thoroughbred. But immaturity may be his biggest problem today as he has only seen a racecourse twice in his life and was beaten into second place in a slowly run Greenham Stakes at Newbury two weeks ago.

"He's crying out for better ground and a faster pace," Eddery believes. "The results of the Classic trials have been turned around in the Guineas before now and on decent going I'd be hopeful of beating that Newbury winner. But don't judge him too harshly on what he does this weekend. He's still growing and he'll be a much better horse in a few months' time."

Eddery has sat on some of the greatest racehorses of the last quarter of a century, from Grundy to Dancing Brave and Bosra Sham. He has made mistakes, none more glaring than the disastrously overconfident ride that cost him the 1984 Derby on El Gran Senor. But the high points and demonstrations of unflappable nerve more than outweighed the losses. "I remember standing in the paddock at Longchamp with Khalid Abdullah before the '86 Arc and asking Pat what he thought his tactics might be," recalls Dancing Brave's trainer Guy Harwood. "He gave us that look, a bit like Lester used to do, and just turned away. 'I think I'll hold him up,' he said." The rest is history.

Eddery has sat on some of the greatest racehorses of the last quarter of a century, from Grundy to Dancing Brave and Bosra Sham. He has made mistakes, none more glaring than the disastrously overconfident ride that cost him the 1984 Derby on El Gran Senor. But the high points and demonstrations of unflappable nerve more than outweighed the losses. "I remember standing in the paddock at Longchamp with Khalid Abdullah before the '86 Arc and asking Pat what he thought his tactics might be," recalls Dancing Brave's trainer Guy Harwood. "He gave us that look, a bit like Lester used to do, and just turned away. 'I think I'll hold him up,' he said." The rest is history.

webTitle: Olympic Games: 'Dynamic' Athens to stay as host

fields.headline: 'Dynamic' Athens to stay as host
fields.trailText: The Olympic Games will definitely be held in Athens in 2004. The threat to take the games away from the city was yesterday nullified by officials who said here that preparations were "back on track".
fields.body:
The Olympic Games will definitely be held in Athens in 2004. The threat to take the games away from the city was yesterday nullified by officials who said here that preparations were "back on track".

"I can unequivocally rule out any other location for the 2004 games," said Jacques Rogge, the head of the International Olympic Committee's coordination committee overseeing the preparations for the event. "The games will be held in Athens. There is no doubt about that."

The IOC was so concerned last April about the progress of preparations that the president Juan Antonio Samaranch issued an unprecedented warning that unless Athens sorted out the situation the games might be taken elsewhere. That would have been a national disaster for the host of the first ever modern games in 1896.

"A year ago the IOC had to give Athens a strong warning," said Rogge, the favourite to succeed Samaranch as the president of the IOC in July. "But today we have a totally different situation. We are pleased to see the results are very excellent. There is a new dynamism about the organisers."

Rogge hoped that his strident defence of Athens would finally lay to rest renewed speculation that Sydney or Seoul would be asked to step in and host the games.

On his last visit to the Greek capital he had declared he wanted to see "bulldozers working" next time instead of blueprints. He got his wish. In the shadow of the Acropolis the city skyline is dotted with cranes and huge areas are undergoing major redevelopment as the government battles to meet the tight construction deadlines laid down by the IOC.

"Greece is on the right track," said Rogge. "I am certain everything will be ready on time by 2004."

The driving force behind the project is Gianna Angelopoulos, the London-based multimillionairess who won the bid for Athens in 1997 and was brought back last year to ensure that everything would be ready in time. "Now we are gaining speed but know time is our enemy," she said.

Rogge declared yesterday that the games had already "set one world record" in raising $430m (£300m) in local sponsorship. However, he tempered his praise with a warning that Athens still had to build an extra 9,000 hotel rooms before 2004.

webTitle: Cricket: Wasim fires an early warning

fields.headline: Wasim fires an early warning
fields.standfirst: British Universities 74 Pakistan 224-4
fields.trailText: British Universities 74 Pakistan 224-4
fields.body:
Pakistan's warm-up for the first Test at Lord's will begin in earnest against Derbyshire next week when Dominic Cork will be intent on producing a performance to hasten his return to the England side.

Their initial forays were much more mundane, a leisurely dismissal of the British Universities, who were all out for 74 shortly after lunch and will have to bat less compliantly today to avoid the likelihood of a two-day defeat.

Wasim Akram has had a disorienting week. The captain Waqar Younis initially intimated that he did not want him in the squad. But after untold machinations Wasim was included, then presented by Waqar on the Pakistanis' arrival as a "key member" of the team.

The Universities, with five from Durham in their number, can vouch that his bowling talent remains unaffected. An opening sally of four for 13 included the opening-over wickets of Michael Brown and Matthew Banes, and the removal of Essex's William Jefferson, England's tallest first-class cricketer at around 6ft 9in.

Surrey's Tim Murtagh, nephew of the former Hampshire seamer Andy, later gave the Universities heart by taking all four wickets, including Saeed Anwar, whose 89 from 115 balls ended tamely at mid-on.

But there was lasting disappointment for the students: the Pakistanis, after pronouncing on their arrival in England that all mention of history was banned, have yet to prohibit the rest of the curriculum.

Shoaib Akhtar, meanwhile, has said he is likely to be on a plane for England on Monday after suffering from the after- effects of typhoid.

"I am fully perfect, there's nothing wrong with me. I just had a bit of a stomach problem the other day; that's why I didn't fly with the team," he said.

He bowled for two hours in the nets on Thursday and played in a limited-over match in Lahore yesterday. "I've been playing cricket and it's been fine. I'll probably be on the plane on Monday."

webTitle: Cricket: Walker snatches win with a rush

fields.headline: Walker snatches win with a rush
fields.standfirst: Essex 255-6 Kent 257-7 Kent won by 3 wickets
fields.trailText: Essex 255-6 Kent 257-7 Kent won by 3 wickets
fields.body:
Kent had Matthew Walker's magnificent unbeaten century and some untidy at-the-death bowling to thank for their thrilling triumph here. The tiny left-hander smashed a wayward Ashley Cowan to the point boundary to reach a remarkable hundred, then, with five balls to spare, lofted a half-volley from the same bowler over long-on to steal the match.

He finished with 106 from 121 balls as the visitors reached a stiffish 255 target that had once seemed out of their grasp.

Essex, in control for much of the game, had been thrown into disarray by a finely judged display of placement hitting. Walker hit only six boundaries but throughout his innings he plundered ones and twos across the lush outfield.

Walker was well served down the order by Mark Ealham, James Hockley and Martin McCague, but it was only when his decisive partnership with the tall, inexperienced James Golding began to blossom that an unlikely win seemed possible.

Golding bashed 33 runs in 31 balls while Walker darted and stroked at the other end. They put on 78 in 63 balls, and the confidence visibly drained from Essex minute by minute.

The home side's earlier dominance was established by a fluent opening stand of 129 in 30 overs between Darren Robinson and Nasser Hussain.

Robinson, a belligerent and valuable part of the Essex line-up, clouted eight boundaries in a brisk 69, while Hussain lived more dangerously on the way to his 58. He was dropped on 32 by David Masters when he slogged Min Patel to deep mid-wicket, then perished lbw trying to cross-bat Matthew Fleming.

Three run-outs then put a brake on Essex's innings under some form of control. Stuart Law's was the cruellest; as he backed up, Ronnie Irani clumped the ball back to Masters, who finger-tipped the ball on to the stumps.

The Essex total looked more than enough, however, when Kent were floundering at 102 for five, but at that stage Walker had hardly warmed up.

fields.headline: Murali applies the squeeze
fields.standfirst: Derbyshire 117 all out Lancashire 121-0 - Lancashire won by 10 wickets
fields.trailText: Derbyshire 117 all out Lancashire 121-0 - Lancashire won by 10 wickets
fields.body:
Muttiah Muralitharan and Mike Atherton earned Lancashire a glimmer of hope by inspiring a 10-wicket demolition of Derbyshire here yesterday.

Muralitharan recorded the remarkable figures of 10-7-4-1 to help Lancashire to their first win in three qualifying ties and victories over Yorkshire here tomorrow and Nottinghamshire at Trent Bridge on Monday could squeeze them into the quarter-finals.

When Muralitharan conceded eight runs from his first over for Lancashire against Durham last Tuesday, any curious Scousers who had popped down for a first look at him must have wondered what all the fuss was about.

By the end of that spell, when he had bewitched the Durham batsmen to such an extent that only another 11 runs came from his remaining nine overs, they would have had a better idea.

His analysis yesterday was not quite the meanest in the competition's 29-year history - Chris Old conceded only three runs in 11 overs for Yorkshire against Middlesex at Lord's in 1979. Nor was it a Lancashire one-day record - Jack Simmons took one for three in 12 overs in a NatWest Trophy tie in Suffolk in 1985.

But it was almost certainly the most economical analysis recorded by a Sri Lankan in Merseyside in May and, with excellent support from the seamers - notably Peter Martin, Ian Austin and Andy Flintoff - ensured that the Lancashire batsmen would not have much to chase.

They had failed in pursuit of modest targets against Durham and at Leicester on Wednesday but there was no chance of another collapse once Atherton and Mark Chilton had seen off Dominic Cork's five-over opening burst.

If Flintoff's bowling performance, plus a couple of sharp slip catches, had been encouraging for England, Atherton's unbeaten 77 from 111 balls was hugely reassuring.

After he had taken 18 balls to get off the mark against Leicestershire, and then gone for a single, one caustic comment suggested that to describe his batting as rusty would be an insult to oxidisation. But here he eased back into form with 11 boundaries, including an uncharacteristic flay over point, mostly reliant on timing.

Derbyshire, still win-less, are out of finals contention.

webTitle: Cricket: Maher strikes out in vain

fields.headline: Maher strikes out in vain
fields.trailText: Glamorgan 236-6 Gloucestershire 240-5 Gloucestershire won by five wickets
fields.body:
They are still at it: Gloucestershire sustained their stunning one-day form on a day when they had seemed destined for defeat after a brilliant century from Jimmy Maher.

Coaxed and inspired by their captain Mark Alleyne, Gloucestershire won by five wickets. He knew instinctively when it was time for calm mathematics and then a celebratory flourish of the bat; Jeremy Snape cracked crucial off- drives at the other end. The pair buoyantly added 97 runs, making Glamorgan's attack increasingly impotent.

It was cruel for Maher. His 142 not out came excitingly off 151 balls, with 12 fours and a six, his first hundred for Glamorgan. Is there no end to the Australian conveyor belt?

Gloucestershire's innings stuttered at the start. Rob Cunliffe was snatched in the slips at full-stretch by Maher, who appeared as though he could do nothing wrong. Chris Taylor perished the same way. Ian Harvey decided to play with attractive abandon and the boundaries multiplied until he was surprisingly run out. He had become a father the previous day and he went wearily for his fateful single.

Glamorgan had been unlucky to lose Steve James, hit on the left knee by Jon Lewis. The county's new captain had already undergone two operations on the knee. He had been going well with several classic cover drives.

Gloucestershire's outfielding was better than their catching. Michael Powell survived an easy catch to Mike Cawdron. Kim Barnett, at 40, could be forgiven his failure to hold on to a chance from Maher in the covers. But Cunliffe's two late lapses at deep-cover, benefiting Darren Thomas and Maher in the closing overs, were harder to explain.

Glamorgan's total, boosted by old-fashioned slogging, seemed to offer Gloucestershire a real challenge. Yet, if Maher had not dominated with such perky power, there would have been little to chase.

Matthew Maynard was soon taken at the wicket, Powell low down at slip and Adrian Dale, perhaps burdened by the added responsibilities of stand-in skipper, was confused when for the second time in the competition he was run out.
