webTitle: Benson & Hedges Cup: Camelot crumbles to Surrey

fields.headline: Camelot crumbles to Surrey
fields.standfirst: Surrey 194 Hampshire 171 - Surrey won by 23 runs
fields.trailText: Surrey 194 Hampshire 171 - Surrey won by 23 runs
fields.body:
There is a whiff of Camelot about Hampshire's new ground. Marquees flutter and preen under a pale sun, beside the plastic tents and the pavilion with its fluted roof, and when Barry Richards shuffled past yesterday, there was even a lustrous knight.

A joust seems not far away. Beyond the boundary one half expects to view a palace and a court, so the golf course, car park and M27 come as something of a disappointment.

Hampshire were a disappointment, too. This is hardly a side imbued with Arthurian legend. Their first outing at their new Rose Bowl ground was an anticlimax, since all it did was evoke memories of last season's miseries at their humbler home in Northlands Road.

On a slow pitch, and with a vast and lethargic outfield, Surrey's total of 194 emerged from its inherent modesty to prove a match-winning score; Hampshire mustered only 171 and lost this Benson & Hedges Cup tie by 23 runs.

Hampshire's innings needed some early brio, when the ball was hard and their captain Robin Smith and the free-scoring overseas all-rounder Neil Johnson were their batsmen. But Smith, who will be 38 before the season is completed, is past his cudgelling prime. And Johnson flailed at a wide one and dragged on before he had scored in the first over.

After that Surrey were not even required to be at their formidable best, though Ben Hollioake did himself no harm at all, with figures of three for 29. It won him the gold award.

Hampshire's best batsman was Derek Kenway, but he was foolishly run out at 54 when Jason Laney played to midwicket and spurned the single. After that it was just a matter of time.

A target of 98 from the final 20 overs, with six wickets in hand, would be regulation stuff in different circumstances. But in the middle and lower order only Dimitri Mascarenhas had the physical strength to make a monkey of the conditions, and he perished to the bowling of the junior Hollioake for only six.

Surrey's innings contained cameos, nothing more. Alistair Brown was dropped by Laney at mid-wicket before he had scored and then again by Mascarenhas, a straightforward caught-and-bowled chance, when he had made 19.

Mark Butcher was lbw swinging across the line, Ian Ward chipped Johnson's first delivery to mid-on and Mark Ramprakash did not exploit an early reprieve. But they scored enough. And in this joust Hampshire's batsmen were tilting at windmills.

webTitle: Labour donors leave Tories lagging 4 to 1

fields.headline: Labour donors leave Tories lagging 4 to 1
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Labour took more than four times as much in donations from individuals and the trade unions than the Conservatives in the first ever figures released by the new electoral commission yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour took more than four times as much in donations from individuals and the trade unions than the Conservatives in the first ever figures released by the new electoral commission yesterday.

With the election only weeks away it was revealed that Labour raised £2.42m to the Tories' £634,000 from February 16 to the end of March.

The Tories' biggest single donor, with a gift of £40,000, was the mysterious United & Cecil club, with party treasurer Lord Ashcroft giving £30,200.

The dominance of what appears to be a vehicle for discreet donations, together with controversial Lord Ashcroft who has only recently returned from Belize to live in England, is not the only embarrassment for the Tories.

The figures show that the party relied more on taxpayers' money - through the so-called Short money which funds opposition parliamentary activities - than it raised in donations over £1,000. In a further blow to William Hague, there are also few big names on the list of corporate donors.

Labour's biggest single donor was the GMB union, with over £1.2m, but as well as a large bequest several loyal party members - Lords Haskins, Joffe, Paul and Reed - all donated £10,000 each.

The Tory party chairman, Michael Ancram, said: "Labour claim to be funded from a broad base of financial supporters", but as so often with Labour, the truth is very different. Labour has been paid well over £2m by the unions in six weeks. It is now clear that the Labour party are as beholden to the trade unions as they have always been."

The Tories also attacked "parallel" advertising, pointing to a recent Unison-sponsored campaign against the Conservatives which echoed a similar campaign the union funded during the 1997 election. But Labour sources claim that only 30% of its income comes from unions, while a fifth comes from individuals.

The last two elections were dominated by claims and counter-claims about sources of party funding, with the Tories repeatedly embarrassed by their dependence on overseas donations.

The electoral commission - charged with ensuring honesty and openness in party funding - was recommended by the committee on standards in public life. Under the new rules, all donations over £1,000 have to be registered, and must come from an individual who is on the UK electoral role or a company which operates in the UK and is registered either in the UK or Europe.

With Tony Blair expected to launch the election campaign next week, Labour now appears to be slightly in front on cash - but for the first time there is a ceiling on central party spending during the campaign, of £15m. Both main parties are thought to have raised enough cash to spend up to the ceiling.

Yesterday, Labour played down its reliance on union funding and insisted the figures were skewed because they failed to reflect the 40% of the party's income which comes from its membership and from donations under £1,000.

But although Labour was claiming credit for introducing transparency into party fundraising, shadows remain. Earlier this year - just before the electoral commission's first accounting period began - it emerged that three donors, Lords Sainsbury and Hamlyn and Christopher Ondaatje had each donated £2m.

Adding to the row over Formula One boss Bernie Ecclestone's pre-election £1m donation and the subsequent softening of the government's position on tobacco advertising, there is anxiety that openness alone does not solve all the problems of party funding.

The Tory party chairman, Michael Ancram, said: "Labour claim to be funded from a broad base of financial supporters", but as so often with Labour, the truth is very different. Labour has been paid well over £2m by the unions in six weeks. It is now clear that the Labour party are as beholden to the trade unions as they have always been." The Tories also attacked "parallel" advertising, pointing to a recent Unison-sponsored campaign against the Conservatives which echoed a similar campaign the union funded during the 1997 election. But Labour sources claim that only 30% of its income comes from unions, while a fifth comes from individuals. The last two elections were dominated by claims and counter-claims about sources of party funding, with the Tories repeatedly embarrassed by their dependence on overseas donations. The electoral commission - charged with ensuring honesty and openness in party funding - was recommended by the committee on standards in public life. Under the new rules, all donations over £1,000 have to be registered, and must come from an individual who is on the UK electoral role or a company which operates in the UK and is registered either in the UK or Europe. With Tony Blair expected to launch the election campaign next week, Labour now appears to be slightly in front on cash - but for the first time there is a ceiling on central party spending during the campaign, of £15m. Both main parties are thought to have raised enough cash to spend up to the ceiling. Yesterday, Labour played down its reliance on union funding and insisted the figures were skewed because they failed to reflect the 40% of the party's income which comes from its membership and from donations under £1,000. But although Labour was claiming credit for introducing transparency into party fundraising, shadows remain. Earlier this year - just before the electoral commission's first accounting period began - it emerged that three donors, Lords Sainsbury and Hamlyn and Christopher Ondaatje had each donated £2m. Adding to the row over Formula One boss Bernie Ecclestone's pre-election £1m donation and the subsequent softening of the government's position on tobacco advertising, there is anxiety that openness alone does not solve all the problems of party funding. webTitle: Things my girlfriend and I argue about

fields.headline: Things my girlfriend and I argue about
fields.trailText: 'Margret doesn't like to watch films on the TV. No, hold on - let me make sure you've got the inflection here: Margret doesn't like to watch films on the TV.'
fields.body:
Welcome again, my dear, dear friends, to Britain's Catharsis Superstore. This week's specials include:

Margret enters the room. The television is showing Baywatch. Margret says, 'Uh-huh, you're watching Baywatch again.' I say, 'I'm not watching, it's just on.' Repeat. For the duration of the programme.

She wants to paint the living room yellow. I have not the words.

Margret doesn't like to watch films on the TV. No, hold on - let me make sure you've got the inflection here: Margret doesn't like to watch films on the TV. She says she does, but years of bitter experience have proven that what she actually wants is to sit by me while I narrate the entire bleeding film to her. 'Who's she?', 'Why did he get shot?', 'I thought that one was on their side?', 'Is that a bomb?' - 'JUST WATCH IT! IN THE NAME OF GOD, JUST WATCH IT'!

The hellish mirror-image of this is when she furnishes me, deaf to my pleading, with her commentary. Chair-clawing suspense being assaulted mercilessly from behind by such interjections as, 'Hey! Look! They're the cushions we've got', 'Isn't she the one who does that tampon advert?' and, on one famous occasion, 'Oh, I've seen this - he gets killed at the end.'

I'm off to stand in the cupboard under the stairs and scream for the next seven days. Can someone video Buffy for me?

webTitle: Peter Cole on Britain and the euro

fields.headline: Confusion, bewilderment and lots of polls - but no debate
fields.standfirst:
Special report: economic and monetary union
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Recent polls give contradictory views of British opinion on Europe and the euro, says Peter Cole, professor of journalism at Sheffield University.
fields.body:
A busy time for Mori, the opinion pollsters. On Monday a full page advertisement in the Times placed by the British Democracy Campaign shouts that 52% of British voters wanted to get out now. Of the EU, that is. And 71% wanted a referendum on whether we should continue to be members. Note that this is not membership of the single currency, the euro, where we are at present outside; it is EU membership itself, which we have had for a long time.

Mori had interviewed 1,805 British adults, face to face, between March 15 and 21. Mori were polling again, on April 30 and May 1 - this time 1,008 people, on the telephone. They were doing it for the Sun, with a poll that indicated that the Labour landslide was going to be greater this time than in 1997. Again they asked the "leave the EU" question - 47% would vote to get out.

You could say that a 5% move in favour of EU membership in the space of six weeks is rapid progress for the Europhiles, but you would be told not to be frivolous and to remember the margin of error.

The fact is these polls indicate a considerable lack of enthusiasm for Europe. The Sun poll also asked the more relevant question (there isn't going to be a referendum about EU membership) about voting intentions in the single currency referendum. Here Mori found 24% in favour, 70% against joining the euro.

The Sun, which is supporting Labour in the coming election but is strongly opposed to joining the euro, thus found its own poll in complete agreement with its own own position. It could proclaim that "the British public's love affair with Tony Blair goes from strength to strength" while in the same editorial issuing this warning: "He must not be lulled into thinking he can push Britain into the single currency, which the poll shows is opposed by 70% of voters. The election may be a foregone conclusion, but Blair has no mandate for scrapping the pound."

Yet another poll was published this week, which may have sent out a similar message but was interpreted differently by those who chose to report it. Among the pro-Euros ignorance and confusion now seem to be synonyms for antipathy and opposition. The Eurobarometer is published by the EU itself. Its poll this week showed that 21% of Britons supported the euro, compared with an average of 55% across the other 14 member states.

The Times quoted a Brussels official as saying: "There is a strong picture of confusion, bewilderment and ignorance about the EU among Britons."

The poll will have provided wall to wall joy for the Eurosceptics, although their cheerleaders in the press paid it little attention. The Times, usually pretty down the middle on these matters, set out the range of Eurobarometer findings about Britain and Europe: "The British feel the least attached to Europe, the least European and the least proud of being European. They are least likely to vote in the European parliamentary elections. They are least supportive of EU membership, with just 28% compared to an EU average of 50%."

And worse. The Times pointed out: "The British are the most uninformed, with 78% saying that they know little or nothing about the EU. In response to almost every question more British respondents replied 'don't know' than any other nationality."

Headline in the Mirror, pro-Europe, pro-euro: "Euro joy for Blair." This on a story reporting the same opinion poll, but making a completely different point. "Tony Blair has received a huge boost in his battle to persuade voters Britain should adopt the euro." What is this boost? It is the massive ignorance the British have about the EU - that and the fact that they want to find out more about the euro. "It will persuade Mr Blair that he can win voters' support, despite campaigns by Tory newspapers and other groups to rubbish the euro."

So encouraged was the Mirror by this poll, that it backed its short news story with a longer editorial headlined "Tell euro truth." This focused less on Blair's joy than on the ignorance factor. We were admirably honest in admitting our ignorance, said the Mirror. Particularly about the euro. But the survey also revealed why this was. "The government tells us nothing. We don't learn about it at school or work. There is little on the TV and much of what appears in newspapers is lies from wild anti-Europeans. When we know the facts, the people of this country are more than able to make up their own minds. It is time we were told the whole truth."

That seems unlikely in the immediate future. As the Financial Times said in the course of its report on the government's reaction to Gerhard Schröder's proposals for EU reform: "With a general election expected on June 7, the government is keen to avoid a debate on Europe that allows the Conservative party to claim that the EU is becoming a superstate."

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University.

fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.trailText: No55 Engage
fields.body:
No, Engage is not an online dating agency, but a hard-nosed engineering consultancy, and an offshoot of FTSE100 giant GKN.

As existing technologies are pushed to the limits of performance, the degree of precision and sophistication required in engineering is increasing dramatically. What's more, the development of new techniques, technologies, processes and changes to the way we work are all conspiring to create exciting and rewarding opportunities for graduates working in modern engineering enterprises.

Working closely with its client partners Engage creates engineering solutions that support the life cycle of their clients' products.

For example, at BAe Systems, an Engage team provides both an off-site design service and an on-site supply of qualified engineers who are helping to assess fatigue and damage tolerance on the A300-600 series of aircraft.

As part of this service Engage has undertaken a number of tasks ranging from the design of A320 fuselage sections and large portions of wing to providing the core support team to flight test instrument installations.

Parent company GKN is at the heart of the car-making industry, which positions Engage at the leading edge of development in motor engineering support services, collaborating with key manufacturers such as Honda, Ford, Lotus and Jaguar.

The consultancy is also involved with leading rail vehicle manufacturer Eurotram, providing various design and project management services. A team of designers and stress analysts using computer aided design has helped develop the Eurotram bodyshell into a generic product platform which can be adapted for different tram applications in different countries.

The firm is seeking graduates in mechanical or aeronautical engineering who have gained at least a 2:1 honours degree or above and those with further qualifications such as an MEng.

New recruits are initially placed in a team working on client projects and can expect starting salaries ranging from £16,000 to £18,000. Engage places much empasis on its commitment to career progression that can often include international postings. The graduate trainees are encouraged to move around to different project areas every six months or so in order to broaden their experience. This includes working with non-engineering departments such as finance, sales and marketing to gain a deeper understanding of the company's business.

The firm's human resources policy has impressed 23-year old stress engineer Andrew Slaney who has a mechanical engineering qualification from University of Portsmouth.

"From the initial interview onwards I have been impressed with the way that Engage is obviously interested in what it can offer me, as opposed to just what I can do for them," he says. "The company encourages me to think ahead about what I want to do say, in ten years time, and what I need to do to get there."

 Details of application procedures are available from Engage, Recruitment Centre, Atlantic Road, Avonmouth, Bristol, BS11 9GN.

fields.headline: Winning friends and influencing employers
fields.standfirst: Short-cut to training through networking organisations
fields.trailText: Short-cut to training through networking organisations
fields.body:
Flick through today's job advertisements and you'll find many employers demanding a good degree and relevant skills. But if you've spent the last three or four years in lectures and tutorials, how are you you supposed to acquire these skills?

Becoming a member of a networking organisation such as the British Junior Chamber (BJC), might be the answer if you are lacking in the relevant business skills. The BJC is a voluntary organisation which creates opportunities for its members outside of work so they can acquire new skills or develop old ones while making new contacts and friends.

Joe Dilger, deputy national president of the BJC, says: "It's a great opportunity for graduates who want to get ahead of their peer group. Skills are taught that might not be developed in the workplace. We give a fuller picture of the business world and help make members more rounded."

Once you have joined the junior chamber you can attend training seminars, take part in long-term projects and undertake tasks which help build the skills you want. "It's a chance for people to practise in a safe environment, where there is a lot of encouragement and support," says Joe.

Training can take the form of lectures, tuition sessions, debating competitions and public speaking. As you get more involved, you can also find yourself helping to organise regional, national and international conferences and community events.

As there are 123 national junior chambers worldwide, there are plenty of opportunities to travel and meet contacts abroad. "The first conference I attended was in Monte Carlo, which was really exciting," says Joe. "This year the annual European conference is in Finland and the worldwide conference is in Barcelona."

While several networking organisations such as First Tuesday sprang up during the dot.com boom, the junior chamber has its origins in the US during the 1920s. Of 400,000 members worldwide 1,500 members are resident in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

The chamber's ethos is to create opportunities to mix with the great and the good and to encourage leadership and fellowship in local communities. It's not about what the organisation can do for you, but what you can do for yourself by being an active member.

"The more actively involved you become the more you will get out of it," says Joe. " Junior chamber is about learning by doing."

The cost of annual membership varies slightly depending on where your local chamber is but it is usually no more than £100 - £40 of which goes to the national organisation. And you don't have to be working in business to join. The only stipulation is that you must be aged between 18 and 40.

Other networking organisations include Rotaract, a version of the Rotary Club for people aged 18 to 30. Like the junior chamber, Rotaract carries out projects and fundraising for local community groups as well as organising social activities for its members. There are more than 200 Rotaract clubs and 3,000 members in Great Britian and Ireland.

webTitle: How to... develop a can-do attitude

fields.headline: How to... develop a can-do attitude
fields.standfirst: If someone says 'jump', do you ask 'how high'?
fields.trailText: If someone says 'jump', do you ask 'how high'?
fields.body:
No! It's a small word, easy to pronounce, slips off the tongue easily, particularly when you're asked to do something extra, work late, run an errand, fix the photocopier or help out with any one of the endless requests that fly across your desk each day.

Saying 'no' regularly allows you to sail through your day undisturbed, achieving your tasks, avoiding diversions and ensuring that you go home bang on 5.30pm. However, it probably also irritates your work-mates, causes resentment and may ultimately harm your career prospects.

"When I got promoted to lending manager, I was determined to do the job to the best of my ability," says Simon Barnsley, who works for a merchant bank. "I focused totally on my responsibilities, made lists of what I had to do each day and systematically worked through them. If anyone came and asked me to do anything I'd invariably turn them down - not through a desire to be unhelpful, but because I believed nothing was as important as the work I was doing."

It's all too easy to slip into this kind of mind-set, but being focused on yourself and your job to the exclusion of everything else doesn't necessarily bring the best results. "This is a real can't-do attitude," believes business consultant Charles Kay. "The first reaction is always negative - it will take too long, interrupt my work, cause a distraction. It is also selfish - constantly putting yourself first may enable you to work more quickly, but it betrays a lack of interest or concern in the office as a whole and your colleagues individually."

Simon Barnsley admits that it wasn't until he started to be on the receiving end of sarcastic comments from some of his colleagues that he realised his attitude was causing problems. "There are around 15 people in my department and occasionally global emails go round asking for help with a specific problem," he says. "A couple came round that were titled 'Everyone except Simon,' and when I asked the sender why, she said there was no point in asking me for help as I always said no. I asked a couple of other people if they agreed and, embarrassingly, they did."

Offices are a bizarre mixture of individual responsibility and teamwork - and if one member of the team doesn't pull their weight it can breed resentment. "There is always collective responsibility in an office environment," believes Charles Kay, "and a positive and helpful attitude is essential.

"The cliché is that you learn to say 'yes' instead of 'no', but it's not really that simple. It's more about being positive: looking at how to solve problems, thinking about who can help if you are too busy and being charming even if you have to refuse a request."

All of which sounds great in theory, but at 6.30 in the evening, when you've a splitting headache and total brain failure it can be a different matter. "It is about willingness to make an effort," believes Kate McIntyre, head buyer for a department store. "I am impressed by people who are positive, who react well if I ask them to do something extra - whether it's mending the fax machine or staying until 11pm to finish a report."

Kate insists that she's not impressed by yes-men, but by people who display a willingness to help. "It's that terrible Americanism, a 'can-do' attitude," she says. "If I ask someone to work late and they say they have a prior engagement, I'll understand. If they then say they'll come in early the next day instead, I'm impressed. If there's a problem with a supplier, I will remember the person who thinks around the problem and comes to me with a solution, rather than the people who simply accept the situation and think nothing can be done."

"The phrase 'can-do attitude' can be misleading," says work psychologist Nikki Fields. "It doesn't mean you have to say yes to everything that's asked of you, more that you are open to things and positive. If you can't do something, suggest someone who may be able to."

If you don't know the answer to a question you have been asked, try to find it out. They may be small things, but they impress the boss far more than the person who thinks he or she is being assertive by saying no, or that they don't know, or can't help.

"I have really tried to make a shift in the way I think," says Simon Barnsley, "to the extent that if someone asks me to do something, I take a beat before I answer.

"My instinct is still to say no, but I am learning that my workload doesn't suddenly become unmanageable if I take a few minutes out to deal with a difficult client, or advise a colleague. And I even get included in the emails now."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this...

Having a can-do attitude is not about saying yes to everything. It's about being open, positive and upbeat.

"There is always collective responsibility in an office environment," believes Charles Kay, "and a positive and helpful attitude is essential. "The cliché is that you learn to say 'yes' instead of 'no', but it's not really that simple. It's more about being positive: looking at how to solve problems, thinking about who can help if you are too busy and being charming even if you have to refuse a request." All of which sounds great in theory, but at 6.30 in the evening, when you've a splitting headache and total brain failure it can be a different matter. "It is about willingness to make an effort," believes Kate McIntyre, head buyer for a department store. "I am impressed by people who are positive, who react well if I ask them to do something extra - whether it's mending the fax machine or staying until 11pm to finish a report." Kate insists that she's not impressed by yes-men, but by people who display a willingness to help. "It's that terrible Americanism, a 'can-do' attitude," she says. "If I ask someone to work late and they say they have a prior engagement, I'll understand. If they then say they'll come in early the next day instead, I'm impressed. If there's a problem with a supplier, I will remember the person who thinks around the problem and comes to me with a solution, rather than the people who simply accept the situation and think nothing can be done." "The phrase 'can-do attitude' can be misleading," says work psychologist Nikki Fields. "It doesn't mean you have to say yes to everything that's asked of you, more that you are open to things and positive. If you can't do something, suggest someone who may be able to." If you don't know the answer to a question you have been asked, try to find it out. They may be small things, but they impress the boss far more than the person who thinks he or she is being assertive by saying no, or that they don't know, or can't help. "I have really tried to make a shift in the way I think," says Simon Barnsley, "to the extent that if someone asks me to do something, I take a beat before I answer. "My instinct is still to say no, but I am learning that my workload doesn't suddenly become unmanageable if I take a few minutes out to deal with a difficult client, or advise a colleague. And I even get included in the emails now." If you don't remember anything else, remember this... Having a can-do attitude is not about saying yes to everything. It's about being open, positive and upbeat.

webTitle: An ABC guide to developing a competitive streak

fields.headline: An ABC guide to developing a competitive streak
fields.trailText: Moving on up
fields.body:
A. Play the game

Does the thought of proving yourself superior to others fill you with fighting fervour or make you want to crawl into a dark space? If you prefer to avoid situations that push you into showing you're better than the rest, finding work and flourishing in a job can be a strain. Unfortunately, most courses, jobs and promotions have more candidates than places. Don't let that put you off. Even the most competitive professions are full of ordinary people. Their most special characteristic is a belief in themselves, something anyone can develop.

B. Entry rules

Don't hide behind protestations that you're not combative or kid yourself that your natural ability will be spotted. Not having a go because you're afraid of losing makes it easy for others to win. Bolster your confidence by familiarising yourself with both written and hidden rules of the contests you have to enter. You're more likely to succeed if you know what to expect and have taken time to practise the techniques involved.

C. Against all odds

Although it may appear sensible to participate only when you feel you have a good chance of victory, it can be easier to cope with losing if you aim high. A plucky outsider is more impressive than a complacent contender who has not seen a need to make the effort. Even if you don't win, a memorable performance can create opportunities. There's much to be gained by taking part and learning from more accomplished performers.

fields.headline: Country retreat?
fields.standfirst: Areas of growth for agriculture graduates
fields.trailText: Areas of growth for agriculture graduates
fields.body:
Let's not pretend that a graduate opening in agriculture is a stunning debut career move. Apocalyptic television coverage of insane cows and burning carcasses has done little to swell applicant numbers to the Royal Agricultural College at Cirencester and there are plenty of voices arguing that the UK's rural economy is in terminal decline.

Some 1.92m agricultural jobs were lost in the European Union in the 1980s and 54% of farmers are now over 55 years of age. Only 8% are less than 35-years old.

But while farm labourers may be a dying breed, demand for those who can bring skills and fresh thinking to the rural sector is high. And smart graduates are well placed to direct how the UK's struggling rural economy can rejuvenate and evolve.

According to the Higher Education Statistics Agency, 14,760 students were studying agriculture and related subjects such as forestry, food science and agricultural science in 1999-2000 - the latest year for which figures are available. Received wisdom is that a majority of these are going back and working on their parents' farms - but this is far from the only option available.

"Many others are drawn to areas of advisory work in both the UK and abroad," states the prospectus for the University of Reading's faculty for agriculture and food. "Some take postgraduate training before entering professions such as accountancy, land agency, teaching or research."

Agriculture graduate Will Kallaway is now working for issues management firm Luther Pendragon. "The careers advice wasn't fantastic," he recalls of his alma mater, Cirencester, "but then I don't remember unemployment being a big issue. If you didn't come from a farming background you would get picked up and employed by one of the big agribusinesses like Cargill and Dalgety - anything from the international grain trading companies to the international livestock enterprises like PIC."

As with other non-vocational degrees such as English and history, the skills you pick up during the course can be as or more valuable to an employer as the curriculum.

Will always wanted to be a farmer. But by the time he graduated in 1996, the agricultural crisis had "really kicked in" and agricultural prices were falling. He knew people who were going into farm management and not earning much money at all. "After my gap year gaining experience on farms both home and abroad and my placement which was part of the course, I decided I didn't really want to be a farm manager working morning, noon and night for someone else," he reflects. "Cirencester ran a series of specialist courses in my third year and I opted to take journalism and marketing and decided I would try to specialise in agricultural PR."

Martin Newton, 25, is another dissenter. From a farming family, he read rural land management at Cirencester with a view to a career as a chartered surveyor. "I used to help out at home over the summer, but there are only so many ways you can look out of a tractor cabin."

Attracted to the "bright lights" of London after he graduated, he initially temped at the London Stock Exchange and took a permanent position when it became available. But Martin harbours long-term ambitions to go into the music industry either in publishing, events management or royalties. Ironically it's an area that ties in with his undergraduate study. "I did my undergraduate dissertation on the organisation and mechanics of pop festivals on rural land," he says.

Initiatives such as Agritrax, a new consultancy and website, aim to bring both high fliers and technology to the rural sector. "Agritrax teaches farmers specialist Sage accountancy software and farm recording packages, for example," says 30-year old founder Julian Davies. The firm also offers website design for any rural sector business and advertises student placements and graduate jobs on its website www.agritrax.com.

Julian, who graduated from Harper Adams University in 1996 with a 2:1 in agriculture, rural land and farm management, always hated the idea of a desk job. "I worked in London for six months as part of my sandwich course, getting up at 6.30am to commute in," he says. "Nowadays the machinery is bigger, which means that farms are employing less staff and so the ones they have need to bring as many skills to the sector as possible."

And then there's government money. The England Rural Development Programme aims to support a thriving rural economy, in which farmers may continue to produce high quality agricultural products, "within an environmentally sustainable, attractive landscape".

Last December Nick Brown, minister for agriculture, fisheries and food, announced government plans for a £1.6bn rural development programme, involving £300m of new Exchequer funding. The aim is to help farmers and foresters to respond better to consumer requirements and become more competitive, diverse, flexible and environmentally responsible.

"There are some colleges trying to get farmer's sons to do green- keeping courses - but to be honest, how many pitch-and-putt golf courses can the countryside support?" says one agriculture graduate. Other more tangible options include working for MAFF, applying for the graduate training programme with the National Farmers' Union or joining one of the management training programmes for one of the large farm management companies such as Velcourt, which manages thousands of acres in the UK.

Or you could go global: Monsanto and AstraZeneca have international opportunities. There is, after all, a whole world to feed.

Will's experiences of both agriculture and big business has given him strong views on how the UK's rural economy can bounce back and develop. "The future lies in getting closer to the consumer, informing people what goes on in the countryside and how food is produced. Whether it's rare breeds or organic, farmers need to think about how they communicate what they do to the wider public." He cites www.somersetorganics.co.uk and www.fletcherscotland.co.uk as examples of local suppliers marketing themselves effectively.

fields.headline: Stoke Park Club, Buckinghamshire
fields.trailText: The rooms are staggeringly gorgeous. Oak-timbered four-posters very likely slept in by Queen Elizabeth I, who owned the place ...
fields.body:
Address: Park Road, Stoke Poges, Buckinghamshire, SL2 4PG. Tel: 01753 717171.

Web address: www.stokeparkclub.com.

First impressions: Don't say that Grade I listed house, with beautiful grounds and golf club and boating lake and a starring role in Bridget Jones's Diary (the hotel where the dastardly Hugh Grant takes our windswept Bridget on a mini-break) could possibly be where we're staying?

What are the rooms like? Staggeringly gorgeous. Oak-timbered four-posters very likely slept in by Queen Elizabeth I, who owned the place; sofas; lots of cushions; big windows with luscious view.

The bed test A great night's sleep had by all; especially good if you draw the curtains on the four-poster.

The bathroom test: Under-floor heating, glamorously-overflowing bath, twin sinks. And some very, very nice towels.

The restaurant: Impeccable food (especially the chocolate fondant) and the most charming waiter ever (particularly good if you want gossip from the Bridget Jones set). Side-by-side seating was slightly odd.

The lounge: Very relaxing, more cushions.

What is there to see within walking distance? Just the grounds: golf, tennis, the lake.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? The bourgeois quartet of Windsor, Eton, Henley and Ascot are terribly near. Otherwise, there's Slough.

How much a night? Doubles from £245 a night. Two-night Bridget Jones package (champagne, breakfast, dinner, BJ goodies) £235pp.

webTitle: Storm as head of national blood authority calls gay donors 'evil'

fields.headline: Storm as head of national blood authority calls gay donors 'evil'
fields.trailText: The head of Britain's blood donor service sparked outrage yesterday after claiming that gay men who defied a ban to give blood were "evil".
fields.body:
The head of Britain's blood donor service sparked outrage yesterday after claiming that gay men who defied a ban to give blood were "evil".

MPs and gay rights groups united in questioning the judgment of Mike Fogden, the chairman of the national blood authority, who also accused gay blood donors of "putting at risk the innocent lives of innocent patients".

The Department of Health said it "deplored" the tone and language of the remarks which it described as "inappropriate and unjustified", while Angela Mason, the director of the gay rights group Stonewall, suggested the government should bring him to account.

Mr Fogden's comments came in a response to a letter in the Pink Paper, in which a 29-year-old gay man said: "I'm about to commit a moral offence. I'm going to give blood even though they clearly state they do not want 'Men who have had sex (even safe sex) with another man'. Am I evil?"

Mr Fogden replied: "The answer is yes, he is evil and also a liar. He is evil because he is prepared to put at risk the innocent life of an innocent patient (even a newborn child) to satisfy his own selfish prejudice. He is also a liar because he is dishonest in answering our questionnaire."

The paper ran a three-page feature and editorial condemning his views.

Last night, the Department of Health said Mr Fogden had been hauled into a meeting with the junior health minister Lord Hunt, who oversees blood donor issues, and told that the letter "was totally unacceptable and displayed a serious lack of judgment". The body's chief executive was also contacted, and Mr Fogden forced to write an apology.

In this second letter to the paper, he offered his "sincere apologies" for the letter, which had, he said, been written in haste. "The tone was ill-conceived and unnecessarily judgmental," he added.

But he maintained the policy behind the comments was correct, arguing that the ban was necessary since screening methods for blood still fail to detect HIV during the first 22 days of infection. He added that, in a recent case in the UK, a gay man who gave blood on a regular basis transmitted the HIV infection to three patients while in this "window period".

Britain has banned blood donations from all gay men since the early 80s, as well as donations from other groups deemed high risk, such as intravenous drug users and prostitutes- but gay rights groups have pushed for less stringent regulations.

Last night, the Department of Health said that current medical opinion suggested the policy should remain in place but its criticism of Mr Fogden found widespread backing.

Shaun Woodward, the Labour MP who defected from the Tories because of their hardline policy on gay rights, said: "It is harmful because it sends out the prejudice that HIV/Aids is a gay man's disease and HIV doesn't discriminate in this way."

Mr Fogden was unavailable for comment last night.

webTitle: Penitent Pope attempts to end holy war

fields.headline: Penitent Pope attempts to end holy war
fields.standfirst: John Paul woos Orthodox Greeks by apologising for sins of crusade
fields.trailText: John Paul woos Orthodox Greeks by apologising for sins of crusade.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II made a bold attempt to heal the 1,000-year split in Christianity yesterday by asking God to forgive Catholics for past sins against Orthodox Christians.

The pontiff, who was in the Greek capital on the first leg of his six-day "jubilee pilgrimage" retracing the footsteps of St Paul, prayed for forgiveness for "the occasions, past and present, when sons and daughters of the Catholic church have sinned by action or omission against their Orthodox brothers and sisters".

He is the first Pope to visit the predominantly Orthodox country since the "Great Schism" of 1054, which divided Christianity into its eastern and western branches. The visit is one of the most controversial of all his 93 apostolic trips outside Italy and has provoked uproar within Greece's conservative-minded Orthodox church.

The increasingly frail pontiff, who is accompanied by four doctors, sees the pilgrimage as a way of advancing his dream of reconciliation between Catholicism and Orthodoxy, as well as an opportunity to improve relations with the Muslim world. He will visit Syria tomorrow, and then Malta.

But Greece's monks, parish priests and nuns were furious with the church leadership for lifting its long-held objections to the visit, and religious hardliners had promised a hostile reception for the Pope, whom they dubbed the "arch-heretic" and "the grotesque, two-horned monster of Rome".

Archbishop Christodoulos, leader of the Greek Orthodox church, had been called the "anti-Christodoulos" for his decision to lobby the church's ruling body, the holy synod, to agree to the visit.

The Greek Orthodox church harbours a litany of perceived misdeeds that date back 1,000 years-from the schism in 1054 through the sacking of Constantinople by the fourth crusade in 1204, to the "poaching" of Orthodox believers in eastern Europe by the Uniate church, or eastern rite Catholics, whose services resemble Orthodox ones, but who show allegiance to Rome.

More recently, many Orthodox Greeks have been outraged by what they regard as western (read Catholic) aggression against fellow Orthodox Serbia.

But yesterday John Paul, who has made atonement something of a leitmotif of his papacy, attempted to address Orthodox grievances.

At a long meeting with Archbishop Christodoulos, he broached the touchy subject of Constantinople. "It is tragic that the assailants, who set out to secure free access for Christians to the Holy Land, turned against their own brothers in the faith," he said. "The fact that they were Latin Christians fills Catholics with deep regret."

Christodoulos clapped his hands in relief as the Pope spoke. A few minutes before, the popular archbishop had delivered a stinging rebuke to the pontiff for the Vatican's historic lack of contrition.

"Traumatic experiences remain as open wounds on [the Greek people's] vigorous body," Christodoulos had said. "Yet until now, there has not been heard even a single request for pardon."

Archimandrite Vasilios Drossos, of the archdiocese of Athens, said the Pope's remarks were "very very positive". "He was apologising for something which has its roots in historical fact. It is now time to look forward," he said, adding that he hoped dialogue between the churches would now be on a "much sounder footing".

He said the Pope's visit would act as a sign to the world's 200m-300m Orthodox that "they would no longer feel out of the mainstream". It was a good omen for a possible papal trip to the Patriarchate in Moscow, the most powerful of the various national Orthodox churches, he added.

But hardliners remained unconvinced. Father Anathassios, a monk of Mount Athos, one of Orthdoxy's most revered places, accused the Pope and the Greek church leadership of staging a confidence trick. "Orthodoxy is the true way - all others are mistaken," he said.

Other conservative Orthodox, including members of the Old Calendarists, who adhere to the Julian calendar but are regarded as schismatic by the Greek church, rang church bells in protest.

Archbishop Christodoulos had issued repeated calls for calm from hardliners opposed to the Pope's presence. But critics say he bears some responsibility for inflaming religious passions in Greece. He has been engaged in a protracted struggle with the modernising socialist government of Costas Simitis about its decision to remove the statement of religion from Greek national identity cards.

"The Pope is still a heretic," read one quickly prepared poster in Athens last night.

But as arch-heretics go, the Pope looked pretty mild-mannered, even humble, as he emerged from his jet into the spring sunshine.

"Where are his horns?" Yiannis Dimitrakopoulos, six, asked his father at the gleaming new Athens airport as the frail 80-year-old pontiff removed his cap and gave a short wave before descending. "He must have left them in his Pope-mobile," came the reply.

Due to the Pope's lack of mobility, the traditional kneeling and kissing of the soil was replaced by the offering of a bowl containing earth from the hill of the Areopagos, facing the Acropolis, which the Pope was due to visit last night. This is where St Paul preached the sermon of the unknown God to the Athenians in the 1st century.

At the Areopagos a "common message" was read out on behalf of the Pope and Archbishop Christodoulos, calling for Europe's Christian roots not to be forgotten.

The Pope's visit, which will finish this morning with a mass for Greece's 200,000 Catholics at the Olympic basketball stadium, was conducted amid tight security.

As he sped towards the centre of Athens in a bulletproof Mercedes, the roads were lined not with well-wishers, but with many of the 8,000 policemen who had been drafted in for the occasion - more than for the equally controversial visit of President Bill Clinton in 1999.

Every last detail of the visit has been the subject of tough negotiations, from the size of the venue to be used for the mass this morning, to the music that would accompany his triumphal approach to the Areopagos. The Four Seasons was chosen, and not the usual Handel's Messiah which the Orthodox church felt was too Catholic.

A member of the Holy Synod involved in the organisation of the visit said: "It was like painting an icon; arduous, and finicky, but worth it in the end."

The Greek press view

Eleftherotypia, centre-left daily

The Greek tradition of hospitality, which predates Christianity, is enriched by the Christian injunctions to love thy neighbour and even thine enemies. During the Pope's visit, let elementary Christian dignity prevail, with a civilised attitude that is not reminiscent of the Dark Ages

Kathimerini, centre-right daily

With direct shots about the silence of the pontiff over the tragedy of Cyprus, references to the sufferings Greece has undergone from the Catholic west and emphasis on the need for cooperation of both sides without intolerance, Archbishop Christodoulos greets Pope John Paul today.

Ethnos, populist daily

Those who feared objections to the visit would provide an opportunity for negative comments to be made about our country, have been justified. It is natural for there to be a few hundred, or even thousand, fanatics in a country, but it is anything but natural for the biggest TV channels to have them as guests every day and the leading topic of news bulletins

Avgi, leftwing daily

Here's a coincidence: the re-release of the Exorcist opens in Athens cinemas today

The increasingly frail pontiff, who is accompanied by four doctors, sees the pilgrimage as a way of advancing his dream of reconciliation between Catholicism and Orthodoxy, as well as an opportunity to improve relations with the Muslim world. He will visit Syria tomorrow, and then Malta. But Greece's monks, parish priests and nuns were furious with the church leadership for lifting its long-held objections to the visit, and religious hardliners had promised a hostile reception for the Pope, whom they dubbed the "arch-heretic" and "the grotesque, two-horned monster of Rome". Archbishop Christodoulos, leader of the Greek Orthodox church, had been called the "anti-Christodoulos" for his decision to lobby the church's ruling body, the holy synod, to agree to the visit. The Greek Orthodox church harbours a litany of perceived misdeeds that date back 1,000 years-from the schism in 1054 through the sacking of Constantinople by the fourth crusade in 1204, to the "poaching" of Orthodox believers in eastern Europe by the Uniate church, or eastern rite Catholics, whose services resemble Orthodox ones, but who show allegiance to Rome. More recently, many Orthodox Greeks have been outraged by what they regard as western (read Catholic) aggression against fellow Orthodox Serbia. But yesterday John Paul, who has made atonement something of a leitmotif of his papacy, attempted to address Orthodox grievances. At a long meeting with Archbishop Christodoulos, he broached the touchy subject of Constantinople. "It is tragic that the assailants, who set out to secure free access for Christians to the Holy Land, turned against their own brothers in the faith," he said. "The fact that they were Latin Christians fills Catholics with deep regret." Christodoulos clapped his hands in relief as the Pope spoke. A few minutes before, the popular archbishop had delivered a stinging rebuke to the pontiff for the Vatican's historic lack of contrition. "Traumatic experiences remain as open wounds on [the Greek people's] vigorous body," Christodoulos had said. "Yet until now, there has not been heard even a single request for pardon." Archimandrite Vasilios Drossos, of the archdiocese of Athens, said the Pope's remarks were "very very positive". "He was apologising for something which has its roots in historical fact. It is now time to look forward," he said, adding that he hoped dialogue between the churches would now be on a "much sounder footing". He said the Pope's visit would act as a sign to the world's 200m-300m Orthodox that "they would no longer feel out of the mainstream". It was a good omen for a possible papal trip to the Patriarchate in Moscow, the most powerful of the various national Orthodox churches, he added. But hardliners remained unconvinced. Father Anathassios, a monk of Mount Athos, one of Orthdoxy's most revered places, accused the Pope and the Greek church leadership of staging a confidence trick. "Orthodoxy is the true way - all others are mistaken," he said. Other conservative Orthodox, including members of the Old Calendarists, who adhere to the Julian calendar but are regarded as schismatic by the Greek church, rang church bells in protest. Archbishop Christodoulos had issued repeated calls for calm from hardliners opposed to the Pope's presence. But critics say he bears some responsibility for inflaming religious passions in Greece. He has been engaged in a protracted struggle with the modernising socialist government of Costas Simitis about its decision to remove the statement of religion from Greek national identity cards. "The Pope is still a heretic," read one quickly prepared poster in Athens last night. But as arch-heretics go, the Pope looked pretty mild-mannered, even humble, as he emerged from his jet into the spring sunshine. "Where are his horns?" Yiannis Dimitrakopoulos, six, asked his father at the gleaming new Athens airport as the frail 80-year-old pontiff removed his cap and gave a short wave before descending. "He must have left them in his Pope-mobile," came the reply. Due to the Pope's lack of mobility, the traditional kneeling and kissing of the soil was replaced by the offering of a bowl containing earth from the hill of the Areopagos, facing the Acropolis, which the Pope was due to visit last night. This is where St Paul preached the sermon of the unknown God to the Athenians in the 1st century. At the Areopagos a "common message" was read out on behalf of the Pope and Archbishop Christodoulos, calling for Europe's Christian roots not to be forgotten. The Pope's visit, which will finish this morning with a mass for Greece's 200,000 Catholics at the Olympic basketball stadium, was conducted amid tight security. As he sped towards the centre of Athens in a bulletproof Mercedes, the roads were lined not with well-wishers, but with many of the 8,000 policemen who had been drafted in for the occasion - more than for the equally controversial visit of President Bill Clinton in 1999. Every last detail of the visit has been the subject of tough negotiations, from the size of the venue to be used for the mass this morning, to the music that would accompany his triumphal approach to the Areopagos. The Four Seasons was chosen, and not the usual Handel's Messiah which the Orthodox church felt was too Catholic. A member of the Holy Synod involved in the organisation of the visit said: "It was like painting an icon; arduous, and finicky, but worth it in the end." The Greek press view Eleftherotypia, centre-left daily The Greek tradition of hospitality, which predates Christianity, is enriched by the Christian injunctions to love thy neighbour and even thine enemies. During the Pope's visit, let elementary Christian dignity prevail, with a civilised attitude that is not reminiscent of the Dark Ages Kathimerini, centre-right daily With direct shots about the silence of the pontiff over the tragedy of Cyprus, references to the sufferings Greece has undergone from the Catholic west and emphasis on the need for cooperation of both sides without intolerance, Archbishop Christodoulos greets Pope John Paul today. Ethnos, populist daily Those who feared objections to the visit would provide an opportunity for negative comments to be made about our country, have been justified. It is natural for there to be a few hundred, or even thousand, fanatics in a country, but it is anything but natural for the biggest TV channels to have them as guests every day and the leading topic of news bulletins Avgi, leftwing daily Here's a coincidence: the re-release of the Exorcist opens in Athens cinemas today

webTitle: Home loans: When advisers get it wrong

fields.headline: When advisers get it wrong
fields.standfirst: The Consumers' Association is telling people to do their homework before looking for a mortgage as finding good advice is not easy, writes Jill Papworth
fields.trailText: The Consumers' Association is telling people to do their homework before looking for a mortgage as finding good advice is not easy, writes Jill Papworth.
fields.body:
Mortgage advisers are giving people biased advice and making misleading claims that could add thousands of pounds to the cost of their home loan, according to research from the Consumers' Association published this week.

An investigation of 48 mortgage advisers carried out by Which? found that getting good advice is a hit and miss affair. Much depends on the individual adviser rather than who the adviser works for. Only one adviser - at a Bradford and Bingley branch - was found to give all round good advice.

The researchers visited 40 branches of the top 10 lenders plus four estate agents and four independent financial advisers (IFAs).

Most of the advisers were good at explaining the range of deals available, but some just talked about the one they rec ommended. "This doesn't involve customers in the choice and means they can't be sure that the deal is the best one for them," says the report. It's also a breach of the mortgage code, the voluntary code of practice that most lenders and intermediaries sign up to.

Two-thirds of advisers failed to fully assess the researchers' needs before recommending a deal, again a breach of the code. Such action can leave the customer with the wrong deal.

In outlining the deals, some advisers used jargon without explaining it and many failed to explain redemption penalties - the charges levied on some deals if you want to pay off all or some of your loan within a set period.

An adviser should impartially explain the pros and cons of both repayment methods. With a repayment mortgage, each month you pay your lender interest plus a portion of the original capital loan so that you are guaranteed to have repaid the full loan by the end of the mortgage term. With an interest-only mortgage, you pay only interest to your lender, so the amount of capital you owe never goes down. You also normally pay into an investment vehicle such as an Isa, endowment or pension, with the aim that it will grow fast enough to repay the capital at the end of the term.

There is no guarantee that your investment will perform well enough for this to happen. On the other hand, it might produce enough to repay the mortgage capital and give you an extra lump sum.

The right repayment method for you depends on your attitude to risk. Yet, according to Which?, one-third of those who gave advice on the best way to repay the loan failed to establish the researchers' attitude to risk - another breach of the code.

The investigation also found that misleading advice about repayment mortgages was widespread, with many advisers wrongly painting them as inflexible. Thirteen advisers said you'd hardly pay off any of the capital loan in the first few years, and 14 wrongly claimed that repayments were inflexible because, if you moved, you'd have to start again with another 25-year loan.

In fact, taking a loan over a shorter period can save thousands of pounds. For instance, assuming an interest rate of 7.5%, a £70,000 repayment mortgage over 20 years would increase monthly repayments by £50, but save almost £20,000 in interest over the life of the mortgage. Very few advisers discussed this option.

By contrast, some advisers seemed too cautious to recommend anything other than repayment mortgages. "Some did so without asking about our researchers' attitude to risk - they seemed to assume that a repayment is best for everyone, which isn't the case," says the report. "Cheltenham & Gloucester advisers were particularly prone to this." One plus point was that not one adviser recommended an endowment mortgage.

All but seven of the advisers (two Abbey National, two Halifax, one NatWest, one Woolwich and one IFA) mentioned the Mortgage Code. This was a vast improvement on the last Which? mortgage advice investigation in 1998 when fewer than half mentioned the code. But explaining the code isn't enough - complying with it is more important, says Which?.

Helen Parker, editor of Which?, says: "We will continue to press for mortgage advice to be properly regulated by law. In the meantime we welcome moves by the Mortgage Code Compliance Board to introduce compulsory training for mortgage advisers."

Stand up for yourself

 Arm yourself with as much information as you can about the types of deals (eg fixed, capped, discounted, cashback) and repayment methods available before you go for advice.

 If you want advice, rather than just information, make sure you tell the adviser that you want a recommendation of what's best for you.

 Ask the adviser to tell you about the deals they offer and to go through the pros and cons of each.

 Think about your circumstances and future plans (eg do you want to pay extra off on your mortgage? Is your income likely to change dramat ically in the next few years?). Make sure you tell the advisers about them - don't wait to be asked - and get them to explain why the mortgage they've recommended is suitable for you.

 Think about your attitude to risk. Do you want a guarantee that you will repay your mortgage by the end of the term? Or are you happy to go with a repayment method that doesn't give you that guarantee?

 Be aware of the myths: You don't have to take a mortgage over 25 years. Ask the adviser to quote on a 20-year term or less as well as the standard 25-year term. And repayment mortgages aren't bad if you want to move.

fields.headline: Calling a halt to the house party
fields.trailText: Buying property has been the surest way to earn easy, double-digit returns over the past half-century. But now the party is over, according to long-term forecasters.
fields.body:
Buying property has been the surest way to earn easy, double-digit returns over the past half-century. But now the party is over, according to long-term forecasters.

Nationwide Building Society revealed this week that over the past 50 years the average price of a UK home has risen by a staggering 4,500% - from £1,900 in 1952 to a typical price-tag today of £86,244.

The past two years have been particularly good for homeowners - prices rose by a hefty 13.8% in 1999 and 13.6% in 2000, according to government figures.

But such returns could soon be consigned to history. Forecasting experts at the Centre for Economics and Business Research reckon the boom days are now behind us and house price inflation will slow over the coming 20 years.

They say that while during the past five years UK house prices rose by an average of 7.23% a year, it expects this to fall to an average of 4.97% a year between now and 2010, and then to 4.73% from 2010 to 2020.

"This will still represent an increase greater than inflation, and will mean that house prices will grow roughly in line with average earnings," adds a spokesman. Nevertheless, if you assume inflation remains at around 2.5% going forward, the CEBR's figures suggest that the "real" rate of UK house price growth will be little more than 2% a year.

This prediction of annual house price growth of just a shade under 5% over the next decade is very much a UK average figure - the CEBR expects the south-east, London and eastern England to see slightly stronger growth than this over the next 10 years.

The Halifax broadly agrees. Its economist Martin Ellis says we are in for "a more modest period" of house price growth, something around 5% a year for the next couple of years. However, he adds: "If you look over a long period at housing you do get good returns - comfortably outstripping inflation. You really need to look at housing as a long-term investment."

Meanwhile, today's low-inflation, low-interest environment could have a hidden sting in the tail for homebuyers, warns the Financial Services Authority.

Today's large mortgages are cheaper than in the past because of low interest rates, but unlike the past will not benefit from inflation in effect paying off most of the debt. So borrowers face a heavier burden of real debt repayment for much longer than the last generation of home-buyers.

fields.headline: Hakkasan, London W1
fields.trailText:
Hakkasan

Rating: 17/20
fields.body:
Hakkasan

Rating: 17/20

Is Hakkasan the sexiest restaurant in London, or what? Even finding it provides a frisson of excitement. Go up Tottenham Court Road from the Oxford Street end. Take the first left, Hanway Street. Turn right almost immediately into Hanway Place, a Raymond Chandler mean street if ever there was one, with an air of invincibly seedy dilapidation about it. Don't mind that. Press on. At the top of the street, you will see a large man looking like a smartly dressed brick wall standing by a substantial but curiously self-effacing doorway. Go through it and descend the stairs inside. You pass from day into night, or from real night into more dramatic night. The walls are lined with charcoal-grey slate. At each step there is a square red light set into the wall. It is like something out of a James Bond movie. At the bottom of the stairs is Hakkasan, the latest creation of Alan Yau, the man behind Wagamama.

Hakkasan is about as far removed from Wagamama as it is possible to be. It is as suave as the other is sophomoric, as classy as the other is classless. A large dining room is divided up into discrete areas by oriental screens of geometric design. The lighting is what you might call nightclub subdued, with a kind of prevailing lambent, midnight blue. Waiters and waitresses pass and repass in silhouette, suddenly emerging into the third dimension when they bring your food. A metre or so above each table, a light throws reflected rays up off the dark wood, illuminating the lower halves of people's faces, leaving the rest in shadow. Anyone can look sexy when lit like that, even me - or so I was assured. There is even muzak, but for once its self-absorbed, repetitive, insistent rhythms seemed calibrated to reinforce the sense of sleek chic.

I have eaten at Hakkasan twice so far, once a solitary lunch of dim sum, Mr Yau's trademark noodles and some oddities such as congee, that invalid food of the gods; and once in the evening, when there's a menu of more substantial and elaborate dishes, many involving seafood in one form or another - steamed crab in Shao Hsing wine, soft-shell crab with hot and sour sauce, stir-fried lobster tail in XO sauce, roast duck with mango and lemon sauce, stir-fried jellyfish, squid and Chinese chives, pan-fried rib-eye beef with sweet soya and almond, roast pork with red rice, ginger and Shao Hsing, stir-fried asparagus with lotus roots and lily bulb with black pepper - that little lot rather overdid for three of us at dinner .

Of course, the food is Chinese, but it has been burnished with astute intelligence to sit comfortably with western tastes, with variations on rib-eye steak, poussin, ostrich, lobster and sardines among them. There are even a couple of dishes made with the very Chinese Windyridge merlot and Nicolas Feuillatte champagne. There's no point in going to Hakkasan in search of authenticity - but does it really matter?

Not very much, in my view. I am probably more in favour of the nooks and crannies of the deep-fried pig's oesophagus and steamed eel with preserved plum sort than most, but here much of the food was so delicious in its own right that I felt perfectly happy to eat more. And more. The lobster, steamed crab, roast duck and roast pork were outstanding at dinner; ditto the scallop shumai, tienging bun, cod congee and plum wine jelly, and lychee sorbet at lunch. If I have a criticism, it's that too many dishes on the dinner menu had sweetish overtones, which made for a certain monotony. But considering that this was within a few days of the place opening, it was a pretty alpha-plus showing; no doubt such minor flaws will get sorted out along the line. Yau and his team have even managed to solve the problem of how to make Chinese food look terrific, partly by borrowing from the Japanese.

Needless to say, just as Hakkasan isn't your average slam-bang, quick, quick, in-and-out Chinese restaurant, so the cost isn't quite your cheap, cheap, dirt-cheap giveaway, either. Dinner was £142.10, including two bottles of nicely judged Pinot Blanc, three beers and a water, which accounted for £51.80 of it. My solitary lunch came to £31 (but I did eat enough for two), plus £11 on the booze. But for the sheer class of the place, it seems a fair price to pay - particularly if it makes you look sexy.

fields.headline: The expert gardener
fields.standfirst: The sweet song of birds
fields.trailText: 'A garden rich in variety, containing shrubs of different heights and density, with plenty of seed- and fruit-bearing plants, will attract a wide range of birds'
fields.body:
Many gardeners are bird lovers, and gardening certainly gives you the opportunity to watch them from the corner of your eye. So long as you go steadily about your job, without making sudden, uncalled-for movements and observing the birds without appearing to, they will feel comfortable in your presence and will treat you as they would a sheep or cow. That is the greatest compliment.

A garden rich in variety, containing shrubs of different heights and density - some against walls, others in the open - with plenty of seed- and fruit-bearing plants, will attract a wide range of birds, without any conscious effort on your part. It is the kind of garden we should want, anyway.

Ours is far fuller of birds than the relatively untamed countryside around. And yet there are fewer of many species than there were 30 or 40 years ago, and the reasons are complex. I do not pretend to understand them all myself.

I'm certain that house martins' nests used to abound on certain of our buildings; they have been gone for many years. More recently, swallows have become scarce. I realise that we now have three cats permanently and officially around, while those belonging to neighbours are certainly no respecters of boundaries; but swallows, by nesting higher in open-sided buildings, can steer clear of them.

Yet when it comes to their gathering season, at the turn of August and September, the hundreds that used to sun themselves on our roofs are totally absent. I believe they find a dearth of insect food. Certainly, I am far less bothered by flies in my kitchen during the summer than I used to be. Modern farming practices are responsible for that. On the whole, we must be pleased, but there are always less welcome side-effects.

We tend to be selective about birds we like and those we resent. Personally, I detest the sight of a bullfinch - or of bullfinches, rather, as they always feed in parties. In the days when they abounded, there was a wide range of shrubs and trees that it was pointless to try and grow. Plums were regularly stripped of flower and leaf buds. It was the same with many cherries. Prunus subhirtella was reduced to writhing, leafless branches. No forsythia blossom, kerria, weigela, exochorda, nor apples (except Bramley, which was spared, for some reason). It was a long list. But then, in the early 80s, bullfinches disappeared from the region where I live and I have joyfully returned to these excluded plants. Bullfinches are beautiful, but handsome is as handsome does.

I welcomed the return of the sparrowhawk after its near extinction by aldrin and similar farm chemicals, later banned, but those who deliberately feed birds and enjoy the feel-good sensation of seeing the creatures regale themselves at the table provided, are usually loud in their wails of protest against its resurrection.

The fact is that we find it difficult to accept nature in the raw. We want it on our own terms. Those terms will vary according to our interests. "I fed it all the winter and now it's eating all my fruit," you hear in protest against a blackbird. What did you expect? Shouldn't the blackbird's song be compensation enough? Apparently not.

So long as you go steadily about your job, without making sudden, uncalled-for movements and observing the birds without appearing to, they will feel comfortable in your presence and will treat you as they would a sheep or cow. That is the greatest compliment. A garden rich in variety, containing shrubs of different heights and density - some against walls, others in the open - with plenty of seed- and fruit-bearing plants, will attract a wide range of birds, without any conscious effort on your part. It is the kind of garden we should want, anyway. Ours is far fuller of birds than the relatively untamed countryside around. And yet there are fewer of many species than there were 30 or 40 years ago, and the reasons are complex. I do not pretend to understand them all myself. I'm certain that house martins' nests used to abound on certain of our buildings; they have been gone for many years. More recently, swallows have become scarce. I realise that we now have three cats permanently and officially around, while those belonging to neighbours are certainly no respecters of boundaries; but swallows, by nesting higher in open-sided buildings, can steer clear of them. Yet when it comes to their gathering season, at the turn of August and September, the hundreds that used to sun themselves on our roofs are totally absent. I believe they find a dearth of insect food. Certainly, I am far less bothered by flies in my kitchen during the summer than I used to be. Modern farming practices are responsible for that. fields.headline: To die for
fields.standfirst: The bright stuff
fields.trailText: 'I'm not one to cook or clean, and I've always been of the opinion that kitchens, and their appliances, are best neither seen nor heard.'
fields.body:
I'm not one to cook or clean, and I've always been of the opinion that kitchens, and their appliances, are best neither seen nor heard. Until recently, things seemed to be going reasonably well for anti-domestic types such as myself. A long, unbroken run of stainless steel that looks like it's never been used is my idea of domestic bliss and has, of late, been the sort of thing to which designy types really aspired. The country kitchen had its time and place (the 70s, and in parts of Hampstead/ Wilmslow). And if you want quarry tiles, panelling and the incredible inconvenience of an Aga, so be it. You will be endlessly cosy and your drop scones will be sheer perfection.

But there is an alternative trend, a worrying one, far removed from the world of National Trust paints and English oak cupboards. It is the reinvention of white goods as very, very loudly coloured goods, as the most obtrusive objects in your house, as the purchases that apparently define your status and taste. Gone are the days when you hoped visitors would judge you by the refinement of your art or the grace of your antiques. Now you're hoping they'll be overwhelmed by your vacuum cleaner.

I'm not just thinking about James Dyson's effect on the world of industrial design, although he has a lot to answer for. There surely isn't a reader among us who wouldn't instantly recognise the lurid yellow plastic trimming of his Cyclone vacuum cleaner. Dyson products look like they do because they are wearing their technological advancement on their sleeve (although I've always wondered about the sort of consumers who really want to see their own dirt being sucked through a transparent cylinder: is it a sanitised 21st-century nostalgie de la boue , perhaps?). The very latest model, the Root8Cyclone, which will appear in the shops on June 1 and which retails at a sobering £219, boasts 45% more suction and appears to have about 45% more searing yellow plastic about its mechanical person.

Kitchen colour at its worst, though, emerges in the utterly kitsch. For a long time I've been bewildered by the lack of discretion of the Smeg fridge - those big curvy models (called the FAB28, just so you get the idea) that come in pastel green and blue, red and the seriously retro cream. There they stand, screaming for attention, willing every visitor to walk in to the room and exclaim, "I love your fridge." Smeg is even thinking of capitalising on people's desire to express their individuality through appliances, by launching glossy black and pink versions, although the marketing department was a little free with its information and the press office is dismayed that I even knew of such a radical plan.

The apotheosis of all this has to be Leisure Consumer Products' Swink (above). It was flamboyantly launched in a nightclub to the sound of banging techno and, accompanied by viciously coloured cocktails (it was 10 o'clock on a Tuesday morning), the world's press was blown away by the world's first illuminated kitchen sink unit fashioned from refined translucium (a state-of-the-art polymer, but then you knew that). Should you want a disco-themed kitchen, this has to be the sink for you. If not, I leave you with two short but singularly important words: white goods.

 Caroline Roux on design appears weekly.
