fields.headline: Snooping around
fields.body:
The Coach House
Rostrevor Road, London SW6

It's a curious southern-England phenomenon that stand-alone piles built before 1900 are called either coach houses or hunting lodges. Presumably buyers keen on address one-upmanship will pay more for the label.

Pros A freehold house north of the swanky Fulham Road. It's been newly refurbished and has a large courtyard, suitable for parking your petunias or your BMW. If foot and mouth has soured your pastoral fantasies this 'idyllic cottage lifestyle in central London' could be the solution.

Cons Only two tiny bedrooms, and a pretty intimate sitting room.

Price £299,950. Available through Douglas & Gordon, 020-7731 4391.

Castle Rock View
Port Isaac, Cornwall

Peer through the bedroom windows in this romantic hideaway and you should absorb enough inspiration to write your very own Daphne Du Maurier-style novel. This home has everything a jaded incomer might expect from Cornwall: jumbly cliffs, wild seas and a self-consciously pretty town down the lane.

Pros Five bedrooms, the sort of view you get on the front of Sibelius CDs, real fireplaces and paddling on the beach just outside your front door.

Cons The wild, windy, cliff-top perch can take its toll on the fabric of the building. There's only one bathroom and, by all accounts, an undislodgable lodger in the form of an ectoplasmic Victorian matron (that's a ghost, to you and me).

Price £300,000. Available through John Bray, 01208 880302, and Jackson Stops & Staff, 01872 261160.

Little Thatches
Isham, Northants

The trouble with many country idylls is that your neighbours are all London weekenders. Here, though, you have all the necessaries - thatch, old stone, verdant views - and the happy knowledge that nobody takes their holidays in Northamptonshire.

Pros Obvious charm factor; pious position beside the village church, away from the main road.

Cons Only three bedrooms, and a cramped garden. It needs a face-lift, but it's a listed building and English Heritage will be keeping a hawkish eye on all embellishments.

Price £300,000. Available through Jackson Stops & Staff, 01604 632991.

Earlswood
Chepstow, Gwent

h Frisky weather has led to a penchant for ugly pebbledash in Wales. But this house is a pretty exception. You can have four bedrooms and two acres of grounds, including pond, for the price of a flat in South Kensington.

Pros What hasn't it got? Leaded windows, beams, period oven range, quarry-tiled floor, ornamental bridge, conservatory with resident passion fruit vine.

Cons The drive needs new tarmac and you're a car journey from the nearest shop.

Price £285,000. Available through Archer & Co, 01291 626262.

fields.headline: How to wear clothes
fields.trailText: 'Every year at about this time, glossy magazines declare a new fashion holy grail: the Weekend Break Capsule Wardrobe.'
fields.body:
Every year at about this time, glossy magazines declare a new fashion holy grail: the Weekend Break Capsule Wardrobe. As Bridget Jones knew, the countryside mini-break may seem like an innocent two-day holiday, but beneath the surface, it is a maelstrom of complications, first and foremost being the vexed matter of what to wear.

The Capsule Wardrobe, as suggested by most magazines, is big on oyster-coloured silk cashmere shoulder wraps for 'chilly evenings' and handmade mushroom suede driving shoes. But where is the logic of splurging £500 on clothes that you are going to wear for two days in the countryside, where no one is going to appreciate your butterfly silk appliquéd duster coat anyway?

Buying expensive clothes that have no place in your real life wardrobe is not the answer. But you do have to make concessions to the mini-break cult, if only to get into the mood. However idyllic you expect it to be, pack an anorak alongside the silk cashmere wrap. And when selecting footwear bear in mind, for example, that "quaint" generally translates as "cobbled". Twisted, swollen ankles don't really fit with skipping through fields.

Of course, fields open for skipping being in shorter supply than the Louis Vuitton 'Speedy' graffiti bags right now, you may need to retune your packing. Think country pub: ie, something that will provoke neither passion nor violence from the locals. A vaguely rustic, back-to-nature theme - Marni's abstract flower print skirts, or Chloé's horse prints - will make you pleasingly at one with your surroundings. Or go for the Deauville striped look: very classic, very Coco in navy and white, or pure Marc Jacobs in pink and black.

And then there's the luggage. Leave the 12 monogrammed trunks at home: you need Chanel's pale pink tweed holdalls, or - the slightly cheaper alternative - Bally's newly revamped range.

fields.headline: The new black
fields.trailText: 'When talking to other black women, hair is never far from the conversation. We're either bemoaning the latest black celebrity to get theirs straightened, or agonising over what messages we're sending out ourselves.'
fields.body:
From as far back as I remember, I wanted to have straight hair. In the early years, as the only black girl in my school, I was convinced that if I could just get my hair the same as everyone else's, I'd be able to blend in. I cursed my father for not letting me get it straightened - he said I had to wait until I was 16, for fear of burning my scalp or ruining the hair with harsh chemicals. I remember walking around the house with a towel on my head and flicking my imaginary locks over my shoulders.

When talking to other black women, hair is never far from the conversation. We're either bemoaning the latest black celebrity to get theirs straightened, or agonising over what messages we're sending out ourselves. If a woman's pride and joy is her hair, then black women spend their life being told theirs is ugly, wild and needs taming. As a result, whether we like it or not, our hair is a political issue. "As a racial signifier, hair is second only to skin," says cultural historian Caroline Cox. "In the 60s and 70s, the afro became a symbol of black pride. To straighten your hair implied poor political consciousness."

Rightly or wrongly, people make assumptions about you based on how you wear your hair. If it's straight, you will be accused of selling out - of "wanting to look white", whatever that means, of trying to deny your heritage. If you wear your hair naturally in an afro, people congratulate you on your cultural awareness. If cornrows or braids are your style, then you'll be patted on the back for having the balls to wear a proper African style - that is, unless you're Bo Derek.

The older I got, the more confident I became, and the more I grew into my hair. Being black was no longer something to be ashamed of; in fact, it became desirable. But the longer my hair got, the harder it was to style, so for most of my time at university I had a root perm to make the hair drop, rather than grow upwards. On one occasion when I was having my roots re-done, the hairdresser offered to blow-dry it straight, so I could see if I wanted to get it "done" properly. I hated it. I couldn't help feeling I'd let the side down.

fields.headline: Dando trial man seen at her home
fields.standfirst:
Accused had 'exaggerated interest in well-known figures'

Special report: Jill Dando trial
fields.trailText: Jill Dando was murdered on the doorstep of her home with a single shot to the side of the head by an obsessive who had an "exaggerated interest in well-known figures, the army and the media", the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Jill Dando was murdered on the doorstep of her home with a single shot to the side of the head by an obsessive who had an "exaggerated interest in well-known figures, the army and the media", the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Barry George, 41, was seen by witnesses loitering and behaving strangely outside the TV star's home in Gowan Avenue, Fulham, hours before she was killed at 11.30am on April 26, 1999.

But when police questioned Mr George about the killing, he initially denied he had left his ground floor flat in nearby Crookham Road before noon, and claimed he had never heard of Miss Dando, and did not know what she looked like.

Later, Mr George changed his alibi and said he had walked to a nearby community centre, taking an unusual route which avoided Gowan Avenue. "Why did he choose to take the longer route?" asked Orlando Pownall, prosecuting counsel. "He had just shot Jill Dando and did not want to be recognised."

The evidence was heard on the first day of a much anticipated trial in court one at the Old Bailey before Mr Justice Gage.

Mr George, who denies murdering Miss Dando, sat quietly in the dock, head slightly bowed and scribbling notes, just feet away from the presenter's fiance, Alan Farthing and her brother, Nigel.

The court heard what Mr Pownall called "compelling categories of circumstantial, forensic and scientific evidence" that had implicated Mr George.

Mr Pownall admitted there was no apparent motive for the murder, no witnesses had seen the shooting and no weapon had been recovered.

But he told the jury of seven women and five men that Mr George's personality, and his behaviour on the day Miss Dando died, were "persuasive of guilt."

Mr George had adopted several names of people he admired over the years, including Thomas Palmer, an SAS soldier, and Barry Bulsara, the birth name of the late Freddie Mercury, lead singer of the rock group Queen.

When the police searched his home, officers found a large number of documents, magazines and photographs of presenters and newscasters.

Three years before Miss Dando's death, a man fitting Mr George's description and claiming to be Freddie Mercury's cousin, told a jeweller he had met Princess Diana and "the woman from Crimewatch", the court heard.

Mr Pownall added: "Whether he harboured a hidden grudge against (Miss Dando), believing her to have wronged him or figures he idolised, such as Freddie Mercury, is impossible to determine.

"However, if he did not know who she was before, his reaction to her death was out of all proportion to what one might expect from an individual who was not an admirer and would not have even recognised her.

"He visited shops and sought letters of condolence. He even suggested to a local council that they should consider a memorial."

When he was interviewed by police he claimed to have had no access to firearms since serving with the Territorial Army in the early 1980s. When officers searched his flat,only 500m from the road where Miss Dando lived, they found a photograph of him posing in a gas mask with a gun, claimed Mr Pownall. Also discovered were documents and paraphernalia relating to the army, especially the SAS, and handwritten lists of weapons. References to gundealers in magazines were highlighted.

The jury heard that a few days after Miss Dando's death Mr George - who was to tell police he had a "mild personality disorder" - spoke of the shooting with a friend and told her: "I was there, you know". The woman dismissed the claim as fantasy.

Mr George told another woman, Lenita Bailey, about the police's interest in him. Ms Bailey asked him: "Did you do it?" Mr Pownall said: "The defendant remained silent and stared at the floor. She repeated the question twice more and asked him to look at her. His lips moved as if he was thinking of an answer but none was forthcoming."

The trial continues.

fields.headline: 'Why would anybody wish to kill her?'
fields.standfirst:
No witnesses, no obvious motive and the killer's gun still missing

Special report: Jill Dando trial
fields.trailText: Jill Dando was "excited and bubbly" that Monday morning, the Old Bailey heard. She was looking forward to marrying Dr Alan Farthing, cutting back her numerous television commitments and, perhaps, starting a family.
fields.body:
Jill Dando was "excited and bubbly" that Monday morning, the Old Bailey heard. She was looking forward to marrying Dr Alan Farthing, cutting back her numerous television commitments and, perhaps, starting a family.

The day began at her fiance's home in Chiswick, west London. She made him a cup of tea and poured him a bowl of cereal. After shopping in Hammersmith, she went back to her own home in Gowan Avenue, Fulham, where she was confronted by her killer on the doorstep.

A neighbour heard a scream. A passerby saw her slumped and bleeding. Behind the top of her left ear, there was an impression of the muzzle of a gun, "suggesting it had been pressed firmly against her head upon discharge."

An exit wound lay above her right ear, and the damage to her front door showed she was crouching when the shot was fired, the court heard. A small bruise on her right forearm may have been caused by the gunman grabbing her.

She was pronounced dead at Charing Cross hospital at 1.05pm.

Opening the case yesterday, Orlando Pownall, prosecuting, conceded that nobody had witnessed the attack, and that the gun, had never been recovered. The motive, he admitted, was also unclear.

"Why would anybody wish to kill Jill Dando? She had none of the pretensions that are sometimes associated with those who achieve fame," he said.

However, a year after her death, detectives had pieced together "compelling categories of circumstantial, forensic and scientific evidence, which, when taken together, prove that [Barry George] was the man in Gowan Avenue who was responsible for killing Jill Dando".

Mr Pownall, a senior Treasury counsel, said that Mr George, 41, lived in a ground floor flat in a nearby street. There were, he said, "obsessive aspects to his personality", including "an exaggerated interest in well known figures... the army, weapons and the media."

Over the years, he had called himself Steve Majors (Lee Majors played the character Steve Austin in the US series The Six Million Dollar Man), Thomas Palmer, after an SAS soldier who was involved in the Iranian embassy siege, and Barry Bulsara, the birth surname of Freddie Mercury, the lead singer of Queen. He also had an unusual interest in the BBC, collecting the in-house magazine Ariel and telephone numbers and photographs of stars, including Anthea Turner.

Mr George had been a member of the Territorial Army, 10th Battalion Parachute Regiment, from December 1981 to November 1982, and later joined the Kensington and Chelsea Pistol Club. He had, Mr Pownall said, a "fascination with the army and firearms and owned a large number of books and magazines relating to guns, weapons and the military.

Mr George had owned three guns, and on one occasion, caused panic when he went to a friend's flat dressed in combat gear and fired a blank from a pistol.

The negative of a photograph which was found by police in Mr George's flat showed him wearing a respirator and holding the same weapon.

An expert identified the gun as a Bruni blank-firing pistol, which had been modified, the jury heard.

"The gun used to kill Miss Dando had either been converted from a blank-firing pistol to one capable of firing bullets, or a deactivated weapon which had been similarly converted," said Mr Pownall.

The evidence of the eye witnesses was of "paramount importance" to the prosecution case, the court heard. At 7am on the day of the murder, a neighbour, Susan Mayes, spotted a man acting suspiciously opposite the star's house. At an identity parade, she picked out Mr George. "She was not the only one to see him there," said Mr Pownall.

Theresa Normanton also saw someone outside Dando's home at 10am. She picked Mr George during an ID parade, but hesitated because the man she remembered did not have a goatee beard. "She did not merely identify the defendant, but claimed the man did not have a goatee beard on April 26. She was right."

Charlotte de Rosnay, another of Miss Dando's neighbours, said Mr George was the man she had seen in the road at 9.40am.However, he insisted to detectives he had not left his flat on the morning Miss Dando died.

"We suggest that you can be sure he was there at 7am and later at 10am and was paying close attention to No 29," said Mr Pownall. "Why is he lying about his movements, if these identifications are correct and reliable? What reason did he have for being there? The crown suggest he was there hoping that Miss Dando would appear."

When Mr George was interviewed in May last year, he said he had been at home until around 12.30pm. But months later, he made "significant" changes to his alibi, the court heard, claiming he had left home at 10.30am to walk to a nearby community centre, Hammersmith and Fulham Action for Disability (Hafad).

The quickest route to Hafad would have taken him towards, or down, Gowan Avenue, but Mr George said he went another way, doubling the length of the journey. Mr Pownall said: "Why did he choose to take the longer route? The answer is plain. He had just shot Jill Dando and did not want to risk recognition."

The prosecution alleges that shortly before 1pm, Mr George arrived at a minicab office two minutes walk from Hafad. Working backwards, Mr Pownall said, he would have left Hafad at about 12.50-12.55pm. He must have arrived at the centre at about 12.35pm - an hour after Miss Dando was shot.

Mr Pownall said it was the crown's case that Mr George returned home after the shooting, changed his clothes and went to Hafad hoping staff "would be able to provide him with sanctuary and an alibi".

Two days later, the court heard, Mr George revisited Hafad and the cab company. At Hafad he was "threatening and intimidating", telling staff that he fitted the description of the murderer and asking what time he had visited the centre on the day of the shooting. He asked the cab company manager what time he had been there and what he was wearing.

Mr Pownall also said that two days after the shooting, he told a journalist that he used to see the presenter on Crimewatch. Yet later he told police that he had never heard of Dando before her death.

A few days later, speaking of the shooting, he told a friend: "I was there, you know". The woman thought it was a fantasy. He also visited his local council to ask if it had thought of putting up a memorial and asked the owners of local shopsto write letters of condolence. The following month he told a fellow bus traveller that he was on his way to do a reading at Dando's memorial service.

When he was finally interviewed by police in April last year he told them that he had a "mild personality disorder". He claimed to have had no access to firearms since his time with the territorial army.

But when officers searched his flat they found - as well as the photograph of him posing with the pistol - documents, magazines and items connected to weapons. In military magazines references to gun dealers had been highlighted. They also found a letter in which he said he planned to re-enact the SAS storming of the Iranian embassy to raise money for the army.

After his flat had been searched, Mr George told a woman, Lenita Bailey, about the police's interest in him. She asked himif he had done it.

According to Mr Pownall,"The defendant remained silent and stared at the floor. She repeated the question twice more and asked him to look at her. His lips moved as if he was thinking of an answer but none was forthcoming."

The trial continues.

webTitle: Pensioners spark race row at home

fields.headline: Pensioners spark race row at home
fields.trailText: As an original member of the Specials, Clifton Golding's son Lynval is something of a local hero in Coventry. But the celebrity connection cut no ice last week when Mr Golding senior tried to move into one of the city's residential homes only to be told he would not be welcome - because he was black.
fields.body:
As an original member of the Specials, Clifton Golding's son Lynval is something of a local hero in Coventry. But the celebrity connection cut no ice last week when Mr Golding senior tried to move into one of the city's residential homes only to be told he would not be welcome - because he was black.

The band's lineup of black and white musicians, and blend of reggae, ska and punk, may have been an important multicultural influence in the late 1970s, but its message clearly did not reach a group of white pensioners at the home. They threatened to walk out if Mr Golding senior, who is 76 and suffers from emphysema, moved in.

Despite the efforts of the home's proprietor to distance himself from their attitudes, Mr Golding's family have made a formal complaint to the council and to Coventry's race equality council.

But they believe the incident also raises wider issues about care provision for Britain's ageing ethnic minority population, 50 years after the first wave of Caribbean immigrants to the UK.

"When my dad first came to England from Jamaica in 1953, there were signs on guest houses saying 'No blacks, no Irish, no dogs'," said Lynval Golding. "He had to sleep in a shed for two weeks, because he could not find anywhere to live. Now he is in old age, he has to go through all that again."

Yesterday Ken Grasby, proprietor of the Cordelia Court home, said he was shocked by the attitudes of five elderly white women in the home.

"The ringleader, a 90-year-old woman, said: 'I have lived next to them for 40 years and I don't want to retire with them.'

"I am appalled that people still have attitudes like this, but they obviously do," he said.

Mr Grasby approached the council for advice on the situation, later telling the residents that if they did not like living with a black man they could leave. But Mr Golding's family believe he did not act decisively enough.

"I have spoken to the family and apologised on behalf of a very bigoted minority of residents," said Mr Grasby. "As far as I'm concerned there was never any question that he would not be allowed here."

Despite his apology the Goldings decided not to move their father into the £300 per week private home. He is now in temporary respite care, looking for somewhere else to live.

Sawarn Malhotra, race equality officer for the Coventry race equality council, said the incident illustrated a wider problem in the provision of care for elderly people of non-white backgrounds.

"Service providers need to recognise the needs of diverse communities, and to be geared up to providing facilities that are genuinely multicultural," he said. "Different facilities might be needed for people with specific religious, cultural or dietary needs.

"Social services need to look specifically at whether a home is suitable for all the minority communities living in the city. As a service provider there's more to being mulitcultural than simply not being racist."

A spokeswoman for Coventry city council, which licenses the home, said it viewed the incident as "totally unacceptable". "The owner of a home will sign a contract with us, part of which is to ensure that all people are treated equally. They need to tell racist residents in no uncertain terms that their behaviour will not be tolerated."

Mr Golding's daughter Connie said: "The council needs to look into why more black people aren't going into homes and whether, when they go into these places, they are made to feel welcome."

fields.headline: Looking through Irish eyes
fields.standfirst: Peter Lennon finds that Irish documentaries are about entertainment, not issues - with a few notable exceptions, screened in London this month
fields.trailText: Peter Lennon finds that Irish documentaries are about entertainment, not issues - with a few notable exceptions, screened in London this month
fields.body:
Molly Malone, immortalised in song as she "wheeled her wheelbarra/ through streets broad and narra'/" is the symbol of Dublin's sturdy working-class street traders, mothers and daughters with their portable kerbside stands and pram stalls crying their wares. They are the subject of Sé Merry Doyle's documentary, Alive Alive O!, which opens the Ireland on Screen festival at the Hammersmith Centre in London on Wednesday.

In a country where welfare was miserly or nonexistent, and mostly in the control of interfering clerics, these street traders provided the supplementary income for their impoverished tenement families. They were not crooks or con merchants, they gave good value and were for generations liked and appreciated by all classes. They were part of the sounds and flavour of central Dublin.

Molly "died of the faaver/sure no one could save her". Now her sisters and daughters are dying of a different kind of illness: the avaricious gold fever of tiger- economy Ireland, which wants both to wipe out cheap trading and present a glossy image to the outside world.

The Mollys have been the targets of heavy-handed action from the police, ostensibly trying to stamp out illegal trading but, as the north end of Moore Street and west of Henry Street have been demolished to make way for shopping centres and office blocks, it is clear enough whose interest the authorities are protecting. Often unable or too embarrassed to drag muscular Dublin mothers to jail, the police use sneaky tactics and take the wheels off the trader's prams.

Sé Merry Doyle sees this as a symptom of a general mind-set in Ireland. "People are trying to elevate themselves. They don't necessarily want to forget the past, but they don't want to see it. There is a sense in which the new society in Ireland does not feel happy in both camps, as we used to."

Another documentary, May the Road Rise Up (shown on May 30) charts the virtual annihilation of another impoverished Irish group, the travellers once known as tinkers. They are said to be the descendants of the evicted tenants of the Great Famine (1845-47) who roamed the country eking out a living mending pots and pans and breeding ponies. In the 1960s, Alen MacWeeney spent two years photographing them. Now, 35 years later, he returned to discover that their way of life has virtually been snuffed out.

But the documentary which uses the camera as a weapon to attack or analyse social and political problems makes only sporadic appearances in Ireland. The problem is partly economic: there is no theatrical distribution for social documentaries. In addition, Doyle says: "The Arts Council does not really have a clear policy on documentary and with RTE, it is still very much a begging-bowl situation". But there also appears to be an innate cultural inhibition. Harvey O'Brien, who teaches at the Centre for Film Studies at University College Dublin, wrote recently: "Contemporary documentary practice has a tempered approach to social and political issues. The Irish voice now prefers to whisper." There have been notable exceptions, among them Louis Lentin's Dear Daughter (1996), an account of abuse in a Dublin orphanage which opened up a debate which was to reveal horrendous abuse in schools and orphanages nationwide. Francis Barrett - Southpaw (1998), the story of a member of the same disenfranchised community featured in May the Road Rise Up, was one of the great successes. This story of a young traveller's attempt to qualify as a boxer for the Atlanta Olympic games was shown at the Sundance festival.

But, as Harvey O'Brien says, "Most Irish documentaries are concerned not with issues but with entertainments". He even suggests that there is a psychological constitutional obstacle: article 40, section 6 of the constitution deals with the education of public opinion and declares that liberty of expression "shall not be used to undermine public order or morality or the authority of the state", the state, of course, being heavily guided by Irish Catholic morality. O'Brien adds that while literature and the theatre have demonstrated their independence "the limits of freedom have never really been tested by broadcasting and the visual arts".

 Ireland on Screen is at the Irish Centre, Hammersmith, London W8 from May 9. For details phone 020-8741 3211.

webTitle: French film does it à la Hollywood, and wins

fields.headline: French film does it à la Hollywood, and wins
fields.standfirst: France opens the Cannes festival next week on a high in its cinematic war with the US
fields.trailText: France opens the Cannes festival next week on a high in its cinematic war with the US.
fields.body:
French cinema, once a byword for navel-gazing and verbosity, is experiencing a sudden box office boom because of home-grown blockbusters in which the country's most popular film-makers ape Hollywood values.

At multiplexes across France, films featuring long talks in cafes are out; short drops from helicopters are in.

"These are the best box-office figures for French films in 20 years," an expert on the industry, Elizabeth Conter, told the Guardian.

The Cannes Film Festival, which starts on Wednesday, finds French cinema in buoyant spirits in its battle against the might of Hollywood. According to latest figures, 18.5m viewers went to see French films in the first two months of the year - more than half of cinema-goers. And the success is likely to be consolidated through the year as populist domestic movies take on American imports.

For a decade, French films have been overwhelmed by American competitors that regularly took at least 55% of weekly box-office receipts. France generally managed only a 35% share of its own market.

The worst year for the domestic movie industry was 1999 when even Gérard Depardieu as Obélix in the film Astérix could not stop Hollywood commanding 64% of the box office while French films managed a meagre 27%.

This business revival is all the more significant because French governments have repeatedly tried to legislate to restrict the invasion of purportedly philistine American culture and to maintain the so-called exception française . Cinema has been the chief battleground: politicians have long regarded it as an art form rather than an industry and as a standard bearer for national cultural prestige, and so have offered generous subsidies.

The new boom has been seized on with pride by film critics who see their cinema as for once beating Hollywood at its own game - not this time thanks to state intervention, but because film-makers are serving up populist entertainment and thus keeping American culture, and the English language, at bay.

"France has always had this tradition of films d'auteurs with people being sad, talking endlessly and having their sex life in the kitchen, you know," says Antoine de Caunes, best known in Britain as the TV presenter of Eurotrash. His directorial debut film, Les Morsures de l'Aube (or Love Bites as it will be titled in Britain) was released in Paris recently.

"But now what we are seeing are genre films' rise in France - adventures, fantasies, crime thrillers and comedies," adds De Caunes. "I know you awful British don't think we French can make comedies, but we can and we do - maybe not for export, but they are still great and French people want to see them."

And that seems to be the secret behind the new trend - films made specifically for a French market about identifiably French themes, with no great pretensions to intellectual or artistic merit, but thoroughly entertaining for the multiplex audience. De Caunes's nocturnal thriller, dabbling in voguish vampirism. is typical: the public likes it (though many critics do not).

Other popular offerings are Yamakasi, an adrenaline-pumped drama produced by Luc Besson, about seven tough kids from the Parisian suburbs and their streetwise acrobatic skills; and La Tour Montparnasse, a chase flick set in Paris's ugliest skyscraper.

A recent special effects film set in the department of Egyptian antiquities at the Louvre, entitled Bélphegor, showed French film-makers at last exploiting demographics. The film drew on a popular 60s TV series, ensuring that nostalgic parents would buy tickets; it also had the special effects and glamour (in the form of Sophie Marceau) to capture the youth vote.

Ever since the war France's cinema industry has been heavily backed by the state. Artistic merit was one criterion. Much of the funding for this aid came from a 10% levy on tickets - meaning that Hollywood, which always dominated the French box office, was subsidising its French counterpart.

There have been 80 types of state film subsidy in total, including one that requires television broadcasters to invest a proportion of their turnover in the country's film production companies. At least 40% of TV companies' programming must be French-made and half the films they show must be French speaking.

Whether the new domestic film resurgence has much to do with these subsidies and quotas is a moot point: arguably the likes of Luc Besson - whose production company is behind many recent domestic French hits - operate more like Hollywood moguls than state-subsidised artists.

One reason French cinema is doing much better than in the early 90s, says Elizabeth Conter, is that more films are being made - 181 in 1999 compared with 111 in 1994. But the question is not just of quantity, but quality.

What is most striking about the recent glut of French triumphs is their diversity - there are thrillers and comedies, while art house films still thrive too.

No British films have been selected for competition at Cannes, while four French ones have been picked to compete for the Palme d'Or - La Répétition by Catherine Corsini, La Chambre des Officiers by François Dupeyron, Roberto Succo by Cédric Kahn and Va Savoir! by Jacques Rivette (along with Eloge de l'Amour by the former doyen of the Frenchnew wave, Swiss director Jean-Luc Godard).

This week's big French release in Paris is a documentary about a French thinker, Pierre Bourdieu, entitled Sociology is a Combat Sport. French cinema isn't really to succumb completely to Hollywood values just yet.

fields.headline: Baled out
fields.standfirst: Captain Corelli star Christian Bale clearly loves his profession - he just doesn't like talking about it, or his fans, or hanging out with actors
fields.trailText: Captain Corelli star Christian Bale clearly loves his profession - he just doesn't like talking about it, or his fans, or hanging out with actors
fields.body:
He's survived a POW camp (Empire Of The Sun), been sodomised by Ewan McGregor (Velvet Goldmine) and eaten brains (American Psycho). Now, as Greek fisherman-turned-revolutionary Mandras, in Captain Corelli's Mandolin, he gets to snog Penelope Cruz - and grow an impressive beard.

Did you hang out with Nic Cage and Penelope Cruz on Captain Corelli's Mandolin? Are you a social animal?

I don't tend to hang out too much. I do it actually less and less the more movies that I make. I sort of enjoy my time making a film as work, and to be honest I don't socialise an awful lot, although in Greece I did have quite a relaxed schedule. I was there with my wife, and we sort of went off on journeys around Greece when I had a few days. And then in the evenings I generally hung out with my Greek driver, Lewis, who would take me to different festivals. I had to learn a number of the local Greek dances for the movie, and so he would take me to these places, and it was just sort of a wine-fest with all-night drinking and dancing.

Are you a heavy drinker?

I'm not at all, so it tends to hit me pretty hard. But I enjoyed my nights of wine out there.

I hear you don't like talking about your job very much.

I tend to find it a mind-numbingly boring conversation talking about acting. But primarily I find that I don't talk about it very much because I think the more you talk about it the worse it gets. And I think that a good actor has a natural instinct for it and I don't think an awful lot has to be discussed. There's a danger in acting that you can come to find that because you are playing with emotions, it can actually numb you to everyday life. So in many ways I attempt to avoid that.

Do you read your fan-mail?

I tend not to, no. I attempt to keep it to a minimum, purely because it makes me self-conscious. And that's not good for acting in the slightest.

Have people reacted to you differently since starring in American Psycho?

I kept finding again and again that people kept thinking of me as "the nice guy period actor". And and it sort of stumped me a little bit because I hadn't done that many period movies. But that was the perception of me, so suddenly, yes, American Psycho was a polar opposite.

Do you chase roles?

Absolutely, I believe in chasing roles, you know. Some actors that I've worked with have been surprised when I've read a script, I want to do it and I'm calling up the writer, [or] the director, you know? I will call around [to] people, I like to be in there and be involved. A lot of actors don't enjoy that. They just prefer their agents to call them. I just believe that if you're passionate about something, then there's no need to disguise that.

You've just wrapped on a sci-fi thriller, Equilibrium.

I got sent a script and asked to play the character, and I read it and thought there was potential for a good movie. I spoke with the director and the most convincing thing he said to me was, "I've cast Emily Watson", and I thought that was a great indicator of how it was gonna go. So I called Emily and we spoke and she said, "Come on, do it!" She's never done a movie like that, I haven't done a movie like that, if we're gonna do a movie like that, it seems like a good one to try.

fields.headline: Waiting to exhale
fields.standfirst: Clancy Sigal is a Hollywood screenwriter, one of 11,000 on tenterhooks in the run-up to this week's showdown with studio bosses. He reports on the gravity and weirdness of a dispute where his union negotiator is a millionaire
fields.trailText: Clancy Sigal is a Hollywood screenwriter, one of 11,000 on tenterhooks in the run-up to this week's showdown with studio bosses. He reports on the gravity and weirdness of a dispute where his union negotiator is a millionaire.
fields.body:
As I write this, I still don't know whether, by the time you read it, I will be on strike. My best guess is that we will still be in limbo, deadlocked, but not actually striking yet. The enormity of what a strike would mean- or, more to the point, cost - has sunk in, and there have been panicky attempts by powerbrokers outside Hollywood, including LA's mayor and California's governor, to push the two sides together. Until now, it has been as if we were all on board the Titanic, steaming toward the fateful iceberg, with this difference: the captain and his passengers were eerily aware of the impending catastrophe and mesmerised by it.

At issue - in a dispute involving 11,000 screenwriters and 120,000 actors - have been money, union-busting . . . and respect.

The contract between my own union, the Writers Guild of America (WGA), and the bosses - Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP) - expired on May Day. The Screen Actors Guild (SAG) and its sister union, American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA), have been threatening to strike eight weeks later. Last year SAG actors, not known for militancy, staged a strike in the commercial ads industry for six difficult months, the longest actors' walkout in history. Tempers ran high. A few big names such as Elizabeth Hurley and Tiger Woods blacklegged by making TV commercials. Even bigger names such as Julia Roberts and Tom Hanks donated $100,000 each to the strike fund. SAG's stoppage was the curtain raiser to this week's showdown.

The Economic Development Corporation estimated a strike would cost the the city of Los Angeles half a billion dollars a week - $250 million in lost wages and another $257 million indirectly in the neighbourhood delis, auto repair shops, dry cleaners, hair salons and personal trainers that depend on movie pay checks. Those kinds of figures concentrate the mind. The real decision makers are not Hollywood "suits" but multinational CEOs in New York, London, Berlin, Paris and - who knows? - Melbourne, if Rupert Murdoch is visiting. Forget the "golden age" of Fox, Metro and Columbia. Think AOL-Time Warner, Viacom, Sony, Vivendi and Murdoch's News Corporation, the conglomerates which now own the movie business and for which picture grosses are a mere footnote.

"The control of the business is out of the hands of short Jewish men from Brooklyn. That's scary," sighed a producer recently. It's scary because the men from Brooklyn, even when they were (almost to a man) conservative Republicans who despised unions, were members of a social compact, rooted in the shtetls of eastern Europe, that culturally dictated that there was enough pie for everybody and a tough settlement was better than a long strike. Of course, it didn't always work out that way. In the 30s and 40s, there were bloody picketline clashes between unions and the studios.

Hollywood's dirtiest secret is not sex but industrial relations. Class struggle - incognito, schmoozed over, never spoken about openly - is at the very core of how business is done. "Negatives not people count in this company town," a successful TV producer told me. In current movie-making jargon, actors, directors and writers such as myself are (and always have been) interchangeable "elements" in a "product". The new, potent element is "vertical integration". Simply, it means that a Viacom or AOL-Warner might own a studio that manufactures a movie and also own all the distribution channels that screen the final "content". This fresh potential source of income for writers - the heart of the dispute - includes TV, cable, satellite, fibre optic networks, video and DVD, foreign distribution (which accounts for an increasing share of movie grosses), and soon, internet sites and "wireless entertainment networks" that nobody quite understands yet.

The writers' and actors' unions became restless because at each step of the new technology this monopoly of production and distribution makes millions - in the case of a blockbuster such as Titanic, hundreds of millions - from the sale of just one product. The pie grows, but the pie makers have been getting less of it percentage-wise. Even after the WGA reduced by 75% its demand for an increase in DVD residuals - or an extra penny per sale - the producers' offer was a zero increase. The entertainment corporations, emboldened by an anti-labour Bush administration in the White House, made it clear they were out for blood.

That our Hollywood lives are being ordained in faraway places by tycoons who don't know a grip from a best boy is not flash news. Even back in the silent era, Hollywood moguls genuflected to New York or Boston banks. True, the Golden Age's feudal studio system was managed by famous names such as Harry Cohn (who liked to do business sitting on a toilet), Sam Goldwyn and LB Mayer, but the real power, to whom they were accountable, lay with paymasters at Morgan Guaranty and Chase Manhattan. The Atlantic sea-board bankers let the vulgar moguls make the deals and screw the starlets and bribe shady union officials and break the honest unions, but ultimate authority rested 3,000 miles away in Wall Street boardrooms.

It says something about how the film business is normally conducted that Hollywood, in the grip of strike fever for the past few months, has rarely been more businesslike. "It's like in the old times when each studio had to grind out a movie every week," a talent manager told me. "I wish it was always this efficient. I even get my phone calls answered the same day."

New movies have been stockpiled; agents have been pushing their stars into back-to-back projects just to keep them working; writers in mountain retreats have scribbled overtime to finish scripts before the deadline. Yet it's estimated that the studios' pell-mell rush to squeeze film product through the pipeline has actually been more expensive (in exorbitantly paying star talent, for example) than settling with the unions. At the moment, only $100million - the cost of one big, bad Hollywood blockbuster such as Godzilla - is all that separates the combatants.

Inevitably, producers began, ever so gently, wink wink, to suggest privately to writers, ahem, "If there's a strike, of course, we know contractually you won't be able to work, but maybe, in your spare time, you might, well, you know, give our script a little tweak or two . . ." In other words, blackleg. Such hints didn't come from the lips of producers who are Neanderthal, anti-abortion, rightwing George Dubya fanatics. This is not currently Hollywood's style. In the bad old days, the bosses and their mink-draped wives were famous for giving generously to worthy orphans, United Jewish Appeal, Gandhi and the Red Cross. They just didn't want to give money to writers or deal with unions. At least they had the integrity to vote Republican. Now, almost to a man or woman, the studio heads are liberal Democrats whose cash hearts bleed for battered wives, Aids victims, Taliban-oppressed Afghan women and Hillary Clinton. However, their philanthropic compassion often stops with the people who work for them. (Ask their maids and nannies.)

There are other Hollywood anomalies. This is the first dispute I've been involved in where my union leadership resembles the bosses more than the ordinary members. The writers' guild president, John Wells, is a "hyphenate" - an outrageously wealthy writer-producer of TV shows such as West Wing and ER. He probably makes 60 times more money in a week than the management negotiators he's been facing across a table do in a year. Included in the union's team have been its chief negotiator, John McLean, for 25 years a CBS network official, and Charles Holland, former head of business affairs for Rupert Murdoch. Behind this cautious, business-oriented leadership, there is a strong, united union. Contrarily, SAG, the actors' union, is so faction-split that police had to be called to a recent mass meeting.

That strike became such a real possibility is thanks to ideological radicals such as Murdoch, Disney's Robert Iger and DreamWorks' Jeff Katzenberg - and their corporate masters and peers. The producers have boasted openly of the economic benefits of a strike in cutting payrolls and getting rid of the "deadwood" of producer deals gone sour, not to mention the sheer primitive pleasure of humbling the union.

It would take a Freud or perhaps Marx to lay bare the deep, ancestral roots of the film industry's equivocal attitude to labour unions. Most producers and CEs (creative executives) I meet haven't a clue about the virulent Hollywood traditions that shape their relationships with colleagues and underlings. History simply does not exist for them, except perhaps in the likes of Braveheart and Gladiator. Yet it is history that gave weight to the strike threat.

It took blood and guts to build Hollywood unions in the face of fierce, sometimes brutal resistance from the producers. Almost from the start, the studios preferred buying labour peace from corrupt, Mob-tied union bosses to dealing with clean and militant workers. Hollywood's record of industrial relations is stained by paternalistic and arbitrary work rules, blacklists and police-and-brickbat violence when bribery and threats failed. The watershed Conference of Studio Unions (CSU) strike at major studios in 1945 - in which unionists traded punch for punch with strikebreakers - escalated into a lockout that helped unleash the Red-baiting Hollywood Ten purges that allowed the studios to crush CSU and take total control of the production process. There is a sense in which the unions never quite came back from the 1945-46 defeat.

Who are the screenwriters, anyway?

Most of us are independent business people who work from job to job and are treated like workers on an assembly line. In Hollywood's glory days, when films were 70 minutes long and credits flashed on the screen for a few seconds only, the writers were often as oddball as their movies. You'd get strange types with real life experience - first world war aviators, oil field roustabouts, taxi drivers, hookers, proletarian novelists, communist playwrights, fake Viennese noblemen, and hordes of drunken journalists such as Herman Mankiewicz and Ben Hecht. Snuffling for easy cash, the writers would rather have cut their throats than burble about "cinema art" or "creative responsibility". The phenomenal Hecht (Nothing Sacred, Notorious) laughed at the whole credits system, and didn't give a damn if his name was on the screen or not. But, of course, that was before residuals - that is, money the Guild won for writers from theatrical and TV reruns.

Today's Hollywoodised culture, its tentacles in every small town and academic film department, promiscuously breeds screenwriters. Once upon a time, carhop waitresses dreamed of being "discovered" like Lana Turner; farmhands wanted to be Clark Gable. Now they write scripts. Eleven-year-old children are "into" screenwriting as a normal stage between Pokémon and first sex. Many of my colleagues spring directly from the loins of film school or have studied screenwriting in college or writers' workshops.

College educated or not, writers - in Rodney Danger-field's immortal phrase - still "don't get no respect". At the recent Academy Awards, veteran screenwriter Ernest Lehman (North By Northwest) plaintively pleaded the writers' case. "It all starts with the script," he remarked to the splendidly coiffed Academy audience, who normally clap hands for anybody, including a trained seal. Lehman's thinly veiled show of solidarity with WGA noticeably failed to provoke applause from the Academy's brave souls.

As Yorkshire and South Wales coal miners know, work stoppages are about dignity as well as money. Screenwriters (and actors) are astonishingly low on the Hollywood status ladder. The myth that writers are "schmucks with typewriters" and actors cattle is hard to kill. Thus, "respect" became a (muted) strike issue. Among WGA's lesser demands was the end of the monstrous "possessory credit" - the tagline "A Film By" - that some directors grab to show writers and everyone else involved in a movie's collaboration that nobody counts except the "helmer". My union, a little unconvincingly, also staked a claim for writers to be involved on the set so their scripts won't be tinkered with by directors and stars. And pigs will fly, too.

Lack of respect for writers was built into the very first basic Guild agreement in l942. It contained the fatal clause: "The studio hereinafter referred to as the author." Unlike plays and novels, a screenplay, once sold, belongs to the buyer not to the author.

I support my union 100%, except on this issue. Respect stinks. Give me the money, and minimum courtesy, and you can shove respect. Writers do their best work when they are least respectable. When they are, in fact, schmucks with typewriters. For me, respect implies respectability which too often translates into pretentiousness, of which - take a look at any movie more than 90 minutes long - we have an oversupply. Writers should be cautious of getting above themselves. We are worker-craftsmen and women, no less, no more. Let's not get too solemn about the dream-images we put on paper, draft after flagellated draft until a Final, Final Shooting Script is complete, eight or nine other writers having had "creative input". (I'm not complaining - I've been one of the eight or nine .)

My normal strikeless day in Hollywood involves writing scenes, pitching ideas to studio execs, scanning the trade paper Variety for my daily anxiety attack, inventing and discarding blue-sky "concepts", staring into my writing partner's baby blues, scratching my nose and trying to figure out a market trend before it happens (eg, teenage-oriented movies, hot yesterday, tanking disastrously today). The game plan for a strike, is to keep on writing but not turn anything in, while maybe going back to that long-lost novel - or going a little crazy. Actors are more used to second jobs (waiting table, massage therapy) than writers, but I've had a return to taxi driving at the back of my mind. The fact is, hitherto, the Guild has never won anything important, including its pension plan and superb health benefits, without a strike. The present crisis may yet yield an unexpected benefit: solidarity instead of personal competitiveness, and militancy where least expected. Last year's actors' walkout educated a lot of normally apolitical or conservative union members. Each generation invents its own passions, as the studio bosses may discover to their chagrin.

I've been on strike before, though never as a screenwriter. In a corner of my secret heart, I looked forward to a strike now, confident in my union leadership, my union brothers and sisters, and in the perhaps sentimental knowledge that I am helping to bring history up to date, from that night in 1933 when a group of 10 writers - including two of the later Hollywood Ten, Lester Cole and John Howard Lawson - gathered at the Roosevelt Hotel in Hollywood to brainstorm a different kind of union, a dream this time for themselves and not the producers.

The writers' and actors' unions became restless because at each step of the new technology this monopoly of production and distribution makes millions - in the case of a blockbuster such as Titanic, hundreds of millions - from the sale of just one product. The pie grows, but the pie makers have been getting less of it percentage-wise. Even after the WGA reduced by 75% its demand for an increase in DVD residuals - or an extra penny per sale - the producers' offer was a zero increase. The entertainment corporations, emboldened by an anti-labour Bush administration in the White House, made it clear they were out for blood. That our Hollywood lives are being ordained in faraway places by tycoons who don't know a grip from a best boy is not flash news. Even back in the silent era, Hollywood moguls genuflected to New York or Boston banks. True, the Golden Age's feudal studio system was managed by famous names such as Harry Cohn (who liked to do business sitting on a toilet), Sam Goldwyn and LB Mayer, but the real power, to whom they were accountable, lay with paymasters at Morgan Guaranty and Chase Manhattan. The Atlantic sea-board bankers let the vulgar moguls make the deals and screw the starlets and bribe shady union officials and break the honest unions, but ultimate authority rested 3,000 miles away in Wall Street boardrooms. It says something about how the film business is normally conducted that Hollywood, in the grip of strike fever for the past few months, has rarely been more businesslike. "It's like in the old times when each studio had to grind out a movie every week," a talent manager told me. "I wish it was always this efficient. I even get my phone calls answered the same day." New movies have been stockpiled; agents have been pushing their stars into back-to-back projects just to keep them working; writers in mountain retreats have scribbled overtime to finish scripts before the deadline. Yet it's estimated that the studios' pell-mell rush to squeeze film product through the pipeline has actually been more expensive (in exorbitantly paying star talent, for example) than settling with the unions. At the moment, only $100million - the cost of one big, bad Hollywood blockbuster such as Godzilla - is all that separates the combatants. Inevitably, producers began, ever so gently, wink wink, to suggest privately to writers, ahem, "If there's a strike, of course, we know contractually you won't be able to work, but maybe, in your spare time, you might, well, you know, give our script a little tweak or two . . ." In other words, blackleg. Such hints didn't come from the lips of producers who are Neanderthal, anti-abortion, rightwing George Dubya fanatics. This is not currently Hollywood's style. In the bad old days, the bosses and their mink-draped wives were famous for giving generously to worthy orphans, United Jewish Appeal, Gandhi and the Red Cross. They just didn't want to give money to writers or deal with unions. At least they had the integrity to vote Republican. Now, almost to a man or woman, the studio heads are liberal Democrats whose cash hearts bleed for battered wives, Aids victims, Taliban-oppressed Afghan women and Hillary Clinton. However, their philanthropic compassion often stops with the people who work for them. (Ask their maids and nannies.) There are other Hollywood anomalies. This is the first dispute I've been involved in where my union leadership resembles the bosses more than the ordinary members. The writers' guild president, John Wells, is a "hyphenate" - an outrageously wealthy writer-producer of TV shows such as West Wing and ER. He probably makes 60 times more money in a week than the management negotiators he's been facing across a table do in a year. Included in the union's team have been its chief negotiator, John McLean, for 25 years a CBS network official, and Charles Holland, former head of business affairs for Rupert Murdoch. Behind this cautious, business-oriented leadership, there is a strong, united union. Contrarily, SAG, the actors' union, is so faction-split that police had to be called to a recent mass meeting. That strike became such a real possibility is thanks to ideological radicals such as Murdoch, Disney's Robert Iger and DreamWorks' Jeff Katzenberg - and their corporate masters and peers. The producers have boasted openly of the economic benefits of a strike in cutting payrolls and getting rid of the "deadwood" of producer deals gone sour, not to mention the sheer primitive pleasure of humbling the union. It would take a Freud or perhaps Marx to lay bare the deep, ancestral roots of the film industry's equivocal attitude to labour unions. Most producers and CEs (creative executives) I meet haven't a clue about the virulent Hollywood traditions that shape their relationships with colleagues and underlings. History simply does not exist for them, except perhaps in the likes of Braveheart and Gladiator. Yet it is history that gave weight to the strike threat. It took blood and guts to build Hollywood unions in the face of fierce, sometimes brutal resistance from the producers. Almost from the start, the studios preferred buying labour peace from corrupt, Mob-tied union bosses to dealing with clean and militant workers. Hollywood's record of industrial relations is stained by paternalistic and arbitrary work rules, blacklists and police-and-brickbat violence when bribery and threats failed. The watershed Conference of Studio Unions (CSU) strike at major studios in 1945 - in which unionists traded punch for punch with strikebreakers - escalated into a lockout that helped unleash the Red-baiting Hollywood Ten purges that allowed the studios to crush CSU and take total control of the production process. There is a sense in which the unions never quite came back from the 1945-46 defeat. Who are the screenwriters, anyway? Most of us are independent business people who work from job to job and are treated like workers on an assembly line. In Hollywood's glory days, when films were 70 minutes long and credits flashed on the screen for a few seconds only, the writers were often as oddball as their movies. You'd get strange types with real life experience - first world war aviators, oil field roustabouts, taxi drivers, hookers, proletarian novelists, communist playwrights, fake Viennese noblemen, and hordes of drunken journalists such as Herman Mankiewicz and Ben Hecht. Snuffling for easy cash, the writers would rather have cut their throats than burble about "cinema art" or "creative responsibility". The phenomenal Hecht (Nothing Sacred, Notorious) laughed at the whole credits system, and didn't give a damn if his name was on the screen or not. But, of course, that was before residuals - that is, money the Guild won for writers from theatrical and TV reruns. Today's Hollywoodised culture, its tentacles in every small town and academic film department, promiscuously breeds screenwriters. Once upon a time, carhop waitresses dreamed of being "discovered" like Lana Turner; farmhands wanted to be Clark Gable. Now they write scripts. Eleven-year-old children are "into" screenwriting as a normal stage between Pokémon and first sex. Many of my colleagues spring directly from the loins of film school or have studied screenwriting in college or writers' workshops. College educated or not, writers - in Rodney Danger-field's immortal phrase - still "don't get no respect". At the recent Academy Awards, veteran screenwriter Ernest Lehman (North By Northwest) plaintively pleaded the writers' case. "It all starts with the script," he remarked to the splendidly coiffed Academy audience, who normally clap hands for anybody, including a trained seal. Lehman's thinly veiled show of solidarity with WGA noticeably failed to provoke applause from the Academy's brave souls. As Yorkshire and South Wales coal miners know, work stoppages are about dignity as well as money. Screenwriters (and actors) are astonishingly low on the Hollywood status ladder. The myth that writers are "schmucks with typewriters" and actors cattle is hard to kill. Thus, "respect" became a (muted) strike issue. Among WGA's lesser demands was the end of the monstrous "possessory credit" - the tagline "A Film By" - that some directors grab to show writers and everyone else involved in a movie's collaboration that nobody counts except the "helmer". My union, a little unconvincingly, also staked a claim for writers to be involved on the set so their scripts won't be tinkered with by directors and stars. And pigs will fly, too. Lack of respect for writers was built into the very first basic Guild agreement in l942. It contained the fatal clause: "The studio hereinafter referred to as the author." Unlike plays and novels, a screenplay, once sold, belongs to the buyer not to the author. I support my union 100%, except on this issue. Respect stinks. Give me the money, and minimum courtesy, and you can shove respect. Writers do their best work when they are least respectable. When they are, in fact, schmucks with typewriters. For me, respect implies respectability which too often translates into pretentiousness, of which - take a look at any movie more than 90 minutes long - we have an oversupply. Writers should be cautious of getting above themselves. We are worker-craftsmen and women, no less, no more. Let's not get too solemn about the dream-images we put on paper, draft after flagellated draft until a Final, Final Shooting Script is complete, eight or nine other writers having had "creative input". (I'm not complaining - I've been one of the eight or nine .) My normal strikeless day in Hollywood involves writing scenes, pitching ideas to studio execs, scanning the trade paper Variety for my daily anxiety attack, inventing and discarding blue-sky "concepts", staring into my writing partner's baby blues, scratching my nose and trying to figure out a market trend before it happens (eg, teenage-oriented movies, hot yesterday, tanking disastrously today). The game plan for a strike, is to keep on writing but not turn anything in, while maybe going back to that long-lost novel - or going a little crazy. Actors are more used to second jobs (waiting table, massage therapy) than writers, but I've had a return to taxi driving at the back of my mind. The fact is, hitherto, the Guild has never won anything important, including its pension plan and superb health benefits, without a strike. The present crisis may yet yield an unexpected benefit: solidarity instead of personal competitiveness, and militancy where least expected. Last year's actors' walkout educated a lot of normally apolitical or conservative union members. Each generation invents its own passions, as the studio bosses may discover to their chagrin. I've been on strike before, though never as a screenwriter. In a corner of my secret heart, I looked forward to a strike now, confident in my union leadership, my union brothers and sisters, and in the perhaps sentimental knowledge that I am helping to bring history up to date, from that night in 1933 when a group of 10 writers - including two of the later Hollywood Ten, Lester Cole and John Howard Lawson - gathered at the Roosevelt Hotel in Hollywood to brainstorm a different kind of union, a dream this time for themselves and not the producers.

fields.headline: Murder, he wrote
fields.standfirst: A new TV profile of crime writer James Ellroy reveals a man 'who stares at the worst humans are capable of'. It may also solve a 50-year-old murder mystery, explains director Vikram Jayanti
fields.trailText: A new TV profile of crime writer James Ellroy reveals a man 'who stares at the worst humans are capable of'. It may also solve a 50-year-old murder mystery, explains director Vikram Jayanti
fields.body:
27 January 1997: I'm in Las Vegas airport, desperate for a good book. Amazingly there's a Waterstone's here, and a pile of James Ellroy's American Tabloid on the table out front. I've spent years avoiding his crime novels, thinking he must be a cheap knock-off of Elmore Leonard, but it's a great title, so I pick it up. And I'm immediately blown away. It's raw, visceral, brutal, profane, hilarious and deeply true about the darkness underlying the American Empire: politics as street crime moved up a rung. That one-page preface ("America was never innocent. We popped our cherry on the boat over and looked back with no regrets") grabs you and you stay grabbed.

19 February 2000: I'm in Vegas again, for a wedding. There are only a few guests, and Ellroy's one of them. I tell him why I think American Tabloid is the Great American Novel. He loves that, and in return tells me that When We Were Kings (the 1997 Oscar-winning Muhammad Ali documentary, which I co-produced) is crap. I love that too, and afterwards we set off to join two homicide cop friends of his for a bar crawl before some late-night boxing bout they're in town for. I'd imagined some hard-drinking, chain-smoking, red-meat-chomping, in-your-face-and-who's-asking kind of guy. But as we sit there, nursing our San Pellegrinos while the detectives hit the bourbon, I find out he's a non-smoking, non-drinking vegetarian. Though he's definitely an alpha male, there's even an old-fashioned courtesy about him, but with his brilliantly filthy mouth and the world's most fabulous, grotesque and gory true-crime stories to tell, he's a fun guy to hang out with. The cops clearly love him too.

Though best known in Britain for LA Confidential, the novel that redefined Los Angeles noir and spawned a hit movie, the one that's made the most impression lately is his memoir of his search for his mother's killer, My Dark Places. Now 53, Ellroy was 10 years old when she was murdered, and by the age of 11 he was obsessed with true crime literature. Dropping out of school in his mid-teens, he got into a street life of drink, drugs and petty crime and only started writing when he was 29. It saved his life.

10 January 2001: Ellroy and seven homicide detectives, from the LAPD's elite Robbery And Homicide Division, are at the Pacific Dining Car, talking crime. Their days frequently begin where our imaginations end, or as one of them says, "Our eyes see more than our souls can take."

Because they trust Ellroy, they're behaving as they do when they're alone together - telling uncensored tales of body dumps, charred bodies in trunks of cars, and from their years on the vice squad, hilarious reminiscences about hand-job bars, and who's a fruit in Hollywood. My 11-person crew is hanging on every word.

The Pacific Dining Car is one of LA's oldest restaurants, and one of its most expensive, opened in 1921 and by the 40s a favourite hangout of Raymond Chandler.

Ellroy lives in Kansas now, but whenever he's in town he eats there every night and a spontaneous salon forms around him. His friends from Hollywood mingle with his friends in the LA police, and the subject is crime - especially great unsolved murder mysteries.

At the first one I was invited to, Matt Damon and Winona Ryder rolled in, but the cops didn't bat an eyelid. This is their turf, and they're talking about their world: the overwhelming physical evidence against OJ; the spinning, pinwheel eyes of Richard "Night Stalker" Ramirez; the autopsies conducted by Dr Noguchi ("coroner to the stars"). Two men in particular stand out: Detective Rick Jackson broke the Oswaldo Perez case, nabbing a 17-year-old serial killer after just three break-in murders of women living alone; Detective Bill Stoner of the LA County Sheriff's Department broke the Cotton Club murders, and reopened the investigation of the 1958 death of Ellroy's mother, Geneva Hilliker Ellroy. Rick and Bill are now among Ellroy's closest friends.

11 January 2001: Tonight it's the turn of the Sheriff's Department, with a special guest - Larry Harnisch, a journalist from the LA Times. After years of self-financed research, he's come up with a new theory about the infamous Black Dahlia murder, and he's here to expound it before two of the world's experts on the murder: Ellroy, and Detective Brian Carr, the current custodian of the Black Dahlia files. As America's most famous unsolved murder, it remains under active investigation by the LAPD, more than 50 years after 22-year old Elizabeth Short's severed and mutilated body was discovered lying in a vacant lot on the morning of 15 January 1947.

The Pacific Dining Car is creaking with scepticism. The sheriffs are half cut, and giving Larry the third degree, while Ellroy looks on with delight. Larry is nervous and long-winded and the cops are not impressed when he argues that there's no proof that Short was hooking. Rather, she seems to have had a fine line in what one of the detectives delicately calls "prickteasing", so another detective figures it was a justifiable homicide. In the midst of this scurrilous debate, Nick Nolte wanders in, wearing his trademark all-day dressing gown, and takes a seat. Again, the movie star is ignored.

Larry grinds towards his conclusion, assembling his evidence brick by brick, and one by one the cops fall silent - his theory is persuasive and covers all the known facts of the case. By the time he unleashes his clincher - why the enraged killer slit the Black Dahlia's face into that grotesque bloody grin, and why the killing happened on the exact date it did - the place is electric with tension. Both Ellroy and Detective Carr agree that Larry's theory is watertight. At this moment, in the film, we reveal the only existing photograph of Larry's suspect.

My documentary is not for the squeamish. We show explicit pictures of the crime scenes for both Mrs Ellroy and the Black Dahlia's murders. The autopsy pictures of Elizabeth Short are more shocking than imagination can prepare anyone for. But my use of them is not for shock value: it's a deliberate mirror of Ellroy's literary technique.

Violence - particularly violence against women - too often serves writers and film-makers as an easy plot device, or it gets aestheticised and sanitised. We are inured to the reality of violence, which is messy, terrible and which, once experienced, never leaves our consciousness. But as Ellroy says in the film, "Closure is bullshit." I believe Ellroy, who has been exposed to violence in the most intimate way, is determined not to let the results of violence heal over. He stares unblinkingly at the worst things humans are capable of, trying to get to the true meaning. And the true meaning is not pretty. Look away and you let the bastards get away with it.

Another surprise: Ellroy is a profound moralist. Why? Because he's on to something that only artists can reach. A truth which is truer than the facts themselves can ever be. By writing about unsolved real murders - or unresolved ones, such as the JFK hit - Ellroy is concerned with what gives rise to such killings, not who. Who is for the cops to find out - Ellroy's job is to use fiction to reach beyond the facts for the essential, fundamental truth of real things. Isn't that what art is for? I think so. *

fields.headline: Last night's TV
fields.standfirst: It was the mints that gave it away
fields.trailText: Brookside's Barry Grant has always had women trouble. He tormented Jacqui Dixon, toyed with Lindsey Corkhill's affections and made Sue Sullivan take a tumble off some scaffolding to her death.
fields.body:
Brookside's Barry Grant has always had women trouble. He tormented Jacqui Dixon, toyed with Lindsey Corkhill's affections and made Sue Sullivan take a tumble off some scaffolding to her death. Such was the emotional torture he inflicted upon poor Julie Peasgood, she has taken to advertising frozen petit pois and laying loft insulation on a cable TV channel. Not to mention her blackest shame of all - appearing on Hollyoaks.

So it should come as no surprise that when Barry (Paul Usher) turned up in ITV's The Bill as PC Taverner, he had a run-in with Sunhill's lovely ladies, especially as he seems to have had his genes spliced with a Mitchell brother on his way to the station. "I didn't know life was supposed to be a popularity contest," he purred at Scowlin' Minx DS McAllister. She scowled some more and flounced out of the room. (She does a lot of flouncing, does Minxy McAllister. It often looks as if she is in a shampoo advert and is not best pleased about it.)

A gentleman rapist was on the loose and Taverner had a hunch. McAllister and the DC who used to have big hair but now has none at all thought it was a refugee from EastEnders who dunnit; Taverner, however, thought the bloke who robbed the chemist was the multiple rapist. His evidence? Mints and cologne had been nicked from Kapoor's Pharmacy. Well it stands to reason, doesn't it?

It came to pass in this very watchable episode of The Bill that he was right. Conrad, the mixed-race, cokehead fine arts student, was attacking women on the Jasmine Allen estate. Caught in the end, we could be sure he was on his way to Wandsworth prison.

The only worrying aspect of all of this was Taverner's assertion that his hunch came from "the little man inside". Either he is taking instructions directly from his penis or he is an automaton - a robocop, if you will - being controlled by a miniature version of his creator embedded in his chest. If this is the case, we must wonder who is operating him. My bet is on Sergeant Cryer, who was unceremoniously dumped from Sunhill and has built a robot with which to wreak his revenge on his former colleagues. Then again, perhaps I have been watching too much Buffy the Vampire Slayer.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our front-page story yesterday on errors in the cervical screening programme, an editing mistake made it appear - alarmingly and wrongly - that a third of women going for a smear test were being given the wrong result. That is not the case. The audit in Leicester showed that a third of cervical cancers in women who went for regular tests had not been picked up. Most of those would be slides that were hard to read. The vast majority of normal slides would be easy to read and women would get the right result. Apologies for that.
fields.body:
In our front-page story yesterday on errors in the cervical screening programme, an editing mistake made it appear - alarmingly and wrongly - that a third of women going for a smear test were being given the wrong result. That is not the case. The audit in Leicester showed that a third of cervical cancers in women who went for regular tests had not been picked up. Most of those would be slides that were hard to read. The vast majority of normal slides would be easy to read and women would get the right result. Apologies for that.

In a report headed Credit act "denies fair deal", page 8, May 3, we reported that the court of appeal had made its first "declaration of incompatibility" with human rights since the Human Rights Act came into force last year (in a case relating to the Consumer Credit Act). This was, in fact, the appeal court's second such declaration. The first declaration was made in a Mental Health Act case, reported in the Guardian on March 29.

In a report headed British film actors threaten to strike, page 5, yesterday, we said, "The biggest of the British films that may be affected is The Emperor's New Clothes, a story about Napoleon, starring Ian Holm." We made the same suggestion in the caption to an accompanying picture of Ian Holm in the film. In fact the film, which is no longer called The Emperor's New Clothes, but My Napoleon, is not affected at all by the threat of a strike. Filming has finished and it is now in editing. Apologies.

A captioning error on page 40 of today's Weekend magazine dates the Hollywood strike, in which pickets are photographed struggling with police, in 1960. In fact, the photo shows a strike in 1946.

The readers' editor writes about the reader response to the Hazlitt Memorial Fund in Saturday Review.
