webTitle: Kiley given free rein to run tube

fields.headline: Kiley given free rein to run tube
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
Special report: Greater London authority
fields.trailText: Tony Blair appointed Bob Kiley chairman of London transport, with full authority to  to negotiate changes to the government's public-private partnership.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has personally intervened to defuse the growing crisis over the future of the London Underground before the election by giving Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner Bob Kiley a free hand to make a deal with the companies bidding to take over half of the tube.

Mr Kiley has been appointed chairman of London Transport, following meetings with the prime minister and John Prescott, with authority to negotiate changes to the government's public-private partnership (PPP) scheme to give him unified management control of the underground.

The surprise announcement by Mr Prescott last night follows weeks of public conflict over the part-privatisation plans - with Gordon Brown playing a pivotal role in blocking agreement with Mr Kiley - which risked spilling over into the election campaign.

With the open endorsement of the prime minister and negotiations scheduled to begin on Tuesday, the hope is now that the private consortiums bidding to run track, stations and signalling will concede Mr Kiley's demand for public control of the tube network.

Despite the breakthrough, Mr Kiley warned last night that he was not "brimming over with confidence" that a deal with the contractors was possible and he has refused to abandon next month's high court challenge to the PPP, saying he still regarded the scheme as "utterly unacceptable".

Last night's announcement was described by the Tory transport spokesman Bernard Jenkin - who predicted months of negotiation before there was a settlement - as "the most astonishing and dramatic u-turn", carried out on the eve of a bank holiday weekend to "try to minimise the embarrassment".

Under the terms of yesterday's agreement, Mr Kiley will take over from Sir Malcolm Bates immediately as chairman of London Transport - London Underground's parent body - and open negotiations with the "preferred bidders" announced by Mr Prescott last Wednesday to achieve unified management control within some form of PPP structure.

Mr Blair last night "warmly welcomed" the agreement, as did Mr Livingstone.

"I've met with Bob Kiley," Mr Blair said, "heard his concerns and have confidence in his ability to deliver a PPP which meets those concerns and ours and will be good for London." Mr Prescott added that he was "delighted that we have now found a way towards unified management control within the framework of the PPP".

Mr Kiley nevertheless cautioned that yesterday's agreement was "a beginning, not an end" and said he was not sure that "satisfactory modifications to the PPP to meet my concerns are possible".

Referring to Mr Prescott's decision to press ahead with the announcement of preferred bidders for two sets of deep lines this week, he said it was a move with which he disagreed and one which "could have an impact on my ability to persuade the private firms to accept my point of view".

But Mr Kiley believes that it will become clear very quickly, before the election, whether the consortiums hoping to sign 30-year contracts to take over the tube infrastructure - and the financial institutions planning to finance them - will be prepared to accept the minimum changes he believes necessary.

fields.headline: Tainted Robinson wins three-month reprieve
fields.standfirst:
MPs delay final action after former minister's plea for chance to find missing cheque at centre of inquiry over undeclared £200,000

Full text of the report
Special report: House of Commons
Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: The millionaire Labour MP, Geoffrey Robinson, yesterday won an extraordinary three month breathing space before facing near certain suspension by the House of Commons - despite a damning verdict that he both failed to declare a £200,000 business interest and misled fellow MPs.
fields.body:
The millionaire Labour MP, Geoffrey Robinson, yesterday won an extraordinary three month breathing space before facing near certain suspension by the House of Commons - despite a damning verdict that he both failed to declare a £200,000 business interest and misled fellow MPs.

Though the cross-party Commons standards and privileges committee endorsed the tough conclusions produced by the standards commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, they also agreed to his plea for time to find a cashed - but missing - £200,000 cheque. He says it can prove his innocence.

He plans to organise a search, starting on Tuesday, through hundreds of boxes in the bankrupt estate of the late Robert Maxwell who allegedly authorised the disputed cheque in December 1990.

But Mrs Filkin's verdict is that there is enough evidence already to conclude that, after months of badgering the Maxwell camp, Mr Robinson got his cheque for helping restructure Hollis Industries.

Cheque No 001751 was drawn on Pergamon AGB, Maxwell's key company, paid by an unknown person into a NatWest branch at Tavistock Sq, London, and immediately transferred to a branch at Colmore Row, Birmingham - where Mr Robinson and his engineering firm, TransTech, both had accounts.

Evidence included an invoice from the MP, cashbook records and a secretary's post-it sticker which said: "Geoffrey is not registered for VAT. Proposes make cheque payable to him personally."

Yet the cheque has not been found and Mr Robinson is adamant he never received the money. Even the bank admits that payments of £200,000 going in and out of one branch in a single day may be unrelated, he told the committee.

Mrs Filkin concluded: "It is stretching coincidence beyond the bounds of credulity" to claim there is no link. Mr Robinson's own diary shows he checked the Birmingham branch account number the same day and wrote: "One down, one to go" - a reference, Mrs Filkin said, to two Maxwell debts he was owed.

The committee upheld Mrs Filkin's endorsement of Tory complaints that Mr Robinson had failed to provide "full and accurate" responses during an earlier 1998 investigation.

"We find that Mr Robinson had a registrable interest which he failed to declare," the MPs' report said yesterday. They also backed Mrs Filkin's conclusion that he had "misled the committee by denying that he had agreed or solicited the £200,000 fee" at the heart of the running controversy.

In a statement yesterday, the MP, who quit the government in 1998 over his secret £374,000 home loan to Peter Mandelson, said: "I have co-operated completely with this inquiry. I do of course accept the committee's findings and wish to assure them that there was no intention on my part not to provide full information or registration in 1998."

Local activists in Coventry where the 61-year-old MP has a 16,601 majority, appear to be backing the man who has represented them since 1976. "The key thing for Geoffrey is to find that cheque and clear his name," said one regional Labour official. David Heathcoat-Amory, the shadow trade and industry secretary, told Radio 4's World at One yesterday: "They haven't withdrawn the whip from him, they do, under their rules, have the power to withdraw his party card which means he couldn't stand in the election."

The MP has already been criticised twice and forced to apologise once for undeclared interests. Yesterday's committee report, completed and printed in haste before the election, endorsed an impressive piece of high-speed detective work over the missing cheque.

Mrs Filkin's predecessor in the post of parliamentary commissioner for standards, Sir Gordon Downey, concluded in 1998 that the "likelihood" was that the former paymaster general was the victim of an accounting error by Hollis Industries who owed him the money for management services - but did not pay it.

But Mrs Filkin's renewed inquiry was better placed to delve deeper because of access to parts of a still-unpublished Department of Trade and Industry report into the management of Hollis and a piece of evidence unearthed by the journalist Tom Bower.

In his book, The Paymaster, an expose of the MP's business methods, was an invoice for the disputed sum written by Mr Robinson from his Surrey home, six weeks before the £200,000 cheque was issued. Published in March it prompted Mr Heathcoat-Amory to lodge three new complaints with Mrs Filkin.

She upheld them after re-interviewing witnesses. Mrs Filkin's report cannot say whether the money was paid to Mr Robinson personally or into a TransTech account, where it was used to pay off debt owed by Roll Centre Ltd, a US firm he had an interest in.

The purpose might have been to inflate TransTech's profits and thus increase its value because Mr Robinson was planning to sell it to Mr Maxwell. Mr Robinson's evidence was scornful of that theory. Whether or not he got the money himself the committee regards this as a "subsidiary point".

Yesterday's evidence shows that his Labour colleagues sounded sceptical during cross-examination.

webTitle: Ministers join lost lottery ticket row

fields.headline: Ministers join lost lottery ticket row
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: The government has joined the row over Camelot's refusal to pay a £3m jackpot to a couple who lost their winning national lottery ticket.
fields.body:
The government has joined the row over Camelot's refusal to pay a £3m jackpot to a couple who lost their winning national lottery ticket.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, told BBC1's Question Time on Thursday that the lottery operator should "see reason" over its refusal to pay Kay and Martyn Tott, from Watford, Hertfordshire, despite concluding that their claim to have lost the winning ticket was genuine.

Yesterday, Downing Street publicly backed Mr Smith's comments, and criticised the rules preventing a pay-out.

The couple had seen their numbers, a combination of anniversary and birthday dates, appear in a March 5 television appeal which was looking for winners who had not claimed their prize from a draw on September 6.

There were just hours left before the 180-day claims deadline ran out and the Totts immediately rang Camelot. However, they had failed to register their ticket as being lost within 30 days of the draw.

Kay, 24, and Martyn, 33, then endured seven weeks of investigation. Finally, Camelot decided the claim was genuine but said the 30-day rule meant the money could not be paid without damaging the integrity of the lottery.

Asked by the programme's presenter, David Dimbleby, whether he would force Camelot to pay up or risk losing its licence, Mr Smith said: "Well, they've got their licence back, but I hope that they will actually see reason in this matter." He told an audience member who asked whether Camelot should pay: "There is no legal requirement on them to do so, but if I were them, I would."

Mr Tott, a purchasing manager, said yesterday: "I am pleased that someone of his stature in the government is supporting this. It is double standards on Camelot's part. They could well sink lower, and lower yet, but I am encouraged by all the coverage we have received.

"I think that Camelot may now have a bitter pill to swallow over this, and this may be just the pill they need."

A spokeswoman for the Department of Culture admitted the problems were exacerbated by the little-known 30-day rule. She said: "It would be a lot simpler without the 30-day rule because then they wouldn't have had a chance and that would have been that."

Camelot insisted it was forced to withhold payment, and that not to do so would "open the floodgates" to similar claims and jeopardise the entire lottery system.

In a statement it said: "It is not a question of 'seeing reason' - it is about upholding rules that protect the national lottery and its ability to raise funds for the public good."

The Totts' claim is gathering momentum, aided by the PR consultant Max Clifford and celebrities speaking out on their behalf.

webTitle: Il Cavaliere closes in on power - with a little help from his media

fields.headline: Il Cavaliere closes in on power - with a little help from his media
fields.standfirst: Silvio Berlusconi is days away from spawning the biggest conflict of interest in western democracy
fields.trailText: Silvio Berlusconi is days away from spawning the biggest conflict of interest in western democracy.
fields.body:
Five minutes before 7pm the commercials fade and the show begins. Cymbals clash, drums roll and light floods the screen. A yellow 4 looms into focus. Trumpets resound as the music swells into a crescendo of urgency. It is the sound of battle.

Graphics dissolve to reveal a man gazing into the camera. He wears a double-breasted suit and tight smile. Before the jingle has died he begins to talk, quickly, for there is much to say.

Today a great leader has shared his wisdom with the people. He has come among the poor, the jobless, the fearful, to offer hope. A sunlit upland awaits and he knows how to get there.

But the presenter looks sad. Something else happened today. Some idiots - there is no other word - attacked the leader. They hurled abuse and lies and threats. They massacred his character, invented stories and even had the cheek to steal his ideas. No, today the news is not good.

And this is the news, six nights a week, on Retequattro, a national television network in Italy. It is the domain of Emilio Fede, the anchor and editor-in-chief. He punctuates broadcasts with sweeps of an arm, purrs of approval and gasps of horror. No story is complete without comment.

Mr Fede veers from apoplexy to euphoria. "Those communists never change," is one of his favourite expressions, referring to Italy's centre-left. "There they go again."

Mr Fede has a hero. He calls him The Knight (Cavaliere) and says "he is my Bible". The hero is Silvio Berlusconi, 64, Italy's richest man, founder of the Forza Italia party, head of the centre-right opposition and favourite to win next Sunday's general election. He is also Mr Fede's boss.

Retequattro is just one part of a vast media empire which gives Mr Berlusconi unrivalled influence over public opinion. His Mediaset company also runs Italy's two other private television networks, Canale 5 and Italia 1. His family also owns a newspaper, Il Giornale, and Italy's biggest publishing group, Mondadori. The billionaire is eight days away from spawning the biggest conflict of interest in any western democracy. Polls suggest his coalition will beat the government on May 13 despite an international uproar branding him unfit for office.

"The separation of powers which states rely on to protect democracy would be destroyed. You cannot allow a democracy to depend on the goodwill of one man," said James Walston, a historian at the American University of Rome.

European partners are concerned and amazed: how could Italy let this happen? How blatantly does Mr Berlusconi exploit his empire? How dangerous would he be once in control of state television? The answers are surprising but not reassuring.

Mr Berlusconi says a conflict of interest law will be passed during his first 100 days in office and that an announcement about the sale of Mediaset will be made next week. Sceptics predict many loopholes but the Cavaliere responds with a smile: trust me.

Despite what some overexcited supporters shout, he is no Duce. He does not vet his media's output like Benito Mussolini, who stayed up late rewriting the next morning's headlines. "I have not once made a phone call to the office to see what's going on since 1994," he says.

Devoted employees

That was the year he was elected prime minister and formed a government which collapsed in acrimony and corruption charges after seven months. He clawed back credibility with the help of media employees chanting the mantra that leftwing magistrates cooked up baseless accusations.

None come more devoted than Mr Fede. His paens are legendary, earning the nickname Fido from his master's aides. Unedited Berlusconi speeches and press conferences dominate his broadcasts. When reporting on the left the anchor rolls his eyes.

Police have seized recordings on suspicion that a law guaranteeing equal air time to left and right has been breached. Preliminary analysis: two hours devoted to Mr Berlusconi, three minutes to his rival, Francesco Rutelli. Privately Mr Berlusconi admits Fede is an embarrassment but says Retequattro's audience of mostly housewives is too small to matter.

The news on Italia 1, aimed at the young, depicts a country overrun by criminals and illegal immigrants - echoes of the Cavaliere's election campaign. The editor, Mario Giordano, enjoys bashing the left.

Independent watchdog figures calculated that from mid March to mid April Mediaset's networks devoted 11 times more coverage to Mr Berlusconi than Mr Rutelli. Even so, it is less partisan than before: no advertisements for Mr Berlusconi's Forza Italia party, fewer celebrity endorsements. Mediaset's chairman, Fedele Confalonieri, instructed staff to give equal coverage to the other side during the election.

The flagship channel, Canale 5, has largely done so under its respected head of news, Enrico Mentana. Two weeks ago he was the only anchor to report a Berlusconi gaffe when he appeared to accuse the centre-left of terrorism. Maurizio Costanzo, a star chat show host, is left-wing. Yet insiders say self-censorship is routine. "Lines exist and we do not cross them. It's a question of tone. No one has to tell us."

Two weeks ago Mr Berlusconi did exactly that, phoning to carpet Mr Mentana for the gaffe story. "It was very tense," said one staffer. That was unusual and the Cavaliere is trying to dissuade the anchor from jumping to a rival network, knowing Canale 5's credibility would suffer.

Panorama, an influential weekly magazine, champions its patron and rubbishes his opponents. Il Giornale, a national daily newspaper owned by Paolo Berlusconi, turned partisan after his brother entered politics.

Indro Montanelli, the dean of Italian journalists, quit as editor in protest. "Without my knowledge he came into the newsroom and said everything must now be changed because now the newspaper must be put at his service."

What would make a Berlusconi victory so alarming is the control of the three state television and broadcasting networks, called Rai. Almost the entire broadcasting system in the world's sixth-largest industrialised economy would then be in one man's hands.

For the past five years Rai has balanced media power by supporting the ruling centre-left. "That would change under Berlusconi because Rai has always been on the side of the winner," said Claudio Lodici, a political scientist.

In 1994 Mr Berlusconi tried to purge unfriendly faces at its headquarters in Viale Mazzini, near the Vatican. Less need this time. Over the past year key journalists and executives have been detected toning down criticism of the likely new boss. They went too far when Rai failed to report the Berlusconi gaffe covered by Canale 5. An internal inquiry is under way. "Some people are not turning up at editorial conferences so they can distance themselves from the news," said one insider.

Professor Walston has noted the same trend in supposedly independent newspapers. "Many columnists are university academics who rely on government funding for their departments. There is trimming of sails because the wind is changing."

An oft-floated solution to the dilemma of a potential conflict of interest between Mr Berlusconi as leader of Italy and the country's dominant media figure is a blind trust. When he was last in power in 1994 he made a similar proposal, but his government collapsed before it came to anything.

Under this model an independent fiduciary, typically a bank, would manage the tycoon's assets until he leaves office. Yet his holding company, Fininvest, is probably too big and in any case his son Piersilvio and daughter Marina are in senior positions. No one believes they would stay mum at the dinner table.

The other solution would be to sell Mediaset. Rupert Murdoch and Telecom Italia are both interested but Mr Berlusconi worries they would bounce out his children. He also worries he could fall from office prematurely, leaving him stripped of influence. He has promised to make an announcement next week but resents the pressure.

His indignation filled a Palermo sports hall last week. "To think that I, after all I have done for democracy, would take my place in the prime minister's office to take advantage of that position of power for my own interests, is a joke that no one can take seriously."

On Retequattro that night Emilio Fede took that as his cue to laugh heartily.

Would-be PM set on road by property boom

1936

Born the son of a Milanese banker.

1959

Becomes property developer and cashes in on Milan building boom.

1978

Launches local cable channel, Milano 2.

1980

Channel goes national, becoming Canale 5.

1983-84

Buys Italia 1 and Retequattro.

1990

Law safeguarding his concentration of ownership passed with help of Bettino Craxi, leader of Socialists.

1991

Beats rival tycoon Carlo De Benedetti for control of the Mondadori publishing group.

1993

Founds Forza Italia party after Socialists and Christian Democrats consumed in corruption scandal.

1994

Elected prime minister as head of centre-right coalition which crumbles after seven months. Magistrates launch corruption inquiries.

1996

Narrowly loses to Romano Prodi's centre-left coalition in general election.

1998

Changes mind about selling Mediaset to Rupert Murdoch.

2000

Shakes off corruption charges and wins regional elections.

The empire

Silvio Berlusconi and his family own 96% of the holding company Fininvest which has media, financial and property interests. They include ...

Television

A 48.25% stake in Mediaset, with revenue of 2.3bn euros (£1.4bn).

Its three networks have a 43% share of the national audience and 60% of television advertising. They rival the three state-owned Rai networks.

Canale 5

fields.bodyText: Five minutes before 7pm the commercials fade and the show begins. Cymbals clash, drums roll and light floods the screen. A yellow 4 looms into focus. Trumpets resound as the music swells into a crescendo of urgency. It is the sound of battle. Graphics dissolve to reveal a man gazing into the camera. He wears a double-breasted suit and tight smile. Before the jingle has died he begins to talk, quickly, for there is much to say. Today a great leader has shared his wisdom with the people. He has come among the poor, the jobless, the fearful, to offer hope. A sunlit upland awaits and he knows how to get there. But the presenter looks sad. Something else happened today. Some idiots - there is no other word - attacked the leader. They hurled abuse and lies and threats. They massacred his character, invented stories and even had the cheek to steal his ideas. No, today the news is not good. And this is the news, six nights a week, on Retequattro, a national television network in Italy. It is the domain of Emilio Fede, the anchor and editor-in-chief. He punctuates broadcasts with sweeps of an arm, purrs of approval and gasps of horror. No story is complete without comment. Mr Fede veers from apoplexy to euphoria. "Those communists never change," is one of his favourite expressions, referring to Italy's centre-left. "There they go again." Mr Fede has a hero. He calls him The Knight (Cavaliere) and says "he is my Bible". The hero is Silvio Berlusconi, 64, Italy's richest man, founder of the Forza Italia party, head of the centre-right opposition and favourite to win next Sunday's general election. He is also Mr Fede's boss. Retequattro is just one part of a vast media empire which gives Mr Berlusconi unrivalled influence over public opinion. His Mediaset company also runs Italy's two other private television networks, Canale 5 and Italia 1. His family also owns a newspaper, Il Giornale, and Italy's biggest publishing group, Mondadori. The billionaire is eight days away from spawning the biggest conflict of interest in any western democracy. Polls suggest his coalition will beat the government on May 13 despite an international uproar branding him unfit for office. "The separation of powers which states rely on to protect democracy would be destroyed. You cannot allow a democracy to depend on the goodwill of one man," said James Walston, a historian at the American University of Rome. European partners are concerned and amazed: how could Italy let this happen? How blatantly does Mr Berlusconi exploit his empire? How dangerous would he be once in control of state television? The answers are surprising but not reassuring. Mr Berlusconi says a conflict of interest law will be passed during his first 100 days in office and that an announcement about the sale of Mediaset will be made next week. Sceptics predict many loopholes but the Cavaliere responds with a smile: trust me. Despite what some overexcited supporters shout, he is no Duce. He does not vet his media's output like Benito Mussolini, who stayed up late rewriting the next morning's headlines. "I have not once made a phone call to the office to see what's going on since 1994," he says. Devoted employees That was the year he was elected prime minister and formed a government which collapsed in acrimony and corruption charges after seven months. He clawed back credibility with the help of media employees chanting the mantra that leftwing magistrates cooked up baseless accusations. None come more devoted than Mr Fede. His paens are legendary, earning the nickname Fido from his master's aides. Unedited Berlusconi speeches and press conferences dominate his broadcasts. When reporting on the left the anchor rolls his eyes. Police have seized recordings on suspicion that a law guaranteeing equal air time to left and right has been breached. Preliminary analysis: two hours devoted to Mr Berlusconi, three minutes to his rival, Francesco Rutelli. Privately Mr Berlusconi admits Fede is an embarrassment but says Retequattro's audience of mostly housewives is too small to matter. The news on Italia 1, aimed at the young, depicts a country overrun by criminals and illegal immigrants - echoes of the Cavaliere's election campaign. The editor, Mario Giordano, enjoys bashing the left. Independent watchdog figures calculated that from mid March to mid April Mediaset's networks devoted 11 times more coverage to Mr Berlusconi than Mr Rutelli. Even so, it is less partisan than before: no advertisements for Mr Berlusconi's Forza Italia party, fewer celebrity endorsements. Mediaset's chairman, Fedele Confalonieri, instructed staff to give equal coverage to the other side during the election. The flagship channel, Canale 5, has largely done so under its respected head of news, Enrico Mentana. Two weeks ago he was the only anchor to report a Berlusconi gaffe when he appeared to accuse the centre-left of terrorism. Maurizio Costanzo, a star chat show host, is left-wing. Yet insiders say self-censorship is routine. "Lines exist and we do not cross them. It's a question of tone. No one has to tell us." Two weeks ago Mr Berlusconi did exactly that, phoning to carpet Mr Mentana for the gaffe story. "It was very tense," said one staffer. That was unusual and the Cavaliere is trying to dissuade the anchor from jumping to a rival network, knowing Canale 5's credibility would suffer. Panorama, an influential weekly magazine, champions its patron and rubbishes his opponents. Il Giornale, a national daily newspaper owned by Paolo Berlusconi, turned partisan after his brother entered politics. Indro Montanelli, the dean of Italian journalists, quit as editor in protest. "Without my knowledge he came into the newsroom and said everything must now be changed because now the newspaper must be put at his service." What would make a Berlusconi victory so alarming is the control of the three state television and broadcasting networks, called Rai. Almost the entire broadcasting system in the world's sixth-largest industrialised economy would then be in one man's hands. For the past five years Rai has balanced media power by supporting the ruling centre-left. "That would change under Berlusconi because Rai has always been on the side of the winner," said Claudio Lodici, a political scientist. In 1994 Mr Berlusconi tried to purge unfriendly faces at its headquarters in Viale Mazzini, near the Vatican. Less need this time. Over the past year key journalists and executives have been detected toning down criticism of the likely new boss. They went too far when Rai failed to report the Berlusconi gaffe covered by Canale 5. An internal inquiry is under way. "Some people are not turning up at editorial conferences so they can distance themselves from the news," said one insider. Professor Walston has noted the same trend in supposedly independent newspapers. "Many columnists are university academics who rely on government funding for their departments. There is trimming of sails because the wind is changing." An oft-floated solution to the dilemma of a potential conflict of interest between Mr Berlusconi as leader of Italy and the country's dominant media figure is a blind trust. When he was last in power in 1994 he made a similar proposal, but his government collapsed before it came to anything. Under this model an independent fiduciary, typically a bank, would manage the tycoon's assets until he leaves office. Yet his holding company, Fininvest, is probably too big and in any case his son Piersilvio and daughter Marina are in senior positions. No one believes they would stay mum at the dinner table. The other solution would be to sell Mediaset. Rupert Murdoch and Telecom Italia are both interested but Mr Berlusconi worries they would bounce out his children. He also worries he could fall from office prematurely, leaving him stripped of influence. He has promised to make an announcement next week but resents the pressure. His indignation filled a Palermo sports hall last week. "To think that I, after all I have done for democracy, would take my place in the prime minister's office to take advantage of that position of power for my own interests, is a joke that no one can take seriously." On Retequattro that night Emilio Fede took that as his cue to laugh heartily. fields.headline: Fresh calls for Duncan explanation
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: William Hague rallied to the defence of his beleaguered shadow spokesman Alan Duncan last night as a government minister called for him to be sacked over claims that he helped bust oil sanctions against apartheid South Africa.
fields.body:
William Hague rallied to the defence of his beleaguered shadow spokesman Alan Duncan last night as a government minister called for him to be sacked over claims that he helped bust oil sanctions against apartheid South Africa.

The Tory leader made it clear that he will take no action over the allegations, published in yesterday's Guardian, against a member of his trade and industry team so near an election.

Richard Caborn, a trade minister and a former treasurer of the Anti-Apartheid Movement, said the millionaire oil trader and MP for Rutland and Melton should be dismissed if he does not resign.

"Duncan's got to consider his position, particularly given the warm reception Nelson Mandela has received this week from the British public," he said.

Two fellow oil traders claim Mr Duncan was involved in managing covert shipments from Brunei to South Africa in defiance of UN and other sanctions while working for Marc Rich, a billionaire US fugitive controversially pardoned by President Clinton.

Documents seen by the Guardian lend weight to the traders' claims about the rightwinger's role while based in Singapore between 1984 and 1986.

Labour MPs are threatening to raise the issue in the House of Commons next week but Mr Hague hopes the controversy over Mr Duncan, his former landlord as well as a friend and colleague, will blow over.

When asked whether Mr Hague intended to respond to calls for him to investigate, a Tory spin doctor said sarcastically: "The answer is he is not taking any action in the wake of the Guardian's amazing story."

Rich's company, Marc Rich & Co, was labelled the "No 1 embargo buster" in the 1980s by the anti-apartheid Amsterdam Shipping Research Bureau.

Mr Duncan has dismissed allegations that he was involved in the trade as "malicious and false", although he has declined to answer detailed questions in public.

Documentary evidence published in yesterday's Guardian and copied to Mr Duncan were concerned with shipments of Brunei crude oil which ended up in South Africa.

Mr Duncan says the documents were copied to him by mistake. The fuel was sold by a Brunei company to a Japanese trading house and then sold on to Rich who chartered tankers to take it to South Africa where he was paid up to 80% above the market price.

Vincent Cable, the Liberal Democrats' trade and industry spokesman, said: "Serious allegations have been made and they require serious answers from the Conservatives."

Denis MacShane, Labour MP for Rotherham, said: "Until such time as Alan Duncan has given a full and frank account of his work for Marc Rich in the period when Mr Rich was one of the FBI's most wanted fugitives, it would be advisable for Mr Duncan to consider his position as a shadow front bench spokesman."

Mr Duncan is no stranger to controversy. He was forced to resign in 1994 as a ministerial aide after just 17 days when it emerged he acquired a £190,000 council house by advancing £140,000 to a neighbour who qualified for a £50,000 discount under the Tories' right-to-buy policy.

webTitle: Kiley is given free rein on tube

fields.headline: Kiley is given free rein on tube
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Livingstone's London
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Greater London authority
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has personally intervened to defuse the crisis over the future of the London Underground in the run-up to the election by giving Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner Bob Kiley a free hand to make a deal with the companies bidding to take over half of the tube.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has personally intervened to defuse the crisis over the future of the London Underground in the run-up to the election by giving Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner Bob Kiley a free hand to make a deal with the companies bidding to take over half of the tube.

Mr Kiley has been appointed chairman of London Transport, following meetings with the prime minister and John Prescott, with full authority to negotiate changes to the government's public-private partnership (PPP) scheme to give him unified management control of the underground.

The surprise announcement follows weeks of conflict over the part-privatisation plans - with Gordon Brown blocking agreement between Mr Prescott and Mr Kiley - which risked spilling over into the election campaign.

It is expected that the private consortiums bidding to run track, stations and signalling will concede on Mr Kiley's demands for management control, but next month's court challenge to the imposition of PPP has not been called off.

Mr Blair said last night: "I've met with Bob Kiley, heard his concerns and have confidence in his ability to deliver a PPP which meets those concerns and ours."

Mr Prescott added that he was "delighted that we have now found a way towards unified management control within the framework of the PPP".

But Mr Kiley cautioned that yesterday's agreement was "a beginning, not an end" and said that he was not sure that "satisfactory modifications to the PPP to meet my concerns are possible".

Referring to Mr Prescott's announcement of preferred bidders for two sets of deep lines on Wednesday, he said it was a move with which he had disagreed: "But I have agreed with the government to give it my best effort."

webTitle: Shirley Williams on missile defence system

fields.headline: In bed with Bush
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair could lead a European response to the US missile defence scheme

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Liberal Democrat party
fields.trailText: Tony Blair could lead a European response to the US missile defence scheme, argues Shirley Williams.
fields.body:
On July 12 1947, Ernest Bevin, the British foreign secretary, responded to a speech US secretary of state George Marshall had made on June 5, in which Marshall promised to consult with the Europeans about the American proposal to reconstruct the war-torn continent. Bevin had immediately called a meeting in Paris under his chairmanship, where 16 European countries agreed on a combined reply.

Bevin laid before the Truman administration a detailed plan for European cooperation, to be administered by a new organisation called the Organisation for European Economic Cooperation, the OEEC. Without Bevin's initiative, Marshall's speech might have remained just an unfulfilled aspiration. With the united response Bevin had engineered, Washington had no choice but to take Marshall's proposals seriously. So the hugely successful post-war Marshall Plan was launched.

Today a similar opportunity exists for a British prime minister and foreign secretary to bring together the countries deeply affected by American plans for missile defence, both European allies like Germany and Denmark, and former antagonists like Russia. The purpose is of fateful importance - to save and update the fragile network of multilateral arms agreements and arms control mechanisms that have helped to keep peace between nuclear powers for 50 years.

Within that network, a missile defence system directed against states attempting to threaten others could add to international security. Outside it, and in particular if a unilateral missile defence bypassed such existing treaties as the 1972 ABM treaty, the world could become much more dangerous.

The US has, for 60 years since Pearl Harbour, been the foundation of western defence, the "indispensable nation" to use the phrase of the former secretary of state, Madeleine Albright. The responsibilities shouldered have been fully discharged. During the cold war, the US led the successful western strategy of containing, and then undermining, the Soviet Union, without any direct military clash.

The end of the cold war not only changed the nature of the military threat, to include terrorism, civil war, the building of missiles and other weapons of mass destruction by fanatical states outside the ambit of the cold war powers. Combined with globalisation - the opening of closed borders to trade - it has brought a whole range of new challenges, organised crime, drug-resistant disease, Aids, people-trafficking, and made us aware of others, like climate change. None of these challenges can be countered by military responses. They require multilateral responses, and those need trust between nations.

The danger of the Bush proposal is that essentially it is unilateral in tone. As his spokesman put it, it is the responsibility of the US to lead, and of the allies to follow. But that cannot be the basis of a successful multilateral peacekeeping structure. Are we to have genuine consultation, about a scheme not yet set in stone?

In his cautious parliamentary replies on Wednesday, Tony Blair spoke of studying US proposals in detail, and of making sure that "whatever different views there may be are reconciled not just here but everywhere". He specifically referred to Russia. It is a great pity that the nuances of those answers were not reflected in the remarks of Alastair Campbell, headlined by the Tory press to suggest total UK compliance with the US. For this is the most important foreign policy decision for years.

President Bush indicates that he favours a multi-layered missile defence system, which would breach the ABM treaty so seriously that it is hard to see what could be rescued from its remains. Yet missile defence is not technically proved, and it may take years to construct an accurate system. US estimates suggest, at the earliest, three or four years for the first stage. So what will protect the world from proliferation in those years? At the very least, existing arms control systems should remain in place, respected by those who signed them, until they are updated.

Missile defence undermines the credibility of deterrence systems relying on small numbers of warheads. China has only 20 nuclear warheads at present, and is clearly tempted to embark on nuclear rearmament. Both Russia and China have threatened in the past to "mirv" their warheads.

China has been particularly sensitive about space-based missile defence, which she would regard as a reason for building anti-satellite weapons. The hitherto peaceful use of space has provided satellites for telecommunications, climate monitoring and much else of huge value to the human race. The consequences of militarising space are incalculable.

Weakening the network of arms control systems also weakens the constraints on new nuclear states to abide by the non-proliferation and test ban treaties. And there is the danger of developing a Maginot line mentality, setting up defences against last year's threat of missiles from North Korea and Iraq, when the threat of weapons of mass destruction delivered in suitcases and boxes, in particular biological weapons which require no missiles to disrupt the infrastructure of modern industrial states, is at least equivalent.

The UK and Denmark are hosts to crucial early warning and listening stations. They are, in a sense, therefore, complicit to any American decision to abandon the ABM treaty. No wonder that Blair laid so much stress on Russia, a Russia that does now seem willing to engage cooperatively in a new structure of arms control and defence. But it is depressing that the Bush administration has recently cut the funds allocated for securing and protecting Russia's huge arsenal of decaying nuclear weapons and fissile materials.

Nevertheless, the elements of a new multinational arms control system are there. Bush has declared his willingness to reduce dramatically the number of US strategic nuclear warheads. Brought within the Start 2 Treaty, which both the US Congress and the Russian state duma have ratified, that would be a good first step. Russia is willing to cooperate on early warning systems and a common missile defence. European countries are desperate to retain existing measures to contain nuclear proliferation and nuclear testing. President Bush himself referred to "common responsibilities, common defence" in his speech on Monday.

The development of a missile defence system could mean disaster for an interdependent world; or it could mean a huge opportunity to build a new international structure capable of keeping the peace in a post-cold war world dazzled by technology but desperately in need of political answers. We need a new Ernest Bevin. How about it, Tony and Robin?

 Shirley Williams is Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman in the Lords.

No wonder that Blair laid so much stress on Russia, a Russia that does now seem willing to engage cooperatively in a new structure of arms control and defence. But it is depressing that the Bush administration has recently cut the funds allocated for securing and protecting Russia's huge arsenal of decaying nuclear weapons and fissile materials. Nevertheless, the elements of a new multinational arms control system are there. Bush has declared his willingness to reduce dramatically the number of US strategic nuclear warheads. Brought within the Start 2 Treaty, which both the US Congress and the Russian state duma have ratified, that would be a good first step. Russia is willing to cooperate on early warning systems and a common missile defence. European countries are desperate to retain existing measures to contain nuclear proliferation and nuclear testing. President Bush himself referred to "common responsibilities, common defence" in his speech on Monday. The development of a missile defence system could mean disaster for an interdependent world; or it could mean a huge opportunity to build a new international structure capable of keeping the peace in a post-cold war world dazzled by technology but desperately in need of political answers. We need a new Ernest Bevin. How about it, Tony and Robin?  Shirley Williams is Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman in the Lords. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Pain from Spain
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Telefonica's 5% stake in Pearson, owner of the Financial Times, has been an irritant in recent weeks.
fields.body:
Telefonica's 5% stake in Pearson, owner of the Financial Times, has been an irritant in recent weeks.

Every time the share price gets going, rumours that the Spanish telecoms company has hired Goldman Sachs to place the stock with City institutions knock it back down.

This happened again yesterday. Pearson shares ended 5p lower at £14.23 after a report in El Pais, the Spanish newspaper, that Telefonica is preparing to divest the stake as part of a restructuring of its internet and media operations.

The telecoms company will, according to the report, use its annual general meeting at the start of June to provide the market with details of the shake-up.

Pearson shareholders would undoubtedly welcome the clearance of the overhang, even if it meant some short term pain while the stock was digested.

webTitle: OFT inquiry threatens BSkyB deal with NTL

fields.headline: OFT inquiry threatens BSkyB deal with NTL
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Speculation is growing that the long-term deal struck between BSkyB and NTL for carriage of all Sky's main channels is coming unstuck.
fields.body:
Speculation is growing that the long-term deal struck between BSkyB and NTL for carriage of all Sky's main channels is coming unstuck.

The office of fair trading has recently requested further information from the two companies, nine months after the agreement was submitted for approval.

Analysts believe a negative response could give a heavy hint to the result of the broader investigation under the Competition Act into the pricing of Sky channels to other platforms, such as ONdigital.

The investigation into the possible abuse of the broadcaster's dominant position in the market was launched by the OFT in December last year. A result was expected next month and is now likely to appear after the general election.

A clause in the deal with NTL caused it to lapse earlier this year - neither side had expected the OFT investigation to take so long.

A BSkyB spokesman said: "The agreement remains in place subject to regulatory approval and the parties have extended the time frame in which they are seeking to obtain that approval."

The deal between BSkyB and NTL, announced in September last year, agreed a pricing structure for the supply of Sky channels over five years. The deal was trumpeted as a "win, win" agreement, providing BSkyB with certain revenues and NTL with better pricing.

BSkyB's rival platforms have complained that it charges prices for its premium channels, such as Sky Premier and Sky Sports, that make it difficult to generate a return.

The platforms arguments may be weakened, however, as they begin to launch an increasing number of their own channels. ONdigital, soon to be renamed ITVdigital, is launching its own ITV-branded sports channel to coincide with the start of the next football season.

BSkyB will next week announce a shake up of its Open interactive TV subsidiary, which is likely to result in heavy job losses. It will slash costs at the division by integrating it into the parent company. But the Open brand is unlikely to be ditched in the short term and the interactive shopping mall is also expected to survive.

John Florsheim, who runs Open, will take the helm of a combined interactive division at BSkyB, but John Swingewood, director of new media at BSkyB, is leaving the company.

At its third-quarter results on Wednesday, BSkyB is expected to announce subscriber numbers have reached 5.3m.

webTitle: No libel in lookalike porn advert photo

fields.headline: No libel in lookalike porn advert photo
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A high court judge ruled yesterday that the possible confusion between "Miss E", a well-known glamour model, and Ms O'Shea, did not amount to a libel.
fields.body:
When Kerry O'Shea's friends opened the Sunday Mirror on five occasions last summer, they were surprised to see what appeared to be her latest career move.

An advertisement for an adults-only website had a picture of a woman holding a telephone who, Ms O'Shea believed, looked uncannily like her.

But a judge at the high court ruled yesterday that the possible confusion between "Miss E", a well-known glamour model who posed for the photograph, and Ms O'Shea, who had nothing to do with it, did not amount to a libel, despite Ms O'Shea's argument that her friends had seen the picture and believed she was working as an online porn model.

In an important test case for newspapers and broadcasters, Mr Justice Morland said it would put "an impossible burden" on publishers if they had to check for lookalikes in such photographs.

Ms O'Shea, 24, claimed that the advert gave the impression she was "performing on a highly pornographic website containing material of an explicit, indecent and lewd nature, and had shamelessly agreed to promote this website".

But the judge said MGN Ltd, publisher of the newspaper, and Free4Internet.Net could not be held responsible for her doppelganger. Photography and filming played a big role in modern journalism and publishers could not be expected to check for doubles of every compromising image.

"Examples are legion: unlawful violence in street protest demonstrations, looting, hooliganism at football matches, people apparently leaving or entering court with criminal defendants and investigative journalism into drug dealing, corruption, child abuse and prostitution."

The fact that no claim in respect of a lookalike picture had been brought until now indicated that there was no pressing need to apply the law in this area, he said. Ruling in Ms O'Shea's favour would be an "unjustible interference with the vital right of freedom of expression".

webTitle: ITV in turmoil as Richard and Judy defect

fields.headline: ITV in turmoil as Richard and Judy defect
fields.standfirst:
Era ends as jubilant Channel 4 signs king and queen of daytime television

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Era ends as jubilant Channel 4 signs king and queen of daytime television.
fields.body:
In the television equivalent of David Beckham signing for Manchester City, Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan announced their defection to Channel 4 yesterday with a deal that stunned their chiefs at ITV.

The husband and wife team, who turned celebrity chat and pseudo-psychotherapy on This Morning into a driving force in British television, said simply they wanted to "try something different" after 13 years with the main commercial network.

As Channel 4 gleefully paraded their star signings yesterday, recriminations were under way. Granada, which makes the show, and the ITV network, which commissions it, failed to explain how they had allowed the stars to slip through their fingers months after alarm bells had begun to ring. The couple had put out feelers to rival broadcasters, including Sky and the BBC, at the beginning of the year.

Madeley and Finnigan denied that their decision to leave ITV was precipitated by tension with a new controller of daytime programmes at the ITV network: Madeley said the reports were "crap". But he revealed that the couple had not even considered a new offer from Granada; instead, they told their employers of their decision to leave only yesterday morning.

Licking their wounds, ITV executives insisted that This Morning would go ahead without the presenters. They are now left with the task of replacing the king and queen of daytime TV - the crown prince and princess are John Leslie and Fern Britton, who present This Morning on Fridays.

The defection of Madeley and Finnigan marks the end of an era in daytime television. This Morning became an institution after it imported US-style sofa chat at a time when daytime TV consisted largely of repeats of 1970s Australian soap operas.

This Morning's mix of celebrity interviews, health and gardening features and agony-aunt advice made it compulsive viewing for its target audience of mothers and retired people. The presenters' endearing naffness and endless gaffes made them cult viewing for students.

Their cult status was boosted when Madeley performed a convincing - if embarrassing - impression of Channel 4's spoof rapper Ali G, and scaled new heights when Finnigan's dress slipped to reveal her bra at the National Television Awards last year.

It was sealed when the impressionist Alistair McGowan spoofed them on his BBC show.

Their arrival at Channel 4 marks a new stage in the channel's evolution from a minority broadcaster to a mainstream channel. Their new programme, Richard and Judy, will be a "topical entertainment show" airing five nights a week. Channel 4 will almost certainly deploy it at 5pm, a slot in which it is being hammered by the Weakest Link on BBC2.

The pair insisted they would not "turn trendy" for Channel 4 - Madeley said he would not speak in Ali G-style rap and his wife would not be dressing in leather.

Tim Gardam, Channel 4's director of programmes, described Madeley and Finnigan as "unquestionably the best in their field".

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: The US slowdown is making Chancellor Gordon Brown's boast of an end to boom-and-bust look increasingly hazardous. Already many manufacturers are cutting back on investment and jobs.
fields.body:
The US slowdown is making Chancellor Gordon Brown's boast of an end to boom-and-bust look increasingly hazardous. Already many manufacturers are cutting back on investment and jobs.

Faced with an economic downturn, marketing and advertising are the first things many firms cut. Accountants have never been convinced about the value of spending on advertising and brands and so don't think there is much to lose by cutting back.

Also, cutting media budgets is a lot easier than firing staff and it can be done quickly.

But the evidence suggests reducing brand support can be costly in the long term. Compared to the US or even France and Germany, the UK has few powerful brands. Consultants Interbrand show that there are no British representatives among the world's top 40 brands. We don't have any Coca-Colas, BMWs or Luis Vuittons. The only British name in the list of the top 50 most valuable brands is the oil company BP.

One of the reasons for our lack of powerful, desirable international brands is that British companies rarely provide consistent invest ment support for them. A recent survey found that marketing and advertising are the first costs managing directors and financial directors would cut in a slowdown.

The inevitable result is that when the economy subsequently swings out from recession British brands have lost much of their appeal. This is what happened to once great British names such as Rover, Schweppes and Jaeger. When these companies needed to boost short-term profits they curtailed investment in brand development and support. The results were that the brands became dated and consumers shifted their preferences to competitors with more up to date images such as BMW, Coke and Armani.

Just because sales do not immediately drop when marketing spending is cut does not mean it has not worked. Brand support is an investment and, like all investments, the pay-off is long term.

Powerful brands generate shareholder value by creating barriers that prevent competitors stealing their market share.

Even more important, they build price premiums that lead to higher margins and cash flow. Leading brands typically sell at prices 40% higher than weak or unbranded competitors.

Brand support works by confirming consumers' choices. Advertising gives them confidence that their favourite brands remain high quality, up-to-date and still worth paying that little bit extra for.

When marketing is cut, these barriers are allowed to erode and price premiums come under pressure. Competitors with new brands or lower prices are allowed a beach-head into the market. Once the loyalty of consumers to the tra ditional brands is lost it is virtually impossible to win it back.

The result is a decline in the long term value of these businesses. Typically a 1% annual decline in the market share and the price premium of a leading brand would, over a five-year period, halve its value to shareholders. This explains why announcements of cuts in marketing spending generally lead to a fall rather than a rise in the company's share price.

Professional investors understand that while firms that aggressively cut marketing in a recession may increase their short term profits, the cost is usually a permanent erosion in their ability to generate long term cash flow.

 Peter Doyle is professor of marketing & strategic management at Warwick Business School. Email him at P.Doyle@Warwick.ac.uk

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: David Poole: Director, Singer & Friedlander  Investment Management
fields.trailText: David Poole: Director, Singer & Friedlander  Investment Management.
fields.body:
What was your first career aspiration?

To be a vicar.

What has been your best moment in management?

Successfully launching and project managing Singer & Friedlander's first AIM venture capital trust in 1998-99.

And your greatest mistake?

Singing at the office party.

How would you describe your management style?

Generally "laissez faire". Good people don't need close supervision.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Launch a Healthcare Fund at the bottom of the market in 1990.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Their constant raids on my, sorry our, biscuit tin.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

Professed ability to forecast events when everyone knows we can only react to or ride with them.

What is the biggest challenge facing your organisation?

Retaining and building a powerful identity when all around us businesses are constantly merging.

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Be creative, show initiative.

Which management guru do you believe in?

George Soros, who once worked here.

Who is your management hero?

Sir Alex Ferguson and, no, I'm not a Man United supporter.

Who is your favourite politician?

Michael Portillo.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

Deter young, dynamic companies from selling up too quickly.

Do you have a view on British membership of the EMU?

We must participate in cross-border trade, but beware of ceding fiscal/civil autonomy.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

"Sure".

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Finding a quiet moment in a beautiful spot and remembering what it's all about.

What annoys you most?

My inability to do two consecutive late nights and still be civil.

How do you relax?

Tinkering on the piano and guitar and singing nursery rhymes to the children.

What was your last cultural experience?

Standing outside a mosque in Dubai as the service began.

What is your favourite city?

Adelaide.

Do you have a favourite website ?

Tesco.com - that frees up time for other things.

What is your greatest regret?

Not buying a sports car before we had children.

What is your biggest fear?

Taking things for granted, and then it's too late.

What would you really like to have been?

After watching Popstars, and Posh and Becks on Red Nose Day, perhaps my original aspiration was not such a bad one!

fields.headline: Truth and reconciliation
fields.standfirst:
Europe's verdict shows Ulster needs both

Special report: human rights in the UK
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Conservatives and unionists were bound to find it hard to accept a verdict from the European court of human rights that 10 IRA men shot dead by security forces had had their human rights violated.
fields.body:
The response was not difficult to predict. Conservatives and unionists were bound to find it hard to accept a verdict from the European court of human rights that 10 IRA men shot dead by security forces had had their human rights violated. In their view it was simply "perverse": how could the court give £10,000 compensation to each of the families of the IRA men - terrorists whose victims would have received no such reparation? What kind of madness is this, when a court rewards killers as if they were innocents? No wonder the Conservatives demanded an instant appeal. No wonder the unionist leader David Trimble confessed himself astonished.

But the judgment in Strasbourg bears closer examination than those instant reactions suggest. For a start, as the Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid, was quick to point out, the court has not said the killings of the men - including the eight slain by an undercover SAS unit during an IRA ambush on a police station at Loughgall - were themselves unlawful. Nor has the court told the British state that it had no right to defend itself; nor has it established the principle that IRA men can kill with impunity, but that to kill them is to violate their human rights. These are all distortions of the court's actual and discrete ruling.

What the court has condemned is the state authorities' failure to investigate the deaths properly. It accepted the families' argument that the subsequent inquest into the SAS ambush was flawed: there was no legal aid for relatives, no compulsion on the soldiers who fired the shots to give evidence and the notorious "public interest immunity certificates" were used to mask state activity. These tainted the legal investigation and so deprived the dead men of their rights. That is the relatively narrow point the court has made: it did not, as yesterday's critics charged, either condone terror or question Britain's right to resist it.

For all that, the security forces should be seriously discomfited by this decision. Why were those investigations so inadequate? Would the state have worked so hard to keep the full facts from coming out had they not had something to hide? In other words, do not these four separate cases, involving the deaths of 12 people between 1982 and 1992, weigh as troubling evidence of the long-alleged shoot-to-kill strategy pursued by the security forces in Northern Ireland? Isn't this what prevented full investigations, and the consequent violation of human rights?

"So what?" reply the more honest critics. Even if the security forces had operated such a policy, they say, that was their right: they were, after all, in a war against ruthless terrorists; they were doing nothing the IRA would not have done had the tables been turned. And there is the rub. For we expect the agents of our state to be better than mere terrorists. If the IRA shoots people on sight, rather than bringing them to trial, then that is their way. But it cannot be the way of the British army or the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Least of all in cases like these, where the authorities had ample evidence against the men who were shot: they should have been arrested, not killed.

This week Martin McGuinness admitted his past in the IRA. Now Strasbourg has offered its own reckoning with a piece of the Northern Irish past. These are helpful steps, but they merely underline the need - when the province is ready - for a process akin to South Africa's search for truth and reconciliation. For now, both qualities remain in tragically short supply.

It accepted the families' argument that the subsequent inquest into the SAS ambush was flawed: there was no legal aid for relatives, no compulsion on the soldiers who fired the shots to give evidence and the notorious "public interest immunity certificates" were used to mask state activity. These tainted the legal investigation and so deprived the dead men of their rights. That is the relatively narrow point the court has made: it did not, as yesterday's critics charged, either condone terror or question Britain's right to resist it. For all that, the security forces should be seriously discomfited by this decision. Why were those investigations so inadequate? Would the state have worked so hard to keep the full facts from coming out had they not had something to hide? In other words, do not these four separate cases, involving the deaths of 12 people between 1982 and 1992, weigh as troubling evidence of the long-alleged shoot-to-kill strategy pursued by the security forces in Northern Ireland? Isn't this what prevented full investigations, and the consequent violation of human rights? "So what?" reply the more honest critics. Even if the security forces had operated such a policy, they say, that was their right: they were, after all, in a war against ruthless terrorists; they were doing nothing the IRA would not have done had the tables been turned. And there is the rub. For we expect the agents of our state to be better than mere terrorists. If the IRA shoots people on sight, rather than bringing them to trial, then that is their way. But it cannot be the way of the British army or the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Least of all in cases like these, where the authorities had ample evidence against the men who were shot: they should have been arrested, not killed. This week Martin McGuinness admitted his past in the IRA. Now Strasbourg has offered its own reckoning with a piece of the Northern Irish past. These are helpful steps, but they merely underline the need - when the province is ready - for a process akin to South Africa's search for truth and reconciliation. For now, both qualities remain in tragically short supply.

webTitle: Net gain Nokia boost for troubled Psion

fields.headline: Net gain Nokia boost for troubled Psion
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Beleaguered hand-held computer maker Psion yesterday won a ringing endorsement for its mobile internet platform from Nokia.
fields.body:
Beleaguered hand-held computer maker Psion, which produces netBooks for schools, yesterday won a ringing endorsement for its mobile internet platform from Nokia, the world's biggest mobile phone company.

Jorma Ollila, chief executive of the Finnish firm, predicted that half of all the phones it builds by 2004 will be based on Epoch, the operating system created by Psion.

The prediction, combined with a trading statement saying revenues for the first quarter were ahead of last year, boosted Psion shares 26% to 129.5p. Its shares have fallen sharply over the past year, during which time it recorded its first loss in 10 years.

Chief executive David Levin, speaking at Psion's annual meeting, said that trading at its core Teklogix business remains on track despite the economic downturn in the US. Teklogix, a maker of hand-held industrial devices, has become Psion's largest division.

fields.headline: Knives out for SRA chairman
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Sir Alastair Morton's position as chairman of the strategic rail authority was under fresh attack last night after he irritated ministers by complaining that the government was not investing enough in railways.
fields.body:
Sir Alastair Morton's position as chairman of the strategic rail authority was under fresh attack last night after he irritated ministers by complaining that the government was not investing enough in railways.

Lord Macdonald, transport minister, was said to be angry that Sir Alastair had voiced his displeasure at the Commons transport select committee earlier this week.

Lord Macdonald is particularly annoyed because he is one of the main architects of the government's 10-year strategy for the railways in which the chancellor has promised a £60bn investment.

Government sources said yesterday that ministers were upset with Sir Alastair's comments and his suggestion that more money would now have to come from the public rather than the private sector.

The sources said that Sir Alastair's disenchantment with government policy was becoming untenable and that a replacement would have to be found for him after the election.

No serious candidates have emerged although several names, including that of Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Trains, have been mentioned. Sir Alastair's departure would be likely to be closely followed by that of Mike Grant, his chief executive, and a close colleague who worked with Sir Alastair at Eurotunnel during the building of the Channel tunnel 10 years ago.

The original plan was to allow Sir Alastair to resign as soon as he had presented his much delayed strategy for the industry, an issue which has aroused considerable criticism, particularly among train operating companies.

But if Labour is re-elected, Sir Alastair would not be expected to enjoy such a good understanding as he has had with John Prescott, who is widely tipped to be replaced by Jack Straw.

Government sources said that Sir Alastair would almost certainly be replaced before he had a chance to present his strategy, due in September but which may not be ready until November. Mr Prescott's successor,it was said, would not be prepared to wait that long.

Lord Macdonald is also upset at what the government regards as a failure by Sir Alastair to reach a decision on who gets the new franchise for the east coast main line between Edinburgh and London.

The decision should have been made last month but GNER will have to wait until after the election to hear whether the SRA has awarded it a new franchise to operate the line.

GNER and Virgin Trains are in a head to head to obtain the franchise, but the SRA which has to make the formal decision cannot make up its mind.

Mr Prescott promised a quick decision last month, but knows that the SRA could face a legal challenge from either company if the decision goes against them.

Rail industry sources said that the SRA was likely to fudge the decision by allowing GNER to operate the franchise for a few more years while it called on potential operators to present plans for new 120-mile high speed rail route linking the north and the south.

webTitle: Merrill Lynch pulls plug on internet fund

fields.headline: Merrill Lynch pulls plug on internet fund
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Investment group Merrill Lynch yesterday showed how even the most successful of stock pickers have been hit hard by the implosion of the dot.com bubble, by pulling the plug on an internet fund that has lost more than $800m (£556m) in just over a year.
fields.body:
Investment group Merrill Lynch yesterday showed how even the most successful of stock pickers have been hit hard by the implosion of the dot.com bubble, by pulling the plug on an internet fund that has lost more than $800m (£556m) in just over a year.

The Internet Strategies Fund, which opened with $1.1bn in investors money two weeks after what turned out to be the peak of the technology laden Nasdaq market in the US, has lost 80% of its value in 13 months.

The residual $215m capital will now be rolled into Merrill's Global Technology Fund, which invests in a broader range of technologies than just the internet.

"It has become apparent that the internet is now so integrated into other technologies that it is no longer the sub-sector it was 13 months ago," said Christine Walton, a Merrill Lynch spokeswoman.

"Given market conditions over the past couple of months and the change in the way internet companies are valued we thought it would be better to give investors broader exposure to technology."

The Global Technology Fund has lost about half its value over the past year, even though it was invested in "conservative" tech stocks.

The Nasdaq composite has fallen by 42% over thesame period. The TechMark in London is down 44%.

Merrill Lynch is far from the only investment house to see the value of its internet-related fund slump.

Several internet funds run by smaller houses have been liquidated, and with an estimated 30 separate net funds remaining, analysts are predicting further write-offs.

Perhaps the most famous internet investment fund disappointment in Britain has been Framlington's NetNet fund. By April it had lost 75% of its value and was rated one of the worst performing funds in the UK.

Having raised £60m from investors, plus a further £40m in debt, it had less than £8m in assets left last month.

webTitle: How an Indian collared the Thai business

fields.headline: How an Indian collared the Thai business
fields.standfirst: Atique Choudhury had a lot on his plate when the chefs walked out of his parents' restaurant. But, as Martyn Seal discovered, it gave him the start he needed
fields.trailText: Atique Choudhury had a lot on his plate when the chefs walked out of his parents' restaurant. But, as Martyn Seal discovered, it gave him the start he needed.
fields.body:
There are few things more frustrating in business than having your good idea copied by a competitor. In fact the only thing more frustrating is having your staff filched by the same copy cat.

So imagine how frustrated Atique Choudhury's parents were back in the 80s when that's what happened and three chefs walked out of their south Indian vegetarian restaurant in north east London. With a keen interest in the restaurant business Atique was thrown in at the deep end and asked to run the kitchen.

"The staff were offered ludicrous amounts of money in the short term to build up the competitor's business," he remembers. "So it was very difficult, but these are the pitfalls of business, and it's how I got my training as a chef. It gave me the ability to run a kitchen and our business was gradually built back up."

It was his big break into catering and it's gone on to be the business that has seen him running a top chain of Thai restaurants called Yum Yum.

Atique's interest in the food business was first seen when he set up a tuck shop that rivalled the school canteen.

"I knew from a young age that I'd be in business. I had quite an enterprising mind, I learned how to build an operation and how you make a profit out of a deal.

"When I was young I remember running the school tuck shop. That was a great project, we built it up and then got told off for being too good at it, since we were taking business away from the school canteen."

His entrepreneurial knack is a talent that runs in his family. His vegetarian mother spotted the potential in opening a vegetarian Indian restaurant and Atique, after running his own Indian restaurant, soon spotted the potential of opening a Thai restaurant well before they became a common sight on the high street.

"When I took over the Indian vegetarian restaurant Thai people used to work for me, preparing dishes.

"They were very good at presentation and had good knowledge of the diversity of ingredients and the kinds of taste that could be made. At that time Thai food in this country was in its infancy. So my wife and I decided to open a Thai restaurant together which we did in 1990.

"The name Yum Yum came from one of my favourite dishes, a Thai salad with chillies, lime and coriander. The response was crazy from the start, we were incredibly successful. We had complaints that people could never get into the restaurant because it was always full."

Because of its popularity by 1992 he had converted his existing south Indian vegetarian restaurant into another Thai.

So what was his secret? "What I did was make Thai food accessible with good descriptions of the food and at a good price. At that time people weren't aware of exactly what the Thai menu meant. We made the surroundings and atmosphere less pretentious than many other places, I wanted a relaxed environment and somewhere people would find the experience of eating fun."

He's gone on to establish a Thai internet cafe. But setting up successful eateries wasn't his only venture. Having left school to go straight into work he returned to education after his businesses were running to do a level four NVQ in restaurant management.

And doing this he realised what useful training these courses could be, allowing those participating to understand and work through difficulties that crop up in catering. He also discovered that there was no NVQ specifically for Asian restaurants.

"I got my training on the job, but I realised how useful a qualification like this could be. The Asian food business has a massive turnover and I thought this would bring more professionalism to it, make students think and ask questions such as how is your business to be structured, how do you manage staff, how do you deal with customer complaints."

He chaired a project called "breaking the log jam" set up by the hotel and catering training foundation which has now established the new NVQ.

And expansion will come from the creation of even more niches.

"You'll have restaurants set up specialising in regional tastes. Different parts of Thailand have totally different dishes, seafood dishes, vegetarian dishes so there'll be more emphasis on variety rather than just one menu," he says.
