fields.headline: US jobs carnage gathers pace
fields.standfirst:
Recovery hopes dashed as unemployment rises more than 200,000
Special report: Global recession
fields.trailText: Recovery hopes dashed as unemployment rises more than 200,000.
fields.body:
Hopes that the US economy was on the mend were dashed yesterday after official figures revealed it is shedding jobs at the fastest rate since the last recession.

Nearly a quarter of a million Americans lost their jobs last month, as firms slashed the size of their worforces in an attempt to restore profitability. The 223,000 fall in non-farm payrolls pushed unemployment up to 4.5%, from 4.3% in March, the highest rate since October 1998.

"The number is certainly a lot weaker than anyone was expecting," said Scott Brown, chief economist at Raymond James and Associates, in St Petersburg, Florida. "We're right at the edge of the precipice and it looks like we're starting into the downward spiral."

In Britain, company insolvencies soared in the first three months of the year, providing fresh evidence that the US slowdown is hurting the UK. The number of companies going bankrupt rose to 4,455, a 12.7% rise on the same period last year, according to figures from the Department of Trade and Industry.

Some analysts had suggested last week that the worst was over for the US economy after the government released stronger than expected estimates for growth in the first three months of the year. But optimism evaporated in the wake of yesterday's figures.

Economists fear rising unemployment could prove the final straw for America's debt-burdened households, leading to a sharp slowdown in consumer spending, which has powered the 10-year expansion.

"If consumers hunker down, then the trough to the growth cycle could be quite deep," said Matthew Wickens, from ABN Amro, adding that a recession was possible.

Speculation that the weaker than expected state of the labour market could prompt a further round of interest rate cutting by the US Federal Reserve cheered up investors who had reacted with initial alarm to the figures.

John Canavan, analyst at Stone & McCarthy, said the numbers increased the chances of another rate cut at the Fed's next meeting, on May 15. "We see the Fed cutting 50 basis points on May 15 to 4% - and that's not the end," said Mr Canavan. "We believe we will see 3% later in the year."

The Dow Jones industrial average of leading shares erased a 60 point opening drop, gaining 54.52 points, or 0.5%, by midday to stand at 10,851.17.

"It's been a very muted pullback," said Guy Truicko, equity portfolio manager at Unity Management. "The market is looking forward and seeing a Fed cut in a couple of weeks, perhaps a trough in earnings this quarter and perhaps better business conditions in the second half."

Wall Street's rebound helped reverse fortunes for London share prices. The FTSE 100 ended up 104.5 points or 1.8% at 5,870.3 after spending a volatile final hour of business tracking New York markets.

webTitle: Patient treated for rabies after dog bite in Philippines

fields.headline: Patient treated for rabies after dog bite in Philippines
fields.trailText: Doctors are treating a suspected case of rabies at a London hospital, the public health laboratory service (PHLS) confirmed last night.
fields.body:
Doctors are treating a suspected case of rabies at a London hospital, the public health laboratory service (PHLS) confirmed last night.

The patient, who is described as seriously ill, was bitten by a dog while travelling in the Philippines and became ill when he arrived in the UK.

The unidentified patient is undergoing treatment while doctors await the results of tests to confirm the disease, a PHLS spokesman said.

Cases of rabies in humans are rare in the UK. The last indigenous case was in 1902 and since 1969 only 12 people are believed to have been treated for the disease after contracting it abroad.

While the laboratory service says it is not "a massive public health issue", medical staff treating the patient will be offered immunisation as a precaution.

The only recorded human to human transfer has been as a result of a corneal transplant operation.

The disease, which is transferred through contact with saliva through bites, scratches or broken skin, has a very low survival rate after symptoms appear.

The PHLS said: "Rabies affects the central nervous system and the brain. It is usually fatal, but those who do survive, often survive with disabilities.

"The symptoms are anxiety, a headache and a fever, followed by a spasm of the swallowing muscles leading to ultimate paralysis."

There are around 40,000 cases of rabies reported each year, almost entirely in developing countries.

The PHLS said anyone travelling in the developing world should take immediate action if they were bitten by an animal. A spokesman said: "People have to be aware of this and the sooner you can seek medical attention the better."

Vaccines are available for people who are at risk of contracting the disease and these vaccines can be effective if given to people shortly after they have been bitten by a dog or any other animal.

But if it is left for too long there is no other treatment for the disease.

fields.headline: Portraits of an artist
fields.trailText: Why are theatre programmes so awful? I went to see Feelgood at the Garrick this week, and enjoyed it, though I resented paying £3 for a programme which was packed with material I didn't want to read.
fields.body:
Why are theatre programmes so awful? I went to see Feelgood at the Garrick this week, and enjoyed it, though I resented paying £3 for a programme which was packed with material I didn't want to read. Worst of all are the mini-biographies of the cast, which consist only of lists of the plays, films and TV shows they've appeared in. Who cares that they were once in Richard III at the Yelverton Festival, or that "TV credits include Heartbeat and Kiss Thy Neighbour"? They should tell you what you really want to know, and reflect the questions people are whispering to each other during the first act.

"Yes, she did play the wife of the abusive don in that Inspector Morse," it would read, "you know, the one about the college servant who was pushed downstairs. And you might have seen her as the nosy neighbour in The Larkins Of Lark Rise. She also came on as a supply teacher on Grange Hill a few years ago, but if you blinked, you'd have missed her..." Or, "you're right, he's the bloke who always plays really bad-tempered old geezers, like Victor Meldrew only without the easy charm. He was in that sitcom, No Laughing Matter, but of course they ended it in mid-run it was so bad..."

Alternatively they should make the mini-biog into a proper profile. "Susan Bastable is famous as one of the whiniest, most self-obsessed people in the profession. She never stops banging on about her four cats, and God, if she ever does get a part you never hear the end of it. I mean she was a nurse in Holby City recently, and if she was on the screen for more than six seconds I'd be surprised. Then she actually started boasting that she was inside the giant Twix costume in that chocolate ad, I actually had to leave the room I was giggling so much..."

Or, "His camp manner conveniently conceals the fact that Cecil Transigent is one of the most notorious shaggers ever to walk into the Garrick Club. Not safe in taxis? He isn't safe in a crowded restaurant. Once a stage hand banged on his dressing room door and shouted: 'Twenty minutes, Mr Transigent!' and he replied, 'yes, not bad for a man of 62, eh?'"

I'd pay a fiver for that.

 Do other cities have middle-class beggars? The other day I was in Mayfair, when a fairly smartly dressed woman came up. She had a proper handbag, and she wore old-fashioned glasses, giving her a studious look. When she approached I assumed she was a tourist. Then she said, in a well-modulated but neutral accent: "Excuse me, would you mind giving me some money, so that I can buy something to eat?" She gave me a polite little smile, much as if she'd just inquired the way to Green Park tube. I was so startled that I gave her 73p, which is what I had in change. It would be nice to report that I spotted her five minutes later heading into Claridge's restaurant, though I didn't, and I suppose she's no less likely to have spent it on drugs than those shaggy men under piles of grubby sleeping bags.

Apparently the airhead - "gosh, I'm so silly, I've just lost my car keys, and I can't get home, I could really kick myself, please could you let me have something towards a taxi?" - is quite a common figure in the streets these days. That's a scam, but the woman I met was perfectly straightforward about what she wanted.

 There's something quite biblical about the nation's recent afflictions. The great floods of last year and the pestilence on the land would both have been recognised as old friends by the Israelites and the Egyptians. Even the failures of the Dome and the new Wembley Stadium bring us echoes of those sacked and crumbling palaces, stone symbols of power dethroned. Now the tabloids are obsessed by the vanishing British bosom. This started with Geri Halliwell losing weight and taking on the appearance, below the neck anyway, of a 12 year old boy. Then last week Denise Van Outen, the television star who has just joined the cast of Chicago, said that all the dancing and frolicking had reduced her once superb embonpoint to an A-cup. Pictures suggest that Martine McCutcheon's bosom has more or less disappeared and there's a lot less of Liz Hurley and Carol Vorderman than there used to be.

Sir James Frazer, author of The Golden Bough (1890), the world's greatest work on anthropology, would have known the significance of shrivelled bosoms. It's up there with impotence and infertility. They're another plague. These things matter even today; they have resonances which we don't always fully realise or appreciate. See Eliot's The Waste Land. For instance the fact that Tony Blair has recently fathered a fourth child, while the younger William Hague has yet to produce one, does count in some atavistic way. Well, it might be good for three parliamentary seats, anyhow.

 I was sorry to see that Striker, the brilliant, almost 3-D, football comic strip in the Sun, is now sponsored by Richard Branson. His Virgin phones logo is drawn on the fictional players' shirts, and he appeared this week as a character in the strip, nicely sketched, looking calm and friendly in the face of aggression. I don't know how much he's paying, and it is only a cartoon, but will the Sun now be just as eager to tell us about the latest Virgin Rail disaster, or to reveal the problems of another Branson company?

 Some years ago I used to run a Greaser Of The Week feature in the parliamentary sketch, though I stopped it when we seemed to be getting 17 good candidates per day. The Macallan malt whisky wanted to sponsor this, as Smoothie Of The Week, and give the winner a bottle. I was outraged, but I suspect that this kind of thing may soon be commonplace - the Ford motoring column, for instance, or the Equitable Life financial report.

I went to see Feelgood at the Garrick this week, and enjoyed it, though I resented paying £3 for a programme which was packed with material I didn't want to read. Worst of all are the mini-biographies of the cast, which consist only of lists of the plays, films and TV shows they've appeared in. Who cares that they were once in Richard III at the Yelverton Festival, or that "TV credits include Heartbeat and Kiss Thy Neighbour"? They should tell you what you really want to know, and reflect the questions people are whispering to each other during the first act. "Yes, she did play the wife of the abusive don in that Inspector Morse," it would read, "you know, the one about the college servant who was pushed downstairs. And you might have seen her as the nosy neighbour in The Larkins Of Lark Rise. She also came on as a supply teacher on Grange Hill a few years ago, but if you blinked, you'd have missed her..." Or, "you're right, he's the bloke who always plays really bad-tempered old geezers, like Victor Meldrew only without the easy charm. fields.headline: Indonesia's new woes
fields.standfirst:
Ousting Wahid will not solve them

Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Growing pressure within political circles in Jakarta to oust Indonesia's president, Abdurrahman Wahid, does the country no favours.
fields.body:
Growing pressure within political circles in Jakarta to oust Indonesia's president, Abdurrahman Wahid, does the country no favours. Mr Wahid's performance since he won office in the autumn of 1999 is open to justifiable criticism. Although the economy has recovered some ground since the crash of 1997, with exports up thanks in part to higher oil revenues, the country remains saddled with large debts and vulnerable to currency fluctuations. A laudable programme to devolve central government powers amassed during the Suharto years has increased this sense of flux.

Instability and occasional bursts of outright revolt in Indonesia's more far-flung territories, such as Aceh, continue to challenge Javanese rule. Ethnic and inter-communal violence, for example in Kalimantan, on Borneo, between native Dayaks and Madurese immigrants, has repeatedly exposed government weakness and indecision. The process of bringing to justice those responsible for violence in East Timor before and after the independence referendum in 1999 (and of Suharto himself, on corruption charges) meanwhile continues at a snail's pace.

Mr Wahid has been personally derelict in spending too much of his presidency abroad, in appearing disdainful of parliament and in getting himself entangled in two separate financial scandals. But all the same, he cannot sensibly be held responsible for all of Indonesia's ills after so many years of virtual dictatorship and the brief, hapless reign of BJ Habibie. In voting to censure him for a second time last week, and thus increasing the likelihood of impeachment, opposition MPs appeared to want to heap all the country's problems at his door. Nor, in demanding a sacrificial head, do his critics seem to have given much thought as to who and what could follow.

The favourite to succeed Mr Wahid, should he fall, is his vice-president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, who commands the largest parliamentary faction. Many felt in 1999 that she was robbed of the presidency. But since accepting the number two job, her public performance, too, has been less than inspirational. If she has a vision for Indonesia, she has kept it to herself. She says little and does less. In recent months, she has notably failed to back Mr Wahid, thereby encouraging his opponents. As the neighbouring Philippines recently, painfully, discovered, destroying a presidency is much easier than constructing a shared future.

fields.headline: Capital letters
fields.standfirst: Got a problem? We want to hear about it. Get in touch with Tony Levene here at Jobs & Money and we will try to help
fields.trailText: Got a problem? We want to hear about it. Get in touch with Tony Levene here at Jobs & Money and we will try to help.
fields.body:
In 1994 I bought shares in Helene plc. In 1997 I received a letter from the chairman announcing the company had requested the cancellation of its share listing. I have heard nothing since. Is the company still in existence? If so, even though it is no longer listed, do I still not own a small part of it?
JS, Norfolk

Sadly all you own is a share of nothing. The company went into compulsory liquidation in November 1997. As a shareholder, you came last in any distribution of assets. If you want more details, contact Henderson Matthew Purdon, 23 Queen St, Edinburgh EH2 1JX. But your certificate could help you establish a capital loss to set against any capital gains tax.

 Since I stopped working, I have been paying Class 3 National Insurance contributions. Should I?
JB, Lancashire

Class 3 NI payments, currently £6.75 a month, are "voluntary". They are paid by those who may work largely out of the country or who have chosen to give up work and live on their savings. They give entitlement only to widow's benefit and the basic state pension. They need no longer be paid if you have "home responsibilities protection" - looking after a child or an invalid. If your NI contribution record has huge gaps already, you might do better to bank the money.

 I am a divorced mother of four children, three of whom are still dependent on me. Until the Married Persons' Allowance was abolished I received this as the children lived with me and my ex-husband was not in work. But I can't get the new Children's Tax Credit because my partner (who is not the father of my children) is just in the top tax bracket and was therefore to be the person to sign the form and receive any benefit. It is unjust and discriminatory. Child Benefit is paid to the mother as a matter of course, not to the natural father.
DR, Manchester

The government claims it would be too difficult to pay a credit to a partner who may not be working as it is paid through the income tax system. But there is a more significant unfairness. Both parents can earn just under the higher rate threshold (around £34,000) and receive the full rate on a £68,000 household income. But if there is one earner only, bringing in more than around £43,000, the benefit is lost.

 I'm 27, earn more than £30,000 per year, have no debt, around £6,000 in savings and always pay off my credit card at the end of the month. I was a student for seven years (I have a PhD); since then I've had three professional jobs in three years in three locations. I can't get a mortgage. Why?
CI, London WC2

You've fallen for a mortgage catch 22. You can't have a home loan because your address keeps changing; yet you cannot have a stable address because you can't get a loan. Your job pattern is very common for academic posts and many others. One solution is to go for some form of self-certification mortgage but you would need a minimum 25% deposit for most schemes. Sun Bank says it has a loan which might help. Another idea would be to approach a specialist mortgage broker - try any who advertise in publications aimed at university lecturers.

 We welcome letters but cannot answer individually. Write to: Capital Letters, Jobs & Money, the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or email jobs.and.money@theguardian.com. Do not send original documents but do enclose a daytime phone number. Information is general and offered without any legal responsibility. Always take professional advice if in doubt.

webTitle: When tartan fur flew over Wembley

fields.headline: When tartan fur flew over Wembley
fields.trailText: Digger: Vivek Chaudhary uncovers the stories behind the news
fields.body:
It always makes for an interesting conversation when two Scots get together and disagree over an important issue. So it was on Tuesday morning when Derek Casey, the chief executive of Sport England, the organisation that distributes sports lottery money, arrived at the Football Association's headquarters in London's Soho Square to speak to his counterpart Adam Crozier.

You may recall that Sport England gave the £120m of lottery money towards buying the Wembley site to construct a new national stadium.

Casey, however, had just got wind of the fact that the FA was about to announce a few hours later that it was effectively pulling the plug on the project by refusing to be the sole financial backer. What resulted was a furious row in Crozier's swanky office, with the two fiery Scots exchanging opinions, as well as a few insults no doubt.

Casey told Crozier that he felt betrayed and let down. He also expressed his complete surprise at the FA's decision to ask the government to intervene, given that the feedback Sport England was receiving from the City was that the banks were on the verge of investing in the project.

Casey also complained that Sport England had not been consulted over the FA's decision and that different ways to finance the stadium had not been examined.

Crozier's response was to tell Casey that he wanted to explain to the public the FA's exact position on a new national stadium and that the matter had nothing to do with Sport England.

Still, there's nothing like burying the hatchet, particularly with one's fellow countryman.

Casey and Crozier have now shaken hands and made up, both pledging to work together for a new national stadium. Ahhhh!

"They eventually had a meeting of minds. They are both passionate Scotsmen who believe in what they are doing," said a source.

The ministerial working group led by the home secretary Jack Straw, which is now examining the Wembley project, was also brought together a few months ago to prepare a report into next year's Commonwealth Games in Manchester.

The report has now been completed and passed on to No10. According to those who have seen it, it paints a damning picture of financial irregularities in the organisation of the games and also points out a number of concerns that the 2002 Commonwealth Games might in fact be a financial flop.

Manchester council has underwritten the event and the city's ratepayers may be asked to make up any shortfall in revenue.

Tony Blair is currently digesting the report's contents and some harsh words are about to be said to the Manchester organising committee.

Wembley, Dome, the Commonwealth Games . . . the list just grows and grows.

Overheard 'They are still interested in moving to the Dome,' - a Greenwich council official claiming that Arsenal still want to move to south London . . . I Fought the Law and the Law Won (the Clash), Money, Money, Money (Abba), Money for Nothing (Dire Straits) and Taxman (the Beatles) - songs blaring over the sound system before Brighton's home game against Chesterfield on Tuesday night . . . 'I quite like going to Wembley' - home secretary Jack Straw.

A case of perfect timing Ken Bates, once chair of Wembley National Stadium Ltd, ironically held a farewell dinner with his former staff on Tuesday, the day the project hit the buffers.

fields.headline: Service without a smile
fields.trailText: I am unconvinced by Charlotte Raven's defence of the desultory (Why I am grateful for service with a scowl, G2, May 1), where she claims that studied surliness among those in service occupations is excusable.
fields.body:
I am unconvinced by Charlotte Raven's defence of the desultory (Why I am grateful for service with a scowl, G2, May 1), where she claims that studied surliness among those in service occupations is excusable because they have higher things on their minds and better things to do.

I see no evidence to suggest that were "Devon" not shackled to the check-out (or, indeed, Charlotte not marooned in the supermarket queue), they would be grappling with an ingenious proof in superstring theory, developing a recipe for world peace or writing penetrating sociological analyses. More likely, they would, like the rest of us, be down the pub, sprawled in front of the telly or engaged in other kinds of shopping.

It may be better to see reluctant service and the indifferent treatment of customers as the products of our continued false equation between service and servility, as well as the decline of duty and sense of personal humility in favour of a manufactured individualism, obsession with personal gratification and over-inflated sense of self- importance. Where, before, we would accept that most endeavours involved some measure of the necessary but mundane, yet got on with it and gave it our best shot anyway, now we simply couldn't be arsed, on the spurious assumption that we were destined for higher things.

This is depressingly evident in my own "service" profession among those academics who disdain all contact with students as a dreary distraction from their "work".
Prof Colin Hales
Guildford, Surrey
c.p.hales@talk21.com

 I have always been ambivalent about adopting US "enjoy" standards of service. But after spending just 36 hours in Moscow, it was interesting to read Charlotte Raven.

Landing in Heathrow at midnight on Saturday - after a four-hour flight and a three-hour delay at Moscow - I was greeted by the receptionist at one of the airport hotels who smiled at me, said I looked tired, and advised me to have a quick drink at the bar before going to bed. For one awful moment I thought I was going to cry. Granted, this may say more about me than Moscow, but I think this is the first time that good service has almost moved me to tears.
Adam Legge
Bristol
adaml@dircon.co.uk

 Charlotte Raven's operator, was just rude, not displaying some mythical, noble quality known only to us Britons. Surely she has tried buying a ticket on the Paris metro? The supermarket and fast-food outlet, with the phoney "enjoy your meal", are imports from America. Years ago, small shops were centres of gossip and staff always knew their regulars. I can remember, as a child, there was always laughter in butchers' shops.
John Munson
Maidstone, Kent

 Our willingness to accept shoddy service comes from identifying ourselves as consumers rather than customers. The consumption of the goods Charlotte Raven bought was probably more satisfactory than the process of buying them. If not, she has significant consumer-protection measures for redress. We are sadly short of customer-protection measures.
Dr Paul Dawson
Brighton

fields.headline: Report condemns Israeli expansion
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A US-led investigation into the causes of the Middle East conflict calls for Israel to halt the illegal expansion of Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza.
fields.body:
A US-led investigation into the causes of the Middle East conflict calls for Israel to halt the illegal expansion of Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza.

The big increase in settlements over the last decade, often provocatively placed on hilltops overlooking Palestinian towns and villages, is one of the biggest causes of Palestinian hatred of Israelis.

Draft copies of the former US senator George Mitchell's report have been handed to the Israelis and Palestinians for comment before a final version is published later this month.

Mr Mitchell and his team have been deliberately even-handed in order to avoid fuelling high tensions.

Palestinians blame the start of fighting on the visit by Ariel Sharon to the holy site known to Arabs as the Noble Sanctuary and to Israelis as Temple Mount. The report says the visit was not the direct cause but a contributing factor.

There was more disappointment for the Palestinians when Mr Mitchell rejected their call for an international observer force to protect them from the Israeli army.

In a further piece of juggling, the report calls for the Palestinians to stop firing at Israelis from civilian areas and urges Israelis to show restraint when returning fire to avoid excessive injuries to civilians.

The Palestinian information minister, Yasser Abed Rabbo, said the document gave a "firm and clear rejection of all settlement activity".

Although the Israeli government insists it has imposed a freeze on new settlements, it is encouraging the expansion of existing ones. The Palestinians say this is taking place even though there are empty flats and houses in the existing settlements and the Israeli government is finding it increasingly hard to get people to go to the West Bank and Gaza.

Violence continued yesterday when four Palestinians wanted by Israel were injured in an explosion in the West Bank. Palestinian sources said they were members of the Islamic militant group Hamas who were carrying a bomb that went off prematurely.

Elsewhere on the West Bank, there was trouble at flashpoints that have almost become a Friday ritual, such as a roundabout in Ramallah and the old city of Jerusalem, where Palestinians threw rocks at Jews praying at the Western Wall below.

webTitle: Little General gets marching orders on trip to Disneyland

fields.headline: Little General gets marching orders on trip to Disneyland
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: The "Little General" who is being groomed to inherit North Korea's communist dynasty was unceremoniously kicked out of Japan yesterday after he tried to sneak into the country with his family for a trip to Tokyo Disneyland.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts  in Tokyo and John Gittings  in Seoul
fields.body:
The "Little General" who is being groomed to inherit North Korea's communist dynasty was unceremoniously kicked out of Japan yesterday after he tried to sneak into the country with his family for a trip to Tokyo Disneyland.

Kim Jong-nam, his wife, son and another relative were deported to Beijing three days after immigration officials at Tokyo's Narita airport detained them for attempting to enter Japan on false passports. The Japanese government refused police requests to press charges and sent the illegal immigrants to China without formally identifying them.

There is little doubt, however, that the 29-year-old man at the centre of all the attention is the eldest son of North Korea's "Dear Leader," Kim Jong-il. TV footage of the departure showed a man closely resembling the north's leader. Portly, balding and wearing gold-rimmed spectacles, the deportee sauntered with great self-assurance from the security van to the jet that was taking him out of the country.

According to Japanese media reports, immigration officials had been tipped off about Kim Jong-nam's arrival with two women and a child, believed to be his wife, four-year-old son and another relative. When they questioned him, he admitted buying the forged passport for $2,000 (£1, 300) and revealed his identity.

He told investigators that he planned to take his family to Tokyo Disneyland, saying he had been there once before in his teens. This revelation is an embarrassment for Japan, which has hostile relations with North Korea. According to South Korean media, Kim Jong-nam has been a member of the north's intelligence services for almost two years.

Yet it appears that he has secretly visited Japan on numerous occasions. The forged Dominican passport showed that he entered the country twice in the past 12 months alone.

If revealed in North Korea, Kim Jong-nam's planned Disneyland vacation is unlikely to go down well at a time when millions face starvation.

His father, however, may be more understanding. The Dear Leader has hinted that he travelled overseas incognito on several occasions. As an aficionado of Hollywood films, the older Kim may also empathise with his son's apparent passion for American-style entertainment.

Some Pyongyang-watchers suspected that Japan had deliberately leaked news of Mr Kim's illegal entry to weaken North Korea's position in future negotiations.

fields.headline: Arts revolt grows
fields.trailText: Gerry Robinson has proved himself a great champion of the arts, and we are all thankful for that. But "the current arts funding system does not work" (Letters, May 3) is a curious claim.
fields.body:
Gerry Robinson has proved himself a great champion of the arts, and we are all thankful for that. But "the current arts funding system does not work" (Letters, May 3) is a curious claim.

The arts funding system has been working since the days of Maynard Keynes. It has constantly evolved. There is much to its credit, but it must constantly adapt and improve. Whether a "single organisation", a monolith with regional offices controlled from London, would be an improvement on the present regional arts boards is a questionable proposition. The local authorities, which provide half the funding of the arts across the country, appear to have no place in it, save in some marginal advisory capacity. As a national system for funding the arts what Gerry Robinson proposes simply won't work - which is not to say that further change and development is not necessary. But please, let's work it out together.

By the way, our staff are not "bureaucrats". They are arts developers, promoters, supporters and brokers: an active role adding value to what the government, the arts organisations and the artists are trying to achieve.
Robin Guthrie
Chair, Yorkshire regional arts board

 It is utterly disingenuous to argue that merging the regional arts boards under the arts council will "allow greater regional influence on national policy". The effect, like that of all centralisations, will be precisely the opposite. London will ensure that, by "speaking with one voice", there is precious little difference between the strategies of England's very diverse regional cultures.

There is no evidence that his model would cut costs, bureaucracy or the time it takes arts organisations to be granted public money. The current system does not work because the arts council of England is loth to let the regional arts boards do their job. Too many schemes and programmes are dictated from the centre as the arts council tries to justify its continued existence in a form inconsistent with the principle of subsidiarity.

Regional arts boards are far better placed than the arts council (even with regional offices) to participate in regional forums, negotiate with local authorities and monitor the quality of work that they fund. There is a fundamental difference between the philosophies of regional accountability and central policy enforcement and no amount of superficial spin will reconcile them.
Robert Maclennan MP
Liberal Democrats spokesman on culture

fields.headline: Life on Mars
fields.trailText: According to the Lib Dem councillor Mark Williams (Letters, May 1), his colleague Zev Lieberman, the Lib Dem crook who is in jail for electoral fraud in Hackney, is a victim of an oppressive system of justice.
fields.body:
According to the Lib Dem councillor Mark Williams (Letters, May 1), his colleague Zev Lieberman, the Lib Dem crook who is in jail for electoral fraud in Hackney, is a victim of an oppressive system of justice.

The argument, and Williams is not the only person to advance it, is that Lieberman is in prison because of a conspiracy that involved the home secretary, the law officers, the crown prosecution service, the Met, special branch, the trial judge, the jury and journalists on the Jewish Chronicle, the Guardian, the Independent, the Daily Telegraph and the Hackney Gazette - oh, and the 31 MPs who signed an early day motion condemning the fraudsters.

Oh and by the way, the Martians are coming!
Brian Sedgemore MP

fields.headline: It may safely be asserted
fields.standfirst: 180 years old and still going strong...
fields.trailText: From The Prospectus announcing the publication of a new paper, The Manchester Guardian, on Saturday May 5, 1821, price sevenpence.
fields.body:
"It may be safely assumed that no former period in the history of our country has been marked by the agitation of questions of a more important character than those which are now claiming the attention of the public. To any one who regards, for a moment, the conflicting views and wishes of the commercial and agricultural interests - the considerations which may arise out of the existing laws for the regulation of our currency - the present and anticipated pressure of the national debt and of taxation - this statement will be sufficiently apparent.

But there are other subjects, of greater and more permanent importance, which the circumstances of the times are forcing upon public attention. The effect of the great diffusion of education within the last quarter of a century, is attested by the greatly increased interest which political subjects excite, and the immense extension of the circle within which they are discussed. It is of the utmost importance that this increased in terest should be turned to beneficial account; that it should be made effective in promoting all those ameliorations in our laws and political institutions of which experience has proved the necessity, and in fixing upon a broader and more impregnable basis the fabric of our liberties.

Though the concerns which relate to the internal prosperity of this country must always be of paramount consequence to its inhabitants, foreign politics will now be a subject of anxious observation. The friends of freedom everywhere must watch, with intense anxiety, the progress of those efforts which several continental states, as well as others in the New World, are now making to free themselves from the incumbering pressure of antiquated and despotic governments."

fields.headline: Beyond petroleum
fields.trailText: With their construction of the country's two most important pipelines, BP's subsidiaries in Colombia (ODC and Ocensa) have left a desolate human and ecological drama, still unresolved after 10 years.
fields.body:
With their construction of the country's two most important pipelines, BP's subsidiaries in Colombia (ODC and Ocensa) have left a desolate human and ecological drama, still unresolved after 10 years. This was not mentioned in your excellent articles on BP (Pipeline row dents BP's new image, April 19).

Three hundred and fifty small-holding peasants from Zaragoza and Segovia lost their livelihoods with the large-scale disturbance of the land, which contaminated water supplies and eroded the soil on their farms, making it infertile. The companies are offering derisory compensation of $3,000. Today the peasants are in ex treme poverty, going hungry, without land to cultivate, without education and without basic public services. Meanwhile, Colombia is BP's fifth most profitable country. A number of peasant families have been forced to migrate as displaced people to cities.

The companies have always evaded their responsibility. We call on all sectors of British society to communicate with us, to express your solidarity in this affair and to demand an immediate solution from BP.
Marta Hinestroza and Carlos Sanchez
Lawyers on behalf of the peasants, Medellin, Colombia
Csanchez71@Yahoo.com

webTitle: Letters: Curse of the thinking class

fields.headline: Curse of the thinking class
fields.trailText: Your article on French reactions to the latest lay-offs by M&S, Danone etc (Where le fairplay still counts, May 2) misses two points.
fields.body:
Your article on French reactions to the latest lay-offs by M&S, Danone etc (Where le fairplay still counts, May 2) misses two points. First, though unemployment is falling, it is falling from a much higher level than in UK, and most ofthe "new" jobs are almost all created by the state.

Second, your analysis omits the completely different social reception of unemployment in both countries. While the "idleness of the able-bodied" is still an acceptable argument in the moralist debate of Britain, les chomeurs and les defavorises are among the heroes of French life, looked upon as homeowners are over here. And for those in employed work, le boulot is mostly seen as an obstacle to the pursuit of happiness in an out-of-work world, where hobbies tend to be intellectual and cultural, rather than manual and traditionalist (such as DIY and gardening).

You might argue that such a piece of social thought has no place in the finance section of a flagship national broadsheet. However, if even the Guardian is not able to cater for out-of-box interpretations, one might as well read the FT.
Ralf Nocker
Visiting research fellow, Birkbeck College, London
rnocker@econ.bbk.ac.uk

 Though wrought-ironing "Work makes you free" over a concentration camp entrance (Letters, May 3) was presumably an early instance of the famous fascist sense of humour, the notion itself, to at least one of the involuntarily unemployed, seems intellectually respectable and may even be true.
James Leigh
Thornton Watlass, N Yorks

fields.headline: Death row
fields.trailText: The "execution tapes" of 23 prisoners electrocuted in the state of Georgia between 1983 and 1998 included, according to your report, two that "went wrong" (Taped executions broadcast on New York radio, May 3).
fields.body:
The "execution tapes" of 23 prisoners electrocuted in the state of Georgia between 1983 and 1998 included, according to your report, two that "went wrong" (Taped executions broadcast on New York radio, May 3). This would make "going right" the application of 2,400 volts into the body of a prisoner strapped to a chair by state officials employed to coldly and deliberately kill a fellow human being.

What is actually wrong - as your editorial (Brutality gets an airing, May 4) pointed out - is that the US is still allowing the calculated cruelty of the death penalty.
Kate Allen
Director, Amnesty International UK

webTitle: Go hang Florida passes sentence on notorious chads

fields.headline: Go hang Florida passes sentence on notorious chads
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The state that became synonymous with electoral bedlam in the five weeks between presidential polling day last November and George Bush being declared the winner adopted reforms yesterday that will banish the infamous hanging chad.
fields.body:
The state that became synonymous with electoral bedlam in the five weeks between presidential polling day last November and George Bush being declared the winner adopted reforms yesterday that will banish the infamous hanging chad.

Florida's senate and house of representatives agreed a deal aimed at banning punch-card ballot machines and replacing them with optical scanning systems or touch-screen computers.

"I think it's worked out very well," said Jeb Bush, governor of the state and the president's brother.

"We're going to have a single standard for the state, high-quality machines, absentee ballot reform and recount standards that are clear and easy."

Hanging, dimpled and pregnant chads - the pieces of cardboard that are meant to be removed to indicate a voter's preference - were a focal issue in the post-election weeks, as it became clear that thousands of votes had been discarded.

About 180,000 ballots were set aside in Florida, either because of undervotes - no choice could be discerned - or overvotes, where more than one candidate was selected.

Democrats complained that the new laws, allowing $24m (£16.7m) for new machines and more to train poll workers, retain recounts by hand in the case of close elections.

The Republican party fought against hand recounts in numerous court hearings.

"All the things we were attacked on before, like manual recounts, all of a sudden they are the biggest supporters," said Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

"If we had the manual recounts a year ago, Al Gore would be in the White House."

But Kay Albowicz, communications director for the National Association of Secretaries of State, said: "This would be one of the most comprehensive electoral reform packages that have been passed."

Many bills have been drawn up to address reform in the six months since election day but only Georgia has put its plans into action before Florida, and the president's budget for next year includes no funds to tackle the issue.

While attention was directed at Florida, one study showed that even more ballots - 190,000 - were discarded in Illinois. Many experts believe that few reforms will be in place in time for the country's next important elections, in 18 months' time, or even the next presidential poll two years after that.

fields.headline: Sneaking Sony through the alley
fields.standfirst: Interview Howard Stringer, chief executive, Sony Corporation of America
fields.trailText: Interview Howard Stringer, chief executive, Sony Corporation of America.
fields.body:
A day after our lunch, Howard Stringer phoned to say that he had found a magazine article about the 10 most famous Brits nobody has ever heard of. "I'm there, on the list," he said, rather proudly. "Alongside a world-class drugs dealer and the head of Mossad."

Most people in America's media industry have heard of Howard Stringer. As head of Sony Corporation of America, he is responsible for all the movies and music produced by the electronics and entertainment colossus.

During a 30-year career as a journalist and producer with CBS, the US television network, he won several awards and was inducted into the Broadcasting and Cable Hall of Fame. Two years ago, he won a humanitarian award for his contributions to charity.

Yet, such was the surprise when he was knighted in the Queen's honours list just over a year ago that several British newspapers hinted at skulduggery. One even suggested that his contributions to the Labour party - about £5,000 - had paid for his gong.

Oxford-educated Stringer gives the impression of not caring very much about his lack of a public profile in Britain. He happily admits that his younger brother is far more famous than he is, though Rob Stringer is perhaps better known as the partner of Julia Carling than as the head of Sony Music UK and backer of B*Witched.

Only once, when he was in the running for the top job at the BBC in 1999, did this perfect example of a global citizen - a Welsh-born naturalised American working for a Japanese company - have cause to rue the fact that he is little appreciated at home. He had to endure several stories along the lines of "Howard who?" - one even suggested that he did not have enough broadcast experience for the job after a career in US television.

As the head of Sony's American operations his star has been in the ascendant in recent weeks.

The company's decision not to launch a portal or set up a dot.com division has looked shrewd rather than stupid during the dot.com collapse. Although profits have been hit in the past two years by the problematic launch of PlayStation 2, the early part of this year has seen signs of a turnaround as Sony Pictures enjoyed record box office success with films such as Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and the Wedding Planner.

In March, Stringer had the chance to revel in some public schadenfreude during a debate on prime time television. He poked fun at the internet craze as well as his Japanese masters and the audience, full of bitter former webheads, loved it. "After three years of being patronised by the dot.coms, I suddenly found myself back in vogue," he said. "And it was a lot of fun."

At the annual gathering of the world's movers and shakers in Davos, Switzerland, earlier this year, Stringer was even credited with marking a turning point in the development of 21st century corporations. During one panel discussion in which Bill Gates and other hi-tech supremos talked about the ever-wired future, Stringer jumped up and said: "Doesn't anyone here think this sounds like a vision of hell? While we are all competing or dying, when will there be time for sex or music or books? Stop the world, I want to get off."

Emily Susskind, the head of Sony's US broadband services group, described this outburst as "quintessential Howard".

Stringer likes to call himself an accidental corporate executive. "I'm not an MBA corporate," he said. "I don't sit around thinking about how to make everybody rich."

Yet, during his time at Sony, he has significantly reorganised the management team and helped to bring cohesiveness to a company that has always struggled to connect the disparate parts of its empire.

His present role has its limitations. While the media and technology worlds were being upended by the likes of AOL and Time Warner, Sony struggled to play catch-up in key areas such as the internet and mobile communications.

Nobuyuki Idei, head of the Sony group, has indicated that "soft alliances" are the way forward for the company and two weeks ago it announced a $500m (£348m) joint venture with mobile phone group Ericsson.

This strategy can be frustrating for a US chief executive officer looking to enhance his company's position in the world's largest market. To fill the company's need for a distribution outlet, for example, Stringer contemplated a bid for DirecTV, the US satellite broadcaster now in takeover talks with Rupert Murdoch. Sony baulked and the idea was dropped.

Investment bankers question the group's strategic direction. Without the equity base to bulk up or the cash flow to spend on expansion, they argue that it will be left behind in the race for the consumer's home and heart.

Stringer believes that Sony has shown that style and pace can win the day. "As always with Sony, we're sneaking through the back door," he said of the new Clie hand-held just launched to rival the market-leading PalmPilot. Sony, which eschewed the personal computer industry as a business tool, now sells the fastest growing computer in the Vaio.

The company is also placing its bets on broadband as the route to ubiquitous use of its movies, games and music.

Stringer inspires a great deal of loyalty from outside as well as within the company. Several of New York's media power brokers readily return calls when asked to talk about him. Tom Brokaw, the television anchorman, describes a funny and thoughtful friend. "I have never known anyone who has so successfully lived in two cultures. Several friends also questioned his self-image as a corporate outsider. Herbert Allen, the investment banker who hosts the annual star-studded retreat at Sun Valley, said: "Apart from having a great sense of humour, he is one of the most talented media executives in the business. I don't know anybody who isn't a fan of Howard Stringer's."

A consummate networker, Stringer lists writer Nora Ephron and TV host Charlie Rose as his friends. He sat next to Jennifer Lopez at a post-Oscars party and drops the name "Paltrow" during one mobile phone conversation. In his panoramic office is a large bronze of a rodeo cowboy inscribed: "To Howard, The only network executive I can hang out with and still love," signed by Burt Reynolds.

The gregarious raconteur is a rarity among the ranks of senior Japanese executives. Even Stringer's physique - 6ft 3in and once fair curly hair - stands out among the Sony hierarchy.

'I was like Sgt Bilko'

Stringer's path to the inner circle at Sony has also been unusual. He arrived in America in 1965, looking for adventure and inspired by stories of John F Kennedy and civil rights protests.

He had not quite spent his second pay cheque as a CBS log clerk when he was drafted into the US army. This surprising turn of events led to two years' service in Vietnam.

"I was able to make myself useful enough," he said. "I was like Sgt Bilko."

He was, however, awarded a US Army commendation for meritorious achievement and won more medals, five, than his father did in 30 years with the RAF.

"You get some medals for simply showing up," he said. "And I was actually in charge of medals."

Army life ended in 1967 and he returned to the US to work as a researcher for CBS. After spending 10 months travelling across the country during one of the most exciting elections in US history, he was hooked. He rose through the ranks of CBS, before becoming president in 1988.

Asked now why he has never returned to Britain, Stringer said: "I got myself trapped in an adventure and couldn't bring myself to return too soon and prove everybody right."

Although he came from modest roots, he says he was "hardly socially handicapped" in Britain, having won a scholarship to Oundle and a place at Oxford to read history. Yet the first time he thought seriously about returning was in 1972. "I was hardly an overnight success," he said. "I was still a researcher at 30 and felt mildly suicidal."

Then he started to work on award-winning programmes and never looked back.

Stringer said an emotional farewell to broadcasting in 1995, when he left CBS to start Tele-TV. Reports at the time suggest he had grown disillusioned with the cost-cutting ways of the firm. His new venture, designed to provide home video delivery via phone lines, collapsed within two years. He describes this entrepreneurial exercise as having the same effect as being drafted. "Every time I want to be bold, adventurous and swashbuckling, it's a disaster."

Sony immediately approached him to help tackle its problems in the US, where it was struggling with huge losses from Hollywood and a great deal of internal dissent.

He evidently enjoys his job now, but admits to some regrets about the BBC interlude and to an intermittent desire to return to Britain. "The part of me that has got lost in this country is that notion of public airwaves and responsibility to the viewer," he said.

When he tells the story now, however, the 59-year-old recalls his much younger brother phoning to ask: "Why would you want all this hassle in the twilight of your career?"

Home swap

His wife, an English-born dermatologist, recently persuaded him to swap a home in the Hamptons outside New York for a country house in Oxfordshire. She would like their two young children to attend English schools.

He is constantly referred to as a Welshman in US profiles and conversation. Although he left the principality when he was four, he spent every summer of his youth there. His charitable activities and Manhattan socialising have made him as Welsh as St David's Day. His office sports at least two Welsh flags, a miniature model of Cardiff Arms Park and an award in the shape of a coal miner's lamp.

Tom Brokaw said of Stringer: "We have always believed he would go back [to Britain] at some point. That's his DNA."

Whatever imprint his youth left on him, however, he is deeply imbued with a wistfulness about his halcyon days at CBS. When he talks about the benefits of Sony's jobs for life culture or the Beeb's responsibility, he is remembering public service broadcasting in the America of the late 1960s.

"I have one foot in the past," he said. If he were to return to Britain, a corporate job to top his present one would be difficult to imagine. He is much more likely to plump for a job in public service or with a charity.

Before taking that step he has some ambitions to fulfil at Sony. "We think we can play catch up," he said. "And do it before I drop dead."

fields.headline: Chicken products recalled from sale
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Thousands more chicken products are being withdrawn from sale amid fears they contain meat that should only be used for pet food.
fields.body:
Thousands more chicken products are being withdrawn from sale amid fears they contain meat that should only be used for pet food.

Fourteen varieties manufactured by Perkins Frozen Foods were recalled yesterday following warnings from the government's food standards agency that they might be unfit for human consumption.

They include Farmfoods chicken nuggets and chicken burgers, Nisa chicken steaks and chicken and mushroom pies, and other lines marked with "best before" dates of between June and November this year.

The latest recalls mean that 29 product lines, including Shippam's and Sainsbury's spreads and two other Perkins products, have been withdrawn as the result of an investigation by Derbyshire police and food safety authorities into an alleged food scam which has so far involved the arrests of 19 people.

Perkins said the alert had been raised after it received meat from Northampton-based MK Poultry. The police are investigating allegations that it bought condemned meat from the Derbyshire-based pet food processor Denby Poultry Products before selling it on.

Denby's premises were raided in March and police are now sifting through computer files and paperwork, suggesting more recalls are possible.

David Walker, spokesman for Perkins, said many of the products could have been eaten already, although it was highly unlikely people's health had been affected.

The volume of products was "relatively small" although he could not put a value on them. "This is a sweeping-up operation to be entirely sure. It is highly unlikely only a small proportion of those [products] listed could have contained any dubious raw material. We do not know precisely enough to be sure."

Most of the lines would be sold by small shops, mostly in the north of England and in Scotland. Consumers should check their homes for such products, discard the contents and send the packaging to Perkins at PO Box 1386, Stoke-on-Trent ST4 8HX to obtain a refund.

Supermarkets have promised to refund shoppers who return recalled products to stores. The food agency, which is considering new measures to make it more difficult for any scams, said: "This is a precautionary measure, as it is unlikely that there would be any significant health risks from these products. But the agency advises against their consumption."

The recalls coincide with news that the European commission is considering legal action against Britain over the way its food industry prepares 700m chickens a year for consumption. The commission's vets declared that the authorities had not done enough to bring improvements after their devastating report last year which criticised hygiene and supervision on poultry farms and in the plants that pack Britain's most popular meat, responsible for 40% of all meat sales.

Action promised or taken by British agencies over poor lay-out of factories, separation of "clean" and "dirty" areas, unsatisfactory equipment, cleanliness and maintenance had "without any doubt failed".

The inspection team delivered a similar verdict on the failure of the British authorities both to improve official veterinary supervision of farms, slaughterhouses and packing plants, and the checks made during the killing process by industry-appointed inspection assistants.

But Britain's chief vet, Jim Scudamore, said "certain areas of the existing meat hygiene rules are unrealistic and impractical" and it was arguable whether others achieved high levels of public health protection. In a letter to the commission's health and consumer protection directorate, he said that proposals to change EU rules recognised this.

The Ministry of Agriculture said attempts to improve documentation required for imports and exports of chicken had been delayed by the swine fever outbreak last autumn and then foot and mouth.

 A list of the products recalled is available on www.foodstandards.gov.uk/

webTitle: EU scurries to contain Macedonian flare-up

fields.headline: EU scurries to contain Macedonian flare-up
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonia's latest crisis brought a flurry of diplomatic activity yesterday, with Nato and the EU deeply concerned that the country's fragile peace was blowing up in their faces and threatening wider Balkan instability.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and AP in Vaksince, Macedonia
fields.body:
Macedonia's latest crisis brought a flurry of diplomatic activity yesterday, with Nato and the EU deeply concerned that the country's fragile peace was blowing up in their faces and threatening wider Balkan instability.

Lord Robertson, the Nato secretary-general, and Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy chief, fly to Skopje on Monday to urge the Macedonian government to combine tough military action against armed rebels with real political dialogue to defuse the resentments of ethnic Albanians.

Mr Solana, consulting EU foreign ministers in Sweden over the weekend, will go on to the Kosovan capital, Pristina, to urge its Albanian leaders to restrain their Macedonian kinsmen.

"It's pretty alarming," one well-placed Brussels diplomat said last night, while Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister, spoke of his "great concern".

Diplomats said that K-For monitoring of the porous border between Kosovo and Albania had improved since the March crisis. Nato intelligence is now being passed to the Macedonian army.

EU officials also welcomed this week's offer by President George Bush to increase US bilateral economic and military assistance.

In northern Macedonia yesterday tanks rumbled over cobbled roads and helicopter gunships thundered overhead as government forces unleashed a fresh assault on ethnic Albanian rebels. There were unconfirmed reports of civilian casualties.

Military officials, waging their largest offensive against the rebels since fighting subsided in late March, accused the insurgents of holding 3,500 people, mostly women and children, as "human shields" in the towns of Vaksince and Slupcane.

A defence ministry spokesman, Gjorgji Trendafilov, said that "all available means to eliminate terrorists" would be used. He claimed that the army had inflicted "serious damage" on the rebels since the offensive began on Thursday after two of its soldiers were killed and a third abducted in a rebel ambush.

Last weekend, eight members of an elite government unit were killed in another ambush.

Yesterday, thick smoke billowed from rooftops, fields and forests on the outskirts of Vaksince, about 15 miles north of Skopje.

An army spokesman said there were no civilian casualties, but media in Belgrade and Kosovo reported two civilians killed in the fighting in Vaksince, and the mayor of Lipkovo, Hysamedin Halili, said that at least seven people had been killed there.

"It is war," he said. "The people are hiding in the basements. They are in the villages and they do not want to leave their houses."

Western monitors accused soldiers of the Kosovo Liberation Army of operating inside Macedonia and demanded their immediate withdrawal.

In a sign of how tensions have engulfed the former Yugoslav republic a hand grenade exploded in a Slav-owned cafe in central Skopje yesterday morning. The cafe was closed at the time and no one was injured, said an interior ministry spokesman.

The rebels made no statements yesterday, a day after they called for a ceasefire and talks with President Boris Trajkovski on how to prevent bloodshed and "maybe civil war".

webTitle: BT knocks a further £350m off its debt

fields.headline: BT knocks a further £350m off its debt
fields.trailText: BT yesterday continued the drive to pay down its debt pile with the £350m sale of its stake in Malaysian mobile phone network, Maxis Communications.
fields.body:
BT yesterday continued the drive to pay down its debt pile with the £350m sale of its stake in Malaysian mobile phone network, Maxis Communications.

The sale, though making only a small dent in the £30bn owed by the company, impressed investors coming as it did fast on the heels of the £4.8bn banked from two separate deals earlier this week. The disposal caps an eventful first week for chairman Sir Christopher Bland who replaced Sir Iain Vallance on Tuesday and who has made it clear he hopes to accelerate the debt reduction programme.

Sir Peter Bonfield, BT chief executive, was in upbeat mood, saying "this announcement shows yet again our determination to manage for value and is a further step forward in our debt-reduction plan".

BT has pledged to pay off £10bn of its debts by the end of this year.

On Wednesday the company agreed a deal to sell its inter ests in Japan Telecom and J-Phone for £3.7bn and Airtel in Spain for £1.1bn, both to Vodafone.

BT is also in discussions which could lead to the sale of its Yell directories business to a consortium of venture capital firms for a further £3bn. If that deal is concluded, BT will be just £2bn short of its target with seven months to go.

Shares in the company which have responded well to BT's more decisive action this week, added a further 9.5p to close at 600p. The City is still braced for a discounted rights issue from BT.

BT bought its 33% stake in Maxis in 1998 for £280m. The disposal represents a 25% profit on its original investment. It is selling the stake to its partner in the business, Usaha Tegas.

 Oftel has cleared BT of abusing its dominant position in the pricing of its internet access packages. The regulator said yesterday it found no evidence to suggest BT's pricing was anti-competitive.

The sale, though making only a small dent in the £30bn owed by the company, impressed investors coming as it did fast on the heels of the £4.8bn banked from two separate deals earlier this week. The disposal caps an eventful first week for chairman Sir Christopher Bland who replaced Sir Iain Vallance on Tuesday and who has made it clear he hopes to accelerate the debt reduction programme. Sir Peter Bonfield, BT chief executive, was in upbeat mood, saying "this announcement shows yet again our determination to manage for value and is a further step forward in our debt-reduction plan". BT has pledged to pay off £10bn of its debts by the end of this year. On Wednesday the company agreed a deal to sell its inter ests in Japan Telecom and J-Phone for £3.7bn and Airtel in Spain for £1.1bn, both to Vodafone. BT is also in discussions which could lead to the sale of its Yell directories business to a consortium of venture capital firms for a further £3bn. If that deal is concluded, BT will be just £2bn short of its target with seven months to go. Shares in the company which have responded well to BT's more decisive action this week, added a further 9.5p to close at 600p. The City is still braced for a discounted rights issue from BT. BT bought its 33% stake in Maxis in 1998 for £280m. The disposal represents a 25% profit on its original investment. It is selling the stake to its partner in the business, Usaha Tegas.  Oftel has cleared BT of abusing its dominant position in the pricing of its internet access packages. The regulator said yesterday it found no evidence to suggest BT's pricing was anti-competitive.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Money Channel runs out of cash
fields.body:
Money Channel runs out of cash

Adam Faith's Money Channel yesterday called in the administrators after running out of cash.

The personal finance television channel, backed by the 1960s singer, appointed PricewaterhouseCoopers after failing to find a buyer. It has about 30 employees and was founded in January 1999.

Shares in the company were this week suspended at 13p after earlier touching highs of 522p.

Pfizer expands its R&D centre

Drugs company Pfizer is to create 400 new jobs by building a £134m extension to its research and development centre in Sandwich, Kent, where scientists came up with the anti-impotence drug Viagra.

The project is backed by £5m of government money. It was welcomed by the pharmaceuticals industry, which had warned that increasingly aggressive animal rights demonstrations were deterring foreign investment.

Pfizer's operations in Sandwich employs 5,500 people. The site has developed four of the US group's top 10 medicines.

Laura Ashley's family cash in

Relatives of the late Laura Ashley have raised £2.7m by cashing in 11m shares in the fashion and furnishings company.

The company was rescued from bankruptcy two years ago by Malaysian industrialist Dr Kay Peng Khoo, who now owns 44% of the business.

Last month the store chain announced it was back in the black and announced expansion plans.

There are now no members of the Ashley family involved in the business, but they still own more than 57m shares - a 9.55% stake - worth nearly £14m.

Action against slave labour

The government has set up a task force to counter west African slave labour used to make chocolate bars sold in Britain.

It will involve joining forces with chocolate makers and west African governments to put a squeeze on the practice, said Foreign Office minister Brian Wilson. The announcement was welcomed by groups campaigning against modern-day slavery.

Mr Wilson announced the cocoa task force after meeting representatives of the cocoa and chocolate industries, and officials from the governments of Ghana and the Ivory Coast.

Pace cuts 470 jobs in Shipley

Pace Micro Technology is to end manufacturing at its plant in Shipley, West Yorkshire with the loss of up to 470 jobs.

The plant, which produces set top boxes for digital television companies including Sky and Telewest, will continue as an R&D operation.

The production line is being outsourced to overseas companies, possibly in the Czech Republic or Ireland.

The Shipley plant is the last part of Pace's manufacturing division still based in Britain.

Pace expects the job losses to come in the form of redundancies, voluntary departures or re-training, and has set aside £4.5m to cover the restructuring.

Shipley is Pace's biggest British operation, employing 1,200 people out of a total of 1,400 nationwide.

webTitle: Bitter all round with a couple of vitriol chasers

fields.headline: Bitter all round with a couple of vitriol chasers
fields.standfirst: Notebook: Battle of the pub landlords
fields.trailText: Notebook: Battle of the pub landlords
fields.body:
The letters page of the Publican newspaper can rarely have seen such vitriol. Two of Britain's most powerful pub landlords, Tim Martin of JD Wetherspoon, and Punch Taverns' Hugh Osmond, are hurling insults at each other in this week's edition like a pair of fishwives.

Mr Osmond takes great delight over an incident in Devon, where a Wetherspoon pub was fined for watering down its vodka. He maintains this is symptomatic of the high-pressure, under-the-gun nature of Wetherspoon's race to maintain its growth record.

Mr Martin, naturally, is unimpressed. He reckons Punch is "transient and financially driven", and suggests that Mr Osmond is out of touch with grassroots landlords.

This spat is just the latest bit of bad blood between the pair, who have clashed publicly on the Beer Orders, staff wages and on numerous esoteric quirks of Britain's unwieldy licensing laws. At one stage, Martin's mouth ran truly out of control as he described his rival as a "Vichy-style collaborator".

As multi-millionaire pub bosses go, the pair could barely be more different. Mr Osmond is on the flash side, with fast cars, slick clothes and a country estate. Mr Martin, who has shoulder-length ginger hair and a languid manner, named his pub company after the character called "JD" in the Dukes of Hazzard.

Perhaps the pugnacious duo should remember what business they are in. Heaven help the public if either of them ever goes "back to the floor" and tries to keep the peace in a pub on a Friday night.

BT bounces back

Things only seem to be going well for British Telecom, now it has a new thrusting chairman on board in the shape of Sir Christopher Bland.

Close to £5bn has been bagged from stakes in Japan and Spain, the sale of Yell.com for perhaps £3bn is clearly well advanced, as is the sale and leaseback of its property portfolio. A hugely significant decision has been taken to abandon the old City headquarters, a psychological break with the past which provides a real chance to foster cultural change. And the week was rounded off with a perfectly formed little deal to sell a Malaysian mobile stake for £350m.

Of course, all these moves must have been in train for weeks. But good, well managed news flow is important: it not only keeps the City's chattering classes quiet, it also builds staff morale and makes customers feel more comfortable.

Tot the numbers up and, yes, after all the fretting, BT is suddenly rather close to meeting that promise of bringing projected debt down from £30bn to £20bn. (Nevertheless, the property transaction does not count in the eyes of the credit-rating agencies, since the liability is ongoing.)

So even the rights issue story is looking like a reasonable piece of news management. A week ago, some were speculating that BT might have to raise up to £10bn. It is now in a position to undershoot on the consensus £5bn figure.

Whatever the figure, the company should nevertheless get a move on. Vodafone's latest market tap, raising £3.5bn, might have demonstrated the appetite for telecoms paper among the institutions, but there is also the equivalent of £5bn in Deutsche Telekom shares which are due to come loose once its takeover of America's Voicestream is completed. In short, there is already a lot of telecoms stock around and there is no guarantee that stock markets generally will remain jitter-free for long.

Phoney no longer

Yesterday's US unemployment figures were a watershed, according to one analyst. They mark the end of the phoney downturn and the beginning of the real one.

Job cutting has spread from manufacturing into the services sector - reinforcing Thursday's NAPM survey which suggested that service sector firms have joined industry in recession.

Unemployment is a lagging indicator, of course, and some optimists believe the pickup in growth in the first quarter of the year is a sign that the worst is over, but the improvement was largely driven by a fall in imports which narrowed the trade deficit.

In fact, yesterday's numbers suggest that much worse is coming down the slipway. Consumer spending was relatively buoyant in the first quarter, helping to keep the economy alive. Rising joblessness is likely to frighten US consumers, who are heavily in debt. Businesses have started cutting back on investment plans and on staff. If consumers rein in spending, the contractionary forces acting on the economy could result in a real recession not just a growth slowdown.

webTitle: The inside view: Some investors are more equal than others

fields.headline: Some investors are more equal than others
fields.standfirst: German refusal to sign the new EU takeover code would be a setback for Europewide equity ownership
fields.trailText: German refusal to sign the new EU takeover code would be a setback for Europewide equity ownership
fields.body:
All shareholders are equal. That, at least, is the theory. In reality, some are more equal than others. The authorities periodically take a bulldozer to the playing field, but they'll never get it level. This week, like any other, threw up examples of this. Tempting though it might be to let them pass without comment, my conscience was pricked by reports that Germany might welch on its commitment to an EU takeover code.

The reports are, for the moment, just that - reports. However if, as they suggest, the Germans refuse to sign up to the proposed new code, the cause of wider equity ownership in Europe will have been dealt a severe blow.

The new EU code has been years in the political and bureaucratic making. If ratified and passed into statute, it would introduce a single regulatory structure for the conduct of merger and takeover activity across the EU. It is fair to expect that this would facilitate much greater cross-border corporate activity.

There are those who argue that bigger companies are not necessarily more efficient, and they would be right.

But it seems reasonable to assume that, on average, the agglomeration of companies across Europe would generate economies of scale and operational efficiencies to the benefit of shareholders and, ultimately, the economy overall.

Germany's apparent reluctance to subscribe to the proposed code is said to represent a nationalistic fear of German businesses falling into foreign hands. No feelings of European nationhood here, then. The German equity market has long been one of the most distorted in the developed world. Riddled with cross-shareholdings between companies, subject to minimal disclosure requirements, employing accounting standards of disgraceful opacity, with a takeover regime designed to frustrate, it stands as a monument to entrenched self-interest.

Miracle model

For a while in the late 1980s and early 1990s this "model" was hailed as one of the secrets of Germany's industrial success. Now it is laid bare as a millstone around the nation's economic neck.

Germany's "miracle" was a function, inter alia, of recovery from wartime industrial obliteration, relatively late discovery in the 1980s of the benefits of a developed equity market, and then the supercharging of reunification. Now, with these exceptional factors in the past, the drag that is Germany's entrenched self-interest is clear.

The UK's takeover code is non-statutory. However, as its introduction makes clear, it is effective because of its implied sanction of exclusion from the machinery of the markets for those failing to comply with its requirements. In effect, self-policing works because the generality of market participants accepts its core objective - "to ensure fair and equal treatment of all shareholders".

Adoption of the EU code would see Britain abandon this non-statutory approach. Traditionalists might mourn the passing of the "blue book" but the prize is substantial and worth pursuing for the good of the European economy - not to mention the City of London through which much of the ensuing M&A work would flow.

If, as is also reported, the UK government is tempted to horse-trade with Germany to achieve other unrelated aims, it should desist forthwith. There is no hope of a unified European economy if issues of nationality are allowed to distort questions of ownership, or if the rights of shareholders are not policed in a transparently fair fashion.

Back at home

London is, of course, not without its xenophobes, nor its own equity market distortions. It should be remembered that the two merger proposals presented to the London Stock Exchange's shareholders were repelled with a fervour rich in nationalism. Ironically, perhaps, a single EU takeover code would constitute one more encouragement towards a single European stock exchange.

What of this week's local distortions? One stands out: the decision by software group SurfControl to adjust the strike prices of their employee and executive share options as a result of the collapse in the company's share price along with the rest of the tech sector.

Suddenly, staff have options close to the current share price rather than substantially above it. They have fewer of those options - the "price" they've paid to become reincentivised - but the bear market has been written out of their personal history books.

This practice is widespread in the US, but rare in the UK. It is controversial in both jurisdictions. One can see the benefit to SurfControl's board. By extension there may be of benefit to external shareholders. But the only way that this can be tested is for it to be presented as a proposal at an EGM. Unfortunately this is not on the agenda.

Equity ownership is by its nature a risky business. The minute these risks are reduced or defrayed for some classes of shareholders and not others the integrity of the system is called into question. Equity ownership also confers rights that all investors should fight to uphold. Someone else's outrage at flagrant market abuse might be yours tomorrow.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities
