fields.headline: In God they trust
fields.standfirst:
While Blair and Hague court the religious vote, they should be praying the rest of us will turn out

Special report: Labour party
Special report: Conservative party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: May 6, Nick Cohen: While Blair and Hague court the religious vote, they should be praying the rest of us will turn out.
fields.body:
My many friends in New Labour have urged me for years to ridicule William Hague by reporting his opportunist conversion to evangelical Christianity. Now that he is wailing about the tempora and the mores, it is easy to forget that he won the Conservative leadership in 1997 by posing as a man who might outmodernise Tony Blair. He did not then see Britain as a 'foreign land' but was content to allow his fellow citizens to find their own paths to what limited happiness was on offer.

The age of consent for homosexuals should be lowered to 16, he said, and gays should be allowed to marry. ('When they're not causing harm to other people, why should we object?') The single mothers his party had hounded in office should be cherished. ('It is better for a child to have one happy parent who cares and loves him or her than to have two and suffer from domestic violence.') Hague went to the Notting Hill Carnival in shorts and baseball cap and although he looked the saddest white rasta in town that day, his desire to show a faint solidarity with black Britons was worthy.

Many of his followers were mortified. 'Why do I share a party with those who advocate sodomite marriage?' cried Norman Tebbit as his treacherous leader abandoned bigotry. Tim Montgomerie, the director of the Conservative Christian Fellowship, warned Hague that sleeping in the same bed as Ffion Jenkins before they had been united in Holy Matrimony violated 'the Christian ideal'. Only by remaining the guardian of the 'Judaeo-Christian' tradition, he added, could the leader 'attract many Christians and others of traditional belief into the activist-hungry Tory party'.

Three years on, and Hague had undergone a conversion as profound as Constantine's. In a scene beyond satire, he addressed 8,000 ecstatic evangelicals who gathered to bother God in the Butlins camp at Minehead last year. His flirtation with homosexual rights was a schoolboy phase. He had, it transpired, been opposed to repealing Clause 28 long 'before the issue became newsworthy'. He went on to offer the righteous a deal. If they voted Conservative, he would allow religious broadcasters to catch the souls and money of viewers and listeners. 'With so much material on television no parents would want their children to see, we must give a full opportunity for Christians to put forward exciting and wholesome alternatives. The next Conservative government will ensure that Christians have the same right to national and digital licences as anyone else.'

Labour's PRs were ecstatic. Hague was admitting his weakness. He had noted that the average Tory activist was a pensioner, who was not likely, what with the lumbago and shortness of breath, to be particularly active. The Conservative leadership had been forced to take Tim Montgomerie's complaints seriously, and was wooing the energetically religious. If the price of their support was abandoning tolerance and bringing tele-evangelism to Britain, Hague would pay it.

I was disconcerted to hear condemnations of apostasy fall from the lips of Tony Blair's followers. But you can't knock New Labour every week and I wrote about the Conservative Party's sinister links with the religious fundamentalists around the American Republicans. I would happily do so again, were it not for a press release dated 3 May from Janet Anderson, the Labour Broadcasting Minister. Representatives of every mainstream religion - Christian, Jewish, Hindu, Muslim, Sikh - had met her to discuss 'whether the restrictions on ownership of national broadcasting licences by religious bodies should now be relaxed due to the greater opportunities the digital age will offer,' she said. They had received a sympathetic hearing.

The porn baron, Richard Desmond, whose websites feature Grace, a 79-year-old woman, who masturbates for the delight of the audience and asks: 'Would you like a pair of my wet panties?', is allowed to own the Daily Express (and has been courted by the Godly Hague and Blair). Rupert Murdoch is allowed to own just about everything else.

Britain's media law is hardly fastidious. Tele-evangelists may exploit the terrors of the credulous, but it's hard to argue that the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God, which owns Liberty Radio, and whose teaching that the sick are possessed by demons may have led to the horrible death of Anna Climbie last year, is more pernicious than, say, the News of the World .

The Government's U-turn on religious broadcasting would matter less were it not part of a paradoxical pattern. Britain is one of the most profane societies on Earth - thank God. Yet as faith collapses, sectarians are elevated.

You always get you into trouble when you quote statistics on worship. The devout emphasise the numbers who tick boxes in hospitals or on the census form which mark them as Anglican or whatever and talk up evidence of general spiritual yearnings. Atheists can't see how you can be a conforming Christian unless you go to church. The last issue of Religious Trends , published by Christian Research, said that a mere 7 per cent of the population attends church on the average Sunday. Its editor, Dr Peter Brierley, admitted: 'All claims that Britain is a Christian nation will finally have to be given up.' Judaism is disappearing. Despite the relatively recent arrival of black Pentecostal churches, mosques and Hindu and Sikh temples, the British Social Attitudes Survey reports that the number of respondents saying they had no religion rose from 31 per cent in 1983 to 45 per cent in 1998.

For all their unpopularity, the Government is more than happy for one third of schools to be controlled by religious organisations and only the National Secular Society complains about the humiliations which follow.

Parents, it points out, debase themselves to get a child into a school which may be a few yards from their home and whose costs are paid for by their taxes. They have to protest convictions they don't have. They must attend church to worship gods they don't believe exist, and stand by while priests decide on the future of their children's education. Teachers, too, are caught. If they don't have or can't fake piety, they can be excluded from jobs in thousands of schools.

The prisons are going the same way. Religious charities and chaplains control inmates more completely than denominational schools control children. The results are often outrageous - the National Secular Society has letters from prisoners who have been denied parole for refusing to pray - but occasionally hilarious. The Home Office allowed one religious outfit, the Kairos Trust, to take over wings in four prisons. Its director, Kenner Jones, may soon be getting closer to his charges. He was convicted of embezzling funds recently and faces a custodial sentence.

The same Millbankers who implored me to have a go at the Tories, were eager to tell me about Marvin Olasky. I and other leftish hacks were more than happy to listen. Hague had invited George W. Bush's religious adviser to Britain and the man looked like a dangerous fruitcake. He didn't want to vote for women if he could possibly help it, and preached that public services and money should be given to churches.

In March, almost a year to the day after Olasky's visit to London was mocked by all good Blairites, the Prime Minister told religious charities that he had put 'misguided and outdated' principles on the need to separate church and state behind him. He now wanted the faithful to take over care for the sick, homeless, young and incarcerated. There is a fair chance that they will become part of a captive audience. Their punishment will not only include poverty or the deprivation of liberty, but being forced to nod along to dogmas most of the rest of society rejects.

The best explanation for the phenomenon of rulers embracing faith their subjects did not share was given by Edward Gibbon. When he wondered why Constantine had made Christianity the official religion of the late Roman Empire, he wrote that the Emperor found it politic to convert because: 'In the beginning of the fourth century, the Christians still bore a very inadequate proportion to the inhabitants of the empire; but among a degenerate people, who viewed the change of masters with the indifference of slaves, the spirit and union of a religious party might assist the popular leader, to whose service from a principle of confidence, they had devoted their lives and fortunes.'

The election will reveal the indifference of the public to its masters. Participation will be the lowest ever. The triangulating of the parties and their utter cynicism may well persuade a third of adults not to waste their time in the polling booths. In these circumstances professional politicians need enthusiasts to fill the emptying ranks of committed supporters. As a Conservative spin doctor at Butlins put it: 'The evangelical vote could be vital in a general election with a low turnout.'

He did not then see Britain as a 'foreign land' but was content to allow his fellow citizens to find their own paths to what limited happiness was on offer. The age of consent for homosexuals should be lowered to 16, he said, and gays should be allowed to marry. ('When they're not causing harm to other people, why should we object?') The single mothers his party had hounded in office should be cherished. ('It is better for a child to have one happy parent who cares and loves him or her than to have two and suffer from domestic violence.') Hague went to the Notting Hill Carnival in shorts and baseball cap and although he looked the saddest white rasta in town that day, his desire to show a faint solidarity with black Britons was worthy. Many of his followers were mortified. 'Why do I share a party with those who advocate sodomite marriage?' cried Norman Tebbit as his treacherous leader abandoned bigotry. Tim Montgomerie, the director of the Conservative Christian Fellowship, warned Hague that sleeping in the same bed as Ffion Jenkins before they had been united in Holy Matrimony violated 'the Christian ideal'. Only by remaining the guardian of the 'Judaeo-Christian' tradition, he added, could the leader 'attract many Christians and others of traditional belief into the activist-hungry Tory party'. He had, it transpired, been opposed to repealing Clause 28 long 'before the issue became newsworthy'. He went on to offer the righteous a deal. He had noted that the average Tory activist was a pensioner, who was not likely, what with the lumbago and shortness of breath, to be particularly active. The Conservative leadership had been forced to take Tim Montgomerie's complaints seriously, and was wooing the energetically religious. If the price of their support was abandoning tolerance and bringing tele-evangelism to Britain, Hague would pay it. I was disconcerted to hear condemnations of apostasy fall from the lips of Tony Blair's followers. But you can't knock New Labour every week and I wrote about the Conservative Party's sinister links with the religious fundamentalists around the American Republicans. I would happily do so again, were it not for a press release dated 3 May from Janet Anderson, the Labour Broadcasting Minister. Representatives of every mainstream religion - Christian, Jewish, Hindu, Muslim, Sikh - had met her to discuss 'whether the restrictions on ownership of national broadcasting licences by religious bodies should now be relaxed due to the greater opportunities the digital age will offer,' she said. They had received a sympathetic hearing. The porn baron, Richard Desmond, whose websites feature Grace, a 79-year-old woman, who masturbates for the delight of the audience and asks: 'Would you like a pair of my wet panties?', is allowed to own the Daily Express (and has been courted by the Godly Hague and Blair). Yet as faith collapses, sectarians are elevated. You always get you into trouble when you quote statistics on worship. They have to protest convictions they don't have. They must attend church to worship gods they don't believe exist, and stand by while priests decide on the future of their children's education. Teachers, too, are caught. If they don't have or can't fake piety, they can be excluded from jobs in thousands of schools. The prisons are going the same way. webTitle: Families win IRA human rights ruling

fields.headline: Families win IRA human rights ruling
fields.standfirst:
Damages for relatives of terrorists shot by army and police
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Damages for relatives of terrorists shot by army and police.
fields.body:
Relatives of 12 people, including 10 IRA men shot dead by the security forces in Northern Ireland, called for police and soldiers to be charged with murder after a landmark European court verdict yesterday that their right to life had been violated.

But the British government dismissed claims that there was a shoot-to-kill policy and said it may appeal against the ruling, which ordered it to pay each family £10,000, plus up to £30,000 costs.

Outraged unionists, including Northern Ireland's first minister, David Trimble, and victims of IRA violence, condemned the court of human rights' judgment as hurtful and perverse, given most of those killed were heavily armed terrorists.

However, nationalists and human rights groups hailed the decision as a historic victory which could open the floodgates for legal action over the deaths of more than 360 people, including 74 children, shot by security forces in contentious incidents.

"For 30 years, Britain has perpetuated the myth that their role in our country was as peacekeeper not protagonist," said Mark Thompson, of Belfast-based Relatives for Justice. "Today, that image and propaganda is in tatters."

The judges ruled that Britain had breached article 2 of the Human Rights Convention, the right to life, by failing to properly investigate the controversial circumstances, which led to the 12 deaths in four separate incidents.

Eight IRA gunmen and a passerby died in an SAS ambush when the Provisionals attacked an RUC station in Loughgall, Co Armagh, in 1987.

Police shot two other unarmed IRA men in separate incidents in Lurgan, Co Armagh, in 1982, and Belfast in 1992, and loyalist paramilitaries, said to be acting in collusion with the RUC, killed a Sinn Fein official in Co Tyrone in 1991.

Mairead Kelly, whose brother, East Tyrone IRA commander Patrick Kelly, was killed by the SAS at Loughgall, said: "This is a severe indictment of a government that pretends to be democratic and lectures others on human rights. This has been a long wait but it has been worth the wait, and we will fight on for those responsible to be brought to account."

Hugh Jordan, whose son, Pearse Jordan, an IRA member, was shot by the RUC on Belfast's Falls Road in 1992, said: "The next time I see a British minister on TV accusing other countries of being terrorist states, I would like to ask the question 'are they a terrorist state'?"

Jonathan McKerr, son of IRA man Gervaise McKerr, who was shot by police in Lurgan, said: "The RUC, from operational level, right through to the very top are guilty of the murder of my father.

"The British government tried to drag out the process, thinking time would make our voices less poignant. But the time for lies is over. We demand truth and justice for our loved ones."

The families, and nationalist politicians, are urging the Irish premier, Bertie Ahern, to support them in obtaining a United Nations inquiry into the full circumstances surrounding the killings.

But the Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid, insisted the court ruling applied only to procedural matters on subsequent investigations. He stressed: "They are not a finding of unlawful killing or shoot to kill."

The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, said he found the decision perverse, particularly in the case of Loughgall. "It does strike me as astonishing that there would be any case for criticism in the circumstances when the republicans concerned attacked a police station, set off a bomb and opened up with heavy weapons on the police station before fire was returned," he observed.

Joe McIlwaine, father of a 20-year-old Ulster Defence Regiment soldier, also called Joe, whom the IRA shot dead at a golf course in Belfast in retaliation for Loughgall, said he was sickened.

"It feels as if it is all going one way, as if the Protestant victims of IRA violence don't count. There is nobody we can turn to. We feel hurt. It is soul destroying."

Peter Robinson, deputy leader of Ian Paisley's hardline Democratic Unionists, said: "This ruling is insane and offensive. The government should ignore it."

Case two

Gervase McKerr, 31, Eugene Toman, 21, and Sean Burns, 21, three unarmed members of the IRA, were shot dead by officers of the RUC's special support unit in November 1982. The RUC officers said they fired at their car after it crashed through a checkpoint. However, forensic tests suggested they had been shot after the car stopped. The police fired 109 rounds.

Republicans and nation alists claimed the incident proved the existence of a "shoot to kill" policy. The incident took place shortly after the RUC and MI5 conducted a surveillance operation on an IRA explosives cache in a hayshed near Lurgan, Co Armagh. Despite the covert operation the IRA succeeded in retrieving explosives used in a landmine which killed three RUC officers in October 1982, 15 days before the three IRA men were killed. Only the McKerr family took the case to the European court.

Two weeks after the IRA men died undercover RUC officers opened fire at the hayshed, killing Michael Tighe, 17, a Catholic with no connections to the IRA.

The killings prompted an investigation into whether RUC officers had provided false evidence and perverted the course of justice.

The investigation was carried out by John Stalker, then deputy chief constable of Greater Manchester police. Stalker later said up to 21 cartridge cases had been removed from the scene and that a high level inquiry into the nature of the deaths was "shamefully absent".

Stalker later said he found no evidence of a "shoot-to-kill policy as such" but "there was a clear understanding on the part of the men whose job it was to pull the trigger that that was what was expected of them".

Stalker was removed from the inquiry and replaced by Colin Sampson, then chief constable of West Yorkshire police, whose report remains secret. In 1988, Sir Patrick Mayhew, then attorney general, told the Commons there was evidence RUC officers had conspired to pervert the course of justice.

Case three

Patrick Shanaghan, 30, was killed by a member of the loyalist paramilitary group, the Ulster Freedom Fighters in August 1991 not far from his home in Castlederg, County Tyrone.

In the year up to his death he had been arrested 10 times and his home searched 16 times. He had been warned twice by RUC officers that his life was under threat. However, at his inquest the RUC suppressed evidence suggesting it colluded in his murder.

The RUC suspected that Mr Shanahan, an active member of Sinn Fein, was an IRA member.

Case four

Pearse Jordan, 22, was shot in the back by an RUC officer on the Falls Road, west Belfast, in November 1992 - the last recorded killing in the Troubles by a member of the security forces.

Jordan was travelling in a stolen car which was rammed by an RUC car. According to witnesses, police opened fire without warning as Jordan got out of the car in a state of shock.

Witnesses were not sought by the police but offered to provide evidence after one approached the committee on the administration of justice. Jordan received an IRA funeral.

fields.headline: At this price?  Queens Moat
fields.trailText: Hotel chain Queens Moat Houses yesterday issued a profits warning, telling investors that tougher economic conditions and the outbreak of foot and mouth disease have hit trading.
fields.body:
Hotel chain Queens Moat Houses yesterday issued a profits warning, telling investors that tougher economic conditions and the outbreak of foot and mouth disease have hit trading.

The shares fell 16% to 21.75p in the wake of the alert - which came two months after the company said trading was buoyant.

Stanley Metcalfe, the chairman, told the annual shareholders' meeting that the slowdown in economic growth had hit the number of visitors to its international city locations. There had been a significant fall in business and a number of corporate clients had cut their hotel spending.

At the same time foot and mouth disease had hit the weekend leisure market, and the impact was likely to continue to be felt through the summer months.

Queens Moat is the latest in a growing number of companies to report that foot and mouth has hit the bottom line. These range from leather company Pittards to British Airways and Scottish & Newcastle, which this week put the cost to its beer sales and pub trade at £3m.

A reduction in the number of German trade fairs this year means that Queens Moat will not benefit from the same exceptional levels of business there as last.

Trade has been weaker in Cologne and Hanover, but that was offset by a strong performance in Munich and Frankfurt. Overall the company was confident that the German division would trade in line with expectations.

Advertising and promotional activity will be stepped up in an attempt to increase occupancy rates and, the company said, it had clamped down on costs.

Mr Metcalfe said that, long term, he was confident of a recovery.

The shares have had a rollercoaster ride in recent years. Little more than three years ago they were changing hands at 11p, but bounced back to 44p in 1998. Earlier this year they were 32p. Hold.

fields.headline: Buyers flood in to Kelda
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Buyers flowed back into Kelda , the owner of Yorkshire Water, yesterday on hopes that something corporate is in the pipeline.
fields.body:
Buyers flowed back into Kelda , the owner of Yorkshire Water, yesterday on hopes that something corporate is in the pipeline. Over 3.4m Kelda shares changed hands - almost twice the average daily volume - as the price ticked up 6.25p to 350p.

According to one theory, the company was toying with the idea of asking Ofwat, the water regulator, to reconsider its plan to split the ownership and operation of Yorkshire Water. The smart money, however, was betting on something rather more radical - a £1.85bn offer from a cash-rich European rival.

Starved of opportunities in their domestic markets, Europe's biggest utility companies have been busy acquiring British water and electricity assets this year. Powergen and Thames Water are the most notable examples.

Analysts agreed there were worse things the likes of Italy's Enel or France's EdF could buy. "Kelda's cheap. It is trading at a 15-20% discount to its regulatory asset base so a buyer could make a 10% return on something that is pretty low risk," one analyst said. Market makers urged caution. They said it was entirely possible that the story had been put together to get a large seller out of the stock at a good price.

After Thursday's drubbing, it was backing to winning ways for London's leading shares but only after a session of extreme volatility.

In the morning, prices had moved sharply higher only to fall back on news of a hefty rise in US unemployment. Although the figures highlighted the weakness of the US economy, investors decided to look on the bright side and the leeway it gives the Federal Reserve to cut rates further.

Lifted by hopes of a halfpoint cut at the Fed's next meeting, the FTSE 100 ended 104.5 points higher at 5,870.3. BP, up 20p to 611p, Vodafone , 7.5p higher at 196.75p, and GlaxoSmithKline , 56p better at £18.90, delivered most of the upside.

The FTSE Techmark 100 did not perform as well, advancing just 8.9 points to 2,051.16. Dealers blamed the weak showing on Deutsche Bank, which urged its clients to lower their exposure to the IT services sector.

The German broker is worried that Europe will not be able to maintain its status as the "global growth fortress for IT companies".

Logica , down 13p to 945p, Misys , off 12.5p to 564.5p, CMG , 10p lower at 395p, and Dimension Data , 5p weaker at 335p, were among those affected by Deutsche's call.

Biotechs were strong however, with Nycomed Amersham , up 32p to 567p, Cambridge Antibody , 125p higher at £21.37, and Celltech , 33p firmer at £11.43, all supported by positive noises from Merrill Lynch.

The US house expects pro teomics - the study of proteins produced by genes and their involvement in disease - to play a big role in identifying 3,000-4,500 new drug targets and reckons the Nycomed, CAT and Celltech are well placed to cash in on the potential.

On the second line, chip developer ARC International fell back 7.5p to 95.5p as the identity of Wednesday's large seller was revealed as its second biggest shareholder, Nomura. The Japanese investment bank, which was also an early stage backer, said it had cut its holding to 4.73% from 8.53%.

The news shocked traders. With first quarter figures earlier this week, ARC's chief financial officer was reported to have said that no big shareholders were likely to sell at current levels.

In recent months Navan Mining has become something of a favourite in the day trading community and with good reason.

Every now and then a bid story does the rounds and yesterday was no exception. Apparently an offer of between 160-190p will be revealed next week. The shares rose 16p to 120p.

fields.headline: Case two
fields.standfirst:

fields.trailText: Gervase McKerr, 31, Eugene Toman, 21, and Sean Burns, 21, three unarmed members of the IRA, were shot dead by officers of the RUC's special support unit in November 1982. The RUC officers said they fired at their car after it crashed through a checkpoint. However, forensic tests suggested they had been shot after the car stopped. The police fired 109 rounds.
fields.body:
Gervase McKerr, 31, Eugene Toman, 21, and Sean Burns, 21, three unarmed members of the IRA, were shot dead by officers of the RUC's special support unit in November 1982. The RUC officers said they fired at their car after it crashed through a checkpoint. However, forensic tests suggested they had been shot after the car stopped. The police fired 109 rounds.

Republicans and nation alists claimed the incident proved the existence of a "shoot to kill" policy. The incident took place shortly after the RUC and MI5 conducted a surveillance operation on an IRA explosives cache in a hayshed near Lurgan, Co Armagh. Despite the covert operation the IRA succeeded in retrieving explosives used in a landmine which killed three RUC officers in October 1982, 15 days before the three IRA men were killed. Only the McKerr family took the case to the European court.

Two weeks after the IRA men died undercover RUC officers opened fire at the hayshed, killing Michael Tighe, 17, a Catholic with no connections to the IRA.

The killings prompted an investigation into whether RUC officers had provided false evidence and perverted the course of justice.

The investigation was carried out by John Stalker, then deputy chief constable of Greater Manchester police. Stalker later said up to 21 cartridge cases had been removed from the scene and that a high level inquiry into the nature of the deaths was "shamefully absent".

Stalker later said he found no evidence of a "shoot-to-kill policy as such" but "there was a clear understanding on the part of the men whose job it was to pull the trigger that that was what was expected of them".

Stalker was removed from the inquiry and replaced by Colin Sampson, then chief constable of West Yorkshire police, whose report remains secret. In 1988, Sir Patrick Mayhew, then attorney general, told the Commons there was evidence RUC officers had conspired to pervert the course of justice.

webTitle: Torero is cruising for a bruising in the ring bullring

fields.headline: Torero is cruising for a bruising in the ring bullring
fields.trailText: Jose Luis Bote's bottom should serve as a warning to all would-be bullfighters. For his battered backside is a reminder, as Madrid's bullfight season kicks off, that toreros must do more than strut around in sequinned suits and giant codpieces.
fields.body:
Jose Luis Bote's bottom should serve as a warning to all would-be bullfighters. For his battered backside is a reminder, as Madrid's bullfight season kicks off, that toreros must do more than strut around in sequinned suits and giant codpieces.

This, roughly, is what doctors had to say about the Madrid matador's rear end after it was pierced by a young bull's horn three weeks ago: "The wound surrounds the rectum, damages the inner spincter and affects a number of pelvic muscles."

"Ouch!" you might say. Not so "El Bote". "It is a bit uncomfortable, but I should be able to fight again soon," he said after a week in hospital.

I know precious little about bullfighting, but I have developed an, admittedly morbid, interest in the struggling career of Jose Luis Bote - a lame, middle-ranking Madrid matador. El Bote is one of the most gored matadors of all time. The "little spike" to his bottom - as his manager, Pablo Gonzalez, described the four-inch gash - was a minor scrape by his standards.

First he had his femoral artery punctured in a small town outside Madrid. Then he was mauled performing for the tourists in Benidorm. Finally, in Madrid's famous Las Ventas arena, he damaged his spine - leaving him with a limp.

Still he insists on coming back. This year he will turn 35 - an age by which many top toreros have retired. Now he only just scrapes into the matadors' top 50.

I met him once at Madrid's official Bullfighting School. It boasts a mini bullring where children as young as nine wave lilac capes at a pair of bull's horns mounted on a wheelbarrow. Mr Bote, a former pupil, teaches here.

The kids call him maestro . Afterwards I went with Alberto, a 13-year-old Bote pupil, to see him fight at Las Ventas - the Wembley stadium of world bullfighting. On this occasion he escaped unscathed. The crowd, almost out of relief, went wild.

Mr Bote's manager says he will be back at Las Ventas when the Feria de San Isidro starts next week. This is the most important moment in the bullfighting calendar - when reputations are made, or broken, in an afternoon.

This year will see one great change. The abbatoir at the back of the bullring will stay locked. No longer will dead bulls be delivered straight to the butchers who turn the remains into steaks, ox-tail and criadillas - a delicacy made of bull's testicles.

Bullfighting impresarios are worried that mad cow disease will do what anti-bullfighting protests have failed to achieve - put an end to the fiesta nacional . Rather than risk disease, they have decided to burn all the carcasses.

Connoisseurs are upset that Madrid's only source of free-range beef - reared in freedom and fed only on grass - has disappeared. Even the bull's ears and tails, the gory trophies handed to the matador at the end of the fight, have been banned. Bullfighters now get fake ones instead.

fields.body:
Patrick Shanaghan, 30, was killed by a member of the loyalist paramilitary group, the Ulster Freedom Fighters in August 1991 not far from his home in Castlederg, County Tyrone.

In the year up to his death he had been arrested 10 times and his home searched 16 times. He had been warned twice by RUC officers that his life was under threat. However, at his inquest the RUC suppressed evidence suggesting it colluded in his murder.

The RUC suspected that Mr Shanahan, an active member of Sinn Fein, was an IRA member.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Cruise and Kidman work out divorce
fields.body:
Cruise and Kidman work out divorce

The formerly golden Hollywood couple, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman, returned to the business of their divorce yesterday after the diversion caused by an erotic wrestler who claimed to have had a gay affair with the star of the film Jerry Maguire.

Kidman, 33, filed papers seeking joint legal custody of their two adopted children but says she wants them to live with her. Cruise, 38, whose fortune of more than $100m (£70m) is said to dwarf that of his estranged wife, should pay family support to maintain their standard of living, she says.

The star told Kidman in February that, after 10 years, he no longer wanted to be married to her, say the papers. "This came as a shock." Cruise declined to entertain her suggestion of counselling.

Dennis Wasser, Cruise's lawyer, said that he was ready to divide their property evenly. Another lawyer, Bert Fields, said that Cruise was ready to testify in court against the 25-year-old porn actor Chad Slater, who uses the name of Kyle Bradford when he is wrestling.

Slater/Bradford claimed in an interview with the French magazine Actustar that they had a gay romance, which caused Cruise and Kidman to split. Mr Fields said he had received a letter from the star of gay grappling videos claiming that he never gave any interviews about Cruise.
Michael Ellison, New York

Outrage at leniency over UN slayings

Indonesia jailed six men for up to 20 months yesterday over the slaying of three UN aid workers in West Timor, and earned international outrage for being too lenient.

The three workers with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) were stabbed and their bodies dragged into the street and set alight in September after a mob attacked their office in the West Timor border town of Atambua.

"The elements that caused the UN officers' deaths cannot be proved to be [linked to the defendants]... because the action was perpetrated by a mob," Judge Anak Agung Gede Dalem told the North Jakarta court.

The prosecutor in the case said the men were convicted not of murder but of violence against people or things

The six men, all East Timorese who still consider themselves Indonesian despite a 1999 vote for independence, received sentences ranging from 10 to 20 months. They had faced up to 34 years for the slayings of the UN workers - an American, a Croat and an Ethiopian.

"The sentences make a mockery of the international community's insistence that justice be done in this horrific case," the UNHCR said.
Reuters, Jakarta

President to seek second term in Iran

President Mohammad Khatami ended months of speculation yesterday by announcing that he will seek a second term in Iran's presidential election next month.

"There was talk that I doubted whether to stand, and it is true," he said, adding that he hesitated because of "concern about the future of the revolution and the nation".

"Unfortunately, we have so far paid a heavy price for democracy, and there will be more to pay," he said, in a reference to conservative attacks on his reform plans.

Mr Khatami won a landslide victory in 1997 with nearly 70% of the popular vote, on a reform platform backed by women and young people. But his efforts to liberalise were stymied by the conservatives who control key state institutions.

Scores of journalists, student leaders and opposition figures - including some of Mr Khatami's closest allies - have been jailed or are awaiting trial, and more than 30 mostly pro-reform newspapers have been closed down.

Although the 57-year-old cleric is expected to win a second term in the election, on June 8, a smaller majority could be interpreted as a victory for the conservatives.
Brian Whitaker and agencies

French general admits torture in Algerian war

A "horrified" Jacques Chirac yesterday ordered disciplinary measures against a retired general who defended the torture and summary execution of guerrillas and civilians during Algeria's war of independence in the 1950s.

The French president demanded that General Paul Aussaresses, 83, be stripped of his légion d'honneur, and asked his defence minister to investigate the possibility of disciplinary action by the military establishment.

Gen Aussaresses, who was head of undercover operations during the 1957 battle of Algiers, admitted in a book and newspaper interview this week that he and his men tortured and assassinated Algerians with - he said - the blessing of Paris.

Mr Chirac stopped short of calling for a parliamentary inquiry, asking instead for historians to make it a priority to examine government and military archives from the period. But the justice minister, Marylise Lebranchu, favoured an inquiry into whether the remarks constituted "an apologia for war crimes".

In his book, Services Speciaux Algerie 1955-57, Gen Aussaresses detailed acts of torture and cold-blooded executions. This week he told Le Monde: "Torture is efficient, most people break and talk. After that, we'd finish them off. Does that trouble my conscience? I have to say it doesn't."
Jon Henley, Paris

EU refuses Polish delay on sales of land

Poland suffered a setback in its bid to join the EU yesterday when Brussels rebuffed its call for a long delay before foreigners could buy land - a hyper-sensitive issue in the largest candidate country.

With enlargement high on the agenda, the European commission called for a transitional period of up to seven years before citizens of the current 15 member states could buy farms in Poland and four other applicant countries. Poland, fearing a wave of purchases by Germans, especially in areas once inhabited by ethnic Germans, had demanded 18 years.

"That remains our position," a Polish spokesman said. "This is an extremely sensitive issue." Polish land is between five and 10 times cheaper than across the border in Germany.

The commission's move will add to pessimism in Warsaw about Poland's prospects of being in the first wave of new EU entrants.

Although 54% of Poles believe that membership will benefit the existing members more than them, the government is under fire for falling behind other candidates in the race to join.

The commission also wants a five-year delay on the purchase of second homes in Poland, Hungary and the Czech republic.

Parts of Pomerania, Prussia and Silesia, German until 1945, are now in Poland.
Ian Black, Brussels

UN bans export of diamonds from Liberia

The UN security council imposed sanctions against Liberia yesterday for failing to sever its ties with rebels in Sierra Leone.

Britain's UN ambassador, Jeremy Greenstock, said the sanctions would take effect from May 7 and would ban the import of diamonds from Liberia and travel by senior Liberian officials.

On Wednesday, the secretary general, Kofi Annan, said the UN has received unconfirmed reports that Liberia was still supporting Sierra Leone's Revolutionary United Front rebels.

"We have got to bring peace to Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea," said Mr Greenstock. "We have a policy on that, that policy is to force the RUF to stop fighting."

Liberia has said it was closing RUF offices, expelling all RUF members and freezing rebel assets. It grounded all Liberian-registered aircraft and banned the import of all diamonds without proper certification.

The security council authorised the sanctions on March 7 but delayed their implementation in a final attempt to get Liberia to stop the military and financial support that has allowed the RUF to wage a decade-long war against the Sierra Leone government.

Since 1991 the RUF has terrorised Sierra Leone, killing and mutilating tens of thousands of civilians in a struggle aimed at controlling diamond fields.
AP, New York

fields.headline: Farms crisis 'could cost tourism £5bn'
fields.standfirst:
Foot and mouth: As the government claims the battle is being won, industry survey says 250,000 jobs and 3,000 businesses are at risk.
Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth: As the government claims the battle is being won, industry survey says 250,000 jobs and 3,000 businesses are at risk.
fields.body:
Ministers' claims that the countryside is slowly reopening for business with the battle against foot and mouth won were dealt a blow yesterday, when the government's tourism agency joined farmers' leaders in cautioning against false optimism.

Releasing the results of new research, the English tourism council came close to saying that upbeat political assessments were verging on the dishonest with most footpaths still closed - although Snowdon, in north Wales, is re-opening this weekend - and many potential visitors still alarmed by upsetting images of mass destruction.

With only 14% of people planning to take short breaks in England this month, the council calculated that 3,000 small businesses and 250,000 jobs were at risk. Without extra government aid, the tourist industry would lose £5bn this year, it warned.

As Tony Blair clears the decks for a general election announcement next week, farmers' leaders in Cumbria and Devon - the two counties most affected by the outbreak - accused the prime minister of talking down the impact of the disease for political reasons. "You cannot wish away foot and mouth because there is a general election," the NFU in Devon said.

At the same time, the government faced accusations that the Ministry of Agriculture, under orders from Downing Street, was no longer presenting the full picture by not recording animals slaughtered on suspicion of having the disease. "Everything the government is doing is to show that this outbreak is less serious than it really is," the Tory MP for Hexham, Peter Atkinson, said. But he accepted the situation was getting better.

The Northumberland NFU chairman, Malcolm Corbett, said many of his members looked at the government's claims in amazement, with new cases being recorded in the north of the county. In Durham, Tony Blair's constituency home, the NFU chairman, John Ryder, was equally forthright. "The prime minister is counting his chickens before they hatch."

At Hallbankgate, in north Cumbria, farmer Geoff Bell, who was forced to slaughter 800 healthy sheep and lambs in an attempt to save his 90 remaining Limousin and Belgian blue cattle, said Mr Blair had not presented the full picture this week. "While he tells the world foot and mouth has nearly been beaten by the government, we are only just beginning to realise the devastation it has caused," he added. "He has made the government out to be brilliant but this crisis has been dealt with ever so badly."

Against this background, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, was attempting yesterday to persuade councils in disease-free counties to re-open footpaths - more than two months after his ministry threw the countryside into chaos by telling authorities to close rights of way.

"It isn't the footpaths that are at risk from spreading the disease," he claimed. "The major disease risks are the movement of vehicles, the movement of people, and the unlicensed movement of livestock."

Ministers are clearly concerned that, with thousands of looming job losses in manufacturing - from steel in south Wales and Teesside, to electronics in Scotland and the south, and tourist coach building in Scarborough - the crisis in the countryside is adding to unease about the state of the economy.

Those concerns were hardly helped yesterday when the English tourist council chief executive, Mary Lynch, called for businesses in the worst affected areas to be given interest-free loans to help them survive.

All the people suspected of having foot and mouth disease have been given the all-clear. The public health laboratory service said 21 people were tested for the disease and all had proved negative.

The Northumberland NFU chairman, Malcolm Corbett, said many of his members looked at the government's claims in amazement, with new cases being recorded in the north of the county. In Durham, Tony Blair's constituency home, the NFU chairman, John Ryder, was equally forthright. "The prime minister is counting his chickens before they hatch." At Hallbankgate, in north Cumbria, farmer Geoff Bell, who was forced to slaughter 800 healthy sheep and lambs in an attempt to save his 90 remaining Limousin and Belgian blue cattle, said Mr Blair had not presented the full picture this week. "While he tells the world foot and mouth has nearly been beaten by the government, we are only just beginning to realise the devastation it has caused," he added. "He has made the government out to be brilliant but this crisis has been dealt with ever so badly." Against this background, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, was attempting yesterday to persuade councils in disease-free counties to re-open footpaths - more than two months after his ministry threw the countryside into chaos by telling authorities to close rights of way. "It isn't the footpaths that are at risk from spreading the disease," he claimed. "The major disease risks are the movement of vehicles, the movement of people, and the unlicensed movement of livestock." Ministers are clearly concerned that, with thousands of looming job losses in manufacturing - from steel in south Wales and Teesside, to electronics in Scotland and the south, and tourist coach building in Scarborough - the crisis in the countryside is adding to unease about the state of the economy. webTitle: Pensioners spark race row at home

fields.headline: Pensioners spark race row at home
fields.trailText: As an original member of the Specials, Clifton Golding's son Lynval is something of a local hero in Coventry. But the celebrity connection cut no ice last week when Mr Golding senior tried to move into one of the city's residential homes only to be told he would not be welcome - because he was black.
fields.body:
As an original member of the Specials, Clifton Golding's son Lynval is something of a local hero in Coventry. But the celebrity connection cut no ice last week when Mr Golding senior tried to move into one of the city's residential homes only to be told he would not be welcome - because he was black.

The band's lineup of black and white musicians, and blend of reggae, ska and punk, may have been an important multicultural influence in the late 1970s, but its message clearly did not reach a group of white pensioners at the home. They threatened to walk out if Mr Golding senior, who is 76 and suffers from emphysema, moved in.

Despite the efforts of the home's proprietor to distance himself from their attitudes, Mr Golding's family have made a formal complaint to the council and to Coventry's race equality council.

But they believe the incident also raises wider issues about care provision for Britain's ageing ethnic minority population, 50 years after the first wave of Caribbean immigrants to the UK.

"When my dad first came to England from Jamaica in 1953, there were signs on guest houses saying 'No blacks, no Irish, no dogs'," said Lynval Golding. "He had to sleep in a shed for two weeks, because he could not find anywhere to live. Now he is in old age, he has to go through all that again."

Yesterday Ken Grasby, proprietor of the Cordelia Court home, said he was shocked by the attitudes of five elderly white women in the home.

"The ringleader, a 90-year-old woman, said: 'I have lived next to them for 40 years and I don't want to retire with them.'

"I am appalled that people still have attitudes like this, but they obviously do," he said.

Mr Grasby approached the council for advice on the situation, later telling the residents that if they did not like living with a black man they could leave. But Mr Golding's family believe he did not act decisively enough.

"I have spoken to the family and apologised on behalf of a very bigoted minority of residents," said Mr Grasby. "As far as I'm concerned there was never any question that he would not be allowed here."

Despite his apology the Goldings decided not to move their father into the £300 per week private home. He is now in temporary respite care, looking for somewhere else to live.

Sawarn Malhotra, race equality officer for the Coventry race equality council, said the incident illustrated a wider problem in the provision of care for elderly people of non-white backgrounds.

"Service providers need to recognise the needs of diverse communities, and to be geared up to providing facilities that are genuinely multicultural," he said. "Different facilities might be needed for people with specific religious, cultural or dietary needs.

"Social services need to look specifically at whether a home is suitable for all the minority communities living in the city. As a service provider there's more to being mulitcultural than simply not being racist."

A spokeswoman for Coventry city council, which licenses the home, said it viewed the incident as "totally unacceptable". "The owner of a home will sign a contract with us, part of which is to ensure that all people are treated equally. They need to tell racist residents in no uncertain terms that their behaviour will not be tolerated."

Mr Golding's daughter Connie said: "The council needs to look into why more black people aren't going into homes and whether, when they go into these places, they are made to feel welcome."

fields.body:
Pearse Jordan, 22, was shot in the back by an RUC officer on the Falls Road, west Belfast, in November 1992 - the last recorded killing in the Troubles by a member of the security forces.

Jordan was travelling in a stolen car which was rammed by an RUC car. According to witnesses, police opened fire without warning as Jordan got out of the car in a state of shock.

Witnesses were not sought by the police but offered to provide evidence after one approached the committee on the administration of justice. Jordan received an IRA funeral.

webTitle: 1054 and all that still angers Orthodox church

fields.headline: 1054 and all that still angers Orthodox church
fields.trailText: "The Greek Orthodox church plays a very long game," a Greek Catholic bishop said yesterday. "Perceived injustices that others might consign to history, they remember as if they happened yesterday."
fields.body:
"The Greek Orthodox church plays a very long game," a Greek Catholic bishop said yesterday. "Perceived injustices that others might consign to history, they remember as if they happened yesterday."

Chief among these, as far as Orthodox Christians are concerned, are the Great Schism of 1054, which split Christianity into its eastern and western branches, and the sacking of Constantinople by the fourth crusade in 1204.

In their eyes, these events, for which they blame Rome, led to the loss of the Byzantine capital, Constantinople, to the Muslim Ottomans in 1453. The Catholic church also stands accused of indifference to the subsequent 400 years of Turkish subjugation of the Hellenic world.

As Timothy Ware writes in his book The Orthodox Church, in the summer of 1054, Pope Leo IX sent Cardinal Humbert from Rome to try to deal with the growing rift between the two nerve-centres of Christianity - Rome in the west and Constantinople in the east. The two had been steadily falling out over competing claims to supremacy within the Christian world, which had their roots in cultural and political factors as well as theology. There were differences over such things as Rome's imposition of celibacy on the clergy, the use of unleavened bread for the Eucharist, and the temporal authority of Constantinople.

One afternoon, Cardinal Humbert entered the church of St Sophia in Constantinople, the seat of the eastern patriarch, Michael Cerularius, and placed a bull [papal edict] of excommunication upon the altar. Humbert then marched out, followed by a frantic church official who begged him to take back the edict. But he refused, and the edict was dropped in the street.

The resulting schism endures to today.

fields.headline: Britain accused over Ulster investigations
fields.standfirst:
European ruling sidesteps issue of unlawful killing but questions deaths after long-term surveillance
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: European ruling sidesteps issue of unlawful killing but questions deaths after long-term surveillance.
fields.body:
The European human rights court ruled yesterday that Britain had failed to conduct proper investigations in cases involving the deaths of 14 people killed by the security forces in Northern Ireland between 1982 and 1992.

Though the ruling sidestepped the issue of the lawfulness of the killings, at least one of the cases - the shooting of three people in a car near Lurgan in 1982 -remains at the centre of "shoot-to-kill" allegations.

The ruling also raises the question, notably in the SAS ambush of an IRA active search unit at Loughgall, County Armagh, about killings carried out after long-running undercover intelligence operations which offered the alternative of arrest.

Six years ago, the court ruled that more force than absolutely necessary was used on three unarmed IRA members killed by the SAS in Gibraltar in 1988.

In what republicans describe as the Loughgall massacre in May, 1987, eight IRA members, including Patrick Kelly, the East Tyrone commander, were was shot by the SAS - the IRA's biggest single loss - during an audacious attack on an RUC station. A passerby, Anthony Hughes, was also killed.

Loughgall is a small village but hugely symbolic as the Orange Order was founded there in 1795. As Jack Holland says in his book on the Northern Ireland conflict, Hope Against History: "In terms of loyalist mythology it was the holiest of holies."

An interception of a careless telephone call led the RUC and British soldiers to mount a long surveillance operation. On the day of the "spectacular", 24 SAS troopers, armed with machine guns, high velocity rifles and pistols, prepared for the ambush.

In the early evening, the eight-man IRA active service unit, which was experienced and armed and carrying a bomb in a hijacked JCB digger, drove straight intothe ambush. It fired the bomb wrecking the police station.

Immediately, the SAS showered the IRA members and their digger with bullets. The shooting lasted for about 10 minutes. One SAS trooper was alleged to have shot one of the wounded IRA men after he was seen moving. At the inquest, which was not held until 1995, he described it as a warning shot.

According to Father Charles Devlin, the parish priest who administered the last rites, all the men had been shot in the head. In all, 678 rounds were fired, including 78 from IRA guns, according to official figures.

Mr Hughes, 36, was killed and his brother Oliver, seriously injured when they were shot from behind driving through Loughgall after fixing a lorry in a nearby village.

Nationalist politicans did not equate the incident with the "shoot-to-kill" cases. But many questioned why, since the IRA unit had been watched, no attempt had been made to capture and arrest them. They also questioned why the Hughes brothers were allowed to drive into the ambush.

The Unionist MP, Ken Maginnis, rejected the need for a public inquiry at the time. "If it is necessary to kill these people then that is what must happen", he said. The Irish Times commented: "Whatever [the IRA men] may have done or however suspect they may have been, the British Army were not entitled to act as judge, jury and executioner in their case. To do so would be to adopt the standards of the paramilitaries."

Human rights groups argue that a decision was taken to kill rather than arrest those involved and that little regard seemed to have been had for the safety of the public.

 The eight IRA members were Patrick Kelly, 30; Padraig McKearney, 33; James Lynagh, 32; Declan Arthurs, 21; Michael Gormley, 24; Seamus Donnelly, 19; Eugene Kelly, 26; Gerard O'Callaghan, 29.

webTitle: Comment: Decision day looms for the church in Africa

fields.headline: Decision day looms for the church in Africa
fields.standfirst:
Face to Faith
Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Whose side is the established church on? It is a timeworn question, but one that has a special resonance in Africa since the Rwandan genocide.
fields.body:
Whose side is the established church on? It is a timeworn question, but one that has a special resonance in Africa since the Rwandan genocide.

The Rev Tim Neill, former vicar-general of Zimbabwe, will tell you it is certainly not the ordinary people of his country. Neill has finally given up on the Anglican church after months of wrangling with the hierarchy over its failure to offer even the mildest criticism of Robert Mugabe's murderous tactics to cling on to power.

In Rwanda, the Roman Catholic and Anglican churches stood by the government as it killed one in 10 of the population seven years ago. Even today, Rome will not face up to the extent of its complicity in the genocide; the Anglican church has, at least, admitted its culpability.

The scale of the crime is wholly different, but Neill sees the churches in Zimbabwe as no less immoral for their betrayal of those they should be defending. For months, the leaders of neither of the major churches criticised the state-orchestrated violence aimed at perpetuating Mugabe's unpopular rule.

The Catholic church finally issued a pastoral letter, to be read tomorrow, but it falls short of a wholehearted condemnation of the Zimbabwe government. The final straw for Neill came last December, with the election of a new Anglican bishop of Mashonaland, who, he says, described Mugabe as "God's second son". Neill is taking holiday leave, in part to avoid having to attend the new bishop's enthronement this weekend, before finally leaving the church on July 1.

Before he quit, he endured a campaign of vilification, which included a letter, circulated within the church, accusing him of being a racist, and another which threatened him with "an early passport to hell". "The Anglican leadership is in the pocket of the government," he said. "Now, I think it will be worse. I think the bishops will stifle criticism of Mugabe. They will more actively take his side."

At 47, Neill is a highly political priest. He has regularly made his church - St Luke's in Greendale, a quiet Harare suburb - available for opposition rallies. Mugabe's main challenger, Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, spoke there to an evenly divided audience of blacks and whites in March.

Neill rails against the government at "political" funerals, such as those of murdered white farmers. Denouncing the ruling Zanu-PF party, he has said: "Only a cruel and despotic party could spend millions on a pointless war in the Congo and leave its own hospitals without proper medicines."

State-run television has accused Neill of running a hate campaign against Mugabe. The then head of the Anglican church in Zimbabwe, Jonathan Siyachitema, distanced himself from the priest's sermons and even threatened disciplinary action.

It did not deter Neill. "At a time when the nation faces the possibility of great change, the church cannot ignore issues that affect the congregation," he said. "What I have been trying to do is encourage people to know more about the issues that affect them."

The confrontation between the white priest and the Anglican leadership came to a head over the election of the new bishop of Mashonaland. Neill was one of four contenders beaten by the last-minute nomination of the Rev Norbert Kunonga, an outspoken supporter of Mugabe. Neill alleges there were underhand tactics, including a campaign of vilification against him and intimidation of electors by the secret police. "This is a Zanu-PF appointment," he said. "The decision was that this is the man; I think they were scared by someone like me."

Neill tried to block Kunonga's confirmation in January, but bishops of the Church of the Province of Central Africa, headquartered in Zambia, upheld the election. In March, Kunonga stopped Maria Stevens, the widow of the first white farmer murdered by land invaders in Zimbabwe, from commemorating the anniversary of his death with a religious march and service to remember all victims of political violence.

The Catholic church has shown only marginally more willingness to condemn the government's crimes, though for years it tried to stifle criticism. Four years ago, the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace in Zimbabwe produced a damning report on the massacres by Mugabe's army in Matabeland shortly after he came to power in 1980 - it was suppressed by the church. Individual priests have been beaten on opposition demonstrations, but their superiors failed to criticise the police for that abuse.

Earlier this year, the Catholic church's Conference of Religious Superiors attacked the government in a series of newspaper advertisements. "This is no longer a free country," they said. "People live in abject fear of violence, crime and threats. The rule of law is no longer respected; terror and intimidation go unpunished." They emphasised the need for land redistribution, though not as it is being handled. "Those who bear responsibility for the suffering of the people need to know that they will be held accountable for their actions."

The Catholic church leadership belatedly offered a slap on the hand to Mugabe this week with a rebuke of political violence. But it failed to name either the president or his party in the pastoral letter.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: News in brief
fields.body:
Uncle saved by nephew's heart

Lawrence McMonagle was recovering at the Freeman hospital, Newcastle upon Tyne, yesterday following the transplanting of his murdered nephew's heart.

Mark Robinson, 22, was fatally wounded as he walked home after a night out in Derry. He had signed an organ donor card only last week after he saw how his uncle desperately needed a new heart.

Mr McMonagle was flown from Belfast city hospital to Newcastle for the operation on Wednesday.

BBC Experience to close

The BBC Experience, based beneath Broadcasting House in London, will close in July, saving about £500,000 a year for programme making, the BBC said yesterday.

The attraction won a London tourist board award but failed to draw enough people to cover the £1m annual costs.

Edward VIII love letters

Love letters from Edward VIII, when he was the Prince of Wales, to his sweetheart Freda Dudley-Ward are to be auctioned at Bonhams & Brooks in London on June 5.

In one letter, dated April 18 1920, Edward, who would later abdicate to marry the American divorcee Mrs Simpson, told Freda: "Mon amour, I swear I'll never marry any other woman but you."

Air quality improving

Air quality is improving, with pollution levels in the UK almost halving in a year, according to the government's "quality of life barometer" indicators yesterday. They showed there were 16 days in 2000 when air pollution in urban areas was measured as moderate, high or very high. The year before, there were 30 days, and in 1998, 23 days.

Gang murder in Belfast

A gang shot dead a man in his late 30s in Belfast city centre just before 4pm yesterday in what is thought to be a drugs-related feud. The man was shot three times as he returned to his car from his girlfriend's house, a few hundred yards from the city's main shopping area, Royal Avenue.

Black officer gets top Met job

Scotland Yard yesterday said it had appointed a black police officer to the fourth highest post in the force. Mike Fuller, 42, has been promoted to deputy assistant commissioner.

He currently heads Operation Trident, the squad targeting gang shootings.

Island bolthole on offer

Looking for an escape from the rat race? The RSPB is seeking a live-in warden for Ramsey Island, its sprawling 625-acre reserve off the west Wales coast.

fields.headline: Lowry complex honours Guardian photographer
fields.trailText: Denis Thorpe, the photographer who spent his entire Guardian working life in Manchester and escaped before the digital camera became king, once photographed LS Lowry and produced a classic portrait of a smiling artist holding one of his own works.
fields.body:
Denis Thorpe, the photographer who spent his entire Guardian working life in Manchester and escaped before the digital camera became king, once photographed LS Lowry and produced a classic portrait of a smiling artist holding one of his own works.

The morning after Lowry died in February 1976, Thorpe talked his way past the security men to photograph the artist's home before its contents were cleared. It was an act of homage: Thorpe took pictures of the the artist's studio, his sitting room, the hall with battered raincoat and trilby on the pegs and the bedroom where Lowry kept his favourite pre-Raphaelite pictures.

The photographs have become a priceless documentary record of part of the life of an artist who some critics love to hate but who retains a firm place in the hearts of those who hang his prints above their mantlepieces.

Thorpe's photographs and reminiscences have been incorporated into a video which introduces a visit to the Lowry galleries in the new shining arts complex in Salford named after the artist.

So it is fitting that an exhibition of Thorpe's work in Britain and Ireland should be staged at the Lowry. It was opened last night by the former Beirut hostage Brian Keenan, whom Thorpe photographed on the holy mountain of Croagh Patrick in Mayo, having chased round much of the Irish county to find him.

It is the only picture in the exhibition which is in colour: a rainbow arches over Keenan's head in a portrait which speaks of courage, endurance and a kind of peace.

Some of the earliest photographs, taken more than 50 years ago, are of Thorpe's parents at home in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, the town where he launched his career as a journalist: he began as a reporter but was seduced by pictures and was there to record the stricken faces at the Cresswell colliery disaster in 1950.

Thorpe was back with the miners during the 1984-85 strike and caught both resignation and despair in the face of a man on his first shift the day the dispute ended.

Many of us who worked with Thorpe will recognise old friends: Hebden Bridge, the most requested Guardian photograph ever, Ribblehead viaduct (we accused him of putting oily rags in the locomotive's firebox to get the smoke right over Ingleborough), and the juggler on the unicycle.

webTitle: Census post-back scheme brings officials unexpected returns

fields.headline: Census post-back scheme brings officials unexpected returns
fields.trailText: Census officials learned yesterday that they should never underestimate the diligence and sense of civic duty of the people they are trying to survey.
fields.body:
Census officials learned yesterday that they should never underestimate the diligence and sense of civic duty of the people they are trying to survey.

First they found something unusual in one of the yellow post-back envelopes that have already been filled by more than 11m households since census day last Sunday.

A pensioner in her 60s from the north London borough of Islington sent her 2001 form, duly completed. But she also enclosed her 1991 return.

She had filled it in meticulously 10 years ago and stored it in a safe place until someone in a position of authority came to collect it. No one ever arrived.

A census official said: "In 1991 we collected the forms personally from every address, instead of using post-back as we are doing this time. For reasons we will never know she was missed on the collection round. Her form will be treated with respect and stored confidentially with all the others from 1991 for another 90 years."

As news of the event spread around the census grapevine, a report came in from Somerset where a man had sent back forms for 2001 and 1991 with a note attached. "I have been waiting for 10 years for someone to collect this census form," he wrote. "I explained to the lady distributor that I would not be home on Monday 21 April 1991."

A spokesman for the office of national statistics said the post-back system being used this time should increase the efficiency of data collection.

Len Cook, the registrar general for England and Wales, said he was delighted by the number of census forms returned this week by post.

By lunchtime on Thursday 11,031,788 forms had been sent - 48% of the expected total. Sheffield was in the lead with a 61% return, followed by Birmingham (60%), the north-east (59%) and Wales (55%). The laggards were Liverpool (34%) and greater London (40%).

Mr Cook urged the remaining householders to post back the forms. Census staff are to start calling to collect forms from Wednesday.

The number of callers to the census helpline, 0845 301 2001, topped 2m yesterday, but the daily rate has fallen to 37,000.

webTitle: Storm as head of national blood authority calls gay donors 'evil'

fields.headline: Storm as head of national blood authority calls gay donors 'evil'
fields.trailText: The head of Britain's blood donor service sparked outrage yesterday after claiming that gay men who defied a ban to give blood were "evil".
fields.body:
The head of Britain's blood donor service sparked outrage yesterday after claiming that gay men who defied a ban to give blood were "evil".

MPs and gay rights groups united in questioning the judgment of Mike Fogden, the chairman of the national blood authority, who also accused gay blood donors of "putting at risk the innocent lives of innocent patients".

The Department of Health said it "deplored" the tone and language of the remarks which it described as "inappropriate and unjustified", while Angela Mason, the director of the gay rights group Stonewall, suggested the government should bring him to account.

Mr Fogden's comments came in a response to a letter in the Pink Paper, in which a 29-year-old gay man said: "I'm about to commit a moral offence. I'm going to give blood even though they clearly state they do not want 'Men who have had sex (even safe sex) with another man'. Am I evil?"

Mr Fogden replied: "The answer is yes, he is evil and also a liar. He is evil because he is prepared to put at risk the innocent life of an innocent patient (even a newborn child) to satisfy his own selfish prejudice. He is also a liar because he is dishonest in answering our questionnaire."

The paper ran a three-page feature and editorial condemning his views.

Last night, the Department of Health said Mr Fogden had been hauled into a meeting with the junior health minister Lord Hunt, who oversees blood donor issues, and told that the letter "was totally unacceptable and displayed a serious lack of judgment". The body's chief executive was also contacted, and Mr Fogden forced to write an apology.

In this second letter to the paper, he offered his "sincere apologies" for the letter, which had, he said, been written in haste. "The tone was ill-conceived and unnecessarily judgmental," he added.

But he maintained the policy behind the comments was correct, arguing that the ban was necessary since screening methods for blood still fail to detect HIV during the first 22 days of infection. He added that, in a recent case in the UK, a gay man who gave blood on a regular basis transmitted the HIV infection to three patients while in this "window period".

Britain has banned blood donations from all gay men since the early 80s, as well as donations from other groups deemed high risk, such as intravenous drug users and prostitutes- but gay rights groups have pushed for less stringent regulations.

Last night, the Department of Health said that current medical opinion suggested the policy should remain in place but its criticism of Mr Fogden found widespread backing.

Shaun Woodward, the Labour MP who defected from the Tories because of their hardline policy on gay rights, said: "It is harmful because it sends out the prejudice that HIV/Aids is a gay man's disease and HIV doesn't discriminate in this way."

Mr Fogden was unavailable for comment last night.

fields.headline: Edward Rector
fields.standfirst: Pilot at the launch of a superpower struggle
fields.trailText: Pilot at the launch of a superpower struggle.
fields.body:
In the late summer and early autumn of 1941 a group of American pilots, largely drawn from the United States armed services, arrived at Keydaw Field, a Royal Air Force station at Toungoo, in Burma. Their mission was to fight the Japanese, at a time when the US was still at peace. Their presence heralded the birth of America's active military relationship with the Chinese nationalists; a tangled, contradictory involvement whose most recent manifestation has been the furore over US arms sales to nationalist Taiwan and the downing last month of the US Navy spy plane by the Chinese Communist government.

Edward Rector, who has died of a heart attack aged 84, was among those pilots, recruited for a unit whose official title was the American Volunteer Group (AVG). They soon got another name, the Flying Tigers, and, as early as 1942, their flight into mythology had occasioned a John Wayne flagwaving movie.

At a time when the Japanese were sweeping all before them, the 100-strong unit - which never exceeded 70 pilots, or more than 49 Curtiss-P40 fighters ready for combat - provided a glimmer of hope for the western allies. In seven months, they shot down 296 Japanese aircraft (plus 153 probables); Rector, who was credited with the first hit, accounted for 7.5 of them. The group lost four pilots and 12 of its P40s.

Rector had been a flier on the aircraft carrier USS Ranger, based in Norfolk, Virginia, when he received an offer to join the AVG. Born in Marshall, North Carolina, he had graduated from Catawba College, in Salisbury, NC, in 1938, and joined the US navy.

A devotee of Rudyard Kipling and tales of imperial adventure, he saw the AVG as an opportunity to test himself and, as he told Military History magazine earlier this year, "be paid a fabulous salary". As it was, the pilots got $600 a month, plus $500 for every Japanese aeroplane they brought down.

The AVG was the brainchild of Colonel Claire Chennault, a maverick former USAAF fighter pilot, who had been recruited as aeronautical adviser to the Chinese nationalist leader, Chiang Kai-Shek, in 1937 - soon after the outbreak of the Sino-Japanese war. He trained mercenary and Chinese pilots, but they made limited headway against the invaders. The Japanese occupied eastern China, and controlled the coast; Mao Zedong's communists were strong in the north, while the nationalists had moved their headquarters to the mountainous south-west. Their overland supply route was the Burma Road. The AVG was to provide air cover.

The fliers had hardly completed their acclimatisation when the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbour, and precipitated US involvement in the war. One squadron was sent to Rangoon, the other two, including Rector's second pursuit squadron, were deployed to Kunming, in China. On December 20, 14 P40s intercepted 10 raiding Mitsubishi bombers - and shot down nine.

Shortly afterwards, the China-based squadrons were back in Burma. The Japanese advance was accompanied by an intense air battle for Rangoon, which ended in Japanese victory at the end of February. But the record of the AVG - with support from a small British and Austral- asian force flying obsolete planes - was spectacular.

In the words of General "Vinegar Joe" Stilwell, the US supremo in China, the allies had "got run out of Burma". By April 1942, the Japanese had cut the Burma Road, leaving only the "hump", a 500-mile air-transport flight around the periphery of the Himalayas from Chabua, in Assam, into China. Rows broke out between Chennault and Stilwell. In July 1942, the AVG was disbanded, and few of its veterans remained in China with the US Army Air Force. Rector was one of the pilots to stay on.

He then commanded the 76th squadron of Chennault's shortlived China Air Task Force, which fought on against the overwhelming numerical superiority of the Japanese. Early in 1943, the CATF was replaced by the 14th Air Force, by which time Rector had left China. He returned in 1945, and his last aerial victory was that April.

By the end of the war, Rector had accounted for a further three Japanese aircraft. Later, he served in the US military assistance advisory group, which was attempting to shore up Chiang Kai-Shek's corrupt and discredited regime. In 1949, Mao Zedong's communists came to power in Beijing; the nationalists fled; Chennault set about building what became the CIA's Air America transport outfit, and Rector went to Taiwan, to help the nationalists build a new air force to confront communism.

His decorations included the Legion of Merit, and the British DFC - for the defence of Rangoon. He is survived by two brothers and a sister.

Colonel Edward Rector, airman, born September 28 1916; died April 26 2001

fields.headline: 'Busybee' Contractor
fields.trailText: Behram "Busybee" Contractor, who has died aged 70, was India's only full-time satirist, and its most popular humorist.
fields.body:
Behram "Busybee" Contractor, who has died aged 70, was India's only full-time satirist, and its most popular humorist. His Round And About column began in the Evening News of India in 1966, gravitated to the evening paper, Midday, in 1979, and finally settled in the Afternoon Despatch & Courier, a tabloid he founded and edited.

The column was born when Contractor was asked to file a daily 400-word humorous piece for the News' last page, to break the monotony of a section devoted to Bombay crime.

Out of that idea, and writing in English, Contractor developed as Bombay's chronicler par excellence. Nobody understood, or wrote about the city, better. His style was terse, laconic, and with a rhythm that lent itself to deadpan comedy - on corporations, cricket, the common man, food, filmstars, gangsters, politicians. He also wrote with feeling - and in a lighter vein - about the Parsee community, for whom he became an unoffical spokesperson.

Born in Bombay, Contractor was educated at Bilimoria high school in Panchgini, a hill-station. He graduated in English literature from St Xavier's College, Bombay, and took a degree at the Government Law College, Bombay.

His marriage to Farzana coincided with the metamorphoses of Bombay's culture, including Bollywood's take- over of local high society. Contractor's gaze remained unwavering - but the scruffy man living in one room moved to a fancy apartment, and his ties started matching his clothes. A collection of his writing, From Bombay To Mumbai, was published in 1998. Farzana survives him.

 Behram 'Busybee' Contractor, journalist, born January 12 1931; died April 9 2001
