Though the two had been friends since they met in Paris in 1950, they had a public falling-out in the late 1980s, when Paz's magazine, Vuelta, printed a vituperative attack on Fuentes's work. They never spoke again, creating a schism among their disciples that was unhealed at Paz's death in 1998. "He never called me again; it was up to him to do it." According to Julio Ortega, professor of Hispanic studies at Brown University and co-editor with Fuentes of The Picador Book of Latin American Stories (1998), "everybody in Mexico was waiting for Fuentes to fill the vacuum of power at the top of the cultural pyramid after Paz's death. But he's immune to the Mexican rituals of power. His politics are free of ideology or party lines. He sometimes overreacts, but always as an independent political voice with an instinct for social justice." Fuentes backed Castro's Cuban revolution of 1959, and the Sandinista revolution in Nicaragua 20 years later. He found himself harassed by US officialdom. Invited by NBC in 1962 to debate with the Kennedy administration's undersecretary of state for Latin America, he was denied a visa. "The pretext was that I was a card-carrying communist. I said it was untrue, 'But I'm going to become one thanks to your stupid policies - you're going to make communists of us all in Latin America.' " He was barred from the US for much of the 1960s, till a ship he was on docked in Puerto Rico. "This John Wayne character tore up my landing card, saying I was forbidden in American territory. I said, 'Puerto Rico isn't American, it's part of Latin America, so fuck yourself.'" They reckoned without Fuentes's connections. He enlisted Vargas Llosa, Norman Mailer and American PEN, the writers' association, in a campaign, joined by Senator William Fulbright, to get him exempted from the list barring suspected communists (including Iris Murdoch, García Márquez, Graham Greene, Dario Fo and Simone Signoret) from the US. Fuentes attacked US foreign policy, "not in the back yard, but right here, in the front yard" - the US. From the early 1970s he held a series of professorships at US universities. At the height of the US-backed Contra war in Nicaragua, he slammed the Reagan administration in a Harvard commencement speech in 1983. "I said, 'You fools, you behave like Dr Jekyll at home and Mr Hyde in Latin America. You're making a big mistake.' " Caspar Weinberger, Reagan's defence secretary, was in the front row. In 1987 Fuentes became Harvard's first Robert Kennedy professor of Latin American Studies. Of what he calls the "United States of Amnesia", he says: "It's a country with a short memory. It has to be constantly reminded of its vices and virtues." Styron sees Fuentes as immensely influential among US scholars, with a "purposely ambiguous approach to the US. Because he knows the culture so well, he neither panders to it, nor is he promiscuously critical. He's not an unqualified detractor like so many Latin American leftwing intellectuals." His novel The Old Gringo (1985), which became a film starring Jane Fonda and Gregory Peck, explored the US-Mexican border as a real and symbolic frontier. He returned to it in The Crystal Frontier (1995), a novel in nine stories in which Latinos cross the Rio Grande only to become invisible (terrain covered in Ken Loach's new film, Bread and Roses). Despite the brutal economic realities of a land frontier where the first world abuts the third, Fuentes relishes the "silent reconquest" of the Mexican territories lost in 1848. "In the US, 35 million people speak Spanish," he says. "Los Angeles is the second Spanish-speaking city in the world after Mexico City - and before Madrid or Buenos Aires. These people are bearers of culture." He believes the Latino presence will reshape US politics. "The US has become a multicultural nation, which makes it stronger, not weaker - though it has difficulty accepting the fact." His novel Diana: The Goddess Who Hunts Alone (1994) forayed into autobiography with a thinly veiled portrait of Jean Seberg, the actress who committed suicide in 1979. Fuentes had met her at a New Year's Eve party in 1969, as his first marriage was breaking up. He and Seberg had a "passionate location romance". "We went off together to the wilds of Durango where she was filming a tequila western," he says. "She was brilliant, intelligent, beautiful - but I knew it would only last the time of the filming; she was married and had a son. She was a very hurt person; she'd been yanked out of the Lutheran midwest unprepared to cope with fame. I think it disturbed her emotionally. But I can only be grateful for those two months - very grateful." That and earlier portrayals of women in his novels have drawn feminist criticisms. One of Fuentes's translators, Margaret Sayers Peden, feels his work is steeped in a "Latin culture in which women are whores or madonnas". Alicia Borinsky, professor of Latin American literature at Boston University, views Fuentes as "squarely in a tradition that places men at the centre of history". Yet she adds: "It wasn't a conspiracy of the boom writers but the cultural and social context." Fuentes has since praised a constellation of women writers in what he terms the "boomerang" generation that followed his own. He also wrote The Years with Laura Díaz as a "counterpoint" to The Death of Artemio Cruz. "I always felt a little worm inside me: 'Now you need to write a novel with a woman protagonist.' " While Fuentes remains prolific, some feel he is repeating himself. Ilan Stavans, professor of Spanish studies at Amherst College, Massachusetts, says his "early novels transformed Latin American literature; they mesmerised an entire readership with a new view of the novel and how to perceive Mexico through it. But he got stuck in a vision of history and literature that belongs to the 60s nouveau roman . He's a very fluid and dynamic man, but he's lost touch." Fuentes has champions, however, among a new generation of Latin American writers, the "junior boom", as he calls it, of the past three years. Born in 1968, the Mexican novelist Ignacio Padilla says: "Fuentes is like our grandfather; he's the best example that you can be both local and universal, read both as a portrait of Mexico and as an epic of the world looking for its own identity." Fuentes sees President Vicente Fox Quesada, whose election last year ended 71 years of PRI rule, as "a breath of fresh air. A new Mexican democracy is testing itself, warily but surely. The problems are daunting but a big step has been taken." Democracy is changing what he sees as the role of the Latin American intellectual in speaking for the voiceless. "Civil society has grown stronger; there are cooperatives, the feminist movement, gay rights groups, a free press. So a writer may still speak out - but as a citizen." Yet, he says, responsibility remains. "To maintain the vigour of language and the imagination - that's a role the writer cannot renounce." Education: Schools in Washington DC and Santiago de Chile; Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Mexico City; Institute of Higher International Studies, Geneva. Married: 1959-72 Rita Macedo (one daughter, Cecilia); 1973 Sylvia Lemus (one daughter, Natasha; one son, Carlos - deceased). Career: 1954-58 editor, Revista Mexicana de Literatura; 1974-77 Mexican ambassador to France; 1986 Simón Bolívar professor, Cambridge; 1987 Robert Kennedy professor, Harvard. Some books: Where the Air is Clear, 1958; The Death of Artemio Cruz, 1962; Terra Nostra, 1975; The Old Gringo, 1985; Diana: The Goddess Who Hunts Alone, 1994; El Instinto de Inez, 2001. Honours: 1984 Mexican national award for literature; 1987 Cervantes prize; 1992 Légion d'Honneur.  The Years with Laura DÍaz is published on Thursday by Bloomsbury at £17.99.

fields.headline: Down in one
fields.standfirst: Czechvar
fields.trailText: Czechvar.
fields.body:
Okay, so you can't actually buy Czechvar in Britain, but you can buy a classic lager beer called Budweiser Budvar, which is just as wonderful, mainly because it's exactly the same - the small, state-owned Czech brewery has launched its premium 5% beer in the US under a different name to avoid (it hopes) legal action from global giant Anheuser-Busch, owner of the other Budweiser. The two have been slugging it out for more than a century, and in 1939 the Czechs agreed, under threat of punitive court action, to stop selling its beer in the US under the Budweiser label. Ever since, the Czechs have been smarting over that deal, forced on them at the precise moment when the Nazis were invading their country.

The original, and far better, Czech Budweiser is brewed from Moravian malt, Saaz hops and pure water from an artesian well. It has a full, slightly toasted malt and vanilla aroma, with a good underpinning of resiny hops and a delicious touch of citrus fruit. It is aged (lagered) for 90 days, one of the longest periods in the brewing world. One US distributor is using the promotional tag, 'Only the name has been changed to protect the beer'. American Bud, meanwhile, lists rice before malt on the label. Enough said.

webTitle: Jeremy Lee: The joys of spring

fields.headline: The joys of spring
fields.standfirst: Jeremy Lee banishes winter with first courses using the new season's finest ingredients. After months of cabbage and root veg, it's time to celebrate with fresh peas, asparagus, carrots... and morels, Spring's own magic mushroom
fields.trailText: Jeremy Lee banishes winter with first courses using the new season's finest ingredients. After months of cabbage and root veg, it's time to celebrate with fresh peas, asparagus, carrots... and morels, Spring's own magic mushroom.
fields.body:
Spring, at last. Well, sort of, anyway. A sprightly tread replaces the slow, cowed movement of winter. And fresh and bright are those little bundles of small vegetables that require only a snip at their stalks and little more than a wipe and a rinse before cooking.

The new-crop small potatoes are a particular pleasure - and how about the curious marvel that are morels, a mushroom prized higher than ceps in many quarters, including mine? They appear only in spring, and really should be enjoyed in season, even if their price is similar to that of a great vintage Bordeaux wine. They share few visual characteristics with our usual idea of a mushroom, what with their wide, hollow stalk and a cap that is long, slender, and deeply pitted all over, not unlike a knot of lace.

Take great care in cleaning morels, as there is many a small nook in which small stones and the like can reside. Split them through lengthwise, and, if clean enough, go at them with a brush only or, if needs really must, a quick dunk in plenty of lightly salted water. If you take the latter approach, make sure they are completely dry before cooking.

All recipes serve six.

Mussels, clams and peas

Come spring, there is a short, delightful period when the new-crop potatoes coincide with the end of the mussel season - they combine particularly well. A similar line of thought, albeit born out of sheer necessity, resulted in this mussel, clam and pea dish, which was fashioned out of thin air at the restaurant after an especially busy lunch that fair savaged our plans for the evening menu. By the end, the fridge contained little more than a lot of bits and bods, and out of the wreckage we came up with this union. And very good it is, too - so good, in fact, that it soon became a dish in its own right (as well as a very good accompaniment to steamed hake, which is how we served it that first time).

Fresh peas must be cooked as soon after picking as possible, for the older they are, the more starch develops and the tougher and less sweet they become. Good-quality frozen petits-pois, which are frozen as near as dammit straight after harvest, make a pretty decent alternative.

1 kg mussels
1 kg clams
100ml white wine
4 shallots, chopped fine
500g peas, shelled
1 tbsp olive oil
10g unsalted butter
6 tbsp double cream
1 small handful fresh mint, chopped

Remove the beards from the mussels and put them with the clams in a bucket under running cold water. Leave them for at least half an hour. In a great big pot, fry the shallots slowly in the oil and butter over a gentle heat.

Bring a pan of lightly salted and sugared water (a big pinch of sugar helps bring out the natural sweetness in the peas) up to the boil, then tip in the peas, return to the boil and cook for five minutes or so, until softened. Remove from the heat, and leave the peas in the water - this will prevent any wrinkling.

Drain the mussels and clams, and add to the shallot pot, along with the wine, and cover. Raise the heat and, stirring carefully now and then, cook until all the shells have opened. Discard any that do not. Now pour in the cream. Drain the peas and tip them into the pot. Add the chopped mint, mix together and serve piping hot.

An omelette of potatoes and morels

Having eaten my fill of dried fungi over the winter months, and wonderful though they are, jaded, in the cruel light of a spring day, is still jaded. Morels, like most fungi, make a marvellous pairing with eggs. If you baulk at the cost, then you'd better shy away now; if, however, the very idea makes your spirits soar, let cost be damned - reckless abandon is a good enough reason for a small taste of luxury.

This recipe serves six, but the dish would ideally be made for just two, or even one, for two quite simple reasons: first, you can pile in the mushrooms, and second it's an awful lot easier, not to mention cheaper, to make it for one or two than for six.

2 very large potatoes (approximately 900g in weight)
3 shallots
At least 300g fresh morels
1 clove garlic
9 very fresh free-range eggs
30g unsalted butter
100ml double cream
1 tbsp flat-leaf parsley, leaves picked and chopped
6-8 chives, very finely chopped
Sea salt and a fully-charged pepper mill

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. Peel the potatoes and cut them into a very small dice, much as one would an onion. Rinse under cold water, then dry thoroughly.

Cut the morels in half and gently brush away any shred of forest from within. Peel and very finely chop the shallots and garlic. Once all is prepared, gently warm an ovenproof, heavy-based frying pan and slowly melt the butter in it. Tip in the dried potato dice, shallots and garlic, and fry very gently for 15-20 minutes, until soft, then add the morels and stew lightly for four to five minutes.

Whisk the eggs with the cream, liberally season with salt and pepper, then pour over the mushroom mix. Stir the whole lot together, and strew with the chopped herbs, mixing gently as you do so. When large curds start to form in the mix, pop the pan in the oven and leave to cook for five minutes or so. It is done when the centre of the omelette offers the merest resistance to pressure. Serve piping hot, with a feisty green salad, say, and some crusty bread.

A salad of spring vegetables

The tender fronds and leaves of the first crop of baby vegetables are a real treat. In fact, they work very well in many guises - with pasta, risotto and, in this instance, a salad of very definite flavour that makes a particularly delightful starter. The amounts given are only a broad guide, as it may also be served as an accompaniment to a main course. Although the obvious point to this composed salad is the simple boiling of sweet young vegetables, the addition of a few quickly fried morels is a charming and welcome addition.

Two bundles asparagus
Two handfuls young, fresh peas
Two bunches baby carrots
Two handfuls Jersey Royals (or, if you're lucky, small Ayrshire potatoes)
1 bunch spring onions, chopped fine
Two handfuls broad beans
A handful or two fresh morels
1 handful each lamb's lettuce and baby spinach
1 small handful mint leaves
30g unsalted butter
1 tbsp white-wine vinegar
Sea salt and a fully charged pepper mill
1 tbsp sugar

Place two large pans of water on the stove and bring them up to a furious boil. Pick, wash and dry the leaves and mint. Now clean the baby vegetables, peeling, scraping and rubbing as required.

Start cooking the vegetables, the potatoes and carrots in one pot, those grown above ground in the other. Once all the vegetables are done, do not refresh them in iced water, as I would usually recommend, and instead keep them warm and damp, as this will prevent them from drying out - there's nothing worse in a salade composée.

In another pan, gently fry the morels in a little butter for five to eight minutes. Lay the cleaned salad leaves on six plates.

When all the vegetables are 'done', place them in a bowl with the butter, vinegar, spring onions, mint, salt, pepper and sugar. Toss gently but thoroughly, then pile on top of the leaves. Serve at once

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: Darling beds of May
fields.standfirst: Spring is still there to savour but the scent of summer is positively heady. Ian Spence on a glorious month outdoors
fields.trailText: Spring is still there to savour but the scent of summer is positively heady. Ian Spence on a glorious month outdoors.
fields.body:
Many gardeners regard May as one of the best months in the garden, with the freshness of spring and the promise of summer. There are signs of summer everywhere, yet many spring-flowering bulbs, especially tulips, are still at their best. Trees are in full leaf, and shrubs such as rhododendrons are in full flower in most parts of the country this month. But you can't relax just yet: there's a lot to do in the garden in May, if you're to reap the benefits of sturdy and pleasurable summer blooms.

While many plants are gearing themselves up for their summer display, the spring bedding plants will soon be over, and it's time to think about their replacements. A wide selection of summer bedding plants will be on show at nurseries and garden centres, but resist the temptation to buy these too early in the month unless you have a frost-free greenhouse, conservatory or cold frame to keep them in. The majority of these plants are still quite tender, and in northern parts of the country it may not be safe to plant them out until the end of the month or into June. In more southern, sheltered parts of the country you may get away with planting summer bedding around the middle of the month, but do keep an eye on weather forecasts.

The weather in May is usually quite settled, but it can be changeable and there may still be the occasional sharp frost. These late frosts are the scourge of fruit growers. Most varieties of fruit trees will be in flower now and it only takes one sharp frost to destroy a potential crop for the whole year. So any tender plants being hardened off should be watched carefully and given protection with fleece or sheets of polythene, or put into a cold frame whenever required. The tell-tale signs of a night frost coming are a clear blue sky at the end of a warm, sunny day.

Thought for food

In the vegetable plot you should now be harvesting delicious early vegetables planted out under cloches earlier in the year. To guarantee a succession of young vegetables throughout the summer, continue with regular sowing of all vegetables at seven- or 10-day intervals. Hoeing also becomes a very regular chore among vegetables now, as weeds burgeon in the milder conditions. With the warmer, drier weather, watering may now become necessary, but don't use water indiscriminately, especially at this early stage in the season.

Borders

Herbaceous perennials are now growing fast and need to be staked, if this has not already been done. This is a job which often gets forgotten until it is too late, and the plants begin to flop all over the place and look unsightly. By this stage trying to tie up the stems is a hopeless task, and it is often better to cut the plants back hard and let them grow away again. The flowers may be later, but the plant will look much better for cutting back.

A word about water

Water in the garden cools and refreshes the air around it, and is also a real treat for wildlife - not only your regular garden friends, but new visitors such as dragonflies and frogs will be drawn to even the smallest feature. If you already have one this is the time to thin out excessive growth on aquatic plants, remove duckweed and blanket weed and generally tidy up the pond before summer.

fields.headline: Talk of the devil
fields.standfirst: You're not going to believe this, but estate agents are bound by law to tell you the truth. The key is to ask them pointed questions, says Charles Jennings, and take their somewhat florid talk with a pinch of salt
fields.trailText: When you're searching for a place to live, the first really big, defining moment comes at the point where the estate agent shows you around a property. How do you get a true impression of the place, remember which questions to ask the agent and (this is the hard bit) ascertain whether he or she is telling the truth? After all, this is traditionally the agent's job - to be econo-mical with the truth, to be profligate with the hype. How far will they go before telling out-and-out lies?
fields.body:
When you're searching for a place to live, the first really big, defining moment comes at the point where the estate agent shows you around a property. How do you get a true impression of the place, remember which questions to ask the agent and (this is the hard bit) ascertain whether he or she is telling the truth? After all, this is traditionally the agent's job - to be econo-mical with the truth, to be profligate with the hype. How far will they go before telling out-and-out lies?

Theoretically, not that far. Ever since the Property Misdescriptions Act of 1991 came into force, estate agents have been obliged to mind their language. Under the terms of the act, it's an offence to make false or misleading statements about specific aspects of the property or land. Trading standards officers can enforce the act, and prosecution can lead to a £5,000 fine. What's more, a "statement", as the act defines it, can be written, spoken or conveyed by a picture: anything, in other words, that gives you information.

In practice, this means that an estate agent doesn't have to mention the glue factory next door, but if he or she does, they must be truthful about how far away it is and what kind of toxicity emerges from it. When room sizes are mentioned, the dimensions must be correct. If the promotional photos are tinkered with (to crop out the electricity pylon in the garden, say), that, too, may be an offence.

Of course, you'd be foolish not to do your own thorough research: talk to the neighbours and local authority, and walk around the area at different times of the day. Then make a list of questions - mentioning specifics - that your agent will have to answer truthfully: why, exactly, is the back of the house a foot lower than the front? If the place has been on the market for some time, what happened to any other buyers? If they dropped out, why? Have there been any bad surveyor's reports? Finally, remember that estate agents are nothing if not inventive. There are still countless ways they can gild the lily without actually breaking the law. So, for those currently caught up in the property market, here (right) is a brief lexicon of the more popular agents' terms, still cheerfully in use.

Architect designed adj.phr. Doesn't resemble a house.

Character n. Tendency of property to be abnormal, inconvenient, uninhabitable; synonym for old age and decrepitude; in certain contexts exact synonym for damp; as in masses of character , synonym for dangerously eccentric. Also a. in phrase character property , freakish monstrosity.

Charming adj. Unsuitable for anyone under 30; may contain period features (q.v.) and be deceptively spacious (q.v.).

Contemporary adj. Almost imperceptibly out of date. In phrase contemporary feel , indicates hesitant use of brushed steel in kitchen, plus downstairs toilet washbasin like stealth bomber.

Deceptively spacious adj. phr. So deceptive as not to appear spacious at all.

Features n.pl. Anything of debatable value, permanently associated with property; in phrase period features , anything older than 1956 which adds to the inconvenience of the property; in phrase contemporary (q.v.) features, anything added in the past three years on tail end of last design craze.

Flexible adj. Unsuited for any fixed purpose; in phrase flexible accommodation , indicates that previous owners have tried every ground-floor room as dining room before giving up and putting property on market.

In need of modernisation adj. phr. In state of terminal ruination, blighted by rot; may have corpse under floorboards. When used in conjunction with adj. phr. suit DIY enthusiast , indicates property suited to bankrupt fantasist with vast supply of builders' mastic.

In the heart of adv. phr. In immediate proximity to the principal thoroughfare of; girdled by vicious one-way system; has branch of Woolworths at rear. When used in conjunction with specific location (ie, 'In the heart of Winchmore Hill'), synonym for wholly inaccessible.

Presented in immaculate condition adj. phr. Hastily repainted to create impression of startling newness; apparently antonym for in need of modernisation (q.v.) but can, in reality, refer to same building three months after acquisition by property speculator with silver Mercedes and string of pending court appearances.

Prestigious adj. Overpriced.

Spectacular adj. Ridiculous; often used in association with substantial, prestigious (q.v.) ; often refers to homes owned by retired rock musicians, pre-bust software entrepreneurs, TV celebs.

fields.headline: Let's move to...
fields.standfirst: ... The south coast of Fife
fields.trailText: ... The south coast of Fife.
fields.body:
Edinburgh's gorgeous, but you don't see seals sunning themselves on the Royal Mile, do you? Lovers of animals and cutesy cottages should slip across the Firth of Forth, to the coast around Culross and Aberdour. Edinburgh and Silicon Glen are commutable, and once home you can settle in front of a sea view, and watch your own real-life David Attenborough documentary.

Ups: The Ochill Hills are behind you, and, in front, Blue Flag beaches. You want historic monuments, you got 'em.

Downs: It's been 'discovered', so the Edinburgh run is busy. Is it possible to be too quaint? Some dour industry.

Getting around: Aberdour is 30-45 minutes from Edinburgh by train. The M90 is 10 minutes away: you can drive to Edinburgh in 40-60 minutes. Handy too for Stirling (15 miles away).

Schools: Local schools, such as Aberdour Primary or Kirkcaldy High, are fine. The best independents, for all ages, are in St Andrews.

Property: Culross and Aberdour have whitewashed fisherman's cottages with red pantiles: in high demand. Look for modern 'executive homes' in sought-after Dalgety Bay, and country cottages inland. One- or two-bedroom flats £20,000-£30,000. Detached three- to four-bedroom period houses £60,000-£90,000. 'Executive homes' up to £150,000. Agents include Stirling, Eunson & Ferguson (01383 621162) and Your Move (01383 824242).

webTitle: All the people I've ever slept with

fields.headline: All the people I've ever slept with
fields.standfirst: No 3: The best friend
fields.trailText: No 3: The best friend.
fields.body:
School was nearly over. Me and my best friend Jack had spent the summer revising, passing driving tests and sitting exams together. We were, everyone said, like brother and sister, even looked alike. When he started going out with Jane, I teased him and felt a bit usurped, but knew our friendship was stronger than theirs would ever be.

The night of Leavers' Dance, I went to my mate Sarah's house where all the girls got ready. I traded my usual trainers and jeans for a scarlet, strapless dress and high heels. Sarah put on my lipstick and we all tripped into town like kids dressed up in their mothers' clothes. Jack whistled when he saw me, even though his arm was round Jane's milky white shoulders. Later, I stole him off her for a smooch and he whispered in my ear that I scrubbed up pretty good. Later, we shared a taxi back to our suburb. We started kissing, and by the time we got to his house he didn't need to ask if I wanted to go inside with him.

Afterwards, we both laughed because his chest hairs had stuck to my chest with the sweatiness of it all. We spent the summer avoiding Jane and doing it while our parents were out.

Next week: The public schoolboy/proper boyfriend No1.

fields.headline: The daily grid
fields.standfirst: Hold a tile in your hand, and it can be an object of exquisite beauty. Then see it, shimmering and repeating across your wall, and it's a work of art. Sophie Radice is addicted
fields.trailText: Hold a tile in your hand, and it can be an object of exquisite beauty. Then see it, shimmering and repeating across your wall, and it's a work of art. Sophie Radice is addicted.
fields.body:
A year ago I went through every homeowner's nightmare: subsidence. But there was a bright side to the drama. After my house was pulled apart and put back together again by the insurance company, I got to choose new paint colours and - most exciting of all - tiles for the kitchen to replace those which the builder "accidentally on purpose" cracked with a large hammer. They had to be as low-priced as the old ones, but that didn't stop me going on a labyrinthine search to find the most beautiful and interesting tiles on offer. And somewhere along the line, I got hooked.

Once you have tiles on the brain, the whole world seems divided into shining grids. They cover mosques and churches (inside and outside), they provide an easy-to-clean surface for schools, shops, civic buildings and lavatories, they're hard-wearing and, above all, beautiful.

In your hand a tile can be a sensual object. When multiplied and combined with others, it becomes a work of art. Nothing beats a tile for quality and intensity of colour which, when splattered with dirt or toothpaste, needs just a quick wipe or a shower of rain to restore it to its original lustre.

My long (and somewhat obsessive) tile odyssey took me way beyond the local DIY superstore. There's a whole market in old tiles at reclamation and architectural salvage yards, car-boot sales and tile dealers (yes, they exist!). Tiles which are more than about 80 years old are classed as antiques, and can change hands for hundreds of pounds (perhaps it's a bit rash to stick these ones up behind a sink).

But how about a tile made the traditional way? James, from a small, one-off tile shop near my house, proudly shows me a Moroccan tile in matt casbah blue which is still made the traditional way from gypsum and sand. Tiny marks on the back of each tile show where they have been leant up against the wall to dry in the sun. He shows me another Moroccan tile in which the pattern is made with something like cookie moulds. "Look at the light bleeding of the colours into each other," he gushes.

It is these slight imperfections which make them so desirable: each one is unique. You can find modern tiles still made the traditional way in most of the specialist tile shops all over the country. Hand-painted tiles from Seville, with pictures of birds and flowers, or Dutch tiles with pictures of soldiers and horsemen, have not changed much in the last couple of hundred years and can still be bought either in their country of origin or in specialist shops in this country.

What if you want something contemporary? The ancient art of tile-making has definitely entered the 21st century. One of the most popular new techniques is to bubble "oxygenated" glass tiles in pale aqua, turquoise or glacier blue. Their cool, watery colours would look fresh and minty in any bathroom, but might be too toothpastey for your average kitchen. The newest blue translucent glass tiles by Avanti (large at 20cm x 20cm) are wonderful as a single object, but would need a large space not to seem claustrophobic en masse.

Another cutting-edge newcomer is the uncompromisingly modern "live" tile in blue or grey: they're silvery, but they also seem to move with the light, almost like a hologram. Because such innovative tiles tend to dominate any interior, ask to view them over a wide surface area (most tile shops have boards showing how the tiles will look together). Metal tiles will fit in any where, particularly if you want a shiny futuristic look to go with your Smeg oven. Or, for a more radical look, how about Jenni Redstone's tiles covered in graffiti (graffiti is definitely this year's fashion)? To do this, Redstone takes pictures of the graffiti, before computer manipulating the photos and heat pressing the designs on to the tiles.

Dotting the odd expensive tile among cheaper ones is a good way not only of keeping the price down but also stopping a Delft, Mexican or Victorian pattern becoming overwhelming. But it can look odd to intersperse more contemporary tiles with plain white ones: they're too particular to chuck in with something else. The ever-popular mosaic, though, can be mixed in to make lines and edges for the more ordinary tile. Artist Sarah Horrillo uses a combination of mosaic and smashed tiles in her large ceramic compositions for fireplaces, bathrooms and kitchens. She has recently completed a series of large panels for a pub, representing large flower forms. "I like the different textures that the combination of ceramic tiles and glass mosaic gives me," she says. "I also enjoy smashing a plain tile up and making it into something beautiful and interesting." She goes straight to the main importer of Italian mosaic, Udny Edgar & Co, in south London, the mecca to all mosaic makers.

Tile designer Lubna Chowdhary also uses old tiles in her work, cutting plain ones into oblongs to contrast with her own exquisite handmade tiles. Chowdhary works on a commission basis, designing and installing her whole composition, rather then selling individual tiles. Each surface is different and she is constantly experimenting with texture and colour, firing a tile a number of times to gain the rich and varied effect that makes her work so memorable.

"People always comment that because of the bright colours and circular shapes my inspiration must be from nature, but actually I used to follow my dad around and help him with the DIY," she says. "I enjoy taking things apart and putting them together again. Rather than the sun and flow ers, it's more likely to be the inside of a transistor radio that's in my head while I work."

By contrast, Dominic Crinson often exploits the shapes and forms of natural objects, using the hi-tech method of digitally processing images on to ready-made tiles: fruits sliced through the middle, gorgeous flowers, a close up of the purple whirls inside a red cabbage, the sensuous forms of a woman's breast or the curve of a shell. He is coy about the technicalities of achieving such intensity of colour, only saying that the image is "impregnated on to the surface of the tiles". He will even transfer a customer's chosen image on to tiles on request. Unfortunately my insurance budget meant that I had to look elsewhere.

I found some beautiful - and cheap - tiles at my local trade decorating centre, among the beige and floral dross. One friend had advised me to buy plain, white tiles and get my kids to decorate a few with tile paint, but in the end I went for crackle tiles of blue and turquoise green, their surface fired at high temperatures in an Italian factory to create that broken-glaze effect. I put the two colours together, ignoring my mother's advice that "blue and green should never be seen", and created something that gives me a little jolt of pleasure almost every time I see it

 For inspiration and an idea of what different tiles look like in situ, try Blue & White Living, by Stephanie Hoppen (Collins & Brown, £14.99).

fields.headline: Paint a different picture
fields.standfirst: For centuries, artists used dogs as male symbols and cats as female. Today, at long last, such outdated notions have finally been kicked into touch, says JD Carpentieri
fields.trailText: For centuries, artists used dogs as male symbols and cats as female. Today, at long last, such outdated notions have finally been kicked into touch, says JD Carpentieri.
fields.body:
In 1757, William Hogarth painted an image of a dog urinating on a stack of old master paintings. Sadly, this flamboyant piece of art criticism - originally part of Hogarth Painting The Comic Muse - never saw the light of day. Whether he got cold feet or simply changed his mind, the artist buried the cock-legged canine under several layers of paint.

That many of Hogarth's paintings featured dogs is no anomaly. If it's true that the first two loves of British art are the portrait and the landscape, the third is surely the pet. "I had rather see a portrait of a dog I know," observed Samuel Johnson, "than all the allegories you can show me." The appeal of dogs and cats in art has been two-fold. Their presence adds a tone of naturalness to human portraits, as well as telling us about their owners - or even, in Hogarth's case, speaking for them.

The European origin of pets as vehicles of information can be traced to Jan van Eyck's brilliant Arnolfini Marriage (1434), which depicts a freshly wedded couple posing in their new home. Eager and pale, the young wife bunches her dress around her belly. She may be indicating lust, or perhaps an impatient desire to conceive. Her faithfulness is not in question - the lapdog at the hem of her dress is a standard symbol of a woman's conjugal fidelity.

In Nicolas de Largillière's 1695 portrait of James II's children, meanwhile, the exiled monarch's daughter is paired with a similarly faithful pooch. Her brother's majestic greyhound carries its own message; as Byron would later write of his own dog, James's hound conveys "strength without insolence . . . all the virtues of man without his vices". Posed over a vine of morning glory - symbolising the faith of the English people - the regal greyhound is James's alter ego, embodying his claim to the throne.

Ironically, when Elizabeth I posed for an equally symbol-laden portrait more than half way through her reign, she was portrayed not with a large dog emblematic of her status but with the very same type of lapdog seen in the Arnolfini Marriage. "I will make a faithful wife," the 52-year-old monarch wryly promises her political suitors, none of whom she has the slightest intention of marrying.

When the Virgin Queen was crowned, her supporters stuffed cats into straw effigies of the Pope and burned them alive in celebration. By the 19th century, however, the long-standing European belief that cats were linked to witchcraft and evil - and were thus fair game for such tortures - had abated, and the feline form began appearing alongside women in portraits. But it never appeared with men, who continued posing with large dogs - even when those dogs didn't actually exist. Such was the case in Sir William Allan's 1831 portrait of Sir Walter Scott, in which Scott's faithful deerhound rests at his master's feet. Faithful indeed - the poor animal had been dead for years. Even in France, where cats became favourite subjects of both Renoir and Picasso, artists felt that cats were somehow too emasculating to be paired with men. For Renoir, especially, cats and women were twin domestic goddesses, inextricably linked, and in his paintings such as Woman With A Cat (1875) they share a grace and beauty that he felt men could never hope to achieve.

Even today, with cat-owning male politicians still reluctant to be photographed with their pets, David Hockney's Mr And Mrs Clark And Percy (1970-71) is an anomaly. The painting, now at Tate Liverpool, reflects van Eyck's Arnolfini Marriage in depicting a newly married couple in their sunlit home. But there are no symbols of female fidelity or of domesticity in this house. The pet, a haughtily posed puss with its back turned to the painter, has attached itself not to the woman, Celia Birtwell, but to her husband, Ossie Clark.

In a further violation of gender conventions, Mr Clark is seated while his wife stands. As in Renoir, the cat is linked to the rich textures that signify the comforts of home. In this picture, however, it is through Ossie Clark, as he digs his bare feet into the lush shag rug. In a final twist, the cat, whose real name was Blanche, is re-titled Percy, slang for penis. But all this does not mean that Ossie Clark is playing little woman to Celia Birtwell's big daddy - "My main aim was to paint the relationship of these two people," Hockney once wrote.

By freeing the pet from its traditional role, Hockney frees his human subjects from theirs at the same time. Women are no longer defined by their professed fidelity or domesticity, and men don't have to advertise their manliness through canine alter egos. After almost six centuries of being painted with pets, they can, at last, simply be themselves.

Sadly, this flamboyant piece of art criticism - originally part of Hogarth Painting The Comic Muse - never saw the light of day. Whether he got cold feet or simply changed his mind, the artist buried the cock-legged canine under several layers of paint. That many of Hogarth's paintings featured dogs is no anomaly. If it's true that the first two loves of British art are the portrait and the landscape, the third is surely the pet. "I had rather see a portrait of a dog I know," observed Samuel Johnson, "than all the allegories you can show me." The appeal of dogs and cats in art has been two-fold. Their presence adds a tone of naturalness to human portraits, as well as telling us about their owners - or even, in Hogarth's case, speaking for them. The European origin of pets as vehicles of information can be traced to Jan van Eyck's brilliant Arnolfini Marriage (1434), which depicts a freshly wedded couple posing in their new home. Eager and pale, the young wife bunches her dress around her belly. She may be indicating lust, or perhaps an impatient desire to conceive. Her faithfulness is not in question - the lapdog at the hem of her dress is a standard symbol of a woman's conjugal fidelity. In Nicolas de Largillière's 1695 portrait of James II's children, meanwhile, the exiled monarch's daughter is paired with a similarly faithful pooch. Her brother's majestic greyhound carries its own message; as Byron would later write of his own dog, James's hound conveys "strength without insolence . . . all the virtues of man without his vices". Posed over a vine of morning glory - symbolising the faith of the English people - the regal greyhound is James's alter ego, embodying his claim to the throne. Ironically, when Elizabeth I posed for an equally symbol-laden portrait more than half way through her reign, she was portrayed not with a large dog emblematic of her status but with the very same type of lapdog seen in the Arnolfini Marriage. "I will make a faithful wife," the 52-year-old monarch wryly promises her political suitors, none of whom she has the slightest intention of marrying. When the Virgin Queen was crowned, her supporters stuffed cats into straw effigies of the Pope and burned them alive in celebration. By the 19th century, however, the long-standing European belief that cats were linked to witchcraft and evil - and were thus fair game for such tortures - had abated, and the feline form began appearing alongside women in portraits. But it never appeared with men, who continued posing with large dogs - even when those dogs didn't actually exist. Such was the case in Sir William Allan's 1831 portrait of Sir Walter Scott, in which Scott's faithful deerhound rests at his master's feet. Faithful indeed - the poor animal had been dead for years. Even in France, where cats became favourite subjects of both Renoir and Picasso, artists felt that cats were somehow too emasculating to be paired with men. For Renoir, especially, cats and women were twin domestic goddesses, inextricably linked, and in his paintings such as Woman With A Cat (1875) they share a grace and beauty that he felt men could never hope to achieve. Even today, with cat-owning male politicians still reluctant to be photographed with their pets, David Hockney's Mr And Mrs Clark And Percy (1970-71) is an anomaly. The painting, now at Tate Liverpool, reflects van Eyck's Arnolfini Marriage in depicting a newly married couple in their sunlit home. But there are no symbols of female fidelity or of domesticity in this house. The pet, a haughtily posed puss with its back turned to the painter, has attached itself not to the woman, Celia Birtwell, but to her husband, Ossie Clark. In a further violation of gender conventions, Mr Clark is seated while his wife stands. As in Renoir, the cat is linked to the rich textures that signify the comforts of home. In this picture, however, it is through Ossie Clark, as he digs his bare feet into the lush shag rug. In a final twist, the cat, whose real name was Blanche, is re-titled Percy, slang for penis. But all this does not mean that Ossie Clark is playing little woman to Celia Birtwell's big daddy - "My main aim was to paint the relationship of these two people," Hockney once wrote. By freeing the pet from its traditional role, Hockney frees his human subjects from theirs at the same time. Women are no longer defined by their professed fidelity or domesticity, and men don't have to advertise their manliness through canine alter egos. After almost six centuries of being painted with pets, they can, at last, simply be themselves.

fields.headline: Do I have to?
fields.trailText: 'Although I am still devoted to Roly, I must confess that my eyes have started roving around the gym in search of a little diversion.'
fields.body:
Although I am still devoted to Roly, I must confess that my eyes have started roving around the gym in search of a little diversion. But only a little, don't get me wrong - obviously, Roly with his zealous, albeit hopeless, commitment to getting me thin is still my number one man. The thing is, amazing as this may sound, 20 minutes of beating a sweaty path along a treadmill can be a tad, dare I say it, boring. Oh, and it's building up to 30 next week (or so Roly thinks). Once I've got over the Calvinist thrill that I am actually expending some energy, viz the slight moisture dampening my T-shirt - a gym badge of honour - it is my sorry duty to tell you that the excitement does pale somewhat. The first seven minutes or so usually guarantee a wild array of new beliefs that I am seconds away from slim, mixed with a whole load of high- speed images of all those strappy, revealing, see-through dresses I am soon to be wearing proudly.

But, after that, the depressing realisation crashes in that whatever happens as a result of this new fitness lark I'm never going to achieve the shape of a girl who might expect to ensnare the likes of say . . . the youthful he-man that is Michael Douglas. So what am I supposed to do for the remaining hellish 13 minutes? How on earth am I supposed to while them away? My mother would helpfully suggest writing a novel or practising an aria, but it's diversion I'm after, not more bleeding self-improvement. So, naturally, it's time to check out who else is fatter than me, sweating more than I am and managing to look better in their training gear. The answer is everyone.

Everyone at the gym is, in every way, more hardworking and deserving and better-dressed than I am. (Why spend tons of money on clobber that's for getting out of breath in?) Oh God, I hadn't banked on feeling like I'm not in the gang. I'm suddenly awash with early school memories. I'm not wearing the right uniform. Everyone else knows what to do. I'm the only one with brown-bread sandwiches. HELP! What if there's a gym bully and he picks on me? What if I do my sit-ups wrong? Will they all snigger and point at me as I leave? Oh, the 20 minutes are up. That little burst of paranoia served a really useful purpose. The time flew by.

 Arabella Weir's get-fit column appears weekly. She trains at the Laboratory Health Club, London, 020-8482 3000.

webTitle: Will they be there for you?

fields.headline: Will they be there for you?
fields.standfirst: The all-for-one ethic of Rachel, Chandler and co in Friends is a far cry from most people's experience, argues Polly Vernon. In the real world, dealings with friends, even those we think are closest to us, are just as complicated as those with the dreaded family. Little wonder that so many of us now choose to live alone
fields.trailText: The all-for-one ethic of Rachel, Chandler and co in Friends is a far cry from most people's experience, argues Polly Vernon. In the real world, dealings with friends, even those we think are closest to us, are just as complicated as those with the dreaded family. Little wonder that so many of us now choose to live alone.
fields.body:
It's the concept that launched a million sitcoms and contemporary clichés: the sanctity of friendship. Untainted by sexual jealousy and complexities associated with relationships, or by the seething tensions and bad history that invariably accompany blood ties. You can't choose your family, your lovers are difficult and volatile, but, oh, you can choose your friends - so doesn't it make much more sense to live and holiday with them instead? To share darkest secrets and support, and generally function as blissfully and comfortably as families should, but are incapable of doing?

Yet, according to recent statistics, the notion that friends are the new family is fast losing currency. While all the data that once reinforced the ideal is still relevant - we're still getting married later (currently 29 on average for men and 27 for women, as opposed to 27 and 24, respectively, in 1988) and we're still having children later - the fact is that, in the meantime, we aren't necessarily living in substitute family units.

In fact, more and more single people are living on their own - figures from the National Office of Statistics predict that, by 2020, the number of two or more unrelated young adults house sharing will have dropped from 496,000 to 425,000. People are choosing to eschew the Friends lifestyle ideal in favour of a more solitary option. It would seem that the friends-as- family notion has failed us and, as a result, we are ditching it, wholesale.

In retrospect, it's not that surprising. The basic premise of the contemporary perspective on friendship - that we will be there for each other, no matter what, and that no sexual relationship can ever compete with the loyalty levels implicit in friendship - has proved so flawed that we've become disenchanted with communal living, and with the idea that our friends offer a surrogate support system for our unspeakably dysfunctional families.

Part of the terrible irony of the Friends ideal is that those who hold it dearest - the early- to mid-twentysomethings - also tend to be those whose lives are the most turbulent and distracting, and who are therefore most likely to be neck deep in self-absorption in the name of emotional survival and also least capable of "being there" for anyone else. Struggling to prove themselves professionally, vulnerable to terribly competitive instincts, they are, by definition, utterly ill-equipped, and utterly disinclined, to fulfil the emotional needs of their contemporaries. If anything, they are more likely to thrive on their friends' weaknesses, because they offer reassurance that, relatively, their own lives are better.

It is precisely because of the "I'll be there for you" mantra that I find relationships with my closest friends often impossibly loaded with the potential for guilt, and with the basis for negative comparison. How many times should I "be there" for someone who doesn't reciprocate before I begin to feel exploited? Why are my emails longer, my text messages sweeter, my phone calls more regular? Equally, why should I feel guilty if my circumstances, or even my personality, mean that I am not able to be perpetually there for someone else? By embracing such rigid ground rules on relationships, I have merely set myself - and my friends - up to fail.

Worse yet, fashionable notions of the perfect female friendship resoundingly echo feminism and post-feminism, and are the most contemporary incarnation of the sisterhood. The idea that women support each other without question, that we provide continual emotional back up because, inevitably, our lovers will let us down, is the day-to-day incarnation of contemporary feminism.

Therefore, to abandon this, to admit that sometimes your friends are not all you think they should be, is to be politically suspect. I have found it incredibly difficult to reconcile myself to the fact that I compete with my friends. That sometimes I feel threatened by them, and that sometimes I enjoy knowing they're threatened by me. This all smacks a little too fiercely of the traditional notion that, in the end, women can't be close because they're too busy plotting how to seduce each other's men.

Yet surely having an on-going, three-dimensional relationship with someone almost certainly involves ambiguities. Terrible tensions, competition and past bitternesses invariably weave themselves through friendships - particularly the long-standing variety. How else do you have a history with someone? Ultimately, it seems, individual expectation levels have imposed impossible pressures on friendship. Emotionally, it simply isn't that healthy.

I'm not proposing we do away with friendship all together, simply that we be more realistic and honest about its limitations. Admit that most of us are, basically, bad friends, but that this doesn't make us bad company. Keep our families as our families - because, generally, shared DNA seems to oblige us to maintain some kind of connection with each other, no matter how gruesome the finer points of our relationship - and our friends as really good company. Yes, we did choose our friends. But for their ability to make us laugh, not to act as mythically perfect sibling substitutes.

fields.headline: Your personal trainer
fields.standfirst: Got a fitness problem? We have the answers...
fields.trailText: I use up far more calories cycling for 10 minutes than running for the same time, yet running is much harder work. Is there an 'optimum' combination, or does it not matter?
fields.body:
I use up far more calories cycling for 10 minutes than running for the same time, yet running is much harder work. Is there an 'optimum' combination, or does it not matter?

How you are measuring the calories? If you're reading figures on a console screen, then take it as a very rough guide, not an accurate measurement. As a guideline, the effort put in is directly related to the amount of energy expended and, therefore, calories used. If you're working harder when running, you're probably also burning more calories, despite console readings.

Is it okay to go to the gym when my muscles still ache from the last session?

If the soreness is the result of hard training, rather than specific injury, training next day should be fine, but don't attempt the same exercises - muscle soreness is usually the result of a hard session that 'damages' the muscle. Such 'damage' is not necessarily bad, as it may be a stimulus for muscle growth, but too much 'damage' is harmful. Wait at least 24 hours before working the affected area again. Also, remember a day a week should be total rest from training.

 Chris St George is fitness director of The Third Space, London, 020-7439 7333. Send questions to: Your Personal Trainer, Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: To DIY for
fields.standfirst: How to hang a door
fields.trailText: 'When my friend Al told me he'd recently re-hung his bedroom door I sat back and waited to hear exactly how he had ended up in casualty.'
fields.body:
Some people are born to have accidents, others have accidents thrust upon them.

My friend Al has both kinds: accidents that could happen to anyone, and accidents that could happen only to him (he was once struck in the testicles by the freak sweep of a blind man's stick). So when Al told me he'd recently re-hung his bedroom door - a job involving chisels, heavy lifting and a circular saw - I sat back and waited to hear exactly how he had ended up in casualty.

Re-hanging a door is quite a big deal. The first thing you will discover is that your frame is not a regular shape, and nor is your room, nor your house: older houses often have wonky floors, so doors can swing into the middle of the room if hung the wrong way round.

Before unscrewing the hinges, cut some wedges and place them under the door to avoid it crashing on to your foot, then cut door-width slots into some 4x2 to act as a door stand.

You will also need a Door Lifter, which is like a crowbar, but blue and American, with a curved shaft; kick it underneath to hold the door in position.

Normal hinges are reversible, so you can often salvage the existing ones and chisel some recesses for them on the opposite side of the frame. 'Rising-butt' hinges come in two parts: a hook, which sits in the frame, and a socket, mounted on the door so that it lifts on and off easily. But rising-butts are left- or right-handed: get the correct one, or you'll be in a right mess.

Al needed a new door, which he circular-sawed without cutting off his hands and feet. 'What, no accidents?' I said, aghast. 'That's waiting to happen. We haven't had a bedroom door for two years. It's only a matter of time before I smack my face into it in the middle of the night.'

fields.headline: In your face
fields.trailText: 'I have always stood by two cosmetics rules of thumb: first, less is more (admittedly, due mainly to lack of self-assurance), and second, stick with what you trust.'
fields.body:
Maybe it's because I've always been a tomboy, but I've never felt wildly confident around make-up. Instead, I have always stood by two cosmetics rules of thumb: first, less is more (admittedly, due mainly to lack of self-assurance), and second, stick with what you trust. All my favourite products were discovered by stumbling and by happily following friends' recommendations, and they still form the backbone of my current make-up bag.

First up, my faithful friend, the tweezers. As a girl who used to tweezer her bikini line before it got out of hand (ouch!), you could say I'm a little obsessed. I find slanted ones the best, always handy for last-minute moustache and, dare I say, chin hair removal, as well as the usual eyebrow shaping.

Live And Kicking's make-up artist, Lesley, introduced Jamie Theakston and me to the wonder of Dr Harris & Co eyedrops. After a quick, stinging drop and some fierce blinking, you, too, can have TV-friendly eyes, refreshed and puffiness-free. Admittedly, though, these days, my red-eye problems are usually courtesy of a sleepless little one and rarely due to boozy, smoky clubs.

I'm just not a fan of foundations. I just can't apply them without achieving the "70s beauty-counter assistant jaw line". If I need some colour, I use Aveda's face powder in bronze. For the tanned look, I use Guérlain's Terracotta Teint Doré lotion, which I apply with a damp powder puff. It's also great for arms and legs, as you can see the difference immediately - unlike many fake tans - and it washes off if you make a terrible mistake.

I finish my eyebrows with a Chanel pencil in blond (handy brush on the end), then curl my eyelashes (Shu Uemera and Mister Mascara's are the most effective) and then some Maybelline waterproof eyeliner. For long, clog-free eyelashes, my favourite is Vincent Longo's black mascara.

I'm never without Glide dental floss, as it has saved me from many embarrassing spinach-in-the-teeth moments. I have very sensitive skin and have found that highly perfumed, expensive lipsticks trigger off the dreaded cold sores, so I'm never without Zovirax. I keep lips simple. Vaseline or Rosebud Salve give a gentle and moisturising finish. If I want a bit more, I use Ruby and Millie's clear or red lip gloss, which has a tasty menthol flavour. I also put a bit of Vaseline on my eyebrows to finish them off.

I like fresh scents best, and a dab of L'Eau d'Issey Miyake or Jo Malone's Lime, Basil & Mandarin Cologne finishes me off a treat. There you go, what was that about less is more?

 Zoe Ball's beauty column appears weekly.

fields.headline: The right massage
fields.standfirst: Reiki, shiatsu or LaStone? Thai, Swedish or Indian? Picking the right massage can be a baffling business. Well, sit back, relax and let Johanna Sharples help...
fields.trailText: Reiki, shiatsu or LaStone? Thai, Swedish or Indian? Picking the right massage can be a baffling business. Well, sit back, relax and let Johanna Sharples help...
fields.body:
Different massages suit different people. If you are from the "no pain, no gain" school of thought, light-touch treatments will leave you feeling cheated. And if you are uneasy about getting undressed in front of strangers, say, it's best to avoid certain techniques. Some massages aim to restore soul as well as body, so the therapist may well encourage you to air your problems, personal as well as physical, which can be annoying if you want peace and quiet. So here are some guidelines to help you pick the right treatment.

Swedish

A system of movements and techniques created by the Swedish physiologist Per Henrik Ling in the early 19th century, now the basis for most conventional massage. Consists of various strokes - including kneading, friction, tapping and vibration - to alleviate tension, increase circulation and break down lesions.
How much? £20-£35 per hour.
How long? Full-body session is about one hour; shorter sessions for treating specific areas.
Visit: www.massagetherapy.co.uk for more information.

LaStone

Developed in the early 90s, this technique uses hot stones of smooth, volcanic rock and cooled stones of polished marble. The treatment starts with a massage using oil, then stones are placed on specific areas of the body in various combinations and patterns, depending on your needs. Said to increase circulation and lymph drainage, as well as being deeply relaxing.
How much? From £55.
How long? One-and-a-half hours.
Contact: The Complementary Medical Association, 020-8305 9571.

Hellerwork

Developed in the late 70s, this is a combination of deep massage, movement re-education and emotional counselling. If you want the massage without the psychoanalysis, Rolfing uses similar deep-tissue manipulation to restore freedom of movement and improve body alignment. Beware, however: neither method is meant to be soothing.
How much? £50-£75.
How long? A course of around 10 sessions from one to two hours each.
Contact: The Roger Golten Hellerwork Practice, 020-7723 5676.

Manual lymphatic drainage

Ideal if you need a quick fix in the detox department. This gentle and precise massage helps rid the body of toxins by stimulating the lymphatic system. Said to boost the immune system and increase vitality.
How much? £35-£45.
How long? Initial consultation, one-and-a-half hours; one hour thereafter.
Contact: The Complementary Medical Association, 020-8305 9571.

Thai yoga massage

You wear loose clothing while your therapist applies pressure with hands, feet and elbows to points along your meridians (energy lines). Combined with yoga and gentle stretching, it's said to release blockages in the life-force and free healing potential.
How much? From £35.
How long? One-and-a-half to two hours.
Contact: The School Of Thai Yoga Massage, 020-8341 3835.

Reiki

More a laying-on of hands than an actual massage, this Japanese system of natural healing is said to conduct energy from the giver to the receiver and to stimulate the body's own healing capacity both physically and emotionally.
How much? £30-£40.
How long? Between 45 and 90 minutes.
Visit: www.reikiassociation.org.uk.

Indian head massage

Practised for more than 1,000 years, traditionally to improve the scalp and hair condition, the modern system incorporates the upper back, shoulders, neck, upper arms and face, too. Particularly recommended to relieve eye strain and tension headaches.
How much? Around £20.
How long? Typically 30 minutes.
Visit: www.massagetherapy.co.uk.

Shiatsu

Incorporates not only finger pressure, but thumbs, palms, knees, elbows and feet. Pressure is applied to the meridians to stimulate the body's energy flow. Also involves gentle stretching and manipulation.
How much? £20-£35.
How long? Initial session, 90 minutes; one hour thereafter.
Contact Shiatsu Society Of Great Britain, 01788 555051.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
Robert Elms's remarks were enough to make me tear up my ticket for the witch-burning so I could respond (Why I Hate The Countryside, April 28). My son took time off from racially abusing the Asian village shopkeeper to smile at the piece; and my daughter would have enjoyed it, only she works in the big city, and we're too scared of quasi-intellectuals to visit. My husband read it, but he hasn't much to do, what with the cullings meaning he has no sheep to shag. Things are bad enough without crass comments from someone who bought his bullshit from an organic supermarket in Civilisation City - or am I making sweeping assumptions?
Elizabeth Gibson
Hadnall, Shropshire
fields.body:
Robert Elms's remarks were enough to make me tear up my ticket for the witch-burning so I could respond (Why I Hate The Countryside, April 28). My son took time off from racially abusing the Asian village shopkeeper to smile at the piece; and my daughter would have enjoyed it, only she works in the big city, and we're too scared of quasi-intellectuals to visit. My husband read it, but he hasn't much to do, what with the cullings meaning he has no sheep to shag. Things are bad enough without crass comments from someone who bought his bullshit from an organic supermarket in Civilisation City - or am I making sweeping assumptions?
Elizabeth Gibson
Hadnall, Shropshire

I relocated to rural Britain from urban America, and can empathise with Robert Elms's comments. I have been asked "What are you doing here?" so many times that I've begun to ask myself the same question.
Jennifer Hill
Ulceby, North Lincolnshire

Did I detect a smidgen of prejudice against country folk in Robert Elms's article? And a suggestion of anti-French feeling in Julie Burchill's piece? What a narrow-minded, intolerant bunch your cosmopolitan, city-dwelling journalists are.
Marilyn Nellist
Danby, North Yorks

Since when were "ginger dads" an ethnic minority?
Jonathan Beckett
Nottingham

Zoe Williams is right to spike pernicious non-words (Words That Should Be Banned, April 28), but: "Realpolitik" is a German word meaning "doing dodgy deals with your political opponents", such as the pact between Hitler and Stalin to carve up Poland, so, far from being a non-word, it has a very precise meaning. As for "Real Madrid", Zoe makes a mistake typical of monolingual English speakers: "Real" is the Spanish for "royal".
Julia Iskandar
London NW11

Zoe Williams, writing of the Real IRA, breezily declares that what irks her about them is that they're not "real" enough: "Real IRAs blow up proper buildings, not post offices." Are 29 men, women and children enough for you?
Wendy Erskine
Belfast

Wherever Georgia O'Keeffe experienced "strident light" and acquired her sense of space, it wasn't in Wisconsin (All Woman, April 28). The country there is rich farmland with gentle hills, a bit like Kent. The plains start 400 miles west in the Dakotas.
Ann-Marie LeQuesne
London N4

Thank heavens for Charlotte Abrahams and her half-baked article, Under The Weather (Home, April 28). As architects and planners, we make a good living from sorting out the problems of people who follow the sort of ill-informed advice she gave. You have to laugh when the rest of the world is complaining about cowboy builders and she tells us that sorting the red tape is the builder's responsibility. Keep it up.
Ian Haywood
ihp@dircon.co.uk

I wouldn't like your splendid article on ETA to be remembered for indignant letters from people who don't know or are too prejudiced to understand (Dear Weekend, April 28). I'm not a Basque, and I can say that there's nothing quasi-fascist about them. Also, ETA has not been involved in any kind of ethnic cleansing, and their support is nothing like "minuscule". All my respect to the victims and their families, but maybe the Basques have been victims themselves for too many years and nobody heard their cries.
Kiko Amat
kikoamat@onetel.net.uk

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by first post Tuesday for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
